reviews.review: Interesting building. Finally we visited only from the outside during our walk on the Rambla, so we don't know how is the inside.

Beautiful views of the city but some issues.. Beautiful views of the city and a pleasant place for a stroll round but you have to pay to see anything of the Gaudi architecture. And even then you only get a certain time slot to go and see it! Get there early to avoid spending all day waaiting for your slot.

excellent. a must visit. there are specific timings to visit. so be prepared. they only allow a limited number of visitors. The entry ticket is valid only for half hour. plan in detail.
it is nice and beautiful. The park is excellent to view. it also gives good view of the city. a must visit in the city.

Do not miss this out if you only have a few days. This is a fabulous building just off las Ramblas. Quite exquisite woodwork and glass and shows just how superior Gaudi and GUELL were as advocates in architecture. I just wished I could have been a visitor in 1900s!!

Gorgeous. This palace is a must see. In fact, go see any and all Gaudí attractions and exhibits while in Barcelona. You won't be disappointed. This residence built for Gaudí's good friend Grüell is gorgeous. It's floors and walls will take your breath away, as will the genius that masterminded its architecture which is evidient throughout. I loved the Catalan influence throughout, in all the details of this place. It's a lovely afternoon or morning stroll that will leave you feeling enriched and satisfied.

Amazing. This palau is really worth the time to see the amazing work of Gaudi so ahead of his time, we were tossing up if we should go and so pleased we did. From the basement to the rooftop designs mind boggling.

Sadly, didn't go inside but outside is still worth a look.. a Gaudi masterpiece. Make sure you get some type of a guide or tour so you can get the full story behind it. Stand back and look at the roof. Breathtaking.
The Palace. Another fantastic example of Antoni Gaudi's genius. Recommended visiting. Worth every bit of the entrance fee and you should spend as much time there as you can.
Amazing architecture. Palau Guell is definitely worth a visit. You will get a wonderful insight into the genius of Gaudi. Be sure to get the audio guide.
Beautifully renovated Guell home. Don't miss this beautifully restored Guell home located just off La Rambla. Also a Gaudi home, the wood work is incredible. So are the crazy rooftop chimneys.

Just a walk-by review. Because of time between cruises, we hiked La Rambla and took just a few minutes to take a side street to this Gaudi-inspired building. We were there early and it wasn't open, yet a long line had formed for tickets. The front of the building is truly Gaudi. Next time we visit Barcelona we will tour it.
An incredible residence. Gaudi created this home in the early 1900s. The quality of the workmanship, materials used and the beauty of the home is outstanding! Go see it!

You Gaudi see this . My hotel happened to be a 1 minute walk away from this place so decided to visit & for €12 you can't go wrong at all, you are provided with audio guides and information booklet, the place is very interesting and informative, you really learn about Gaudi and this building which is spectacular. The rooftop was my favourite bit with all different chimneys and good views also. I would definitely recommend this place. With this being on the same street as my hotel I walked passed at least twice a day and although in the mornings there can be a que I do believe this is due to the city tours but in the afternoon and evening there wasn't many people at all and this means you can really enjoy this place and take your time to take in Gaudi's great work.A fan of his or not, for €12 definitely add it to the list of things to do whilst in Barca.
Early Gaudi at his best.. One of Guadis early gems. You can see where so much of the later work comes from. No queues when we were there unlike so many of the other Guadis properties.
Beautiful activity outdoor. We spent a few hours in the park. Event in end of September, the park was crowded. It shows the genius of Gaudi. A must to visit.

Guell Done, Gaudí !. This is 100% worth the stop and the 12€. This is gaudis first building and really an amazing tour. Great commentary on the audio tour and the home is beautifully kept up This is a don't miss!! Its smaller than gaudis works so smaller crowds. Very accessible off the rambla.
Gaudi building off Las Ramblas. We bought our tickets online. The audio guide was easy to use and provided interesting information. The palace was beautiful and well worth a visit.

good introduction to Gaudi. This is somewhat understated, as compared to his other famous work in Barcelona, but it gives insight into Gaudi the man and his career. Audioguide is necessary to appreciate his work here. Still very uniquely Gaudi. Tucked away on a sidestreet with a nondescript entrance, the way his patron wanted it. Underground stables were genius, as is the rooftop.
My favorite ! !. How can one pick a favorite Gaudi?? Well, this one is it for me. His magic is every where in this building. A must see ! !
Another building with Gaudi style features. Well worth visiting if your interest is in Gaudi styled features. This building has an underground stables and on the roof the usual Gaudi styles vents.

Architecture is Art. Guell commissioned Gaudi in 1886 to create a palace to reflect the industrialist's wealth and status. The materials, design, color, unique architecture and especially the details successfully presented a lavish home for one of the century's richest men.The basement with Moorish arches and massive columns includes a brick, winding ramp from the ground floor entry for carriages to descend to the stables, as well as a practical small open "courtyard" for ventilation. The impressive, decorative wrought iron doors facing the foyer are designed so those inside have a view of outside, but it is impossible to see inside! The foyer's wide staircase has raised steps along the side in order to assist those mounting or dismounting horses. The staircase continues upward to the living spaces and includes built in benches along the banisters (reminiscent of Frank Lloyd Wright), and becomes the stage to admire the astonishing wood coffered ceilings and chandeliers at each level. The wood carved dining room and the musician's gallery are true showcases for lavish entertainment. The organ actually played music every half hour or so during the tour, and discreet doors to the gilded chapel were open. Hidden "galleries" made it possible for the lady of the house to attend Mass without getting properly dressed, or more interesting, they were a perfect secret venue for Guell to spy on his servants and guests!The roof terrace with broad city views, displays the whimsical, colorful ceramic tiled chimney caps reflecting a playful sense of humor and novel approach to making art out of something so practical....the sweet icing on top of a very elaborate cake!HINT: The audio guide is included in the admission charge.

Off Las Ramblas (look or you may pass by it). If I had one Gaudi building to visit to get a taste of Gaudi THIS is the one to visit. The visit comes with and audio guide which does a excellent job. The 3 story main interior room is absolutely spectacular. I did not book on line but was checking out location on Sun afternoon and there was no line (again probably because it is hidden away on a side street half way up Las Rambles.

Beautiful Park. This a definite must for those visiting BarcelonaOne can meander through this park for hours.If you are lucky you can sit & listen to classical Segovia guitar or other music along the paths.

Fascinating building. The care with which Gaudi chose his materials, and the thought that went into the arrangement and construction of the building , makes this a fascinating tour. Well worth getting the audio commentary.

Nice stroll. I recommend doing a nice stroll around the free entrance parts of the Park Guell. It is great for having a wonderful view at the city, seeing some great architecture and even burning some calories. Then, you can ask yourself if you had enough or still wanna pay for the rest.

Unassuming. A unassuming building close to La Rambla, Palau Guell was one of Gaudi's finest works commissioned by his patron. An interesting fact: when the Guell family lost their wealth, a wealthy American entertained thoughts of purchasing the home and having it transported piecemeal to the US. Thankfully the government put an end to that nonsense.

Gaudi structure. This is just off the Ramblas and it makes for a fine visit . You will enjoy the Gaudi work . If you visit La Pedrera and Casa Battlo you may not need to see this example of Gaudi's work . Interesting , but not as interesting as other sites.

Hidden gem. Tucked away down a side street off la Rambla, this was a very interesting house, from stables in the basement to the roof top, it's surprising how a house like this could fit into the area it did. The audio commentary was also very interesting. Well worth a visit

Gaudi's late 1800's wealthy family home near the Barri Gotic area. Pay attention to the map and street signs when looking for Palau Guell. We were so taken with the sights on Las Ramblas as we walked out of Barri Gotic on Carrer de Ferrah, that we missed the side street on which Palau Guell is located. The Palau Guell is located about 1/2 block down on C. Nou de la Rambla, a narrow street which is almost opposite Carrer de Ferrah and across Las Ramblas. Sidewalk crowd control barriers in front of this Gaudi house indicate which building is the Palau Guell; otherwise we would have walked right by it. Fortunately, there was no line up to enter the house or to buy tickets in the booth next door when we visited on a Saturday afternoon in September without online reservations. The Palau was the 4 storey family home of a wealthy Barcelonean businessman in the late 1800's. Squeezed in now by a bank, a hotel, and modern apartments, the house still retains its exterior splendour with the 2 unusual wrought iron entrance gates probably being its trademark. The interior of the house reflects its 19th Century roots with its use of dark woods, small rooms, lots of stairs, and narrow windows. A very limited amount of furniture is in the whole house and that too reflects the times and taste of the Guell family. One room did showcase some of the chairs Gaudi designed. What was spectacular was the gold leaf family altar set in an alcove which could be closed off by doors when the family held musical soirees in the room. The organ pipes in the central atrium were also an unusual feature in a family home. The audioset which was included in the entry fee emphasized Gaudi's attention to architectural detail in each room and unusual design elements. The one hour audio tour started in the empty bricked basement where the family kept its carriages and storage. Next we entered the ground floor where the family got out of the carriages and walked up a central staircase to the living area. The first floor had a dining room that was roped off, a music room, and a sitting room. The second floor had a number of bedrooms for the 4-5 children the family had and separate bedrooms for the husband and wife. There was just one toilet on this floor. The third floor was the servants' area with kitchen, laundry, and their bedrooms. This upper floor was just one big empty room. Viewing a video here with information on the owner of the house offered a chance to rest tired feet.before climbing the stairs to the rooftop to look at the colorful vents. While several of these fireplace vents still were decorated with Gaudi's original selection of colorful chipped porcelain/ceramic pieces, others had been re-done during the renovation project. These vents could not be seen from street level so I don't know for whom he decorated them. This house is one of 3 Gaudi designed homes that are easily accessible within the downtown area of Barcelona. The entrance fee for Palau Guell is the lowest of the three. After visiting all 3 Gaudi homes, my favorite ones where the 2 on Passeig de Gracia. Casa Battlo and Casa Pedrera have delightful exteriors - eye candy - while the exterior of Palau Guell is more traditional. The interior of Palau Guell is somber while the interiors of the other two begin to show more of Gaudi's unique design characteristics - the use of varying tones of colored glass and tiles, naturalistic forms echoed in woodwork, and remarkable engineering skills. However, I was glad to have visited Palau Guell as it satisfied my curiosity about Gaudi's work and the interior of a home in 19th Century Barcelona.

Marvellous place!. Looks inauspicious from the street, but well worth the 12 Euro entry fee to look at some of the works of Gaudi and some really stunning architecture. The views of the city form the rooftop are really interesting, with the artist chimney stacks and mixture of old and. We buildings.

Stunning and informative. This building looks a bit non-descript from the road compared to other Gaudi structures. But when you get inside it will blow you away. The building was built for the world's richest man, at the time, with world's biggest budget and it shows. And the City has recently restored it to its original glory. The result is stunning and breathtaking. The visit includes an audio tape description of the 30 odd rooms and all the Gaudi contributions. A must visit for those who want to learn anything (or more) about Gaudi.

Leave fave of the Guadi's. We toured most of the main Gaudi structures, and this one was our least favorite. That’s not to say that it was bad, but we just didn’t find it as interesting as some of his others.
Worth seeing. Very nice building. Entrance is very well organized and free to visit on Sundays! Nice inside and free guides in English (I wish they could have more languages than few basic ones).

Interesting insight into Gaudi’s early work. Palau Guell was Gaudi’s first major commission and is a good contrast to his later works. Built between 1886 and 1890 for the family Guell who advised that money was no object. Gaudi took his patron at his word, hence the ornate ironwork entrances and quality of materials used throughout. The highlights for us were the stables in the basement and the rooftop with its colourful chimneys which are typical of Gaudi. You are allowed to take photos without flash but the lighting does not make this easy. You have to deposit large bags in the cloakroom. We bought tickets online in advance to beat the queues but it was not very busy when we arrived late afternoon. Tickets are for a set entry time but there is some flexibility – we arrived 15 minutes early and were allowed in. Entry fees are cheaper than other Gaudi buildings but the signposting and audio tour here are not as easy to follow and we gave up in the end. Interesting insight into Gaudi’s early work but if you are pressed for time would recommend visiting Casa Batllo and Sagrada Familia instead.

Well worth a visit. A really good park with examples of Guaudi,s work the park only lets so many enter each half hour so I would pre book your ticket. We arrived at 12.30 by which time it was busy there was about an hour queue to see the house which we didn't do ,I guess the earlier you enter the less queue time there will be. We took a taxi from the sangrada familia which is recommended and there is a taxi rank at the entrance. We found the park really interesting and spent about 90 mins in total
Dark but beautiful. The house is dark, a stark contrast to cast Batllò and, especially, La Pedrera. A must see, for understanding the whole of the style.
If you are "around" go visit. If you are into cultural things, this should be on your list. Went there in the early afternoon not a lot of people there..

Gaudi's best. If you are in doudt which of Gaudi's houses tot visit first: visit this one. An entry ticket costs 12 euro, including audio guide. The Palau Guell is less crowded then La Pedrera is more beautiful.
Very Empty and doesn't worth the money paid. The palace is very huge and very empty as well.Audio guide is for free but I didn't see it interesting anywa.
GOOD PLACE TO VISIT. It is quite near from El Balcon del Born. It is one of the Gaudi´s buildings although it is not very known. It is worth to visit.

The coolest subdivision that never happened. Sometime things happen that end up for the betterment of humanity. The fact that this "subdivision" did work out gave humanity a beautiful gift. Gaudi's genius is on full display and creativity. Bring a picnic and enjoy all levels of the park.

Incredible iron work . Palau Guell was quite different than Gaudi's other homes on the inside. The Guell family home is incredibly ornate and the materials used absolutely beautiful. The ironwork entrances are stunning and set the tone for the rest of the home. And of course the rooftop is where you can feel Gaudi's presence with more of his beautiful mosaic work.

not yet overwhelmed by tourists. This is gouda's first residential commission. Built in the 1880s for the large family of his part, Guell, the home includes stables in the basement with a ramp descending down through arches. The entry is magnificent and the upper floors just get better.
Beautiful. Clearly shows Gaudi's genius. Every aspect in the home is as beautifully detailed as it is practical. Well worth a visit

terrific restoration of a magnificent house. There was one of the best experiences in Barcelona. The entire house has been restored and open to view. The audioguide is excellent and explained the close collaboration between Gaudi and Guell. Much cheaper than many of the other buildings. Highly recommended

Good introduction to Gaudi. We visited the Palau the day after we visited La Sagrada Familia. It definitely provided a contrast for us about the early work of Gaudi and his final piece. We were given an audio guide which was included in the price of admission, and this helped us to better appreciate the details and context of the site.

A sumptuous palace that is different to the other Gaudi tourist sites. Palau Guell is an interesting example of Gaudi's work and unlike many of his other Barcelona based creations. It is located very close to Las Ramblas. It is sumptuous in nature and is worthy of a visit.
We didn't need to pre-book

Architecturally astonishing. We stumbled upon this while in Barcelona and visited as we have a passing interest in architecture what we seen inside were vistas that took our breath away, beautiful and not expensive for such an experiance.
inspiring. the most gorgeous park you will ever visit ....amazing artist .....if visiting in summer bring plenty to drink and hats etc not much shade

Fascinating building and architecture - worth visiting. On an afternoon we decided to visit the Palau Güell which was one of the first architectural works of Antoni Gaudi who had not only fund a benefactor but also a friend in Eusebi Güell.The building is fascinating, the entrance with it massive wrought-iron gates that seem to have no weight and which allow you to look form the inside out but not the other was around are an art of its own, not ignoring the marvel of the people who did work for him and transform his ideas to live.The works that have been done in and around the house, the pillars, the wooden ceilings, the window shutters with its intelligent closing and opening system and more are amazing and Gaudi was and still is way ahead of many people of today’s time with his mind and thought breaking ideas.On the other hand, even though a fascinating building – it is overloaded and if you consider the rooms for the children of Güell – tiny cells rather than bright and shiny rooms. Anyhow the whole house seems to diminish in all its sombreness.In my personal opinion, it is a great architectural work, but not for the living.

Breathtakingly Unique. . Pure architectual amazement coupled with genuine artist craftsmanship. Asthetically oleasingand thoughtful in so many ways. An easy tour of a modest sized city Palace. Get a reservation snd enjoy the uniqueness. Inebif mybtop 5 fav palaces (and it is small)
Another Gaudi- güell partnership. Barcelona is selling Gaudis works which were paif by Güell and donated to Barcelona city. Yes they are beatiful but all of them are quite expensive :((

Worth the money compared to other Gaudi places. Is this the best Gaudi experience? No, certainly not. Batllo, Mila, Park Guell and the Sagrada Familia are more impressive. But this earlier work which is quite dark and mysterious is worth the money.

So-so. This is a nice park - but it is a LONG walk uphill from both Metro stops. It was a hot day when we visited and after walking about for about an hour or so, we decided that it really was not our favorite place. The Gaudi things are nice - but the place is very crowded and people are milling all over the place. If we had to do it again, I would choose another place to visit.
Very interesting. We saw this as part of a half day tour. Wish we had more time. It is very interesting and worth visiting.

Beautiful and interesting . As for all Gaudi locations in Barcelona, buy tickets ahead of time to avoid queuing. We visited on the national day of Catalonia so were lucky to get free entry but we would have happily paid. So beautiful and interesting, a real eye-opener. Stunning roof-top, for both the views and the chimney pots. If you like chimney-pots you'll be well-served by Gaudi (see also La Pedrera)!

Very impressive, a beautiful house . We really enjoyed this house which we visited coincidently. It was one of the highlights of our trip to Barcelona. The audio-guides give useful information and from the roof-terrace you have a great view over the city.

Incredible architecture. Wow, what a house! We've been to lots of UK National Trust properties, but never seen anything as innovative and as this. Wooden cobbles to muffle the horses hooves. A fold away altar to change the space to a concert area......and amazing decorative chimney pots.
near miss. nearly missed this gem thought it was the park but glad we went in ,managed to come back on the next day and a bonus it was a open door day .

Worth a visit. We walked by this building a few times and saw people photographing it from the outside, so we investigated online and saw that it was a Gaudi designed house for one of his main friends/benefactors "Guell Family" It is a very industrial looking building inside and obviously was very influenced by Guells demands and Gaudis mind.I highly recommend you visit, we found it very interesting.
True Gaudi. Another amazing house by Gaudi, very nice architecture and design. If you like Gaudis work you will definitely enjoy this house.

Great but maybe not for families. We visited here by chance and when we got to the window we asked if we could bring our stroller with us because it was almost nap time for my kiddo. They said we could but when we got in they wanted us to park the stroller and carry her. This was fine but we asked before we bought tickets. There is a lot of climbing stairs here but it was worth the visit. They did say they had baby carriers available but they were all out when we got there.

Details were fantastic. This was our first Gaudì house and it was a good one to start with. The insight to his relationship with Güell and the reference to other buildings was a great foundation for our trip. The visit was all the better for being free as the first Sunday of the month it is one of the free museums. They opened at 10 so we were there about 9.30th get in line which was perfect as we were in the first time slot. It was busy but this didn't negatively impact us and the free audio guide was great. It was interesting to see the reconstruction exhibition and the video but the highlight for me was the roof.

Wonderful experience. This is an inspiring way to get a thorough and intimate view of the genius of Gaudi. The audio guide is very informative and accessible. One of the highlights of our four-day visit to Barcelona.

Every room a pleasant surprise. What a gorgeous place, from top to bottom fascinating! It has been carefully restored including the organ and was finished in 2011. The ceilings were my favorite feature. Lots of walking and standing with steps at the end, don't go tired. It has 6 levels from basement to roof and you won't want to skip any.

Masterpiece of a young Gaudi. The level of detail that Gaudi put into the design of the Palau Guell is unbelievable. Great piece of architecture made possible by industrialist Guell.Do not only admire the outside, the inside, including audio tour, is worth the €12 entry fee.
Inside Gaudi's work. Fascinating mansion of one of Gaudi's benefactors. Design and engineering marvel. Definitely recommend.
Good tour. Free Audio tour guide given with admission which is pretty cool. If you like every intricate detail of architecture this is for you.

Great design, get the Audio . Of the Ramblas street, buy your ticket outside next to entrance then walk in through the metal detector, on the Left side find your locker to store your personal belongings and then start the Audio tour there. It's an interesting design by Guido and efficient way to use space. He made it like modern design where tenants are able to drive their horse or carriage directly in the house, use the ramp to park underground level and then walk up to the servant waiting room.In his design you will notice how he allow for communication methods within residents, ventilation, lighting and use of space.There is entry fees, but I think it is worth it. C U AROUND
Like in a sci-fi movie. This palace built by Antoní Gaudi is definitely worthh a visit. Such an interesting sight, and on every first Sunday of the month it is for free (with an audioguide).
Chimneys are the best. The whole Palau is really beautiful. Very nice explanations with the audio guide. The terrace with the colourful chimneys were the best part

Must Visit. Palau Guell in Barcelona is one of the early works of architect/designer Antoni Gaudi, and a magnificent example of art nouveau. Gaudi was commissioned to create the structure in 1885 by industrialist Eusebi Buelli i Bacigalupi and construction started in 1886. It was planned to be a multi purpose building with apartments and exposition rooms, and only a basic area 18 x 22 meters was available to construct a glamorous palace. Parts of the facade resemble a Venetian palace and Gaudi decorated the house with impressive wrought iron works, wood, ceramic, stained glass, and stone works. The basement contained the stables for horses and sleeping quarters for servants. The elevated ground floor had working rooms, the library, and administration rooms, plus an entry hall with a magnificent staircase leading to the second floor's family rooms. The Palau Guell has been listed as a UNESCO Heritage Site since 1984.

Only saw the outside. This is one place I'd like to have the time to go and see inside. Knowing what I know now about Gaudi it would give a better appreciation of his early works. The 4 rating is only because I didn't get inside to give it a proper review.

Great surprise in the city centre. We spontaneously decided to visit Palau Güell due to some changes. It was totally worth it! We went in the late afternoon and enjoyed the sunset in the end on the rooftop. There was no queue, so we purchased the tickets, entered immediately and also got an audio guide for free. The prices were very affordable compared to other attractions in BCN, and there is also a discount for students.There weren't many people in there, so we could enjoy the tour to its fullest. It seems that Palau Güell is a secret sightseeing spot. Totally recommended!

I liked it, a calm exploration of Gaudi . A pretty amazing place and a calm reprieve from some of the other Gaudi places on offer. He was a very gifted man and this building gives you a sense of that as well as what the turn of the century was like in Barcelona. Buy tickets at the door, audio guide is good and included.

Park De Guell. Better guy ticket online but then you really have plan your time because ticket valid just on that time on which bought. Of course possible to buy ticket on SPOT but on high season there is a possibility that on the same day you can not buy entrance ticket regarding to many ppl.
Hidden Gem. Tucked away on a side street off Las Ramblas, this Gaudi building is an accessible (close-up) example of many of his techniques.

Interesting earlier Gaudi work and well worth the visit. A great insight into how Gaudi thought in terms of his architecture and design. The free audio tour is a huge bonus and is very informative. The palace itself is pretty stunning inside and then you get to the roof which is what you tend to see in the guide books. Great place to visit if you want a different slant on Gaudi. Very good value too.
Very interesting. Very interesting, the audio guide is really good and gives lots of information. Good view of Barcelona from the top.

Palau Güell. The Güell Palace was built by Mr Antonio Gaudí on the 80´s, and is one of the most visited Palaces in Barcelona, for the people that ove Gaudís designs that are espectacular.This Palace was named Patrimony of the Humanity some years ago, and is perfectly preserved, and a place you cannot loose visit at Barcelona , all the building with the special Gaudi´s characteristics and designs
very cool. very cool place - if you are a Gaudi fan then you should make time to see this. there is an entry fee but it is worth it

Cool palace with informative audio included in entry cost. Very much enjoyed nearly 2 hours visiting first class example of Gaudi's architecture. Extensively renovated over 10 years and opened to the public in 2011. Clever architecture for optimum use of light and sun Beware the pigeons on the back terrace, they got us big time and should really be prevented for nesting on the window ledges. Not pleasant when looking up!
Another great Gaudi work. Another great Gaudi architectural work.Audioguides and Locker are free.Master piece of architectural work that doesn't get done anymore because of the costs.

Rather different to other Gaudi buildings take a look. . Crammed this in to a rather busy day but didn't regret going. The basement and the roof were interesting alone and the interior was very different to other Gaudi buildings we saw. Rather warm when we went and being tired we ended up rushing the last few rooms. Very glad we saw it though.

Interesting Visit. This was a thoroughly interesting and inspiring visit to another of Gaudi's masterpieces in Barcelona. It was a very interesting insight in to what can be done with a seemingly small plot of land. The audio guide was very informative about the property and I really enjoyed seeing Palau Guell as part of a wider tour of Gaudi's work. As his earliest main work, this was a useful starting point on a journey through the architect's development and is well worth a visit during your time in Barcelona.

wow a gem of a find just off the rambla opposite the hotel Gaudi.. Wow a gem of a find just off the rambla opposite the gaudi hotel.A really interesting visit spent several hours there ,will go again.Visit on a dry day so that you can go on the roof and see the sights and chimney pots(the roof is closed when the weather is wet for safety reasons)tells you lots of intersting history of Gaudi.
Great experience . If u like Gaüdy's work it worth to visit .. it' really a palace. Ticket's price includes an audio guide and it's good.
Astonoshing!. Full of art and inspiration, this place is the soul of Gaudi. Stay as long as you can, prefer to go in the evening at the last entrance and admire Barcelona form above during sunset...

Great Gaudi. Although we didn't visit here, due to time restrictions, we were lucky that our hotel terrace was directly opposite and looked on to the roof top so we had amazing views of the colourful chimneys. I believe there's loads of interesting architecture to see inside too. Although it seemed popular, it didn't seem to get as busy as other Barcelona tourist sights, so I imagine you could pleasantly stroll around and actually see everything properly. I'll definitely be visiting next time I'm in Barcelona to see more!
Interesting. Interesting to see how Gaudis work progressed from his earliest commission (Palau Guell) through to his later work.

Hidden gem. Impressive enough from the outside but incredible inside and it seemed to go on and on, every floor was great but the rooftop was incredible!
Reasonably priced.

Don't skip this one!. The Rick Steve's guide I had rated this Gaudi home last in terms of what was worth seeing, but our group enjoyed it event more than La Pedrera. The functional uses of the space, materials used, and especially the ceilings are definitely worth seeing, especially since the entrance fee is much less than La Pedrera and Casa Batllo. Plus, it's right next to an amazing pizza place and super close to Las Ramblas.

Poorly organised. Staff have no clue what they're doing. Appeared to have no training and only there to fill time. Not clear where to buy tickets or when next entry times are available. Also they don't direct people to the machines and the quests are longer than should be as a result. Real shame as the attraction was stunning but let down by poor management.

Well worth it. Audio guide for every room in many languages. Nice video in one room. Very interesting history and explanations of Gaudi and also Mr. Guell. Loved every room. Would highly recommend this place.I did see elevators for people who might not be able to take the stairs.

Overpriced . Intersting to see but overpriced if you ask me. If you love Gaudi then it is worth a visit, very interesting to see how Gaudiused his skills to create a beskope home. The roof is very pretty and very cool.
Greaaat . The house is definitely worth visiting. It is one of a kind. Gaudi is just genius. Make sure you get the audio guide otherwise you won't be able to appreciate what you see. Loved it.

Another stunning Gaudi masterpiece. Visited on Monday - to find it closed! Returned on an open day and purchased tickets (reduced prices for over 65s) and only had to wait just over an hour for our timed entry - coffee time!The entry price includes an audio guide (a multitude of languages available) which was very good - although perhaps too long and involved for some.The building is wonderful, from the basement/cellars where the horses were stabled, through to the living accommodation on the upper floors. The quality of materials, workmanship and Antoni Gaudi's vision combine to show the wealth of the Guell family.Glad we visited!

Nice but Gaudi has better works. Gaudi in general is fantastic and this Palau is right alongside the Rambla, but it is a bit darker than his other works. I would prefer Casa Batlló or Parc Guell to this site.
Glad I did it; good, but not great. Maybe I didn't stay long enough, but I did do a guided tour so I thought we'd see everything. Views are lovely. Architecture is incredible.

A huge display of wealth . Eusebi Guëll was one of the richest men in the history of mankind and this palace shows that wealth. Apparently this was Gaudis first big assignment. Sadly a lot of the original furniture is gone, so the real atmosphere of riches and wealth is a bit less, but when you see the great Hall on the main floor... Wow!You do get a few audio guide, but you can also buy the itinerary from the gift shop before you take the tour. It's pretty cheap.

A brilliant bonus. We had passed this building a number of times as it was close to our hotel, not really realising what was inside, after a trip elsewhere for the day, we called in here on the way back, this was one of Gaudis early projects and is a real gem, the interior is fabulous, the large window at the rear remarkable, but it is the roof of this building which is the winner, the chimneys and air vents are awesome, brilliant for that Gaudi picture that you want. Cheaper than the other sites and well worth a visit, its position close the the Ramblas very handy to drop in.

A good Gaudi choice. Another Gaudi creation situated near the Liceu Metro station. This one wasn’t too crowded and we were able to get in without an allocated time. Audio players outline the facts as you wander the rooms. This is an interesting and colourful home with quite a contrast of sights throughout. The basement stables lead up through to the office and living levels (becoming more opulent as you ascend), then the servants’ level and the roof featuring various chimneys in typical Gaudi style. The view from the rooftop is impressive. The cost is 12€ per person. This is one you should include on your Barcelona To Do list and is probably a better option than Park Guell if you have to choose between them.

Surprising gem. We received tickets to Palau Guell as compliments from our hotel and oh boy, am I glad we went! You could totally walk past it if you didn't know it's there. Contrary to other Gaudi's buildings, this one is not so popular among crowds (or we just lucked out?), so we enjoyed touring it with audio guides with just few other people. The building is absolutely stunning inside, with marvelous windows. The audio guides are very informative, which was great, as this was the first Gaudi's landmark we visited. Highly recommend popping in!

Palau Guell. This was a fabulous visit.You could easily walk pass Palau Guell in the street and not notice it but it is worth a visit. A family home with so many innovative ideas and beautiful spaces. There is an exhibition which explains the careful, painstaking restoration.

One of Gaudi's hidden gems. I visited this house in the late nineties and was absolutely amazed by it. I have always wondered why is this house not so popular as la Casa Batlló, la Casa Milà or the Parc Güell. Anyway, this house ('palace' really) has been closed for restoration and fairly recently reopened to the public. You MUST visit it, no doubt about it.
amazing0. absolutely recommend. stunning views .beautiful architecture. just amazing place to be. busy place so recommend to buy tickets in advance.

Paramount Surreal Experience. This is another MUST do while in Barcelona. The Tour Guide young Lady was charming in her delivery of the presentation of the tour. Her sense of humor was also very simpatico. The Light show is/was also extraordinary.
exellent. this is also one of Gaudis buildings, and an absolutely must when in Barcelona. Its as beautiful as the others and his unique style is so very impressive

Beautiful chimneys. The palace is magnificent. There are lots of rooms opened to visit and this is a huge plus. But the main attraction is the roof terrace. The chimneys are very beautiful and unique but you have to check the weather forecast because when it's rainy the roof terrace is closed.
Better places to see. Even though it wasn't bad, there are definitely better places to see in Barcelona. Only couple good rooms throughout but each room had a nice story to it.
Imposing. Even though I was not so impressed by the main part of parc guell, these structures were impressive. Understanding the construction of them is key to understanding and appreciating them.
Artsy place. This is where you can view the architectural design of Gaudi. It is a beautiful art of work everywhere you see. A recommended place to see when in Barcelona

a nice little find. The outside and roof of the building is worth the 12e entry fee. Very informative and well maintained
.

Wow what a place, can just imagine what it was like to live in. Excellent self guided tour provided with the ticket price gives full history and explanation of this amazing place that was beautifully restored by the barcelona government. Very impressive restoration information shown during the visit too. Views from the rooftop, perfect for selfies :P

Amazing place....but bad experince!. A spectacular place with horrible employees. "Today is free, If you dont want...go out" This sentence was said several times to the tourist that was just trying to avoid the burning 35 degrees sun! A shame Palau Guell....a Shame...
Gaudí really excellent. Very nice building , very good audio guide, nice architecture inside ,nice organ , nice stairs , balcony

Incredible and Beautiful. A must see if you have a couple of hours to spare in Barcelona. Great value at E12 per adult and kids under 10 are free.Tip: get there early. We went at 10am on a Thursday just as it opened, were first in the ticket line, and first through the door. Did not join a guided tour party, instead just listened to the audio guide they give you on entry (hand held device like a phone). The tour works in an orderly way, directing you through the rooms, passages and staircases one by one in sequential order. So because we were first in, we were often the only ones in the room! We had our 5 and 8 year old girls with us, so did not linger on the way, but they really enjoyed it, especially the electronic guide which was very informative. It took us about an hour to go bottom to top. The design, quality, detail, in every room was so amazing. Gaudi was a real genius, and clearly had a very strong trusted relationship with Guell. The last stop is the roof terrace which has some very ornate and colourful sculptures, plus the views around the city are a bonus. We did linger there for a while!

Great with teenagers!. I wasn't so sure about the visit here and what a success. I would recommend it with older children. We all had a great time, the 15 year old commented on how it wasn't boring like the places we normally take them to! Loved the spiralling staircases and all the design ideas. We loved the parabolic arches!!,

The beginning of the Genius Gaudi. This is a gem for those who like the Gaudi style of architecture. The audio guide works very well. the roof top is amazing. This was the first of Gauidi's projects and his blend of function and form is awesome.
Iron, wood & ceramic bizarre fusion works. Went in a tour with work event & brought family here & got same (wow) reaction. How you can squeeze a palace into such a small area is unbelievable.

The guide knew this was a great spot. I knew nothing about this place till today.
It was the perfect day, we went after lunch, great place and great views.
Not to many tourists like us, but you need a great guide, Dan was the best and knew it all.
Almost can't get enough of it. So this is a must see, but online and get there early because of the heat in July and August. It's great to see, it's a museum, and up on the roof is really nice.

So worth the money. Loved this! 12€ for a very informative and interesting visit. I'd go back again. I think this was the best thing we did while in Barcelona. A beautiful building and it was great to learn more about it.

Gaudí, Gaudí everywhere. The Palau is amazing! Take the audioguide, listen to everything, follow the story, enjoy! It's absolutely breathtaking.
And pay attention at the roof, it's all criss-crossy and makes you feel funny.

One of Gaudi's projects. Palau Guell is another one of Gaudi's projects. The basement used to be a stable for horses. The design is incredible! After seeing so many of Gaudi's projects, you wouldn't be surprised at the details that he used to think about (space, airflow, light etc,). Palau Guell has also upper floors and a roof to visit.We booked our tickets in advance (online) and when you get there, they give you an audio guide. I love the audio guides because it allows you to go at your rhythm and enjoy it your way. Tickets were about 12 euros each and is worth the price.

An early but great building. While this is my second visit to Barcelona, this is my first visit to Palau Guell. I'm very anoyed that I missed it last time.In this building you can see many of Gaudi's magnificent ideas. It's such a mix of styles it's hard to describe. Being an early work you can see many of these features in later buildings.What amazes me is that the client allowed Gaudi such a wide scope. So many features like the chimneys must have seemed crazy.Don't miss the roof.

Amazing but hot!. This beautiful mansion is well worth a visit. The intricacy of the detail in the rooms is unimaginable and breathtaking. There is an audio guided tour which is interesting (and you can skip through some if you don't want to listen to it all) and available in many languages. You finish the long walk through the many rooms on the roof, which is just incredible: magnificent view and inspiring architecture. The only drawback was that it was extremely hot and stuffy inside. We found one room with an air conditioning system, so stayed in there for a while!

Average. It is nice to see the town that Gaudi the father contributed to its creation. there is a good story behind it. but eventually you can look it up over the net. We were there on our way up to Montserrat which was the main attraction of the Day. PS; no restaurants in town, vending machine instead.

Great - but now need to pay to get in (and book in advance). Great place to visit. Since our last visit in 2010 they have introduced a control on numbers system meaning you book and pay in advance and are given a time slot to get into Zona Monumental. Fair enough I suppose. World class attraction and a must if you go to Barcelona. Go to Lesseps station then walk down hill a little way then up outdoor escalator to top end of park.
site seeing. Lovely place, amazing architecture, well managed and the amount people allowed in was good which enabled some good photos to be taken

Go to the roof!. This is the palace of the Güell family. They lived there but now it is a museum. Amasing! In the hall you can hear organ music. On the roof, you can have a nice view, and some extra art of Gaudi. Go on the top!
Hidden Gem!. This is one of Gaudi's early and formative works. It's opulance, decorations and colourful chimneys are really worth the guided tour! Better than La Pedrera.

Excellent for Hard of hearing/deaf. They have tablets with subtitles instead of audioguides for hard of hearing or deaf people (and they are the only to have got it so far, in Casa Battlo you can ask for text on paper, but it's not the same). You only have to leave your ID when taking the tablet (it's free). The lady on reception was extremely helpful and guards kind. Maybe it's not as colorful as other casas, but it's very well organized, interesting and part of Unesco world heritage, so I heartily recommend visiting it if you're in Barcelona for longer than few days. In comparison with Casa Mila, it's more pleasant for adults to spend day here. The chimneys were Gaudi's first inspirational step in making park Guell. It doesn't matter what time of day you are visiting cause the chimneys on roof always have good lighting for taking photos. Flash is prohibited inside.

What a home!. Easily booked tickets from booth next door. Reduced price for students but they need to produce a student card.Audio description is free and easy to use. Definitely worth the entrance fee to see the architecture and opulent decorating.

Another of Gaudi's fingerprints on the city of Barcelona!. There's no escaping the influence of Gaudi on Barcelona and who would want to? Gaudi's work leaves you in awe from the stunning la Sagrada Familia to Palau Guell (Guell Park). We saw this park as part of a tour and I'm so glad we did. It's yet another example of Gaudi's genius and, like Sagrada Familia, has much to offer and stimulate the mind and eye.The only recommendation I can make is that if you can, go and try to spend at least an hour or two there (or more!). We were with a tour and our time was limited to about 45 minutes or so and it would have been nice to just wander around the park and enjoy everything without being in a hurry. The bottom line: Another Gaudi gem that you shouldn't miss during a trip to Barcelona. Put it in your top 5 "must-see" places for Barcelona!

significant and historical record of gaudi designed and art-decorated buildings. significant and historical record of gaudi designed and art-decorated buildings. like walking thru a magic wonderland of colors, images, shapes and colors. highly recommended, great with kids. can get crowded, go early.

Surprising-glad we went. We went here as the Le Meridien has passes due to some cultural arrangement. We toured it from the outside on a Gaudi tour but went back the next day for interior. Glad we did-AC is not the reason! You visit this for an upclose look at Gaudi's work and some of the most well done marble in a private residence anywhere in the world.

Beyond Incredible!. This was by far my favorite museum that I visited in Barcelona. I did the audio tour and it was so informative. The tour was about and hour and was well worth it! Gaudi was an amazing architect and visionary. This museum is a MUST DO!

Gothic delight. We visited this interesting house. It is unlike some of the other Gaudi creations in Barcelona as it is more gothic in style. You can go around the whole building from the basement to the roof. My favourite parts were the lovely domed ceiling in the main hallway and the roof which has tiled chimneys. I would recommend booking in advance as it gets busy and visitor numbers are restricted.

Beautiful architecture and historic beauty . Beautiful. Excellent for anyone who loves Gaudi or has a taste for the gothic. Palau Guell has a lot of history and the Audi guides are easy to follow and free. Very cheap exhibit as well considering and a great thing to do as a family. They have the option for a full tour or an express tour which is great for younger children of people less interested in the neo-gothic! Only problem is how hot it gets; there is no air conditioning and in 30 degree weather in July its nearly unbearable!
Loved the visit. So glad we decided to visit, what an amazing work by Gaudi I would highly recommend adding this to any itinerary.
Charming. We loved all of the details that the artist and creator put into this part of Guell. Resembling trees a bit, the natural shape is enhanced by the inventive eye of Antonio Gaudi'.

Lovely architecture but guide definitely not fluent in another language. We decided to visit the Palau guell and when we arrived they had a guided visit planned in French which was part of the price so we decided to go for that instead of taking an audio guide. That was our big mistake, this woman guide wasn't at all fluent in French, actually it was her first time. Couldn't understand much, she made very simple comments and didn't gave us a lot of information. That was just a waste of time and money despite it was a very reasonable price which is not common in Barcelona : you need to have your purse open at all times as everything is very expensive and nothing is free.

Worth the time and money. A lovely and interesting place. Visited with my husband. Left kids att home. Teenagers can enjoy but not smaller kids. Do listen to the audio guide! After the visit you will love Gaudí. There was a line, but we only waited 15 minutes (shade). Go!

Why am I writing this?. After enduring the queues of the other Gaudi attractions, I was amazed at the lack of people here. Apart from the Sagrada this was the highlight of our trip. Unassuming from the outside, it leaves you gasping in wonder at the craftsmen at work here. It is run by the council so maybe not all tourists are aware of it due to the low key promotion? Anyhow, we were very happy about that!

Fabulous Gaudi architecture. What can I say an icon of Barcelona. That beautiful & lucky city to have so much Gaudi's legacy. You should try & visit as much of Gaudi's architecture when there, But Barcelona isn't all about him. It's a wonderful city to visit in its own right, with excellent restaurants, bars, hotels, food, La Rambla, La Boqueria, Picasso Museum, even a beach, to name but a few. Great atmosphere if a tad crowded at the height of the season. Just go!
A must if you like Gaudi. Gaudi's mind at work. not very expensive. A different idea of a palace. Close to Las Ramblas in the Raval. This palace was designed by Gaudi for his patron Guell.
Very Interesting. The guy was a genius. I love his work! In all of our trips to Barcelona, we had never visited this place before. Get a guide, as it is most interesting

Magnificent. I learnt of Antoni Gaudi several years ago and said I would like to visit his buildings, I had a significant Birthday this year and my Daughter took me to Barcelona, Palau Guell was one I did not know about. We were given the tip to be a little adventurous and walk down some of the side streets from Las Ramblas (what a great tip this was) and that is how we came across it. The staff were all warm, friendly and informative, especially the very kind man who did not get cross when I couldn't find how to turn of the flash on my camera and very kindly helped me. It is all lovely, I was particularly impressed with the basement and the roof terrace. Personally I have health issues and am slow and found it was lovely to tour at my pace and was not rushed by a more formal style tour. Well worth the visit, I loved it.

Gaudi fest. Great city, very welcoming and I will definitely be back. I first went 15 years ago and found it a little scruffy but now it is clean, modern and easy to get around for able bodied or not.

Very interesting. Very interesting and well done. Didn't have to read pages of information as you have an audio guide. Not as expensive as many other tourist sites. And no where near as crowded. Lovely roof with great views as well. Recommend bringing your student ID if your a student to get €3 off ticket price.

Worth a visit. This small building is a nice gem lost in the streets near Las Ramblas. It costs 12,90 to enter, students pay less, but everyone has acess to audioguides to better understand the arquitectonic and decorative details of this historic place, as well as the reasons behind its' construction. The detail in some of the rooms is exquisite. Overall this is a nice sight, one to see once you have already seen all of the main Gaudi attractions and still crave more of the marvelous architect's work. Do try to go on a sunny day, or else you will not be able to visit the Terrace.

Gaudi(amus igitur). Here, it can be seen what genius and money could create...Güell and Gaudi are obviously full of new mind-blowing ideas, at that century.Please have a look on all the technical details...for example the mechanics for the sun blades to shadowing or the furniture. Hard to believe how the workman could process without any practical experiences or templates.

Natural Gaudi. From Vallcarca metro station, it is about a 20 minute walk to the nature park entrance where you wind you way down the hill of gardens and trees with views of the city of Barcelona all the way. The alternate entry is via Lesseps station which is closer to the Gaudi houses. Devote a whole day if you have time and if you love to walk and absorb the natural environment with the colourful touches of Gaudi.
Interesting but a hike. Although interesting, not sure if it was worth the price and the long walk and queue. As a Gaudi fan there are better places in the city to see his work.

Dark. Visited all 5 of the main Gaudi sites during recent trip and found this one to be the least "impressive" of them all. Overall this old house is very dark and heavy. Even the rooftop area was not as impressive as I had anticipated.

Gaudi at his best. This park is a total Gaudi experience. The artist/architect works have been assembled in a park half way up the foothills of Barcelona. There is an entrance fee, but it is not too badly priced (unless you want a guided tour).It's just a nice place to chill out and observe one of the worlds greatest visionaries.

Roof Top Amazing!. We stayed in a balcony room at the Gaudi Hotel that faced the roof top of Palau Guell. It was amazing to study the many wonderful chimneys on top of the building. It was like gazing at a fantasy land.

Beautiful!! Used to be free entrance - not anymore.. buy tickets online in advance. Beautiful!! Used to be free entrance - not anymore.. buy tickets online in advance we arrived at 11 and there were tickets for 17hr only.. well worth it!!

Paulau Guell is a spectacular and not to be missed while in Barcelona.. This is a must see sight if visiting Barcelona. The gardens are spectacular-my photos are so beautiful they don't look real! The view of Barcelona is gorgeous and is a great photo opportunity. This is a wonderful place to see Gaudi work up close and to enjoy nature at the same time.

Simply stunning . My second visit here. A privilege. I could rave on for hours. .. i won't! Just go. Go and take your time. Enjoy. Sit. Be amazed. A word of advice. .. you can't carry bags in. Security lockers are available. However there are not very many of them and they they require a 1 euro deposit (it goes in the lock mechanism inside the door). My advice... avoid carrying a bag or make sure you have a coin with you.

Uncrowded Gaudi Site. My husband & I really enjoyed touring this mansion, the location was an easy walk from our hotel. Even the basement had Gaudi's mark. I guess the ramp was so the horses & carriages could go in easily . This home is so beautiful , the arches & windows are beautiful , you are able to go all the way to the roof.  The roof is topped with the most unusual chimneys covered with colored tiles. I was surprised by the location ,down a side street with no other houses around , maybe when it was built it was more of a neighborhood. I liked that we pretty much had the mansion to ourselves also they had a very clean restroom (hard to find in Barcelona )  I enjoyed that this was a home & as fancy as it was it was not the crazy Gaudi style that you see in some of his designs
Great tour. Loved the audio tour through this "palace". Would recommend this to everyone! Beautiful building! But don't look out the back windows at the disgusting apartments.

Wonderful Tour. We went on a free day which is offered on the first Sunday of every month.The audio guide was great and we really enjoyed the tour. We spent a lot of time on the roof as the views were amazing in every direction. I recommend this place and the Basilica as a good sampling of Gaudí's work.

Big bubble little burst. Huge lineups to get in, pretty crowded so don't expect to get a clean picture of anything. So the one hour or more it takes for you to get into this place, it's all said in done in less than hour. I would save this for the last part of my trip or better yet take the money and sit in a nice cafe and drink beer.

Wonderful Gaudi experience. Last time we visited Barcelona, Palau Guell was still being renovated. I am so glad we went back... You can lose yourself for several hours in this amazing building. The rooms are beautifully staged, you can really imagine living in them in Gaudi's lifetime. We're not usually fans of the taped guides but the video tour was excellent. The entrance fee is very reasonable and there were no queues to get in! An absolute must see...

Accidentally stopped here- thank goodness we did. We were just looking for something to do before dinner and saw this on the map. (We did not do much planning before we got here). We got there about 50min before closing and knew we had to move quickly. It was plenty of time for us. The house is very interesting and the ceiling really seemed like the highlight to us. That said, it was the roof that was outstanding. The chimneys are awesome and the undulating floor is indescribable. Definitely worth the entry fee (we had one few from hotel and paid for one, but I think this can also be bundled with other guell destinations).

Appreciating Gaudi without the crowd. Seeing the outside of familia sagrada and la pedra and Casa Seeing the outside of La Sagrada Familia, Le Pedera, and Casa Batilo made me want to see the inside of a Gaudi Creation, but i didnt want all the crowds or Time waiting in line. I went at 4:30 on a Saturday to Palau Guell and really enjoyed the audio self guide tour that highlighted Gaudis creativity as an architect.

Worth the visit, although I wouldn't rank it as a top sight. We were fortunate to be in Barcolona on the first Sunday of a month, so our tickets were free!. I'm glad that was the case, because I do not think the ticket prices justify this attraction. It's an interesting home to tour, but it's actually not my favorite of the various Gaudi designed homes throughout Barcelona. I would tour this home only after you've visited other "must see" Barcelona attractions first (e.g., Sagrada Familia, Barri Gotic/Old City, Park Guell, and even Casa Mila or Casa Battlo).

Not too busy . $12 entry fee including audio guide which was very interesting and takes you on a tour. No queue unlike many other gaudi building's and plenty of space to wonder around. Chimneys on roof is highlight and quite contrast to dark Gothic inside. We really enjoyed.

The Evolution of Gaudi. Palau Guell is one of Gaudi’s earlier works. It is full of fascinating elements that will help you see how his style evolved. After you’ve seen Sagrada Familia, Casa Batilo, and La Pedrera, you won’t want to miss this!

Another amazing Gaudi experience. This superb building is a must see in Barcelona being Gaudi's first commission from his great client and friend Eusebi Guell. It is very well presented with an excellent audio guide. The building is quite a labyrinth with lots to see and terrific information about this great architect and his outstanding client. On a side street which runs off the Rambla and close to the Boqueria Market. Metro Liceu.
Amazing castle. I found it a lot more worth than paying for overpriced Casa Battlo. It's grand and the chimneys on the terrace are beautiful.

A different Gaudi. After having seen two other Gaudi scenes the same day this was very different to the others.... In the sense that I thought it was more subdued.In this "piece" .... Calling it that because Gaudi's work presented as art to me.... There is much more use of dark wood, and the emphasis is not just on light but also music!!! The queue here was much less than at the other places. That might having been because it was in the afternoon, so that might be a good time to go.The audio guide was good in terms of what you are told, but at this site you are not given a head-set so if you don't bring your own it can be hard to hear, seeing as a lot of people will be listening to the same thing at the same time as you.
Great tour. Great value. . Took the included audio tour. Great hour and a half. Insight into Guell family. Also less expensive than la Pedrera I think because it is a governmental agency.

Another Breathtaking glimpse into the mind of Gaudi. Breathtaking with each turn you take - this is a fantastic tour that illustrates several of his signature architectural elements and is simply BEYOND amazing

Gaudi shows once again his attention to nature with magical quality. We have visited 3 times now, and were disappointed you now have to pay to see Gaudi's main pieces. You do need to book,or long queues.Great mirroring of nature in his bridge constructions, echoing the trees.The rest of the park is free, it is still a fabulous place to take a picnic and explore other Gaudi bits. Try and get off the metro at Vallecarca and take the full outdoor escalator up, an experience in itself!

Super recommended. Right in the heart of Las Ramblas, this palace is a great way to understand the amazing talent of Gaudi. The audio guide is extremely detailed and in 40 minutes provides you with the full experience into Gaudi's work and mind. Really enjoyable visit.

Excellent value Gaudi. This is a great little find, just a stones throw away from LA Rambla.Its fair to say they are fairly proud of their fella Gaudi in Barcelona. This inner city palace makes impressive use of a 500sq m site, as it appears incredibly spacious inside. It is a fine example of early Gaudi design, lots of wood and wrought iron. However, the rooftop is more typical of Gaudi's inimitable style.This is a great value visit, it takes about an hour and a half to get around. The audio guide is included in the very reasonable 12EUR entrance price. Another note on the audio guide, the attention to detail is impressive. As well as clear information on each room, there are helpful images on the screen as you go and music composed by contemporaries to the Guell family.

Surprisingly impressive and interesting!. I actually enjoyed this more than Casa Batillo. They are both worth visiting b/c they are very different from each other although both designed by Gaudi. This house has a dark, gaudy (no pun intended) style but very elegant and interesting.If you speak English go on Friday at 2pm and buy your ticket in advance....same price for an English speaking tour and is well worth it to understand the history and interesting facts of the house.

Interesting history. The home is centered on a main room for entertaining high society guests. Guests entered the home in horse-drawn carriages through the front iron gates, which featured a parabolic arch and intricate patterns of forged iron-work resembling seaweed and in some parts a horsewhip. Animals could be taken down a ramp and kept in the livery stable in the basement where the servants resided, while the guests went up the stairs to the receiving room. The ornate walls and ceilings of the receiving room disguised small viewing windows high on the walls where the owners of the home could view their guests from the upper floor and get a 'sneak peek' before greeting them, in case they needed to adjust their attire accordingly.
another Gaudi not to miss. this is a nice addition to the Sagrada family and Park Guell, from the bottom up the complexity and finish get richer and richer and richer.
A must see. Palau Guell is a must when visiting Barcelona as it is beautiful with the game of the colors and the architecture created by Gaudi who was a good friend of Guell.

12$ but beautiful. I was surprised by the cost. But loved every minute here. Don't forget headphones for the free audio tour. Students get a steep discount so make sure to mention if you have students.

A Gaudi designed home of elegance. Gaudi designed this elegant home for his friend, Mr. Guell, though it was only lived in by the Guell family for a short period of time. It is elegant and gives and introduction to how Gaudi managed ceilings, attics, basements, various systems for air flow and heating.

Doesn't look much from street level . I wonder how much this would cost to build in todays money? Also, I can't imagine anyone living here. Fantastic to see and we'll worth the entrance fee. Whatever you do, don't forget to look up at the ceilings.
Great view!. If you are a fan of modern architecture you will love palau guel. Great views and definitely something to think about. If you are a fan of Gaudi you will appreciate this place.

Wonderful Macro-view of Gaudi's work. Barcelona is so full of Gaudi's work it is hard to not let them blurr into just a 'style'-that is why I liked the close up view of this one work. We enjoyed it slow and looked at the details. Even the impulsive liked this stop!
Not suitable for disabled people - quite awkward but beautiful . Not a lot of accessibility available but beautiful surroundings and most of the staff except for a few are very helpful and lovely.
Worth seeing! . Brilliant audio guid tour and absolutely stunning architecture from gaudy. One can really see how he developed his craftsmanship as it is the first place he ever built.
Another masterpiece of Gaudi. Beautiful architecture inside and outside this work by Gaudi represents nicely the beauty of modernism.
Interesting and Unique. I went in and have a picture of the outside I will include it was unique and interesting place to visit.

Guadi's 1st master piece / castle - worth your time. If you are familiar with Guadi's architecture, then you know anything he touches is fantastic. This is not an exception to the rule. And I recommend that you experience Palau Guell first then Park Guell, and any others that interest you, finishing with the Sagrada Familia. Guadi's a genius.

Unbelievable. We found this to be by far the best gaudi experience, tucked away down a cool little street, well away from the thousands of tourists at Guell Park or the other Gaudi treasures. From the front it is not that imposing but it is well worth the 12 euro pass, every single corridor, stairway, room you enter is an adventure into the amazing mind of Gaudi, and it is priceless. If you are fed up with fighting the crowds or standing in looooong queues do yourself a kindness and visit this amazing building. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

AMAZING!!! Don't miss this!. We did this because we had an hour to kill before our flight and it was right next to our hotel. It was amazing!! Be sure to do the audio tour. My 6 year old and I were both enthralled by the detail and stories of this unique home.

Great, Affordable Gaudi-designed Palace!. The Audio Tour is included with entry, but you have to ask for it inside at the storage bins. Really fascinating palace! The designs of everything from floor to ceiling are amazing and well thought out. Our favorite part of the walkthrough was the roof top; the mosaic-like chimneys are stunning and there is a decent view of the city. Highly recommend!

Unique and worth while! . Arrived at the Palau Guell just as it opened to ensure a quiet visit. We were among very few other visitors. The ticket included an audio guide which made the experience that much more pleasant as it explained the different uses of the rooms and offered visuals as to how they would have looked during the time in which the family lived there. The Museum only took about an hour to go through as there weren't any crowds, as we were leaving however, two tour groups were just about to come in. Beautifully restored and a wonderfully unique take on architecture!

Great introduction to Gaudi. This was our first Gaudi stop in Barcelona and we were definitely amazed by the style and architecture. Its a short detour from La Rambla so perfectly located for a leisurely visit and there wasn't much of a crowd in the morning. The audioguides are included in the price and give good insight into Gaudi;s genius. The rooftop chimneys are definitely the highlight of this place.

Free first Sunday of the month . If you're in town on the first Sunday of the month it's definitely worth while taking advantage of the free museum tours, which includes Palau Guell.A stunning Gaudi-designed home, located just off the Ramblas.Suggest getting there at least 30 minutes before it opens as lines can be reasonably lengthy.

Very impressive Gaudi architectual building. Short to none line of visitors. A very good explenation by earings device.Very nice building,a complete palace with very impressive and unique style. From basement to the roof and Gaudi's outstanding chimnies, nothing to compare to.

Another must see Gaudi mansion. You can really see the difference between this and some of Gaudi's later accomplishments. It's much darker inside, with all the dark wood used throughout but still very impressive. We bought tickets at the sales window next to the house as it was around 4pm, there was no line to enter. Audio guides are provided. Worth a visit.

Worth the trek.. Best way to get there is Bus 42 from Pla Catalunya (Passeig de Gracia) drops you right at the tkt office (stop - Carretera del Carmel). The metro stop is a walk up the hill away. Book online in advance for timed tkts. Take bus times into account when booking. It is about 2.5 miles from Pla. Catalunya, so walkable, but generally up hill. It's is easier to wak back or on to Sagrada Familia. It's Gaudi - in beautiful gardens, what's not to like! The Porter's house has an informative video. Small cafe, serving fresh smoothies and orange juice. takes about an hour for the 'Monumental Zone'.

Best Gaudi experience so far. This was our 5th Gaudi tour and it is by far my favorite. A wonderful experience to learn more about Gaudi and his partnership with the Guell family. Definitely get the audio tour. The details are absolutely stunning. The rooftop offers spectacular views of the city. Will make you wish you had a time machine!

Best attraction in Barcelona. Not a huge architecture nut but was fascinated by the uniqueness of this mansion. Though I can't recall the timing, it seems that Gaudi must have designed this before going off the deep end with his other projects. Well organized tour and a staff that was helpful and attentive. Not a place for squirmy or unsupervised kids.

Beautiful and worth visiting. For some reason this is the cheapest and least visited of the Gaudi buildings. It is beautiful and while you recognise Gaudi's style it is different from Casa Batllo and La Pedrera. Must see!

Don't bother, waste of time and money. I must have confused this with Parc Guell, this was terrible. An empty building, and you had to pay to see it. In and out in 10 minutes, I was so dissappointed and annoyed with myself for not doing my homework better.

Before its time.. We visited Park Guell and chose a guided tour of the Monumental Zone, definitely worth paying a little extra to get a full overview of the history behind the Park and Gaudi's influence. Our guide was very good.

4 Day visit. This was located in same street as our hotel and at approx 13 euros is fantastic value for money.Another Guadi piece of work but the decor inside is stunningCan get very hot inside as little air con

Loved Palau Guell. Went on this tour spur of the moment. Wasn't on our original itinerary as we had planned on visiting Park Guell and Casa Battlo. We REALLY enjoyed this tour and seeing more of Gaudi's work. Takes an hour or so and is located near Las Rambla, definitely worth a visit.

Palau Guell. This private residence was designed by Gaudi for his patron and benefactor Guell. The furnishings, decor including the ceilings and flooring are magnificent. The central chapel which is visible from many locations ans floors is incredible. Well worth the visit.
Only 12 euros! Go!. More of Gaudi's work bu perhaps not quite as tourisity. This house is impressive, espcially the windows and music room. The roof top was great too with the crazy chimneys

Interesting. It is an interesting visit but expensive. If you ask mi to choose between all Gaudi's buildings, I'll choose this one. But if you ask me where to spend my money, I will not get inside any of them.

Such amazing attention to every small detail. Truely amazing that anyone could pay so much attention to detail and that the building could be so beautifully restored. The audio guide was free and brilliant, walking you through the building and pointing out numerous details. It was not necessary to book a ticket on a June Wednesday, but I would recommend booking - the queues at the weekend had been very long.

Nice - earlier work by Gaudi. Its better to buy tickets ahead if you plan to visit here. You never know about the line ups. It was nice to stroll through this building which was designed by Gaudi though it was a private residence. There are many interesting elements to his architecture especially the chimneys on the roof terrace.

#1 attraction. Visited Europe for 12 days. By far my favorite part of my trip was visiting this museum. Gaudi works it's amazing. Please visit if visiting Barcelona.Ps. The 1 st Sunday of each Month the entry is free. The tickets are limited and there are two section during the day. One in the morning and the second one at 1pm I believe. The line can be a bit long but so worthy. Love this attraction.

NICE. My daughter, who graduated from art school, was told by a professor this was the best Gaudi building. Other than the Sagrata, we only entered this Gaudi bldg. There was NO line to get in and it wasn't crowded. Fee to get in was 9 euros and age 10-17 was only 5 euros. La Pedrera is 20.50 and students are 16.50. It is a better value. Also on the roof there are chimneys that resemble the better know one at La Pedrere. Overall a wonderful visit
amazing. it's great how /gaudi can surprise us with his creations. However Palau Guell has a darker style that matches with the location

gorgeous Gaudi architecture. this was the first Gaudi building I saw and it's impressive - also less expensive than some of the others, and less crowded. Stunning details, interesting details and a lot of access - definitely recommend it highly.
nice. Very nice place, you can pass a few hours visiting the place. Highly recommend, do not give up a visit to Barcelona

Loved it !. Beautiful Park with Gaudi architecture. Good to book online in advance to secure your time into the monument area as entry numbers are limited. The rest of the park is open all the time. Live music was playing which added to the visit. Many street vendors - that get moved on by the police only to pop up again as soon as they have gone ! Fantastic views over Barcelona. Usual café in the park and on the roads outside exceptionally expensive as expected !!

Luxurious. This was one of the only good things to see in/around Las Ramblas. This mansion is interestingly located in a seemingly typical neighborhood, but is full of Gaudi genius. Definitely worth the stop - plan for about 2 hours.

Life Imagined. Another great spot to tour, even if it is raining (just spend very little time on the roof). You'll miss everything if you don't use the little headphones and listen to all the stories and fun facts. That is the tour. Just let yourself drift off into history and imagine living there. People still do.

Exceptional palace...do not miss it!. The last time we were in Barcelona, Palau Guell was closed. This time, we went early on a Saturday and not waiting line, we were in luck. Another Gaudi masterpiece. Amazing sense of details! Too bad they don't open the shutters a bit more, the place looks darker that it really was in the days this house was inhabited. Memorable!

What a place!. A very unusual building. Another Gaudi masterpiece though not, I believe, one of his better known ones. It is hidden down a street off the Rambla and you could walk by and miss it, but don't! It is quite different to his other buildings in the city which are much more fanciful, in this building you can see the personality of the man he was designing for. It is very imposing and has a much more serious feel about it. The wood and iron work is astounding, to think that all that decorative ironwork was wrought by hand. They seem to spread the visitors out so that it doesn't get too crowded though we were there early in the summer season so it might get more crowded. There is an option of an audio tour (we did not use this but it might be a good idea to further enhance the experience) We also got to hear a piece of organ music in the music room (not sure if it was being played at the time on the actual organ designed into the mansion or if it was recorded but it was very impressive) Make sure to go up to the rooftop which gives a great view across Barcelona and is studded with Gaudi's mad chimney pots.
Nice. It is nice, Gaudi style. The terrace is very nice, and when you come down you can identify his style in all objects. Beautifull. But make sure you buy tickets before!
