Amazing work by Guadi. We decided to check this place out and we were not disappointed as it has the most wonderful selection of Guadi's work.
Wonderful. A wonderful building and not so many people. The audio did not work as well as it could have, but we got most of it.

Truly outstanding example of Gaudi's work. The Palau Guell is located conveniently off La Ramblas. The structure is not impressive from the outside, but once inside, it is absolutely breathtaking - from the cellar to the rooftop! This is an exquisite example of Gaudi's early work. The architecture is stunning -- such detail, and so many innovative uses of light and space. You will be amazed!The Palau Guell is very interesting and well worth your time.
Work of art. Another superb work of Gaudi. Earlier and completely different than Casa Batllo. It is hard to believe that people lived in such a palace. Don't miss it.

So beautiful. This gem was right across the street from our hotel. We saved it for the last day of our vacation. What a way to end our time in Barcelona. The Palace is quite breathtaking. To imagine what Gaudi envisioned is truly impossible. The details are exquisite and so well placed. Everything has a reason and a purpose. The architecture is beyond words. How does one describe perfection?

A less well known gem. I took a group of teenagers to Palau Guell on a school trip. The building from the outside does not make justice to the inside, which is actually quite impressive. There aare some rooms kept as they were, and there are some pictures as well of how it used to be in Eusebi Guell's times. I'd recommend to read about the Palau beforehand rather than getting the eaudio guide, as it is hard not to switch off after a while listening to the monotonous voices..

The first example of Gaudi's work. Palau Guell or Guell Palace was Antonio Gaudi's first commissioned project. It was built in the late 1880's and took about 4 years to complete. Gaudi was hired by Eusebi Guell a very wealth industrialist. They went on to become great friends and Gaudi did more many more projects for Guell. The building became the Guell family home for many years. Gaudi came up with new and innovative uses of light and space. There was also much use of wrought iron finely detailed and woof crafted by the finest wood workers of the time. It is very interesting and well worth seeing.

Fascinating. If you like architecture this is the place to go. Filled with Gaudi's imaginative ideas incorporating glass, wood pottery and stone. Easy location off La Rambla and not too costly to enter.
Is there too much gaudi???. Maybe - but this place was also an interesting insight into life at the time. Great architecture and some pretty amazing advanced thinking. Worth the visit

A housing development like no other. Very interesting to experience the vision of Gaudi and Güell in the development of this housing area. A beautiful failure that lives on. Beautiful views of the city from the park. Ability to tour the guards house and gardens. Would recommend booking tickets via Internet at home before you go...this tour is often fully booked and if it is, it necessitates coming back on another day.

Gaudi Design. The visit to this palace designed by Gaudi was a highlight of my trip to Barcelona. The palace belonged to powerful industrialist Eusebi Guell. He commissioned it to Gaudi in 1885. The palace is a tasteful stately home which exudes opulence.This structure impressed me more than the Sagrada Familia Basilca.

Another brilliant Gaudi building. I thought I had seen most of Gaudi's masterpieces but came across Palau Guell on my way to the laundromat! Absolutely worth the visit although my husband was reluctant to go at first we both thoroughly enjoyed the magic of the building. Other reviewers have written in more detail than I can and all the positive reviews are truly correct in everything they say. We went at lunchtime and there was no queue although there was in the morning. For someone whose own lifestyle was so spartan, Gaudi created the most beautiful and imaginative residences for his clients. The detail and design whether it is in wood, iron or tile is wonderous. From the basement to the roof and every floor in between there is something to marvel at. While we were there a lifelike recording from the organ was played and created a fantastic atmosphere in the music room so that visitors could appreciate the acoustics. Wonderful.

Totally recommended attraction. The place is in the city centre, so it is easy to get and get surprised by the gaudi's work! Also, our guide Pablo was fantastic, very polite and friendly. He made feel us like Mr.Guell. We enjoyed really much and we will repeat next time!

The First of Gaudi's Structures, and an Excellent Place To Start. The first Sunday of every month, Palau Guell (pronounced Gway) is free, and that's when we went; we arrived 40 minutes before opening, and were in the second group admitted. If you are purchasing a ticket, it can be done on line on the museum's official site. We loved the house. Not only do you see the beginning of Gaudi's innovative ideas, you see a house you'd be delighted to live in. The audio guide is included in the ticket price (and included in the free admission on the first Sunday of the month), and is interesting and very well done. Gaudi, in this case, was remodeling an existing structure--despite the owner's willingness to tear it down and start from scratch--and had a very limited space in which to work, a townhouse with a relatively small footprint, so the innovations are, in my opinion, even more remarkable, from the atrium-style construction of public areas to the "bricks" in the entry-way, which are actually wood to muffle the sound of the horses hoofs as they entered. The roof-top is pure Gaudi and the audio guide explains the reasons for the "fantastical" chimneys. Some sources say that Palau Guell is not as good a tourist stop as the more well known La Pedrera, but we found it fascinating, and having seen it (and imagined living in it) made our appreciation of La Pedrera greater--and there's no question which one I'd rather live in: Palau Guell wins. Plan on a couple of hours to enjoy this less-visited Gaudi site.
Excellent audio tour . Very reasonable trip with student discount but I suggest booking in advance. Fantastic architecture and very interesting audio tour.

Worth the time if you are a Gaudi fan.. During my first trip to Barcelona, Palau Guell was under renovation and closed. I had to go the next time I was there.I believe this is Gaudi's first large commission. It's very grand, but it's different than his later works. It's not the "Modernisme" style that he adopts later.It's very beautiful and worth the trip just to see his evolution.

Just skip this if you don't have time. Don't spend your time and money here if you only have one full day in Barcelona. Just see basilica segrada familia and casa Batlio, the two best sights. Its style is very uninteresting, lots of cast iron used and wood. Though much time and effort must have gone into it, I sure wouldn't want to live there. Dim...and old....

Modernistas unite!. This is a wonderful Gaudi home to explore. Mr. Guell was the Rockefeller of Barcelona-more money than god. He had Gaudi build this home for him without regard to cost or materials; consequently, it is a luxurious mansion. It even had its own private road to Guell's parents' nearby home.There are 7 stories, each with its own function and character. It's really indescribable: intricate ceilings, lots of marble, museum quality paintings, parabolic arches, "secret" passageways for conjugal visits, and the beautiful, if not phallic, chimneys, 20 of them, on top. The climax is the roof with the splendid mosaic chimneys and the exquisite views of th wonderful city of Barcelona. Get a guide and go for it.

This Building won my Respect for Gaudi as an Architect. Gaudi isn't to everyone's taste. A lot of his work, in my opinion, is freakish and Disneyland-ish. and verges on Kitsch. But Palau Guell won my respect and made me take a fresh look at Gaudi's work.Firstly, I was impressed with his ingenuity. He succeeded in constructing a 'palace' (well, a substantial urban family mansion) on a small and narrow plot. Secondly, I was impressed by his use of materials. The basement level is a horse stable constructed of brickwork columns and arches - but it has the dignity and solemnity of a crypt. The upper levels make use of glass, ironwork, and expensive wood and marble - but you never have the sense that a material has been chosen because of its perceived value. It is all a matter of texture, form, and surface. Thirdly, the building has a remarkable stylistic unity. The style is severe, uncompromising, and rather masculine - until you get to the wavy roof with its colourful glazed chimneys. This building is worth a visit, and it rewards close examination. Make sure you book your ticket in advance.

Get tickets ahead of Time!. This park is not free! There is apart of the park which is free and great to walk up to get a beautiful view of the city! Be sure to have the right shoes as the walk to the top is very long (think hike!) Make sure to get tickets the day before, I don't know if they can be purchased online or not, but it makes it much easier so you won't have to wait to go in the part that's not free. The part you pay for has the walls with the different color tiles and worth the money (it's not that expensive)!

Now this is a garden. So often it seems European gardens seem to fall short on flower displays. Merely green grass parks. Park Guell is both unique in hardscape and interesting in flower displays. Worth the trip out of the central tourist area out to Park Guell.

Nice "Gaudi architected" home, one block off Las Ramblas. Antoni Gaudi was the architect for what was a private home for an industrialist friend. This is a large home with many floors. There are horse stables in the basement level and a kitchen and staff quarters on the top floor.In typical Gaudi fashion, the fireplace chimneys are works of art. View them from the rooftop access.

Gaudi's Magnificence. Built before La Sagrada Familia, Gaudi demonstrates his skill, not only as an eminent architect, but as an engineer as well. The use of colour, a multitude of exotic materials and design that makes anyone seeing it go...wow! Just off Las Ramblas in Barcelona, it is well worth a visit and was nowhere near as crowded as other, more renowned buildings...don't know why!

Gaudi's flamboyance at its best. This seemingly nondescript house just off La Rambla can be easily missed on a casual stroll but make an effort to see the inside and the roof of the building. Gaudi made a huge space within the confines of a small building plot. The touches of his genius is all there starting from the basement all the way up to the roof. The central "space" was used as a music hall and has many clever ways to make use of the limited space and light. There is a self guided audio guide that is extremely handy without which one may miss a lot. The roof is also very flamboyant and tiled and the whole thing is "do not miss".

Awesome!. Brilliant introduction to Gaudi. The audio tour is very informative and entertaining. The place itself isn't too busy in the mornings. I enjoyed this bit of Gaudi modernist route most of all. The chimneys are the most beautiful from all Gaudi's chimneys.

Surprisingly excellent. Neither of us being art or architectural fans we were a bit unsure of what to expect from Palau Guell. Nonetheless we thoroughly enjoyed it. We visited on the first Sunday of the month when entry is free but we would have paid the €12 entry on reflection. Really enjoyable and informative tour via the audio guide and it is a very impressive building. You do not need to have a prior appreciation of Gaudi or art or architecture to enjoy this. Highly recommend.

Book ahead!. We visited on a Sunday morning, shortly after 10am, not realising that if you wish to see the Gaudi statues, mosaics etc you have to buy a ticket. They limit the numbers so we could not get tickets until after 6pm that day. So we had a return trip on the metro and walk (and escalators) up to the park with little reward. We had other things planned later in the day so couldn't return.
Beautiful. Palace designed by Gaudi right off Las Ramblas. The rooms were nice, but the roof is the real headliner, full of Gaudi's unique, colorful take on design. Great view of the city as well.

Great Gaudí study . The value in seeing Palau Güell is increased immensely when seen on the same day as Casa Batlló -- the contrast is startling. It's best to read about both before your visit.Palau Güell is pretty interesting on its own merits - at the least, you can tour an early, Art Nouveau Gaudí mansion. His genius is evident even in this early design, and it's worth seeing if you have the time. If not, save it for your next trip to Barcelona. However, if you DO get here, be sure to see the roof. And since you're in Raval, go see the Botero cat, which is nearby.

A fantastic survivor from the late 19th Century. We walked up at 6pm and there was no queue. Four of us paid and went in. You are IMMEDIATELY taken back 135 years to about 1880. The two main gates allowed horses and carriages in and out of this fantastic Gaudi building. If the carriage was stopping for the night the horses were taken down a spiral ramp to the stables underneath. So we went to the stables and then up floor by floor to the roof with the included commentary machine. With so many ideas constantly springing from Gaudis head I don't know how he completed anything. This was his first building for Mr Guell and their association then went on for a lifetime. Not to miss and near the bottom of the Rambla.

Interesting Palace. This is a lesser known Gaudi building but well worth a visit. Visits are timed and you have to get a ticket from a booth near to the entrance, so don't start queueing at the door before you've got your ticket. The place itself it a tribute to wealth and influence, with plenty of Gaudi touches of art and ingenuity. It's an example of on of the first underground car parks.... but for horses! Wonderful use of light in all the rooms and great craftsmanship. Enjoy!

May half term visit. Another place we didn't pre book - we were straight in though it was about 5pm. Security is practically airport level, with X-ray and bag checks. Gift shop is minimal and costlyBut it's a must go place, it's amazing to think this was a home!Rooftop was a lot of fun (but no good if you're unsteady on your feet)

Majestic town house. The use of peculiar materials, one of the trademarks of Dali's work, is part of this townhouse beautifully made and thought. The whole house is a magical place, the central room and it's high vault ceiling give a nice cocooning feeling, but the most amazing part is the rooftop, with all the mosaic chimneys giving it an enchanted-forest-feeling!!

Interesting to visit if you are in La Rambla area by the water. We wanted to tour at least one of Gaudi's buildings this visit and this one was close by to where we were staying.The detail of the wood carving was most fascinating and the design and use of space most intriguing. The roof was a delight towards the end of the tour.We purchased the audio tour which gave a lot of insight to Gaudi and his working relationship with Guell.
Nice experience. If you are travelling to Barcelona, this should be one of your highlighted attractions. Well worth the price of admission. Will absolutely return in the near future.

Gaudi's most impressive work. Less impressive from the outside than Battlo or Pedrera, it's on the inside that this building stands out. The rich and detailed works of wood, iron, stone and the layout of the building are what make this place truly impressive.As a bonus, it is by far the least crowded of the three... making this a good option to visit at anytime... even late afternoons.Expect to spend about 1:15 in this place

Intriguing. Although not as ornate on the exterior as some of the other of Gaudi's buildings, the property is very interesting. Internally the influence of Gaudi is clear including some intriguing furniture designs. As with his other domestic properties the roof terrace features chimney stacks decorated in bright and vibrant mosaics along with others that are undecorated brick stacks but of interesting shapes.Well worth the visit.

Combine visit with Montserrat!. Initially decided to skip this attraction as it is quite far out from the city, about an hour plus by train just to see a church. However, while we were on our way to Montserrat in the morning, we realised that the stop (Colonia Guell) to Cripto Guell is halfway along the same line to Montserrat (about 2hrs). Hence we decided to complete Montserrat in half a day and visit this place! It's a small walking town and you can get the map of the place and pay the entrance fee to the church ($7 euro) at the tourist information centre (5min walk from the Colonia Guell train station). To get there, after exiting the train station, cross the road and you can follow the signs / blue footsteps that will guide you along the way from the train station. With the Barcelona card, the fee is $7.20 euros including audio guide. The church isn't crowded (aka more photo opportunities!) as I think most people choose not to visit as it is far out from the city. The map shows you the walking route to the rest of the attractions (that aren't so attractive) mostly old buildings like hospital, private housing etc, I think you can skip those if you don't have the time as its mainly looking at its architecture and unable to go in. Only the church is worth visiting.

Amazing architecture and great Audio assist!. The Palau Guell is a fascinating and beautiful tour of a house designed by Guell. There are over 25 rooms that correspond with different audio listening recordings, and each recording is in depth and insightful. We spent over an hour in this house and the architectural quality is superb! Great views of the city from the rooftop terrace, too!

Not to be missed. The architecture of this house is extraordinary- with the theme carried through every element. The audio guide and self-paced tour is one of the best that we have taken, making the fact that we have little Spanish and no Catalan irrelevant.
Palau Guell. Worth a detour off the Ramblas. A home full of history music and culture. Many rooms to visit including the roof. Fine views

Very good but not essential . I really liked the palace but I would put it on the B list of things to do rather than the essential A list must do. It's not quite as sensational as Casa Batlló for example. A good way to visit would be to pop in as you walk down La Rambla. It's only 12 euros (10% off online) and no need to queue as it's quiet which is great for taking your time to enjoy it. It takes about an hour to go around with the decent audio guide. Highlights include the stables, the main entertaining hall and the roof is simply fantastic.Fascinating to see how the rich Guell family lived and entertained their friends.
Wonderful. Fantastic building - never seen anything like it. This is a far better way to get to experience and understand the work of Gaudi than the Parc Guell.
Interesting . Lovely museum and good to have a little gadget that spoke in your language telling you what everything was. Very interesting and the Gaudi on the roof was an added bonus.
Nice park. Nice park but to get in you need to be there at 9AM or buy a timed ticket in advance. It is an uphill walk from the Metro stations with escalators for the steepest parts.

Amazing attention to detail, work of art. You cannot fail to be in awe of Gaudi's amazing attention to detail, and not just for the infamous chimneys here. Well worth a visit, we pre-booked our tour online which saved a little amount of time queuing but it wasn't too busy when we went.

this is a top ten site. this house is so interesting the house has different levels each level has lot as of interesting rooms plus there is a lift for the not so nimble the roof top is worth the climb goudi lovers will be amazed

Early Gaudi. This is an interesting house as it is one of Gaudi's early ones, but if you have limited time do the others . Timed online tickets are n
best .

Interesting for the architecture. The park can be crowded and it is best to purchase tickets online. They allocate entry in 1/2 hour increments, and buying onsite may mean a 2-4 hour wait for your time window to enter. Worth about 90-120 minutes to have a look around. Great view of the ocean by climbing to the top and looking down towards the city.

great Gaudi early work. This mansion is not in the Gaudi district and it's his first mansion he created for the Guell family. Very different from his later houses. Dark. Not as colorful yet still very unique and interesting. Much less crowded then the other houses. More relaxed to see. Not long lines.
not worth. I got of from the tour bus and it is not worth the time or money. Better see and do other things. It was disappointing.
Interesting stop while wandering Ramblas. The gates outside the palace are amazingly wrought iron pieces and indicate the grandeur of the place. The construction is fascinating and worth a visit.

Fascinating building. If we hadn't been on the Runner Bean Gaudi tour we wouldn't have known this gem was just round the corner from our hotel. It seems we weren't the only ones. There was no queue, no need to book in advance, prices more reasonable than the other Gaudi buildings, and very few people inside so we had the time and space to really look around. Audio guides were good and staff helpful.

Fascinating!. This is a fascinating example of Gaudi's early architecture. It is a family house, most of which is open to visitors. There is a free audio-guide which provides essential background (there are no notices in rooms). We were lucky enough to hear the organ playing. The roof terrace provides interesting views of the city and shows features more usually associated with Gaudi than some of those in the house.

Well worth seeing. We found this fairly early example of Antoni Gaudi's work to be extremely interesting, especially because of its fortress-like exterior, so different from the more whimsical touches of his later, better-known, works. Our guide for the tour was both very informative and spoke excellent English; she definitely added to our understanding and enjoyment of what we saw.

NOw opened. I spotter the mosaics on the roof about 6 years ago from the terrace bar in Raval. THe house was still boarded up. IT is now opened and is the first commission for a residence by Antonio Gaudi. THe design includes stables and was home for a family with 7 children. the interior includes some original furnishings.

Start here or finish here for Gaudi!. This is one of Antoni Gaudi's earliest works commissioned by the Guell family. This is in such an unassuming location as it is essentially a palatial home for what is probably one of the richest families back in the bourgeoise in a street off the tacky La Ramblas. It's 3-4 floors (I lost count) and the interiors so ornate in so many ways that you just wouldn't expect looking from the outside on the very narrow street. There's a lot of stained glass, the ceilings are just original and a beauty to behold. The stables! So cool! The attic room (the curves)! The unmissable rooftop with the colourful chimneys which fans of Gaudi will immediately see similarities to the Sagrada Familia. There are so many aspects here that is signature Gaudi before he evolved even more towards nature that inspired him in the first place. Not to be missed!

Amazing architecture. What a find this was, we saw it from La Rambla and decided to visit. The architecture was outstanding. The audioguide was a must as it added so much information.The place is not huge so did not take overly long to visit.Don't forget to see the wonderful chimneys on the roof.Toilets are on-site, as is a small shop. Lockers are available for a refundable E1 coin
Amazing place. The place is amazing and worth finding. My only and small complaint is that it sometimes was confusing to find the room that coordinated with the taped headset.

Grande mansion by Gaudi. This house feels so different from that of casa batlló in the sense that it is bigger and the ironworks in this mansion is just so impressive. It is another amazing Gaudi creation that you shouldn't miss. The stables, the rooms, the ironworks, artworks, design and all are a feast to the eyes. The chimneys are also so unique. You will be given an audio guide but the area numbers can get a bit confusing.Also try and check out the store...the casa amatller chocolates is priced better than outside.

Whaw!. This building is soaked with the incredibly elaborate ceilings, floors, doors, etc. Even the hinges. How does someone get this finished in his period of life? This is a great tourist attraction. The other buildings were crowded at the entrance, but there was no queue at this building. In case of rain they shut the rooftop, so better visit by sunshine.

A must see for early Gaudi. The visit is well organized with a audio tour. Plan on about an hour for a visit, more if you are a Gaudi fan. The roof is spectacular and you can see a bit of it from the street.

Architectural Delight. Simply breathtaking - hard to believe that 100 years ago such gifted artisans in ceramics, wood, iron etc. etc. could execute the mad designs of Gaudi and produce such a stunning palace. Great value - audio guides and ones specifically for kids available - they are a must.

Loved the Stables. One of the few attractions in Barcelona where we had not booked through the internet in advance. There were no long queues waiting to enter and the visitors inside were quite sparse. Surprising really as this building by Gaudi is one of his fairly early works and is definitely worth a visit. We took the audio tour and enjoyed learning about each room. The tour starts with the startling large entrance doors laced with wrought iron which were originally built to accommodate the carriages. From there a paved ramp leads down to the magnificent stables which are light and airy despite being underground. The vaulted ceiling is supported by mushroom=like columns and little details like the watering vat and the unicorn head for tethering the horses, leaps out at the visitor. Upstairs I was impressed by the central hall of the house with its own private altar and organ where the family held services. These were attended by all members of the household from the balconies on the higher floors where the servants stood. The lady of the house had her own private window next to her bedroom from where she could follow the service. In this building the furniture is still in place and this gives a more intimate feeling on how people lived in the house, than in Casa Batllo. All in all, I strongly recommend to visit and explore Palau Guell. Do not miss the terrace and the private terrace garden.

Amost unbelievale architectural detail. A must for anyone interested in architecture and the works of Gaudi. An outstanding example of how the very upper class of Barcelona lived a century ago. The site exhibits marvelous restoration.

Definite must visit. Pricey (unless you have a pass from your hotel), but this a must see. Features and details of the home are spectacular. Enough said....go see it for yourself! We recommend it strongly. Second Gaudi feature besides the Segrada.

Worth the time. We stumbled upon this place while walking around La Rambla. Had heard about it and decided to go in. It was breathtaking. The free audioguide was informative. There is a lift for 2 floors but if you can't walk up stairs you will miss much of the building.

Outstanding Gaudi experience. Didn't visit the other two commonly named Gaudi residential pieces but this one is the "#%*", as they say. Do NOT miss the basement. Built and designed at the turn of the century without computerized help. Amazing, lush and uniquely Gaudi. Wasn't crowded when we went, which I'm sure helps - audio tour very well done. And included in the price. I suppose it may be best for architecture/Gaudi fans but, really, for anyone with an appreciation of art and structure. Apart from the Familia Sagrada - I would recommend you dont miss this on your architecture tour
Master piece !. Well reserved mansion made by Gaudi with much inspiration.Tickets were available on the spot with audio guide. Even the roof was stunning !!

Overpriced, but a great place to visit. Located just several meters away from the Rambla, this house is somehow the least visited by the tourists, which is its biggest virtue - finally, something in Barcelona that you can see without being surrounded by thousands of people.Said that, the house itself is interesting from the historic perspective and has some very interesting parts, but not as flashy as other Gaudi works. At its price, with totally pointless and annoying audioguide, it's overpriced (but so are nearly all the attractions of Barcelona).

Amazing master piece . Amazing architecture - did the audio tour and it gave pretty good background. Would have wiki gaudi before your visit though. Apparently this is the first master piece, which shows how much talent he has.The chimneys are worth a visit and how the interior was constructed with a purpose is very interesting. The visit is good for around 1 hour.

Visual Overload. This "home" for the Guell family is a must see if you are a fan of Gaudi. To think that he created this in 1890 during the Victorian era shows how ahead of his time he was. Equally amazing is that the Guell family gave him so much freedom of artistic license.I thought it to be way too over the top. A riot of textures and patterns. I could only wish Frank Loyd Wright could have been with me and gotten his take on it.
Something from a curious mind. It was designed bu Gaudi for Guell family. It is so luxurious and strange and worth seeing. It as a suprise for as, and a good one.
Another of Gaudi's buildings. A much lesser known building of the famous architect, great design, nice to explore at a leisurely pace, interesting history of the Guell family, a must visit

Wonderful. Just an amazing building and a must see if you are in Barcelona. We arrived about 10.30 and there wasn't a queue and not too many people inside. You walk round at your own pace with a very good audio guide starting with the stables in the basement and ending on the roof. Each floor was so different and shows the breadth of Gaudi's work. The roof just has to be seen - be aware they close it if it rains. Very good value and much cheaper the La Pedrera. Would most definitely recommend a visit.
A must see!. The Palau Guell is pretty impressive. You'll see cutting edge ideas of that time period. There are so many incredible things to see in the main living room. Don't miss visiting.

A Jewel !. This palace is one of Gaudis less known buildings. The history of the Guell family and the building itself are fascinating. Go for it if you have the time.Seeing no queues we decided to give it a try and we were not disappointed. What a treat indeed.The entrance fee comes to €12 and with guide phones you can stay as long as you wish walking around at your own leisure.With just 12€ entry you get to walk around at your leisure with guide phones so you can stay as long as you like.

A must. Along with Casa Batilo this is another must when in Barcelona. Really amazing tour of an amazingly designed palace that is like no other you will ever see. We just pitched up and had no problem getting tickets and getting in . Worth it.
Must see. Arrived around 11am and no queue! Went straight in and the free audio tour was brilliant! Unfortunately it was a rainy day so we could not go onto the terrace.Space and detail amazing.
One of Gaudi's finest works. One of Gaudi's finest works. a great exhibit behind the mind of a talented designer and architech. A must see! Well worth the fee!

Breathtaking. From basement to rooftop, exploring Palau Guell is a breathtaking experience. The audio tour is well done and they limit the number of people who enter at a time so it was never crowded. Gaudi was an incredible visionary ahead of his time. If you enjoy architecture at all you will enjoy touring this home. I would probably not recommend this one for children.
EXTRAORDINARY. Gaudí the genius, one of his master piece it worths a visit, I liked the design of this building, its ornament. You must pay a visit

Our intro to Gaudi. This was the first Gaudi structure we visited in Barcelona, and it was fascinating to compare it to the park and the Eixample buildings. As a fan of architecture and design, I loved it.

Lovely . What a find. Dropped in by chance. Didn't have it on our 'to do list ' and after visiting wecouldnt work out why. It was about €12 to go in, which is typical National Trust type pricing. And so well worth it. It's big enough to spend lots of time in but small enough to not be overwhelming. A great introduction to Gaudi which will want you coming back for more.

The audio guide was wonderful to have as it explained about the history and the family who once occupied this place.. Bonus points here for the incredibly detailed audio guide- it made the experience a million times better than if I'd simply wandered through at random.This particular spot stands out in Europe as being a gloriously decorated bit of real estate without being either an actual palace or in any fashion religious [barring the chapel inside, of course]. The detail in every room is stunning, even just in the stables below which remain plain stone but whose layout is surprisingly sleek. Even the ironwork on the outside of the building is fascinating- carefully shaped to allow people to look out from within, but to block the view from outside.A part of me wants to detail the trip through the house according to my multitude of photos, but I will leave it to you, the reader, to discover the building on your own. Go! Enjoy the coffered ceilings and gilded woodwork, the wrought iron and stained glass and ivory inlay. The geometry of the domed ceiling in the center of the upper floor is of particular note as are the Christmas-Trees-On-Acid chimneys on the roof, but none of it should be missed, from the impressive pipe organ to the peek inside the tiled bathroom with its delft-like blue and white ceramic commode.
Beautiful palace. A beautiful palace with great audioguide that explains a lot about the architecture and each room and its role in the palace.

Pleasantly Surprised!. We went to Palau Guell because my mother wanted to visit, I'm not big into walking around buildings (tend to get bored quickly), however I was pleasantly surprised when we got to this amazing building. It was really interesting and being able to go onto the roof was spectacular! Can highly recommend

Gaudi. Amazing building first time I visited I went in the afternoon without much planning and had no problem on getting in. Must see. First work of Antoni Gaudi and Mr Guell was the main reason why Gaudi made it to the top.

Interesting to See the Start of Gaudi's Genius. We hadn't planned on going inside, but since it was raining, we decided to take the tour. We enjoyed it. The wood ceilings alone were worth the price of admission -- stunning. Even though this house was more in keeping with the style of the times, Gaudi still showed off his creative genius with the use of light and space.

The best of the Gaudi projects. We were fortunate to be in Barcelona on the first Sunday of the month when the entry is free to Palau Guell. Rest of the time it's $12€, but well worth the cost. Very impressive design with unbelievable finishes.
Audio guide is free of charge and the entire tour will take 1 to 1 1\2 hrs.
Highly recommended.
Barcelona Whirlwind tour. Wow! Another fantastic example of Gaudi's incredible talent. I was very pleased to finally fin this gem and would recommend a visit.

A must visit. Palau Guell is fabulous and awe inspiring round every corner and up every staircase. Goudi's architecture is amazing. There are not enough adjectives to describe the woodwork and tiles and sheer beauty of this house. The chimneys on the roof are beautiful and the restoration work throughout has been done so well. Don't miss a visit here.

Beautiful and a Magical Place. Take the tour. Ours was very informative and made the experience fun. Plan to spend at least two hours. On a clear day, as was ours, you can see all of Barcelona to the sea. There are many ways to get to Park Guell. We chose a taxi. It was about 8 Euros (one way) from our center city hotel. I believe you can take the underground. We could from Sagrada Familia to the center of town.

Great views over Barcelona as well as lots of Gaudi Sights. We walked up to the park from Las Ramblas, stopping for lunch in route. Last bit is very uphill but main entrance makes it worthwhile as breathtaking. The park had ticket booths with small queues but we use walked in. Think you need tickets to get in to the mosaic seating area which has timed entrance, but you can see these from above for free. Tickets are also needed to enter the Gaudi House in the park, but you get a good view of it from the outside.Park is built on hill side but as well as steps there are lots of alternative gentle walkways up slopes, their were musicians playing in various places. There are lots of Gaudi designed walkways with built in benches & flower planters and collanades.
Definitely worth it. This wasn't on our "list" but we got free tickets. It was really a nice surprise. Not like the Casa Batillio in design, but really amazing. Worth it

Of all of Giardi sites to see this is the best!. Palau Guell is such a wonderful work of art by Giardi. We came across this on Sunday when it is free. We got our tickets for 2 pm. When we came out there was a very long line to get tickets. Suggest you go early on Sunday. The beauty and functionality of the residence was very much in sync. The tile and wood work was to breathtaking.
Elegant. One of Gaudi's jobs, smart and very elegant! A good way to spend a few hours interesting place not as known Goudi work but nice to see!

An austere Gaudì. Palau Guell is much more austere than other works of Gaudì. The choice of harder and darker materials, gives the house a more "serious" feeling. The Gaudì themes of nature and dragons are however present in the Palau Guell and the hand of the Maestro is evident. The furnishings of the various rooms, help to take you back to the period when the house was made.

Great experience to learn more about Guadi!. This place is definitely worth visiting. It's a self guided tour, and you get to see amazing wood, iron and stain glass work. It's built very thoughtfully. The highlight is definitely the roof top with the amazing decor. This is definitely worth a visit!

A little palace in the heart of the city. Within close proximity of La Rambla is this little mansion. It's not a very long visit which is reflected in the comparatively inexpensive price compared with other Barcelona attractions. Highlights included the rooftop chimneys in mosaic, the organ, and the formal dining hall. Worth a look if you got a spare hour!
Interesting. I would go in. it is worth it, just to start getting accuanited with Guadi and his kind of work. Very interesting

Not the Gaudi you'd expect. It's not the crazy Gaudi you seen in his other homes (e.g. Casa Batlló), but it is interesting nonetheless in its design. Dark, sober and stately home for a wealthy client.
Gaudi's First Project!!. Interesting to see Gaudi start to develop a style of construction in the beginning of his career that would later turn into the famous buildings we know, worth the visit

Unusual and fascinating. Another must see when in Barcelona. You go up to the roof in a lift. Don't go if it is pouring with rain because they may not let you onto the roof and you really must go on the roof. We enjoyed looking around the apartment below the rood also. Quite expensive but worth it especially if you are a Gaudi fan.

Amazing. Stayed in Barcelona and found this park at the end of our holiday. Wow what an amazing place. So lovely we rebooked for 2016 and this is a definate place to visit. Interesting fun cheap excellent and a must.

Gaudi's first residential design. Whilst quite different from his later works this is a marvel of carpentry and iron work. Stunning designs, features and inlaid floors. Again the typical roof area and mosaic chimmneys well worth a visit. Good value in comparison to other properties.

An (almost) hidden gem. Wow oh wow! I've been coming to Barcelona for a very long time. I thought I'd seen all the Gaudi sites when by chance I happened upon an article about the Palau Guell. It's wonderful! It is worth viewing as art in its own right, but also as it is the first work Gaudi undertook for the Guell family. Just about everything else that Gaudi went on to do, you can trace back to this Palau. I don't know why it isn't heralded more loudly on the tourist route but all lovers of Batcelona 'modernismo' and Gaudi in particular, should take time to visit the Palau Guel. The commentary on the headphones is very helpful.

Worth a visit,. This is a lesser known Gaudi building but still well worth a visit. It is council owned whereas the others are privately owned. Only mentioned as it was closed on Monday. However, the self guided tour is excellent, very informative and also included old photos of the building on the handset.

Visit late afternoon/early evening for a quieter experience. I visited at around 6pm and there weren't too many people there. An amazing building and incredibly opulent inside - make sure to appreciate the private organ and orchestra pit. The audio is very interesting and I loved to rooftop and all the chimneys.

A lovely Palace. Head to the roof for the wonderfully decorated chimney pots and poke your head into the loo upstairs for the most ornate loo I have seen in a long while. Managed to avoid the crowds so a serene visit.

A star attraction. . Whilst this doesn't get the same publicity, the Palace is well with a visit. You get an audio guide (free of charge) and the access to the areas is fairly unrestricted. Some great history and of course lots of Gaudi designs. A very interesting story about how the other half lived. It's been very well restored and is well worth the entrance fee of €24 for 2.

One of Gaudi's first . Visitors to Palau Guell are in for a visit that feels intimate. Be sure to use an audio guide, as it will expand your experience and deepen your understanding of the home and Gaudi.

Surprising find. Beautiful house, much less crowded than the other Gaudi sights but just as impressive. Cheaper entry too. Audio guide was informative and tour was longer than expected! This was a "palace" designed by Gaudi for the Guell family. It's a huge house with a stable in the basement, an impressive hall with tall organ pipes in the centre, numerous rooms for various purposes, and a remarkable roof with beautiful views of the city. Thoroughly enjoyed this sight.

Early Gaudi creation - the shape of things to come. Gaudi was commissioned as a young architect to create this house for the Guell family and while the results weren't as advanced as some of his later work, some of his tendencies and preferred materials are clearly on display. Like all Gaudi works it was quite crowded even though it was only early April, so arriving earlier than we did is probably to be advised
At last opended to the public. Very interesing palace to visit. Early Gaudi design. Should be seen before Casa Batilo and Casa Mila.
Gaudi, what else?. Another amazing Gaudi creation. Although somewhat gloomy, it has some wonderful construction techniques and design, as well as wood ceilings with intricate pattersns.

Early Gaudi. This building illustrates Gaudi's early ideas and is a magnificent example of a "palace" located inside a small building. If you are interested in learning more about Gaudi's architecture, don't miss it. The audio guide was most helpful.

Worth a Visit. Right off Las Ramblas, this private home of Eusebio Guell (Gaudi's benefactor) and constructed by Gaudi is well worth a visit. Visit it before going to see other of Gaudi's works as it is one of his early ones. When you visit Casa Milia (La Pedrera) or Casa Batllo, you will be able to better appreciate Gaudi's design evolution.

Wahoo Gaudi!. A great way to experience Gaudi. Because he designed this palace as a living space for his close friend and family, there is a personalization to the space and art that is a true treat. Not overly crowded when we went, on maybe a Tuesday morning. I enjoyed the audio guide on this tour immensely, it was well organized and interesting. Definitely walk towards the park (away from the Ramblas) after wards, there are some nice little cafes in that direction.

Amazing!. It's truly an art in nature. Definitely worth a trip to visit and appreciate our mother nature through the art form. One of a kind, as Gaudi has inspired us all and will continue to do so, along with his work.
Brilliant. You cant or should't visit Barcelona without immersing yourself somewhat in the Gaudi experience, this is just a hint of his brilliance in city full of it

Unexpected. Having visited the other main tourist attractions over the last few years I thought this would be more of the same.However, the quality was amazing, and the guide you use to describe each room really made the visit.Highly recommend.
True Grandeur. It is hard to imagine a family living here, the grandeur was incredible. Gaudy is truly a creative genius.
Worth a visit. If you pass it from the outside you won't even realise this is a palace, until you get in there and see it for yourself. It is beautifully made right till the roof. Go see it

Beautiful!. This was our first introduction to Gaudi and we were sooo impressed with all the beautiful details throughout the six floor mansion. A free audioguide really enhanced the experiemce, as did the excellent staff. We enjoyed our glimpse into what life was like for the wealthy during Gaudi's time and came away with some great photos. Buy your tickets a few doors down to the left. Entry is timed, but we got right in on a Saturday morning. There's a small lift (ask someone in a red coat for assistance) for those unable to climb all the stairs. Many of the rooms are unfurnished, but there's still enough beautiful furniture to see what it looked like at one time. On the rooftop are the fanciful mosaic chimneys and some nice views of Barcelona (several steps, no elevator to it). I'm so glad we didn't miss this.

Well worth seeking out. Another Gaudi masterpiece and well worth a visit. Situated just off La Ramblas the building is an architectural gem. Entrance is by a timed ticket but we didn't have to wait too long to gain admission, which includes in the price a very thorough audio guide detailing the history of the building and the personalities involved. The view from the roof is very nice too! Well worth a visit.
The unknown Gaudi. Easy to miss but worth the look. Some hotels do have "free coupons" for admission. A worth while visit
Gaudi's first work. It is Gaudi's first work and one can see Gaudi's formation especially the roof. It is a must see for any one who likes Gaudi's works.
A first impression of Gaudi. This building was designed by Gaudi for the Guell family. It's nice for a quick visit to have an impression of Gaudi.
Gaudi. Palau Guell is kind of hidden, you can find it in the middle of Ramblas, two streets behind the theatre/opera building.Beautiful rooftop!
Palau Guell. This house is neat but doesn't stand up to Gaudi's "Dragon House". It is an amazing site but not as different as some of his other works.

Finally. After numerous attempts on many visits to Barcelona, we finally were able to visit Palau Guell. May not be as ornate as Casa Mila/Battlo but very informative on the house design needs of the Guell family which are his benefactors in a way. The detail in the design are genius.

Cool place. Gaudi's works are so interesting, and since this was one of the earlier ones you can see how he progressed. The roof structures and the basement are especially visually stunning. That being said, if your time is limited, Casa Batllo, Sagrada Familia, and Parc Guell are all more unique and captivating.

Surprising attraction which must be seen internally to be appreciated. We were initially disappointed we had to purchase tickets and wait for the admission time. BUT we now understand why, this is a town house packed with architectural features and the viewing experience would have been greatly diminished if it was crowded. Wonderful innovative designs throughout although not to my personal taste it is well worth seeing. The roof terrace is a must with the decorative chimney stacks and the cellar/stables are also of note

What a wonderful surprise. On our second trip to Barcelona we didn't feel the need to revisit Gaudi's main works but found this treasure close to Las Ramblas. An original palace, owned by the Guell family, is floor after floor of architectural structures by a range of architects, including Gaudi, all of which have been lovingly restored, from the stables in the basement to the chimney pots. We were lucky enough to see an exhibition of art nouveau furniture too. If you don't have much time this is the place to get a feel of the intensity and diversity of Spanish architecture. We went at opening time and by the time we were leaving there were queues for buying tickets and then for entry. Cameras are allowed without flash. There are lots of stairs but a supervised lift is available..except for the roof level.

Beautiful . We went around the gardens (free)
Beautiful gardens and views
We walked up from the hospital area and walk was worth it
We didn't realise you had to pay for part of the park ........ When we enquires there were no tickets available until 5 hours later which was disappointing
But the rest was beautiful

Up on the roof. Brilliant architecture and design again and again! from the basement, through outstanding rooms all designed by Gaudi and with a piece by William Morriss, when you finally reach the roof you are rewarded with great views and the most spectacular chimneys.

Fascinating. A truly beautiful building. The audio guide was really helpful. I would certainly recommend it, the interior is stunning and the roof with its colourful chimneys is wonderful. I am so glad I visited and would recommend other too.
Stunning............. This is a real must when in Barca! I have been there many times and never visited this place. I now plan to go each time I am there - it is sooooooooooooo amazing!

Amazing gem. . ... We have seen most of Gaudi's work throughout Spain as well as Barcelona and this is the last place we had not visited. .. .if you love Gaudi you have to come here as this was one of the most notable first places that he worked on as a young adult.. . .you truly appreciate his genius as even at such an early age you see his talent and amazing ability to take the natural world order and make it into an architectural wonder. . . .this isnt on many people's list of must see in Barcelona but you would be doing yourself an injustice if you love Gaudi or can appreciate any master in any art form. . . ..as this is the work of a precocious genius. . .. genius as a youth(he was around 26 when he worked on this)!Come here to see the genius as a youth . .. . .

Great afternoon visit for free. Got in free as it was the first Sunday of the month. Had to queue for about thirty minutes for a ticket which allowed us entry an hour later. The audio guide was a bit dull and also kept referring to images which if we looked at meant we missed the audio. Still the house was well worth the visit, especially the roof with the classic chimney pots. Great!

Put your walking shoes on!. Escalators take you to the park entrance as it is high up, quiet a few steps too. Lovely views and peaceful walks. there is a refreshment area which sells baguettes, drinks and ice creams. Lots of people selling things as you walk around, fridge magnets, water, jewellery etc. Not too suitable for wheelchairs/pushchairs, but they would manage.
The beginning of the genius. Hidden in the Rambla, I showed the style of Gaudi at the beginnings not yet accomplished, yet a bit gothic but still absolutely unique.
Absolutely stunning!. Entry is £12 standard, great price for the experience! We were given a free audio guide in our chosen language included in the price which made our visit more informative.

Can't wait to return. Whilst planning my next visit to the incredible city of Barcelona ,I have been reflecting on this amazing building .It was definitely the highlight of my last trip 1o months ago and will definitely be on my list to revisit later this year .Dont miss it !

Architecture hounds abound. We were staying just off Las Ramblas and saw this building on one of our walks of the neighborhood. The Gates are amazing. The stairs, the wood, all are fantastic. It is not open all the time, so plan ahead.
Wow. Amazing place well worth a visit. The ceilings are amazing. The audio was very informative we went later in the day and had plenty of room to wander.

Very intersting. Visited for approx 2 hours and it was very interesting and the audio tour was very good. Inexpensive about 12 euro entry fee and worth it for a morning. Don't miss it if visiting Barcelona. Very good insight of how the other half lived.

Beautiful building, a great piece of history. Unlike other Gaudi buildings in the city, this palace does not look much on the outside, but on the inside it is a work of art. The wealth and prestige of the initial owner can be seen at every corner, with marvelous and expensive materials and shapes. The roof can also be visited, there are free audio guides, and the price of 12 EUR was totally worth it. A must see in Barcelona.

Gaudi's domestic masterpiece. The rooftop & chimneys will be familiar to anyone who has ever read a book or article on Gaudi. These are only open to visitors in good weather and it is the floors below that are most interesting. Gaudi's influences from late 19c France & England can be seen evolving with local craftsmanship & vernacular to make something unique. The audio tour is thorough & well-paced. Get the photographic cliches done then explore the relationships in the spaces while avoiding tripping over the visitor selfie-sticks, those little wands of narcissism :)Concerts are now held featuring the newly built replacement pipe organ. This building has now been given new life after being rejected by the wife of the commissioning patron Eusebi Guell

Be enthralled. My wife and I went to this place by chance on the penultimate day of our visit to Barcelona when we saw a queue outside this glorious palace. It is simply , magnificent and demonstrates the art and genius of Antoni Gaudi's. The audio guide is up there with the best we have experienced in many countries. We ended up spending more than two hours there. Thank you, Gaudi, for this very precious legacy you have left for Barcelona.

Not all Gaudi buildings are alike. Casa Batlo and La Pedrera are much more similar to each other than either is to Palau Guell. It has a much different feel but still exhibits the integrated style of Gaudi. It's quite near the metro and only steps off the Ramblas, so it's easy to visit. We got our tickets on line in advance and saved the wait. The audioguide is worth listening to.

Interesting architecture. One of Gaudi's earlier buildings. Many interesting features, it gives the impression of being rather dark and massive, an almost mediaeval feel about it - till you get out on to the roof and see the fantastic colourful chimneys!

Impressive!. We visited here on day one and really enjoyed it. We booked online but arrived early but they let us straight in. You are given an audio machine and head phones and then you click which room you are in and it tells you all about the room and the history! The top is the best part ... its a great building and truly beautiful.

Alice in wonderland?. Guell & Gaudi had utopian vision, which with today's technology would not be easily constructed. The details and nature inspired solutions are simply ingenious. Consider this was done 100 years ago, and it really makes you feel like Alice
Another example of Gaudi's inventiveness.. Worth seeing as part of a larger city tour. There is a great deal of walking and stair climbing in order to see the entire site.

Don't miss Palau Guell. This early example of Gaudi architecture has been beautifully restored and shows some of his origins as an artist. The roof alone is worth the price of admission, but the entire house is beautiful.

What a pleasant surprise! . I just stumbled into this place when I was walking around and I'm so happy I did enter! It is not cheap (12eur/person) but it is beautiful! So different yet so perfectly executed. With your ticket you get an audioguide which explains all the rooms. The tour takes 45min.
Amazing house by Gaudi. This house has to be seen by Gaudi fans. Each level has such a different vibe to it although with all the stone & tile, it must have been a cold place to live

castle in the city. these days are telling me that my favorite person in the architecture will be gaudi. that is sure by now. this piece is also a unique builing with unbelievable decoration on the top. however the outside seems like a gothic castle with several iron snake, the top is a fantasy world.
Great. An extraordinarily complete example of Gaudi's work, it allows appreciation of the depth of his thinking and intricacy of his planning. Pause and let the tour groups rush past and just look!
Wicked. A fun little stop full of brilliant architecture. Don't miss it- it really is beautiful and awe inspiring.

Another Fun Architectural Highlight. There are so many architectural wonders to see in Barcelona, and Palau Guell ranks up there amongst things to see. This home is not as distinctive as Casa Mila or Batllo, but worth seeing as an earlier work of Gaudi. Keep looking up. The coffered ceilings are a highlight. The central concert hall is marvelous and a restored organ has been added. From the basement stables to the roof deck, worth a visit.

One of Gaudi's first houses in Barcelona. Quite different.. Strongly recommended. Gothic extravaganza - lots of straight lines and angle quite unlike most of Gaudi's better know works. Fabulous architectural details and use of light. The cellars were used by Franco's rebels to torture republican soldiers and supporters. Just off Las rambles on right towards the Columbus column.

Impressive but not as crazy and colorfull as the houses. Good part : it's affordable ( 12euros with a free audioguide) compared to the houses ( perdrera y baltio) that cost 22euros.It's got the emblematic chimneys, and this crazy craaazzyy reception room.it's worth seeing, even if somehow it felt less crazy and colorfull than the houses.Great view of barcelone from the rooftop !

A beautiful place to visit. Nearly missed this even though it was across the road from our hotel.
It is wonderful and if on a limited time visit to the city you must include this house.
Absolutely stunning.

To me maybe one of the best of Gaudi's mansions. close to the rambla tucked between regular buildings it is a pearl easily mised if you just walk by. The house is greatly designed with impressive cellar and amazing roof' and decorated halls. The first choice of Gaudi's work.

Very interesting but not art nouveau as you'd "expect" it. The so-called palace is on a surprisingly small footprint. It is a lovely REALLY early example of his work, and has many featurs that you'd be surprised to associate with the architect. Nothing wrong with that at all, as long as it is expected. The gates, stables etc and soaring ceiling are well worth seeing. The oddities are the small size of the rooms and the outlook over the rear, which appear to be laundry rooms for assorted small apartments.

Gaudi does a mediaeval castle. The audio-guide is included in the ticket but the numbers of the rooms could be a bit more obvious - had to retrace my steps several times! It is a grand and ostentatious house, strangely dark, and I get why the client's family didn't like it, but you must see it.
Beautiful mansion, worth visit. We visited Palau Guell on a Sunday afternoon. Admission to inside is 12E. The roof top chimenies are spectacular. It was not crowded at all.
Loved it!. Beautiful home and a fascinating peek into the lives of the rich and influential of Barcelona. We liked it at least as much as the much more famous Casa Mila (aka La Pedrera).

Another Gaudi Masterpiece. Palau Guell is a mansion designed by Gaudi which is located about a block off of Les Rambles on Carrer Nou de la Rambla.Great site to visit on a rainy day or any day, really. If you like Gaudi's style, you will be inspired by Palau Guell.

Long live GaudÍ!. Barcelona is full of Gaudí – but, for me, this was the best place to see how extraordinary he was. If you want to see how his architecture affected “normal living” (in quotation marks because this house belonged to a millionaire!), this is a place to go to. Wonderful innovative ideas e.g. with regard to light and climate control - a hundred years ago! Make sure to go to the roof and see the chimneys. Ver good (free) audio-guide.

Love the Art. If you are curious about Guidi's art forms this is a great place to visit. The area is alittle sketchy, and the Palace is a little hard to find, but it was well worth it once we found it. It is just off Las Ramblas about 3 blocks.

"A must visit.....". A stunning example of Gaudi's early work. The palace was the Guell Lopez family home. It has a real neo-Gothic style to the architecture. A great view from the roof top and a good audio guide. It is just off Les Ramble.
Palau Guell, Barcelona. Excellent audio guide to go with tour of early Gaudi house. Well worth a visit, especially as a contrast to later Art Nouveau Gaudi.
Gaudi's first piece of work. This was Gaudi's first commissioned piece of work, and was for the Guell family. A very impressive building showcasing the family patrimony. Spend 30 mins here
my favorite Gaudi. this was a magical space of function and light ,,and we were so happy that we took the tour . go to the roof !

Almost missed it, glad we didn't. Our guide recommended that my friend and I visit the Palau Guell when she realized how much we had enjoyed seeing Gaudi's other sites, and we found this to be as amazing in its own way as the Casa Batllo, La Pedrera, Parc Guell, the Colonia Guell, and of course La Sagrada Familia. (We missed Casa Vincens and Casa Calvet, as well as El Drac at Finca Guell, but we'll have something to see next time!) The audio tour and signage is as excellent as it is Casa Batllo, and one gets a deeper understanding of how Gaudi solved such practical problems as the noise of horses hooves disturbing visitors and inhabitants of the house, or how a worship area could be incorporated into living space, in beautiful and functional manners. If you enjoy Gaudi's work, grand homes, or interesting and unusual architecture, you should put this place on your to-see list.

Don't skip this if you appreciate Gaudí. Visited the palace for the first time and loved it. Not as fancy as Casa Batllo or La Pedrera but a great exemple of Gaudi's work in a totally different more sober and darker style. Visited on a saturday and there was hardly anyone there. No line, no ticket reservation necessary. How different from the other Gaudi buildings! Entrance price is way more reasonable too. I would recommend everyone to visit and maybe skip one of Gaudi's other houses. Don't forget to visit the roof!

Great insight into the genius of Gaudi. Even if you're not that interested in Gaudi and architecture you can't help but be fascinated by the genius of this man. It's amazing what he could pack into a pack into a "small" building that looks relatively ordinary from the outside. From the inside, though, it is anything but ordinary. Looking up towards the ceiling towards the ceiling from the central hall is a "wow-moment" and the moment you step out on the roof of the building and see the colors of the chimneys and the sloping "floors" you really see the genius of Gaudi. This was no ordinary man and this is no ordinary house. We visited in the middle of March and had to queue for a few minutes before being allowed inside. The tour did not feel crowded and the audio guide was very useful in pointing out the various features of the house and telling the story behind it. You should not miss this UNESCO World Heritage Site if you visit Barcelona.
Another must!. Very interesting for history lovers, for architecture lovers, for every visitor to Barcelona. I recommend a guide in order to hear the inside stories.

Practical Gaudi. If you like Barcelona, if you like Gaudi and his work, his ideas and they way he was expressing himself, this is a must while you visiting Barcelona. This was a private house and you will see many practical and the same time beautiful solution for a city house, Some of the ideas would work even today.

Beautiful palatial building. This is one of Gaudi's first buildings and a family home. Packed full of amazing architectural details and indications of how it operated as a family home at the turn of the century.
Gaudi's masterpiece. Not as impressive as Sagrada Familia, but it shows the creative development of Antonio Gaudi as an architect. An hour is more than enough for a visit.

Fascinating!. This was one of those "accidental" stops. We were on a very short notice visit to Barcelona with no "research time" and were exploring the Gothic Quarter after a visit to the Sagrada Familia and saw this on the map and wandered over for a visit. Spent a couple of hours here and felt it was worth the time and money (12 Euro each).

A true representation of Gaudi's genius. This "family home" which Gaudi designed and built for his friend and main patron Eusebio Guell. Their collaboration is evident in every inch of the building from the design of the windows to the location of the horse stables - yes horse stables in the middle of the city! If you like arquitecture you have to see this palace.- Plan on taking a half day to see the palace as there is plenty to see- Do get the audio tour headsets - There is an interesting history behind everything in this place and the audio tour - which is very well put together - will help you get the most out of the visit.

Nice surprise. As a Barcelona citizen, I had not been at Palau Guell before, and it was a nice surprise. They offer a good guide (although I usually don't like these, this one was fine) which makes the visit interesting, specially in the last part where they explain Gaudi's story together with Guell's.

Must-see early work of Gaudi. The Palau Güell is an early work of Gaudi where he designed and built a city home for an extremely wealthy family (Güell). Here he started to experiment which finally became his style which cumulated IMHO in the Casa Battlo (another must-see) and of course the Sagrada Familia. It's a a very fascinating, but somehow quite gloomy athmosphere in this house (in contrast to the Casa Battlowhich is so refreshing and lightfull)

Worth visiting!!!. It is worth visiting so as to see a characteristic sample of Gaudi's work. Very well organised, with the aid tools for the tour and the small amount of visitors per hour. You should definitely book your tickets online so as to avoid any possible problems. The rooms are very well preserved and you get an idea of the life back then... We got a little bit disappointed by the roof view as we had read that you can see all the city from up there, which is not like that, anyway the works on the roof are amazing...
Beautiful rooftops. Unique building - similar attraction to Casa Batlo and La Padrera.The price is around ~ 15€.Very beautiful rooftop views. Recommended for history & art lovers.

Go after 6pm in Summers and you can see it for free. Quite exotic, the entry money can be saved if you go after 6pm on weekdays. Filled with tourists, it is wise to buy the ticket online in case you decide to go on a weekday or weekend before 6pm.

Amazing!. Loved this place...just fascinating!A must see on a trip to Barcelona. We spent several hours here and we were enthralled. The history is amazing and the restoration job has been painstakingly achieved to a very high standard by talented tradesmen.

Impressive. I remember coming here some years ago and this being free. However, it is worth paying to visit.Another fine example of Gaudi's work. Tickets are timed by 30 minute intervals, and during peak times the ticket queue can be busy. They are also limited to 400 per 30 minute interval, so you may have to wait approx 1 hour if you queue normally.If you get an opportunity, it is worth buying online prior to the visit.

Less famous but more central important early Gaudi work tied to the history of Barcelona. From the outside it's obvious that this isn't a normal palace, the ornate ironwork and smooth exterior surfaces try to prepare you for what is inside and boy is it a joy!This is one of the Gaudi buildings built for just one family not like 3 of the other houses he built in Barcelona (excluding casa vicens and torre bellesguard which for now are not wholly and easily accessible) The interior here really shows off the wealth of the Guell family from the materials used and quality of the craftmanship. We also get to see some furniture in a separate exhibition. The rooftop is a delight and shows the beginnings of use of trencandis for the chimneys later repeated in casa batlo and casa mila. Location just off the famous las ramblas and being less well known means less tourists here and a great way of saving time yet managing to see some decent Gaudi work right in the old quarter of the city.

Another brilliant Gaudi masterpiece. If you like the other Gaudi houses, you'll love this one. It may not be as colourful as some, but there are loads of interesting aspects and lots to see over several floors.

Fascinating insight into Barcelona's opulent past. This place is fascinating and the audio tour just keeps throwing great nuggets at you. We went at about 3.30 and it wasn't crowded. It's mind-boggling.

Beautiful!. I don't know that I would rate this a must-see over La Sagrada Familia or the Catedral de Barcelona, however, it is beautiful in it's own right. Love the rooftop terrace with the mosaic detailing. Once a day they offer free guided tours with your entrance ticket, but you must select it when booking your tickets online. Totally worth it!! Small group, lots of great info you wouldn't know otherwise by just passing through on your own.

Well worth the visit. The mansion provides interesting insight into more "traditional" Gaudi work and a fine example of how a super-wealthy Barcelona family lived at the end of the 19th century. An amazing space and exploring it with the audioguide was fun for the whole family. We visited on a rainy day, so the roof and terraces were closed, which was a shame.

Wonderful. This attraction is wonderful, like nothing you've seen before. The attention to detail is amazing and the history and information provided is excellent.Probably my favourite attraction in Barcelona.

One of Gaudi's earlier projects. We took a tour of this building and would recommend seeing it before visiting Gaudi's more famous projects as is gives you a good idea of his concepts but the architecture is not so bold.

A Highlight of Barcelona. Despite Rick Steve's comments about Palau Guell (he perfers La Pedrera) we visit the house an enjoyed it immensely. We liked it betteer than La Pedrera although they are quite different even if they were both designed by Gaudi. This private dwelling is unbelievable. It has marble columns everywhere, carved wood, elaborate coffered ceilings. a chapel with a 2300 pipe organ. the rooftop has the characteristic fancy Gaudi chimneys. This was one of the most impressive houses (palaces) we have ever see. We highly recommend Palau Guell.
another glorious Gaudi building. These buildings are so stunning and it is great that you can explore them at your own pace and revisit rooms due to the very descriptive and informative audio guides

Great. Very busy, but loved all the bright colours used (especially on a winter's day in January), and the anticipation of not knowing what you were going to see next. Glad we prebooked this visit as the queues were long, but seem to be moving quite quickly.

Worth queuing to go into. Queue moves faster than you expect. Full of Catalonian Gaudiesque surprises. Commentary was good. Free on first Sunday of the month so a bonus as we happened to be here. Roof top experience is surreal. But I guess that's what it's all about. Combined with the Guell parc a great experience.

Mesmerized. My husband and I were absolutely mesmerized by this wonderful house. Living in a piece of art must have been an amazing feeling once. Palau Guell is definitely one of my favourite places not just in Barcelona but in all the places I have seen in Spain so far.

Spectacular example of Gaudi . Gaudi received a commission for a townhouse from a very wealthy family and this building reflects the finest materials, craftsmanship and design. A little hard to imagine living there in winter with very small fireplaces for heat, but it is Gaudi at his best.

Beautiful home. I've become a huge fan of Gaudi since visiting Barcelona. Palau Guell is very beautiful and the free audio guide is very informative. It even shows pictures of how the palace was decorated when the Guells lived there. The rooftop offers great views as well.

Palau Guell less crowded than Casa Mila. Palau Guell is tucked away in a side street off La Rambla. It is one of Gaudi's first major commissions and definitely worth the visit. We had only a 15-minute wait to get inside (visited on weekday, mid-morning). The fascinating home tour is self-guided with an audio guide. From the cellar (impressive stables) to the rooftop with the whimsical Gaudi ceramic-tile chimneys, the house is filled with amazing architectural elements, art and furniture. Allocate 1-1/2 hours for the visit. You will not be disappointed.

As impressive as his other works !. We had visited all of Gaudi's masterpieces except this one which is less celebrated than the others ! We were expecting something a bit more conservative since this is one of his first creations but were we surprised !!!! Palau Guell is as impressive as his other masterpieces and as wonderful to discover ! It is expensive but well worth the price ! I will let you discover it on your own ! ( the audio guide is a must )

An early masterpiece by Gaudí. One of the great houses built by Gaudí. Located very near the Rambla, in Barcelona's old quarter. Clearly the work of a genius. You can visit most of the place. Very good audioguides. I recommend purchasing the tickets through the web site, to avoid queues. Not cheap (as most things at Barcelona). Definitely a must visit.

Palau Guell. This building is a good proof of Gaudi's talent as he combined classical and modernist forms (the iron work is terrific). And that would warrant a 5-star review if not for the idiotic ice cream cones on the roof.

Super interesting. A look back to an upper class residence from almost 100 years ago, adding in that it was designed by a famous son of Barcelona. Lots of nice little design features and artistic and space saving features.

Another Example of Gaudi's Genius. This early example of Gaudi's genius is a real treasure. Probably one of the most interesting places we've visited and certainly a highlight of our month in Barcelona. Beautiful, quirky, fascinating, and totally strange, this house represents both the essence of the turn-of-the-century Modernism movement, as well as a complete reimagining of its precepts, to glorious effect. The Palau Guell is definitely a must-see when visiting Barcelona, and it's conveniently located in El Raval just off the tourist-clogged Ramblas.

Completely restored and not to be missed. Excellent restoration of this mansion just off Las Ramblas. We went early in the morning as our hotel was only about three minutes away so it wasn't terribly crowded. Terrific wrought iron work.

Fascinating living house. Excellent object just near to Ramblas. Just enjoy the spaces with different height, notice the use of darkness and daylight inside, the whole haus is a big play of Gaudi. Don´´t forget the upper floors, cellar for horses and the terarace.

Great palace. Inaugurated for the 1888 exhibition, this palace is one of the first buildings designed by Gaudi. It reminds me on a Venetian palace with its notable oval portals which allowed an access to the stables with a carriage. The interior of the building is amazing, intimate and grandiose at the same time. There are some astonishing wrought-iron works as well as those made by wood, ceramic, stone or stained glass.
fascinating Gaudi architecture. This palace is one of Gaudis less known buidlings The history of the Guell family and the building itself are fascinating. Worth a visit if you have enough time.

A must-see in Barcelona. We stumbled upon the palace by chance (even though read about it in a guidebook), and since there were no queues (surprise, surprise!), decided to take a look inside. We were not disappointed, and spent the next hour enjoying Gaudi's architectural genius in an intimate setting of Palau Guell. A definite must-see in Barcelona!

Super cool design. We added our Palau Guell visit on a whim, and it turned out to be one of our favorite sights! If you have to choose between Palau of Parc Guell, I'd recommend this one, absolutely. It's easier to get to, more organized, and way less crowded and hectic. The audio guide is super informative.
Amazing . Another jewel of architecture father, big tall building with breathtaking aesthetics, the terrace will be unforgettable.

A must visit in Barcelona for anyone with a taste of the unusual or love of art. One of Gaudi's masterworks designed as a town mansion for a local businessman in the 1880's.A delight from the moment you enter the front door to the chimneys on the roof.Despite knowing some of the history and having seen many pictures of the palace the reality was still a surprise and delight. The old and the new, the light and the dark, the expected and the unusual all integrated in one building.

New venue . This is a building was not known to us and only stumbled on it as it was opposite our hotelWhat a treat at only 12€ entry you get to walk around at your leisure with guide phones so you can stay as long as you like.The building and it's contents are well explained through the headsets with plenty of detail photos from the past tooWell worth a visit

Palau - Guell = home for Barcelona. We caught the last time frame for visits on an evening (max. 7 p.m.) and most certainly enjoyed it. Palau Guell is worth for all the wonderful details in which you will recognize Gaudi as seen in the art albums. Pick up the guided tour unless you want to miss all the stories behind the furniture, rooms design and cheeky life in the palace.
