Your experience will resemble much to the feel of visiting someone's home. The spaces are pretty intimate and allow you to imagine living there yourself. The special treat consists in the rooftop which you will not have enough of!

Important attraction for Gaudi's and architecture fans. This is one of Gaudi’s earliest works and it was very interesting to visit so we could compare with the architectural style of Casa Batllo and La Sagrada Familia. This is certainly less popular than the others; we didn’t even have to buy tickets in advance (highly advisable with the other two) – just stood in line for 10 mi or less, considering it was July, a very busy season, it was real quick. The style used in this house seems to be a bit more austere and dark; the Guells were definitely wealthy people: the quantity of rooms, expensive materials, and the details! These guys had a mini chapel in their main living room, for God’s sake! Make sure you get the audio guide at the reception – it is free and very useful, it makes the visit much more meaningful. The dome you can see from the main hall is wonderful, you just stare in awe! Although I liked Casa Batllo over this – much more airy and brighter, with a somewhat more nature-like, organic style - if you are interested in architecture and Gaudi’s work, Palau Guell is definitely a must. The rooftop with the iconic chimneys is certainly an indication of the kind of style Gaudi was going to master later on. I almost missed the basement – it used to be the stable, but still, there was a lot of attention given to details here.

Lesser-known Gaudi Building. This is an early work by Gaudi. It seems more influenced by traditional Spanish architecture than his later houses, but it still has lovely quirkiness. The tour is individual, with headphones. For those interested in Gaudi & the Guells, there is lots of information.

Worth going in!. It is actually a pretty spacious building with lots of character. Very close to las rambla sector so plan your trip before touring the rambla area. Very interesting structural layout. Do go inside the basement area as it is great to see huge columns that supports the palace. Highlight of the building was the rooftop. Has a lot of stairs so be ready to walk a lot inside the building.
Palau Gaudi. Such an incredible examples of Gaudi's genius. The audio guide was an excellent way to enjoy the experience.
Visit this place now!. I can't belive the beauty of everything Gaudi did! This place is once again an amazing master piece! For sure a most visit in Barcelona!
Understated but lovely. Palau Guell is definitely worth a visit if you have the time, but I wouldn't consider it to be a Must See spot.

Wonderful architcture. Excellent visit - one of Gaudí's first works and lesser known, but well worth a visit. Book your time slot in advance - we paid 12€ each for a visit complete with audio guide. Excellent value!

Interesting site to visit. Gaudi was a really interesting architect; it is important to dedicate some hours to go through the various works like this one. The way in which he worked with the wood is really amazing.

Pretty cool. It was raining the day we went, and entry was a mob scene. Understandably, the roof was closed. Even still, it was certainly worth the visit, but if I had to chose between this and Casa Battlo, I'd choose the latter. If you have time to do both, do- they are really different. This is furnished which gives a different perspective. The furniture reminded me of my grandmother's which was a little distractive.

Could skip this spot if you don't have time. Though it's a stunning building, I felt Gaudi's design was limited. Only showed strongly above the roof.Moreover, not many furniture was displayed and even no animations like Casa batllo, only described with old pictures.There's no audio guides in mandarin.

Interesting Gaudi design. We almost walked right by it - it is not very bold or colorful from the outside. The audio tour that came with the entry fee was hard to navigate, long, and a little boring, especially near the end. That said, the building is still super cool to see, and the roof is the highlight, by far.
The best of the Gaudi Houses . If you are going to do s little Goudi tour - this house is not to be missed. Simply remarkable and the free audio tour is concise and helpful.

A must. Didnt expect much before entering but was fully impressed. you get to see how luxurious the house is, the genius Gaudi once again wowed me. by the way, i talked to three staffs, they were all really friendly. oh it is free on sunday afternoon.
Impressive Gaudi work. Amazing architecture. The visit is not too long and the audio guide makes it very interesting. The chimneys on the rooftop are really cool.
Gaudi delight. Your entry fee includes an audio tour, which is very helpful. The architecture is amazing. Be sure to see the chimneys on the roof.

Very very good (and even better on a Sunday afternoon). ...I say this as free on Sunday afternoon (you still need to get a ticket which will probably be for an entrance 45mins to 1hr later).From the outside it looks very unassuming but inside the detail is amazing. It is as much the attention to functional-detail as well as the design i.e. everything has form and function. It is quite a 'small' house and it is impressive what use has been squeezed out of it whilst still retaining stunning architecture. The audio guide (free) is a bit over the top/gushing but necessary.The house is a bit oddly bare of furnishings (I think a legacy of the building falling out of favour).Initially I was a bit sceptical (i.e. having reached my Gaudi-dosage for the day) but it is very good. A definite 'must-visit' if in Barcelona.

Fascinating conceptualization of a large residence.. This is an enormous family home designed by Gaudi. It features many brilliant functional architectural details and furniture. It is fully wheelchair accessible, staff is very helpful with those requiring mobility assistance.

Beautiful work of A.G. The building has so many beautiful details, worth a visit! Located near the busy street, easy to found. I had a little slip&fall accident myself in the toilet down the stable, the the floor was so wet but no sign to tell the visited about it, I fall on the stairs have a very large bruise on my left thigh. Suggest the management team pay more attention to Health&safety in the building. Luckily I did not damage my bone just some bruises if that was a elder visitor, it would be a very bad accident.
Fantastic!. We stumbled into the Palau on a day when they were doing free admission. WOW! We would've easily paid for a ticket. The house was impressive, but the view from the top is stunning.

One of Gaudi's best. On the last day we visited Palau Guell - another of Gaudi's masterpieces. This gives you a completely different view of the architect. If you only have time for two of of Gaudi's creation, this would be one of them.

Very interesting and beautiful. The cost to enter this place is 12 euros. I didn't do that much research before coming to Barcelona but I knew I wanted to go here because it is highly recommended. It is the house of Guell which Gaudi designed for him. An audioguide is given as part of the ticket. The design is very detailed. I just found the entire Palau very beautiful. I think this place is worth a visit.

Even if you don't like Gaudi.... This is a Gaudi masterpiece, more traditional in architectural style, unlike Sagrada Familia. It's a self-guided audio-tour that can take as long as you wish. Even if you are not an architecture buff, you will immediately appreciate the intricate details, cleverness, and simple beauty. We were so glad we did this on own rather than on tour as a group flew through while we spent an amazing 2 hours (that felt like only one.) We both could have started the tour over again at the end. Who knows? I believe the guard may have allowed us if we asked!

Amzing. This is one of the best places you can visit in Barcelona. When you walk inside you feel some magic that you are not going to find in the other places of the cities. There is something special here. Something that you are not going to find in the other important cities of Europe. Moreover, it is like you are in a film, so the experience is even better

Birthplace of Gaudi's Architectural Style. Palau Guell is one of Gaudi's earliest works, and the one most recently restored. Within this palace that he built for his patron and friend Guell, you can see the early beginnings of Gaudi's architectural style. This place may be best appreciated after visiting one of Gaudi's later works, such as the more famous and stunning Casa Batllo.

Early Gaudi!Tips. You can visit for free this early work by Gaudi:Summer season (from 1st April to 31th October):Sundays from 5 to 8 pm (from 1 April to 31 October). Free tickets will be given out from 4.45 pm.Winter season (from 1st November to 31th March):Sundays from 14.30 to 17.30 h. Free tickets will be given out in two turns: from 14.15 pm to 16.15 h pmDays: 23 April, 18 May and 24 SeptemberFor a Gaudi enthusiast this building is a must!
just awesome in the very center of Barcelona. its not for free, but it's just amazing, a master piece you can't miss. it will just wow you. Its like entering to a peace of the history.
Antonio Gaudi isthe Master!. Unbelievable style and elegance abound at this fantastic architectural masterpiece by Gaudi. Don't miss this if you are in Barcelona!

Saudi's first masterpiece. We chose to visit this museum because it was one of Gaudi's earlier commission. It is truly beautiful, the interior is a simpler style but it feels more like somewhere you could live. Very close to La Rambla.

Not typical Gaudi. We were disappointed by this place after having visited Gaudi's best works at Casa Battlo and La Pedrera. It's good to see though to compare the interiors but we should have visited here before Casa Battlo as this is totally not what you would expect having seen that place.

Great work by Gaudi. Reasonable fee to get in, easy to find, allow about an hour. I know little about Gaudi but once you have had the tour with the free handheld guide you will know a lot more. Very interesting to anyone who likes history, architecture and design.Lacking in here is furniture. You just view empty rooms and get told it was a bedroom. Can't help but think the National Trust would a better job but it is well run and well worth a visit.

I would want to live here. Perhaps less popular than other Gaudi's houses in Barcelona with the ones in Passeig de Gràcia attracting most tourists, this one is definitely worth a visit. It's just off Las Ramblas. The visit is well organised with a helpful audio guide as you work your way up from the stables to the roof to the sound of the organ playing in the chapel (if you're lucky!). It is amazing to see how Gaudi combined functionality and intricate design.Much better and more easily accessible alternative to the over-hyped and overcrowded Parc Guell.

Terrific and less-crowded. I loved the Guell Palace! It doesn't seem nearly as popular as the Casa Mila or Casa Batllo...but I highly recommend it! The pictures might not seem as amazing as the other Gaudi buildings, and indeed the interior and facade is generally more normal and less colorful than Mila/Batllo, however there are beautiful sights. Exploring the subterranean horse stables is interesting. The rooftop is the one part of the house that is very colorful and fantastical. There are somewhere around 20 chimneys, each one completely unique. In fact, the rooftop of Guell Palace is one of my favorite Gaudi sights in all of Barcelona. The domed-ceiling is also terrific. Plus, Guell Palace is cheaper than Casa Mila and Casa Battlo and it was also significantly less crowded. Maybe I had great timing, or it is just generally a quieter attraction, but for most of my visit to Guell Palace I felt as if I had the place to myself. A great experience. PS. As a fan of '70s film, I also enjoyed knowing that a scene for the 1975 Jack Nicholson movie 'The Passenger' was filmed at Guell Palace. (A scene was filmed at Casa Mila as well).
Barcelona . Great surprise to find a new Gaudí masterpiece opened since our last visit. It is beautiful and fascinating.

Summer night, rooftop jazz experience. This was one of the coolest experiences I had on my solo trip to Barcelona. If anyone feels like they need yet another reason to fall completely in love with Barcelona, add this to your list! Palau Guell offers rooftop concerts at sunset, with appetizers and cocktails, all with Gaudi's breathtaking architecture as our setting and Barcelona's beautiful sky-line at night as our backdrop. They offer tours in multiple languages so you can feel comfortable, and before you arrive on the rooftop, you get to enjoy the Palau Guell from the inside, as your tour guide takes you through the house explaining the history and architecture. A beautiful experience!

Must Do. Even if you know nothing about Gaudi (as per my fellow travelers) spend sometime here. Just a short diversion off La Rambla. The outside isn't as impressive as some of the other Gaudi buildings but the inside is stunning. For a modest cost, you get an audio guide that is informative but not too long winded and storage space for free. The interior is an interesting blend of styles and a Gaudi masterpiece. You'll probably end up spending an hour if you're a bit of a photographer or a lover if Gaudi. The views from the rooftop of Barcelona at the end of the tour are a amazing. Enjoy this highlight of Barcelona.
Beautiful house. Cant imagine such a fantastic crazy and wild house was made more than a 100 years back. A must see for all the Gaudi fans.

Impressive. Well organised, good audio and some impressive Gaudi features. Fascinating to see how he transformed a side street house into a spectacular residence. takes about an hour and certainly worth a visit.

Most beautiful Gaudi building in my opinion. Especially when somebody is making music on the organ.. Most beautiful Gaudi building in my opinion. Especially when somebody is making music on the organ. Roof is famous and you can make nice photos. View on the old city of Barcelona is perfect.

Unexpected gem. Having seen some Gaudi houses before, nothing prepared us for the sheer opulence of architectural detail on show in this palace (and palace it is). We spent two hours here, and loved it. The (free) audioguide is excellent.

Beautiful Gaudí Gem.. Barcelona seems to be in the grip of a manic marketisation of its public places and cultural heritage. The Palau Güell appears to be one of the few Gaudí sites in the city to have escaped (for now at least) being overwhelmed by unrestrained package tourism. You still have to get there first thing, before it opens, and we, naughtily, shot straight up to the top to enjoy unimpeded views of the roof decor, before the first pulse of visitors got there. Probably, the management would not like me writing that, as they have done very precise planning of 'through-flow'; free audio guides are provided, and these act to shepherd the visitors around the various parts of the house, while providing really interesting information and context. Numbers did build up, in the course of the morning, but not to the extent of destroying the experience of the building. When we went, in late spring, there seemed to be mainly Gaudí aficionados there, and no coach loads of bored teenagers. The top storey is now a dedicated community education space, which is great as it gives a real sense of a living building, not just a museum. Although Barcelona has a scheme allowing locals free access to monuments, The Palace does not seems to be included in that scheme, which is my only quibble. The people of any city should have access to their own cultural heritage.

Beautiful building. I purchased my ticket online. Visits are timed and the ticket included an audioguide. I would allow at least 2 hours for the visit. This was one of my favourite Gaudi buildings - its like a giant medieval chest with all the wood and iron work detailing.I really love the rooftop - its just magical!
Gorgeous. cool spot to go do some tourism. The architecture is amazing. The gift shop was unbelievably crowded.

Nice visit. This Palau is very amazing.
From outside, you can't imagine what you can see inside...
For visit, you must like architecture...
the advantage of this attraction is that it is not to much less expensive...than the Pedrera..
Step back from rambla fr 2 hours. Great peace of gaudi work. Cheaper than cas Batlo(12euro) and not as busy. Vist between walking on rambla and eating in one of the restaurants there.

Interesting Early Gaudi Architecture. Gaudi is most famous for his later buildings including his famous Basilica. This building is one of his earlier commissions. He was commissioned to remodel the home of the Güell i López family. The work was done between 1886 and 1890. The building does not have the genius craziness of the Basilica because it was designed for the needs of a specific family.Regardless, the building has many out-of-the-box features that would be unusual in a home of that day. We spent about 2 hours visiting the place. Included in the price of your admission is a very complete audio tour that describes what Gaudi was trying to do in each room. The place is not one of the main tourist destinations in Barcelona but you should visit it to see what Gaudi could do with an intimate private home as opposed to large public spaces. There have been comments on Trip Adviser about the need to reserve in advance, the long lines to get in and that the place was crowded. We experienced none of this. We walked right up and there were no crowds in the house. However, it should be noted that we were there in October and it may be more crowded in high season. The Palau Guell home is right off Las Ramblas so it is easy to combine a visit to Palau Guell with a stroll along Las Ramblas. That is what we did.
Stunning building. From the architecture to the decor to the design features this building is amazing. Truly a feast for the eyes - and the hand held tour guide is extremely useful/helpful.
So worth a visit. A must for Gaudi fans. Just off Las Ramblas with all its great bars, eateries and the fab market. Not cheap entrance fee but really great visit.

Totally renovated. Clean, large and easy to access and understand the life a long time ago for the upper class in Barcelona. The palace is really well renovated and the vieuw from the terrace at the end of the day are gorgeous.....with Moujuic in your camera

Beautiful, just amazing.. I have t be honest, I had never heard of this place until we found it by mistakw walking around the city. This is a most visit in Barcelona for sure. I don't know if it is always free but we didn't have to pay for the visit
Beautiful. Beautiful example of Antoni Gaudí's architecture. We went at the end of September and almost had the whole place to ourselves. Nice little store on the first floor.

Beautiful craftsmanship. This is a nice option if you want to get inside one of gaudi's houses, on a slightly lesser budget, 12euro each. It is not quite as colourful as some of his other work, but the craftsmanship and his incredible design skill is all very evident, with an audio guide included its a very interesting tour, and you get to see the rooftop too which is quite interesting.

If you have time for only one Gaudi attraction - this must be it!. Palau Guell is a splendid mansion designed by Gaudi when he was still in his 30's for a very wealthy patron, Eusebi Guell. More than any other Gaudi attraction, one can see the many aspects of Antoni Gaudi design, covering everything from bedrooms to reception rooms, from stables to a chapel. The audio guide is included in the admission price of €12 (or €8 for senior citizens of Europe). You will need at least one hour - we spent two. It was closed for restoration during our last visit to Barcelona when we visited all the other Gaudi attractions, but this is the best of all for an intimate view of so many design features - light and space; materials such as brick, stone and wood, iron and glass. Gaudi was fantastic. Don't miss the roof with all the chimneys.Staff were exceptionally good. Special mention to Sheila.

Beautiful, functional, and way ahead of its time. guadi is known for the unique look of his buildings, and while Palau Guell meets that criteria, its the other design details he used to provide fresh air and natural light throughout the house that ultimately remain in my mind. He was a hundred years ahead of his time and was fortunate enough to find a wealthy benefactor who would finance his early works and allow his genius to shine through.

A Gaudi Treat. A great stop off the La Ramblas is this Gaudi designed home - no queues (in November), great value with an audio tour you can do at your own pace. Nice little shop too with quality gifts at reasonable prices. We chose to see this and the Sagrada Familia as our Gaudi fix - the queues to get into the ticketed part of Park Guell were too long for our patience. We were not disappointed - amazing workmanship on view here - something totally different to what you see in other European cities.

Palau Guell - Interesting Gaudi Building. I recently visited Palau Guell and found it very interesting. It has the usual Gaudi style but not as colourful as say his Casa Batllo. The building is impressive and has a wonderful roof garden which overlooks the city. You can see Sagrada in the distance. The building was built as a family home for Guell who was his best friend and patron at the time.This building is in a side street off the Ramblas and is easy to get to. Although I had pre-booked for 9.30am in the morning, it was not crowded and once inside, it was easy to walk around. The audio was clear and descriptive.This building is well worth visiting if you are interested in Gaudi architecture and design.Lyn, Brisbane Australia

Great if you're a huge Gaudi fan, not so great if not.. Reading the other reviews before our visit meant that this was a must see on our to-do list. However, we're not all that interested in architecture and so to be honest we were a little disappointed. The price was low compared to the other Gaudi attractions and there was an audio guide included in the price. The guide was a little too detailed in places and so we skipped a few of the guide points (here is a antechamber which leads into the main room etc). The building is a house that belonged to the Guell family back in the later 1800s and was clearly designed to impress. However you learn very little about the family themselves as the main focus is the architectural design. I think we have been a little spoiled by the stately home tours you get in the UK where you can see how people lived, whereas this house was empty apart from a few pieces of furniture. Worth it if you're hugely into Gaudi and want to get the full picture of his work, not so much if you just want to see the key Gaudi attractions.

Essential visit, compare the 1% then. So this is one of the buildings that show how the 1% lived 115 years ago. No doubt if it had been London, he would have excavated 4 floors of basement and left the machine down there. Spectacular building, the stables are an amazing space, compare the same column in the horse area at Park Güell. I think my favourite bit is still the chimney pots, I know they aren't architecturally important, but they are lots of fun, can you spot the salamander? Great place for sunset views/photos through the pollution. Audio tour is quite good, not over the top gushing like that at Casa Batllo.Absolutely worth a visit.

great. If you are interested in Gaudi’s work, this is a must see. The palace was commissioned by an industrialist who, in today’s dollars, was worth more than Warren Buffet. The workmanship shows how enormous wealth from the industrial revolution times could be directed to create beautiful things. Very easy to find off Las Ramblas. Worth the trip.

A Fascinating Early Gaudi Building.. This building was designed by Gaudi from scratch & has many features characteristic of his work, such as the parabolic arches, distinctive chimneys & idiosyncratic decorative features. There is a good audio guide provided with your entry. The basement and upper story are symptomatic of how Gaudi solved the problems of functional areas in his buildings. In Palau Guell, polished brown stone from the Guell family's estates was used extensively on the interior, which makes it rather oppressive & somber unlike Casa Batllo which is a symphony of light. This building is well worth visiting to see the beginning of Gaudi's ideas in action.
Palau Guell. Beautiful building created by Gaudi. Well worth a visit though you have to pay to go in. Located off La Rambla.

For Gaudi Fans, Well Worth a Visit. This was an early work of Gaudi, a mansion built for one of his primary patrons. From the stables to the upper bedrooms of his children, there are elements of Gaudi's style that remind us of his genius.
Great, dont miss!. Great example of how visionary Gaudi created not only the outside , but also the inside of a house ( decoration, lights, furniture, etc) from his friend Guell

Another Gaudi Masterpiece!!. This is a must see if you spend a few days in Barcelona! It is an architectural beauty from Gaudi and to see it today and try to imagine how he came up with these ideas during his time. It is a true beauty and worth the time to visit tour. There was a long line to stand in to get tickets, but one person can do it for a group. Then you come back for your allotted time. Go early to get tickets. They do run out!!
Transported to another world...... Beautiful building with great iron work and gorgeous stained glass windows, the top terrace have colorful tile towers that look like candy towers...........

Do this one first. This was the last Gaudí building i visited and I guess it went about it wrong.. I would recommend to make this your first, otherwise you might be a bit underwhelmed like me. I think it's also the first building he designed (in Barce). It gives you a nice insight into the mind of Gaudí, however, he developed his vision and abilities over the years, making his later work more impressive to me.Oh and flash photography is not allowed, while it's quite dark inside. So if your camera had issues with that, like mine, take your phone inside (in stead of leaving it in a locker) to take good pictures.

you have NEVER seen a Palace like that!. We were AMAZED, steel, wood, glass, the most incredible ceilings, in every room different! Have been to Barcelona a few times but only this time to this palace, right around the corner of our hotel Oriente Atiram. Will recommend to everybody!
Cleverly Designed Urban Palace. This is Gaudi's rendering for his wealthy patron industrialist. It is very clever in design. We did not require advance tickets and this is just off La Rambla.
Gaudi showplace. A wonderful experience/ educates to understand Gaudi's approach to architure. Loved getting to strol through one of the apartments set up in Art Neuvo style.

Wonderful Find in Barcelona. There are so many places to tour in Barcelona but this is one not to be missed. You can tour the home with an audio guide in your language at your own pace. The rooms designed by Gaudi are magnificent and gave me a new appreciation for his work. In fact, I enjoyed this tour more than La Pedrera (my opinion). The tour describes each room and the activities of the Guell family that lived here. Don't miss it.

great. It is amazing to think that this was supposed to be a suburb of Barcelona And now it stands and shows the mind of Gaudi.. His attachment to nature, his religious leaning, his genius.. It is beautiful

Residential Gaudi, a masterpiece. The entire effect of this tour on us was, "Wouldn't it be wonderful to live here!" This is a magnificent home, with architectural beauty and joyful creativity that would make it a place that you would love to come home to. It is arranged for the entertainment of friends and family, incorporating a magnificent pipe organ in the very heart of the home, a dining room that was made for conviviality, bedrooms that were designed for comfort, and an overall décor that makes for vitality and interest. This is Gaudi at his most personal, doing his very best for his greatest supporter. Even the chimneys are works of art!

Excellent introduction to Gaudi. A really good building on which to cut your Gaudi teeth. You can book easily on line to skip the queues and the well priced ticket includes an excellent audio guide (once you get over the American accent!). The building is really sombre and throws the bright rooftop chimneys into sharp relief. I love how this gem of a building is surrounded by local dwellings both smart and shabby. An added bonus was hearing an organ recital in the room designed for music. Well worth a visit and excellent value for money.

Stunning Gaudi creation. Note: Many posted TripAdvisor reviews appear to confuse this single-house attraction, with the large park of the same name -- also by Gaudi. But palau = "palace"; this review is for the Guell townhouse/mansion located just off Las Ramblas, closer to the harbor, not the Guell park and planned real estate community (with 2 Gaudi houses) which is rather far across town from this house.I'd wanted to see Gaudi's works since I was a teenager, and this trip was my first chance -- while everyone visits (and probably should!) the Sagrada Familia, I came away from my trip thinking that perhaps this house, just off Las Ramblas near the Gothic Quarter, was in many ways, the more impressive Gaudi structure to me.Built for Gaudi's principal client and sponsor, Guell (of "Park Guell" and "Finca Guell" and "Colonia Guell" -- other must-see Gaudi works commissioned by the same family) this was a private mansion lived in by the rich and powerful Guell family. Guell broke with traditions of the time, for a family of his stature, by locating the house in a run-down, somewhat disreputable neighborhood. It is at times austere and in other ways simultaneously very opulent. Wrought iron appears everywhere inside and out, exceptionally well executed and wonderfully varied. Ornate coffered ceilings mix with polished grey limestone walls and Gaudi's famous catenary arches, all under his clever and creative genius for design. The house is quite vast, spread across (I think) 6 floors, despite the very small footprint of the plot of land it occupies. All the rooms are arranged around a central "court" on the 2nd level -- a single, impressive square room used for entertaining, with a soaring parabolic dome that rises and narrows through three more floors to break through the rooftop, admitting sunlight through little cut-outs that suggest stars overhead. The public rooms (mostly on the street-side of the house) are lavish in their ornamentation, but not in any way lavish like you expect in other "palaces" of western Europe. Calatalan/Gaudi lavish, which relies on exceptional craftsmanship of often "ordinary" materials, such as the wrought iron, wood working, ceramic tile, etc. The private, family-focused rooms (mostly on the rear of the house) are quite splendid themselves, but not nearly as jaw-dropping; simpler in decor and applied ornamentation. Many of the rooms have individual fireplaces, which play an important role in the architect's design, higher up...Besides the parabolic-domed central room, two other stand-out features (of many!) in the house are: The basement level (which housed stables for the coach horses -- coaches pulled directly into the house via a U-shaped driveway at the street level) -- is accessed from the street level via a cobblestone ramp in the house, which the horses could navigate to reach the basement. The rooftop, which is a vast private terrace for the family, turned into something of an outdoor sculpture garden because of the many chimney smokestacks that rise through the roof from all those fireplaces below. Each one decorated and shaped differently from the rest; most covered in colorful, whimsical broken-pottery tile. An excellent audio guide is included with the self-paced tour. Tickets are available online in advance, or at a ticket booth a few doors down the street from the house. I spent 2 hours there and felt rushed (had an appointment elsewhere, or I would have stayed 3 hours!) If you're there to photograph, be sure to take a fast lens; the interior is often in subdued light, making for somewhat dim rooms for a camera to capture effectively.

Well worth the time. This would get the fifth star if the audio tour were a little better at keeping you pointed in the right direction. Nonetheless, it is a fascinating place and its architectural history (Gaudi's work) is very interesting--whether you like the overall effect or not. The building is striking and impressive. Some of Gaudi's touches are astonishing. And the views from the top are excellent (perhaps excluding the immediate neighbors).Take the tour as soon as the building opens for the best overall experience, in my opinion.

It's Gaudi, without the crush. All of Gaudi's buildings are glorious, but this one seems to attract slightly fewer visitors. It's not less beautiful than the others, so I don't know why that's so. All I can say is that means you may actually be able to enjoy yourself during your tour, rather than being crushed by mobs and impaled by selfie sticks.

Mesmerizing. Nice and close to La Rambla. The audioguide is extremely useful and informative! Take your time to listen and then silently admire each room and the various features. The best for last are the mosaic chimneys on the roof. Gave a descent view and was very cool!
A great comparison to the others. This feels very different from the other Gaudi buildings...darker and more glittery and for that it is great to see. Close to la Rambla.

Fascinating!. It is well worth the entrance fee to go inside and see the architecture of this amazing building. The audio guide is very informative. Be aware if you find stairs difficult as you gradually ascend to the top of the building but come down from the top in one long descent. There is a lift for the disabled but they do not encourage it's use.

Beautiful and stylish. We went here in our last day, since on Monday was closed. Beautiful house of family Guell, designed in the same style as other houses made by Gaudi. You'll be mesmerized by what you see.

Loved this place, one of the cheaper Gaudi places to visit and well worth the visit. Pre-book your tickets online and skip the queue is my first recommendation! Children up to 10 years are free too! We went as a family and loved it. The audio is not too lengthy and boring and is included in the entry fee. The tour takes approximately 1hour or longer if you stop to enjoy all the rooms/areas as we did. I would recommend it.
Amazing sights. Loved this place and it is a must if you like Gaudi and mosaic work. It was very busy so go early and book tickets in advance

Magnificent Gaudi Palace!. My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our tour of the magnificent Palau Guell designed by Gaudi! The included individual audio narration was excellent--and the numbering at each location (matching the audio) was perfect. The location is just steps down a side street from La Rambla and definitely worth a few hours to take in all the unusual and fascinating aspects of the home. Even the climb up (and down!) the stairway to the rooftop for a close-up view of the mosaic chimneys (each one different) was well worth it--and the view of the city from the roof is a treat in itself. The giftshop is also lovely--and the staff are charming.

When can I move in?. Astonishing. A fascinating insight into Gaudi's work, the use of space in this palace is spectacular. The innovative and intricate designs and craftsmanship are difficult to conceive as real - completely unique. The audio guide is detailed and interesting while the palace not too crowded. I would recommend booking in advance. Do not miss it!

Another one of Gaudi's must sees. . Palau Guell was easy to find as it was just off La Rambla. Entrance fee was 12 euros and included an audio guide. There was plenty to walk round and see, a few rooms were shut but it didn't matter. The rooftop was closed when we bought our tickets due to rain but luckily opened by the time we went inside. Definitely worth a visit.

Definitely worth a tour!. People make long pilgrimages just to view these wonderful things - the works of Gaudi. In my case, I have a grandchild who was born on Spanish soil. My son fell in love and this is where he ended up! Barcelona. It clearly made sense to visit some of the attractions, and the marvelous Palau Guell wasn't too far from my apartment. (And, by the way, anyone who thinks El Raval is a "bad" neighborhood has truly lived a sheltered life.) I enjoyed the tour and found the staff to be quite courteous. Their pride was noticeable, and it's easy to understand why they feel the way they do.
Very very interesting. One of Gaudi's earliest buildings. Very very interesting as it is an urban palace. Timed tickets mean it's never crowded. Brilliant.

Gaudi's masterpiece - so innovative!. Built by Gaudi, this large home includes so many innovative features, intended to cool and ventilate the space, provide privacy, access the chapel, etc. Fascinating insights are offered through a guided self-paced audio tour. Be sure to access the roof & enjoy the view!
very interesting place. This place is like a fortress. It is beautiful inside and has some of the original furniture as well. Well worth a visit.

Amazing & Interesting Architechture. This is fascinating place to visit with unique architecture in the center of Barcelona on Carrer Nou de las Ramblas. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It has very ornate walls and ceilings and is must see for anyone interested in the works of Palau Guadi, the architect. Definitely a must see in Barcelona!

One of his best works. Being the house of his Mecenas, Gaudi put some considerable effort on this early design. Althought it has some of the Gaudinian caractheristics (roofs, decorated ceilings, brick intrincated structures) it also has a very charming and cozy ambience, which keeps this work in the middle of his exhuberant expressionism and a certain functionalism applied to a mansion in the middle of barcelona. Worth every euro!

Hidden diamond of Antoni Gaudi in the centre of Barcelona!. I discovered it pretty late but am so happy anyway! It's great. Antoni Gaudi combined again different types of building materials, different colours and the results are unique. I loved every level of this Palau, especially the terrace, where the Sun was having breakfast, with us :) The architecture is Antoni 100% and nobody would refuse a romantic dinner inside one of the rooms!

Another important piece in the Gaudi jigsaw.. Spent a few days in Barcelona doing the tours etc. and didn`t realise until the last day that this Gaudi gem was in the next street from our hotel! We saw another side to his creativity and attention to detail. and cannot recommend the Palau Guell highly enough.
Another great work by Gaudi. Loved seeing this as well as the other works by Gaudi. Loved the rooftop views. Audio guide is excellent.

Fascinating. Really enjoyed seeing this start of Gaudi's design. Lots of details worth exploring. Took the as advertised Friday only English tour with a fine guide. Use of headphones was much appreciated.

Fascinating work of Gaudi. We spend 2 days to follow the work of Gaudi in Barcelona, and this palace was a big surprise for me. Except the roof no ornamental shapes but a castle with beautiful way of using wood, stone and iron to create the most surprising rooms and common spaces. And the roof.... not like this seen before. All the colors with such a simple goal as a chimney.

Very interesting Palau. Gaudi's Palau took over 10 years to restore and is a very interesting place with a lok into Gaudi's lifestyle.it is some 6 stories and it is all stairs; not good for those with trouble walking stairs.Great views from the roof of greater Barcelona. It is located about 1/2 block off La Rambla across from te Hotel Gaudi.

One of the best Gaudi sights to see. Another beautifully designed apartment by Gaudi but one of the great advantages of this building is that it is a lot less crowded than the other main attractions. Entrance price is very reasonable and you get an audio guide included which is very informative. The roof with its wonderful chimneys is a particular highlight.

mindblowing. another example of incredible barcelonas unique collection of amazing structures, the imagination of the designers and the era in which this was conceived are truly amazing, DO NOT miss this one

Beautiful and whimsical Gaudi. We stopped off at Palau Guell house toward the end of our stroll down Las Ramblas (glad to get off that!), found no waiting line, and walking right in. What an architectural masterpiece! Jaw dropping and whimsical (save time to explore the rooftop vents and chimneys).
Architecture fan. If you are architectural fan, then you shouldent miss this one. Check it out and enjoy the Guell talent and art.

Impressive piece of art. We visited at the opening hour, so we got in relatively easily. Tickets were not expensive (unlike at other spots). The building definitely worth a visit, we got an insight to what a genius Gaudi was.I was mostly impressed by the view that greeted me on the top: by the fairytale-like colorful chimneys.An impressive experience, a must-do for all Barcelona-goers!
A must to visit !. When in Barcelona, be sure you visit Palau Guell, just steps away from Ramblas, is one of the finest Gaudi art-work
Very interesting. This is an important building where one can see Gaudí's work at its best. Very well kept and the audio device is free and very informative.

Easy and interesting. We found the Palace on our way from our hotel to Las Ramblas, tucked away on a side street.
Decided to do the tour which was very easy to follow with the audio guide provided...was a good way to experience the Palace and only took an hour or so.

Interesting and less expensive than other Gaudi houses. There was only a very short queue when we passed by so we decided to have a look. Gaudi architecture never disappoints but we felt this palace gives examples of different styles and is even topped off (literally) by his famous chimneys at a bargain price compared to what you pay to get into La Pedrera, for example. A really interesting visit!
A must visit place!! . This is incredible architecture and I love it here. At €12 I found this well worth the price and you can spend as long as you like here
Good experience. Lots of interesting stuff to see, you get a pretty good idea of Gaudi after this visit. A lovely afternoon was spent here.
'Hidden' gem. Obviously not really a 'hidden' gem but much less touristic as the other Gaudi designs like La Pedrera and Casa Battlo. Still worth the visit!

Gaudi!. Great place to see Gaudi at his finest. Reasonable admission, free audio tour guide which was very informative. Fun place to visit and although we usually are not the biggest "museum" fans, this was unique and worth the visit!

Restrained Gaudi Architecture. Beautiful private residence designed by Gaudi for the Guell family. The architecture is beautiful and the attention to interior detail is stunning. All interior finishes were crafted by the best and most talented artisans of the time.

Another Gaudi attraction worth seeing.. We had seen so many of Gaudi's other residences that we just veiwed Palau Guell from the outside. It was quite spectacular, and very close to the Ramblas and to Placa Relais, where you can have a wonderful dinner experience.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece with Ornamental Iornwork. A truly unique house built for a rich client who liked to party. This house is an Ornimental Iornworkers Dream. The grand entry was designed for handling many horse and carriges with stables underground. The paving blocks are wood to lessen the noise of the horses hoofs. The main room is not large but it s 3 sroties tall and is accoustically perfect even though it is made of stone and iornwork. Leave it to the genius of Gaudi to make it happen. If you are lucky enough to hear the pipe organ play it is beautiful.Of course you must vsit the rooftop to appreciate his signature chimneys..

Stunning. There is so much about Gaudi in Barcelona that you may need to make choices. This should be one of them! Caution, too, that you may find a Gaudi walking tour only of exteriors of buildings. This is a structure that is all about the interior --and the roof accessible only from the interior.  While the wife of Guell who built this house didn't like to live in it, and I would find it a bit dark and formal, as an early example of Gaudi's work it offers a brilliant introducti into his use of stained glass, pottery shards, delicately carved wood, wrought iron, and endless polished stone. The audioguide, which is included in the €12 price is well done, includes the narration of the ten-minute film, and offers music that was actually performed in the house.  Note, there appeared to be an elevator for use by handicapped, but I am not sure it goes to the roof. On the floor that held servants quarters, there is now a display about how and when the building has been restored trying to follow Gaudi's guidelines. The craftsmanship of the original work and the restoratis in all the different media is most impressive. Note also the impressive attention given to acoustics, including wooden bricks on the carriageway to temper the sound of horses' hoofs. I haven't yet seen all the Gaudi options, but I would have hated to mss this one. Conveniently just off the Rambla. Metro: Liceu.

One of the most interesting buildings in Barcelona. At so many levels, this is one of my favourite attractions in Barcelona. Firstly, Guell himself would have been worth 70 billion euros in today’s currency and so could afford every innovative idea that Gaudi had. Secondly, it’s a story of a wealthy family from that time. Thirdly, this is a more intimate yet comprehensive view of Gaudi’s skills from the stables below to the crazy chimney pots on the roof passing through so many rooms to pause in and enjoy. Fourthly, you can take your time to discover this substantial family home with an excellent audio guide. It’s a remarkable piece of Catalan history; and if you choose the right time when it’s not too busy, a place to spend a fascinating couple of hours.

Spectacular and well worth a visit. Timed entry means that there is plenty of time to go around. The audio guide is informative and there are plenty of staff around to speak to. Go on a dry day as the outside is closed if wet.
Palau Guell visit. A huge palace/mansion. need time to take it all in. Conveniently located to our hotel, Nice contrast to Gaudi's other works.

Worth a visit to see one of Gaudi's private home commissions. Gaudi was quite innovative in addition to his visual style. This home designed for his mentor, Guell, is now a museum. Plain on the outside it is quite something to see on the inside...especially the basement that was designed for Guell's horse stable.
Beautiful work of Antoni Gaudi!. The Palau Güell in Barcelona is one of the early works of Antoni Gaudí and one of the most magnificent buildings of the art nouveau.

Typical Gaudi. Another great building from the one and only Gaudi. Imposing, classy and stunning. I can assure you that you feel like you travelled back in time when you're in the palace. I wouldn't say it's a "must see" in the city, cause there are lot of other excellent thing to visit! But that depends on your taste.

Beautiful palace. The tour of this beautiful palace took about an hour. You get audio headphones so you can get more information about the rooms making up this impressive place. Unfortunately, we were unable to go the terrace because it rained. This palace displays the impressive Gaudi architecture!!
Amazing!. You can buy your ticket in advance not to queue.The place is utterly amazing.Not to be missed on the post-modernism path.A gem!

Amazing building!great architecture!. When visiting park Guell you can't help think about how would it have been to live there in those times!Absolutely amazing architecture and design!Undoubtedly, this is worth visiting and remembering when building one's dream house!

Worth visiting. Untill a view years back this city palace was closed to the public. For work, I used to stay in the hotel opposite (Hotel Gaudi), so I only could look at it from my hotel window. Great I could go inside now and loved it. What beauty and craftsmanship. If you like the work of Gaudi, go and see it!

Amazing!. Palau Guell is a fantastic visit in Barcelona. It's a bit of a hidden Gaudi's gem, I say it because it isn't the most know of his. What I enjoyed of it is that you get to see SOOO much of Gaudi's work. You get to see a mansion from the basement, to bedrooms, to dining room to rooftop. If you have the time, very worth it. It's great that the audio guide is included, like always get tickets online.
Most impressive Gaudi visit. The Palau Guell is one of my most impressive Gaudi's architects buildings visits ever. This one you should not miss during your Barcelona visit.

Stunning former palace of Guell family is a must for fans of Gaudí!. This is a wonderful starting place for anyone seeking to understand the early work and influences that created the genius that was Antoni Gaudí. It is eight floors of an early modernist masterpiece built as Gaudí's first residential project for his early cheerleader, the industrialist Eusebi Guell. there is a basement built to house the family's horses with its own circular ramp so as to facilitate leading the horses up to street level. There is a roof terrace with 15 chimneys decorated with what were to become one of Gaudí's trademarks: mosaics of broken ceramics in a variety of colours.The scope of the project was breathtaking and the attention to detail of the interior decor highly impressive. Gaudí's early style was highly influenced by art nouveau and oriental styles and both are highly evident here.The use of windows, openings and pillars to encourage light and air circulation yet retain privacy for the family that lived here is amazing.Apparently, Gaudí's graduation report when leaving his university's architecture faculty stated that he would go on to become a genius or a mad man. But, this incredible palace is definitely the work of a true genius.

Not my favourite Gaudi experience. I went here with a Gaudi fan and I did enjoy the visit, but wouldn't have bothered if I'd been on my own. The audio tour was very informative and I can see what Gaudi was trying to do. It takes quite a while to go round and a constant diet of how wonderful this carving is and how special that light fitting is started to grate on me a bit. I couldn't help feeling things were half done. Either leave the rooms empty and show pictures of what they would have looked like or restore them fully to how they were when the family lived there. There's something depressing about standing in a child's bedroom and the only thing that survives of them is an overstuffed chair. It doesn't give you much of a flavour of the family and HOW they lived in this impressive and highly designed building. They're secondary to the genius of Gaudi. It's hard to see how practical his designs were for everyday living and given this was a family home it would have been nice to have felt that someone had lived there amongst the splendor rather than just stood and admired the architecture as we were doing. Others will love the well designed and unique aspects of this building and I think it's well worth a visit if you appreciate architecture, design or Gaudi. But I'm afraid it just left me cold.

Worth a quick visit. Interesting place to visit in the centre of town, away from the hustle and bustle. The recorded guide is excellent, taking you through Gaudi's building designed for businessman Guell room by room. Worth about 60-90 minutes. You buy the entry ticket not at the front foor but at a little window about 20 metres to the left, then queue to enter.
Fantastic. My second time here,and we likes it very much,although we had to wait 3 hour because of the place regulations.

The Gaudi house to see if you're only seeing one. Of the Gaudi houses, La Padrera, Casa Batllo & Palau Guell, this one offers the most to see. At only €12 compared to €20.50 for the others, this is also the best value. While La Padrera (Casa Mila) is beautiful Gaudi, the tour only includes the roof and a walk through one apartment. To be fair, this is probably because the building is still inhabited. Palau Guell is entirely a museum and you have access to the entire building from rooftop to underground stables. Do this one and if you're feeling flush or are absolutely head over heels for all things Gaudi, pay for the others.
Got to be seen. Been before but still enjoyed a second visit showing my nephew around. The roof is a must see if its your first time in Barca

Go see the roof!. It's okay, but a bit boring.
The idea of walking around with a recorded tour is very good but sometimes I got lost in the descriptions and the rooms.
A very well organized place.
Don't miss out the roof and the bathrooms!

Palay Guell, a well worth visit !. At first we thought that Palau Guell was in Guell Park. This is not the case as it's just a little of the Rambla, near the Grand Teatre Liceu. We were simply delighted by this visit. Very few visitors and this is probably due to the fact that it's not that easy to locate. Roof top architectural chimneys are probably the nicest ones that you will find in Barcelona. Some of them are part of the icons of the city. Rooms are gorgeous. A well worth visit !
Amazing Gaudi. We had a guide take us through and explained and we were amazed at how futuristic Gaudi was !!!!! The color was amazing and his designs were incredibly awe inspiring !!!!
a surprising find. Gaudi is amazing and this early effort by him is amazing. The audio handsets worked very well and the content was better than expected.
nice. Fantastic, must visit place.. don't forget your Camera's September is a good time to visit when the tourist start disappearing.

Magnficent Mansion -one of Gaudi's most important earlier designs. Built around 1886, this mansion was one of the first important designs, for Antoni Gaudi, taking palce at the beginning of his career. It is located in the neighborhood of El Raval. This was our second time in Barcelona, and we enjoyed seeing the mansion designed for Eusebi Güel, who was an industrial tycoon. I recommend taking the tour, Rates are very reasonable. Tour takes about an hour. This is all part of the UNESCO world heritage site. For those interested, there is a gift shop inside.
The Palace !. Located very near to La Rambla, its the first of Gaudi's buildings I had a chance to visit. Unfortunately, it was closed on the day but I definitely look forward to coming back

Must see when in Barcelona!. It's close to la rambla, when you purchase the ticket you receive an audioguide. You will star the visit where the stable used to be and head up after that. We visited it on a Sunday and it wasn't crowded, no queues at all.

Gaudi was commissined to build a mansion for a wealthy patron. Great example of Gaudi's experiments with parabolic arches.I loved the beautiful curved brick work in the stables This is one of Gaudi's earliest works
Unique Architecture. Be sure to see the Palau Guell when in Barcelona. Gaudi was a real genius in harmonizing with natural elements.

Another one of Gaudi's master pieces. This place is smaller and less hyped than other of Gaudi's houses, but you'll definitely find Palau Guell interesting, if you fancy the Gaudi architecture. Palau Guell has many visitors, but its not as crowdy ad Casa Battlo or La Pedrera.

The genius of Gaudi. The Palau Guell is one of those slightly under the radar places that you hear about from the locals in Barcelona. It's not as famous as the Sagrada Familia, but it is nevertheless a spectacular architectural wonder, and absolutely worth the visit. Only takes a couple hours to walk through the mansion, but absolutely worth it. And then wander down to the Parc Guell and enjoy that too. Highly recommend if you are going to Barcelona and are interested in Gaudi.
todo bueno. once in a lifetime experience.I grew up in NYC,my absolute favorite place tout le monde,but Espana is my #2 dreamworld!

Best yet to come?. This was one of Gaudi's first commissioned works and already contains many of his hallmarks in terms of materials and style. Interestingly it seems to contain a number of Moorish and medieval elements. It's certainly very dark and for me not a patch on the full-blown art nouveau masterpiece that is Casa Batllo. But of course that is like comparing Messi with Neymar! Palau Guell is still the work of one of the world's great visionary architects. Personally, if you're going to do both Palau Guell and Casa Batllo I'd do them in that order to best see how Gaudi's ideas and technical mastery progressed. But don't be worried about being Gaudi'ed out - both are worth visiting (as well of course as the Sagrada Familia and as many other Gaudi creations as you have the time for).
Beautiful. Well worth a visit. Designed by Gaudi for his patron, it is a lovely house with beautiful furnishings,paintings, and architecture. Don't forget to go up on the rood.

A Gaudi mansion, with all his genialideas. It was Gaudi's first Palace design for the Guell family.It's right off la Rambla and there are no lines there to contend with.Very interesting building for its interior, exterior, the roof, the chimneys, the stables, the furniture and everything else.

Darkest Gaudi house I have visited. This is the palace Gaudi designed for Güell who is behind Park Güell. I can't understand how can people writing reviews mix up a house with a park.That out of the way I must say this is very impressive place, but not as "gaudi" as other houses available for visit. Maybe it is all the wood which makes it so dark or somewhat conservative solutions on visual elements. Compared to Casa Battlo this very colorless and unimaginative. But still a worthy place if you like Gaudi or architecture.

Remarkable fantasy. The Palau Guell is a remarkable fantasy from the talented architect Gaudi, who was indulged by a wealthy family. It is hard to imagine a normal and practical life in this labyrinth of exceptional and beautiful craftsmanship inspired by a strange and capricious vision of geometry and organic design. The ticketing and access process works smoothly to control the crowds. The rooftop 'garden' of chimneys is a highlight, as is the jewel box chapel, organ and the ceiling dome. The joinery on ceilings and doors is sublime.

Amazing chimneys. This was our third and final tour. Fortunately it is half the price of Casa Batllo, there was no ticket queue and it takes about half the time.This is an earlier masterpieces of Gaudi and so this tour gave us a background to his life and also of the Guell family. It is the amazing combination of materials to produce the architecture and design that is so fabulous. I really loved the roof top so may be this is not worth visiting unless it is dry. There are so many chimneys with so many different styles and materials.

Another amazing design by Antony Gaudy. Built and designed by Antony Gaudy, this is a place of sheer beauty and splendor. It was also very interesting to see how various components of Gaudy's designs were incorporated in the design and construction of the Sagrada Familia. I would recommend visiting Palau Guell first before going to Sagrada Familia, and then looking for the same concepts in the design.
very interesting place to visit. fantastic book your tickets online and early morning when most people are still in their hotels .a treat

The amazing Gaudi. Barcelona is a synonym for Gaudi. So, if you love Gaudi, don't miss Palau Guell. There are 2 audio guide options (short/long), both helpful. What amazde me was the richness of the palau on a side and the poverty seen from the palau's balcony on the other side. The rooftop is, as we know Gaudi, unbelieveble!

Another Masterpiece. I'm writing this late at night while waiting for a phone call. Each of Gaudi's works are incredible in their vision, their playfulness, their attention to detail. I would not have missed any of his works, but as a non-student, I become jaded. Palau Guell is a wonderful visit. I have not seen them all yet, so I can't rank them, but at this point,(not having seen Sagrada la Familia or Parc Guell) I would rank Casa Batllo number one.
Worth seeing. Stunning place with amazing audio guide that makes you feel like you were present at the time when Gaudi was designin that place!
Speechless. Walked quietly through this beautiful place so I could hear the organist. Amazing. Blissfully uncrowded and unusual.

Gaudi's first commissioned work, AMAZING!!!. So, I accidentally wrote my review for La Pedrera under this location name. This building with all the inspiration and ambition of a very young Gaudi, is a masterpiece and a vision of what to come in his future in architecture and nature.Gaudi had a love for nature and incorporated it in all of his work. The detailed, thoughtfully created ceilings certainly show works of another demention. The mind of a man who at an early age.... thought " outside the box". Not everyone were fans of his way of incorporating nature with structural architecture. These buildings and places Gaudi worked so hard to create still stand today with minimal maintenance to any of the structures. He knew what he was thinking and did follow his dreams inspire of what anyone thought.Be sure to look up while inside the rooms of this house, you will not want to miss these ceilings!
Must see visit. Insane or genious architecture, but definitely something to see. Gaudi is unlike any architect you'll ever see, with his whimsical ideas. Definitely worth the price.

Brilliantly designed house. We visited this place in the morning hours. Once you cross the big metallic gates, you are given an audio guide, that gives you short and summarized information of each corner of the house. Allow around 1.5 to 2 hours for this place. Each of the corners of the house have some intriguing object or design. The most important feature may be the roof in which the colorful chimneys are located,

Very cool and surreal vibe but be prepared for a workout. This place is surreal and summarizes Gaudi well, it is kind of mind numbing that he was able to do this in this time frame. He truly mesmerizes with the patterns and shapes and how he uses the space to really create curvature and shadow that captures the imagination. I love to do a Gaudi Day and plan it in advance and see his sites together. The Park, the Apartments, the La Sagrada Familia, and the Palau. It is repetitive in some areas, but he does an amazing job changing pace with each structure and conform the space to his vision. It is a truly unique style and something you have to see in person and walk through the columns and get a sense for how it incorporated the twists and turns of the space into a maze like space of pillars and the grandiosity of the whole process. I would recommend stretching and not working out that morning, other than a nice swim or warm up.
Awesome. Another amazing example of Gaudi architecture, beautiful fascinating and the mosaic chimneys were the highlight for me

Anazing light show..too many steps. They avertise that you walk up to the roof and atop at every floor for explanation but in reality 7 steep flights to attick everyone was gufing and puffing. An
Explanation of the house and works in the attic ..then..on to the roof
Great place!. Reserve your tickets online in advance. They get sold out in place really fast. Great place to visit.

Amazing building and cheaper than other Gaudi buildings. We wanted to go inside at least one Gaudi building and we basically picked this as it was the cheapest of them all (€12ish if I remember correctly). Beware going if raining though, luckily it cleared up later on, but they shut the roof if it's raining for health and safety. The mosaic chimneys are amazing, but even if you don't get a non-rainy day the rest of the house is incredible too. We weren't expecting it, as it was implied that the chimneys were the only decent thing to see when we were told it was probably best to come back when it wasn't raining. Luckily we did come back when it brightened up so we got to see everything, but the house interior is incredible, with amazing ceiling work and some furniture designed by Gaudi too. Definitely worth a look inside, as compared to his other buildings, this one isn't as spectacular from the outside.

A little culture at kast. My wife dragged me kicking and screaming to this - and as usual she's always right!We were just after a long lunch and I wanted to return to my hotel to rest however, my wife convinced me to go and it was well worth it. My wife was an art student so this was very interesting to her but studying art was necessary to enjoy a fantastic tour around a beautiful urban palace. The most amazing thing is that this is some of Gaudi's earliest work. It was a fantastic tour.
Another strange house. Strange architecture is a hallmark of Barcelona and this house is a sight to see, with its funny icecone towers

Very interesting - my favourite rooftop. The palace is very interesting, you could do this attraction fairly quickly just walking through. It would take a bit of time (maybe an hour or so if you did the audio tour. The rooftop is particularly interesting. There are many very differently designed steeples (for lack of a better term).

More evidence of Gaudi's brillance!. Once again we were awed by the design brilliance of Gaudi. Throughout the park this is evidenced again and again. A good place to spend some time just roaming about.

Awesome creation. Brilliant and unusual architecture, with great colour combination. It was a bit far from the hotel but on the whole amazing layout and design.Definitely something very different, need to see it to appreciate it

Don't miss it if you love Gaudi's architecture. If you think seeing Sagrada Familia, casa Batllo and La Pedrera is enough to understand Gaudi's mind, you are wrong. Every single house is a unique masterpiece and if you love Gaudi, you will love this one too. Is close to center, from the Rambla.
Nice palace of a private family. Surprisingly nice palace of a private family. Much Gaudi's artwork and cooperation with other artists
Stunning. Beautiful park , worth bringing a picnic , views over the city amazing, get a jug of sangria and sit and watch world go by :-)

Guadi brilliance. Just gob-smackingly drop dead brilliant place. The architecture is beyond awesome - and people actually lived here!!!
Well worth the entrance fee (€12)
Worth a visit but a letdown compared to Sagrada Familia. Enjoyed very much, but had higher expectations. Rooftop views were spectacular and apartment layout/furniture was interesting.
Don't miss it.... On of the best palces in Barcelona for sure. Gaudi is genious when he was able to create this place...

A must visit for admirers of Gaudi’s designs. The wonder of the man, as shown in the design and execution of his ideas as built into the the Guell Palace, is his ability to change the way we think. He was way ahead of his time. As a magician with geometry, and intellectual problem solver, we admire today, his advanced thinking that resulted in solutions to common building design problems that we still face. Like how to heat or cool spaces in a natural way. The importance of cross ventilation and light management in a building, sound and acoustic management as well as structural strength using new methods of load bearing structures based on parabolic shapes. All these ideas were revolutionary when he did them, and are still being explored today. If you get the opportunity, don’t miss going. Buying tickets on line is recommended to avoid the sometimes horrific queues that are now days a part of visiting places like the Guell Palace.

An out of the world experience. Another must see in Barcelona. Bring your camera, It is obvious that the creator of this place was either inspired by some unknown force or perhaps ate some mushrooms or whatever.
wow. Spectacular inside! If you only go to one Guadi building - make it this one. Reasonable entry fee and wonderful views from the roof are a bonus.
UP on the roof!. This is the most outrageously over the top gorgeous Gaudi House we visited. Certainly they spared no expense!

Worth seeing for the mosaic chimneys. The Palau Guell is a nice addition if you like Gaudi, but shouldn't be as high on the list of things to see as the Casa Battlo, Casa Mila, and Sagrada Familia. The architecture inside is more conventional than other Gaudi location. If you like his work, check this out for the mosaic chimneys on the roof.
Not worth the wait.. A disappointment. Overpriced a wait for a long time for no reason actually. Try to find a time when not busy. I'm not sure when that would be however. Ask a local.

Meh. Well.. Palau Guell is a house built by Gaudi for his close millionaire friend Guell. The house was tastefully built - no doubt.. Considering the relatively smaller area it was built upon - the space was optimally utilized. There is nothing special about the house though which makes it a "must see" or "one of the best attractions in Barcelona".. I mean its nice but it was built in 1896 - when many of today's modern construction technologies were available . The house was built for a millionaire so budget too was not a problem.. The wood work, layout etc are all nice but not spectacular. I paid 12 Euros to see Palace of Versailles in France which really was awesome and I paid the same amount for Guel's house which was nothing out of the ordinary. Go there if you have 12 extra Euros and an hour and a half to kill or you are really into finer details of architecture or you love Gaudi otherwise you can afford to give it a miss.

Gaudi's best 👌. I've been to Palau Güell,Sagrada Familia, Casa Batllo and Casa Mila(La pedrera) during my trip to Barcelona but certainly The Güell Palace was the one I liked the most although it's not popular as the other two but its rooftop was my favourite one.I haven't had enough of the roof; I kept admiring the chimneys for so long, their colours and the different designs were brilliant and breath-takingThe interior design of the Palace itself was amazing and I could stay in some rooms for more than 10 minutes just admiring the walls and the ceilingMy whole experience in Palau Güell is interesting, unforgettable and simply Perfect!! :D If I had more time I wouldn't mind paying it another visit.

best of all the Guell attractions!!. wonderful- we loved it very very much!! few days later we went to Casa Batio and were very disapointed. this is highly recommended- every small detail in the palace has huge thought into it, it's beautifull with lots of different designs- it's much cheaper than the other Guell attractions and we thought it was th best one

Don't miss this !. This is in a side street just of the Ramblas.Well worth a visit if you're interested in architecture.Really fantastic and while Barcelona was very busy there weren't that many people going round.Absolutely fascinating and the audio system was informative and didn't go on too much.Entrance price was reasonable as well.

Beautifull. These house is amazing! First is one of the first things Gaudi made and he didn't look at dispenses. Second almost no comum tourist know about it so is less crowed. Third is much less than 20€.

Rich and beautiful. My favorite Gaudi building!. The Palau Güell is a mansion designed by the architect Antoni Gaudí for the industrial tycoon Eusebi Güell, and built between 1886 and 1888. Rich detailing and lavish materials make up the interior of this city house. It's fascinating to see the quarters where the Guell family lived, and particularly fun to see the fanciful rooftop ornamentations that are so uniquely Gaudi in style. While Sagrad Familia is over-the-top, this beautiful home is very rich and understated.
Try not to miss this. Amazing visit. The house where Gaudi lived is a must see. A quiet stroll round the gardens is even better when you hear the Spanish guitarists.

House filled with wonders. Palau Guell is filled with wonders - the building is quite small from the street, but once you are in, it is surprisingly spacious. Gaudi played with light and shadow and created a masterpiece of architecture that is unique and intriguing and a must to see once in Barcelona. Roof top features are as amazing as the inside of the house, and it is walking distance from Las Ramblas.
Beautiful house. This was stunning! The outside is just a taster of the inside! It's breathtaking and the roof is stunning not just for the view!

Historically and aesthetically a wonder to see. Must see landmark giving insight into Gaudi's career and his links with Guelli who at one time was one of the wealthiest men in the world. Architecturally this was inspiring especially the design of the chapel and the musicians' gallery. Fascinating.

Art Espania. We just loved this.Tottering around the roof top overlooking the City, this was some crazy looking building and typical of the man himself. The visit was free and is a must for anyone visiting Barcelona, even if you are not a Gaudi fan.

Worth a visit. This attraction is the house that Gaudi designed for his long-time patron, Eusebi Guell. It is located just off La Rambla and is worth a visit to get a flavour of Gaudi. I had visited another Gaudi attraction, Casa Mila, on a previous visit, and would definitely say that Palau Guell was better (and cheaper!).You get an audio tour handset upon entrance, and this provides you with loads of information about the building, pointing out unique and special features. The tour winds around the building, taking in the beautiful dome, and leads you out onto the roof space with the famous chimneys, as well as good views of the surrounding area. The audio guide allows you to get the most of your visit, as otherwise you would miss out on the details of the building. There is the obligatory gift shop at the end, as well as storage lockers and toilets in the basement and up in the attic.

Stunning chimneys. This was one of Gaudi's earlier works and not as exciting as some of his later buildings but there are some beautiful ceilings and the organ playing was lovely. The chimneys on the roof were the real highlight and this was a much cheaper attraction than some of the other Gaudi ones. We were told when we entered that the roof was closed because it has rained but as soon as the sun came out they opened it up and we were so pleased that they had - thank you.

Worth the visit if expectations are in line!. We stopped here as a must see, Antoni Gaudí has such an impact on this city, we tried to take in as many of his marvels as possible. Walk in and enjoy the architecture and age old design. Try to think back to when horse drawn carriage entered, people walked up the marvellous stair case and entertained in the grand hall. So many awesome little features, take the time to finish off on the roof for some good pictures and views.

Amazing . Palau Guell is a must for anyone visiting Barcelona. It is in las Ramblas and is truly magnificent. Make sure it is not a rainy day so that you can go on the roof. Words cannot describe how beautiful it is
Palau Guell. The Palau Güell is a mansion designed by the architect Antoni Gaudí for the industrial tycoon Eusebi Güell, and built between 1886 and 1888.

Lovely park. We visited Palau Guell as part of an organised tour, so had skip the line tickets and learned the interesting history of the place. It is worth visiting, not only to see the Gaudi designs, but also to walk and pass some time in the park, which would be a great spot for a picnic.

Best Gaudi house to visit.. For us the most interesting building. Both on the architectural site, and on the engineering side. Audio guide was interesting and the price was fair compared to the others.

Amazing!. Palau Guell is an incredible example of the early Gaudi genius in a hidden place near Ramblas.Inside is a continue discover of precipus details and well studied combination of materials, design and craft. The old Guell family house is a clear example of mecenatism in form of architectural free development for an unique private house use. From cellars to roof! Don't loose it.
For Gaudí's lovers. If you live Gaudí you need to visit this building, too. Very beautiful and different from his other famous ones.

The work of Gaudi is a must see in Barcelona. It is a must to see the work of Gaudi when you visit Barcelona. You can walk to most places, lift your arm and stop a Taxi or use the touristic bus to stop where you want.

Free tickets on a Sunday!. We read that there were free tickets available on a Sunday between 5-8pm. We went about 16.15 and there was already quite a large queue. At 5pm they open the ticket office and begin giving out timed entry tickets. We got entry for 17.45. This was fine as we had an ice lolly on la Ramblas and walked back down. The house itself was really interesting. Not quite as colourful as the bone house but you could see where Gaudi began. Audio guide is brilliant. The roof is the best part with all the great chimneys.Well worth a visit - arrive early for the free tickets.

Fascinating. What an interesting place - a good hour of history, beautiful architecture furniture art. Look out for the sneaky wooden cats in the furniture ready to mouse pounce. Excellent audio visual to give you a thorough understanding of this remarkable building, its owner and of course Gaudi! Only poor thing was the rude security guys who contrasted with the friendly female staff.
Barcelona Highlight. Designed by Gaudi as a private residence overlooking the city, a very interesting set up with some unusual columns.
Landmark of Barcelona. It was worth the admission to see the insane design of this palace. This is one of the major landmarks in Barcelona and I would not miss it!
Fascinating experience. Worth a visit especially if you enjoy architecture & design. The apartment is fascinating but the rooftop is a must.
Impressive.. It explains how Gaudi came up with the Sagrada Familia architecture. It's like an open air museum. Just make sure to take the bus instead of the metro to avoid tiring flights of stairs.

Astoundingly Ahead of it's Time. Pretty much a must see in my book. While not an enormous Gaudi fan, the man was so far ahead of his time he is still challenging, asthetically. Beautiful surfaces, design motifs and facinating elements. More than worth a walk thru.
The tile and the use of teacups in the buildings was phenominal.. This was by far my favorite on the tour. It was like being in a book by Dr. Suess. I would go again.

One of the best in BCN. This Gaudi masterpiece has been exquisitely restored and been open to the public since 2011. It is breathtaking inside and visitors get to visit almost the whole vast building. I was there for about 1 1/2 hours and was enthralled.
