Quite Different!. Just observed from outside as lines were too long of a wait for our group of elderly ... what a crazy artsy design and style!

Beautiful funky architecture. The term funky emerged well after the period of the architect Gaudi but certainly applies well to his unique innovative style. He creates forms that seem more human and are very colourful. Well worth a visit.

Don't Miss This Visionary's Work!. Antonio Gaudi died in the streets of Barcelona. He collapsed and was so poorly dressed he was thought to be a beggar. Everyone ignored him. Had he gotten help sooner, this visionary, architect, creator may have lived to make another breakthrough. He was the first person to "recycle" using pieces of broken pottery in his fantastic architectural designs. He manifested visions of organic buildings the likes of which no one has seen before or since. Begin in 1852, Gaudi's masterpiece, Sagrada Famiglia, is expected to be a church completed in 2026....maybe!

Art Nouveau and Gaudi unite. An interesting view of domestic architecture in the Art Nouveau style. It feels harder and starker than his other Barcelona masterpieces and for that, it is unique to see. Ironwork is quite fanciful and once again, light pervades.
A must visit attraction. Well worth a visit. We didn't need to book although I believe it can be busy at time. The roof is fabulous

Can be skipped if you are tight on time. The least favorite of the Gaudi tours/experiences. It is more gothic and I believe his first commission. It interesting to see the house and furniture, but if you only have a few days, this should be skipped for the other great works and Picasso museum.
I think it is a place where shriek might live!!!!. Not my style but very interesting large crowds and helpful audio guideThe woodwork and craftsmanship are second to none

Don't Miss!. From the moment you enter untill the moment you leave you breath will be taken away. Excelent service, you will recieve an audio guide which is extreamly well organized and very well planed. The details are fantastic. Yet another Gaudi geniusness!

One of the best examples of Gaudi's work. With a long time interest in architecture Gaudi is a must in Barcelona. This is a building I had not visited in my prior trips and what a treat it is. The organic nature in his work is exemplified in every room from top to bottom. The tile work is beautiful and his mottled glass created a obscure lense to see it through. Were I to recommend just one Gaudi building beside Sagrada Familia this would have to be it!

Arrive early to miss the queues and make more of your visit. This is without doubt a highlight of any Barcelona visit. Arrive early to avoid the queues and get to spend time listening to the audio and reading the detail on this unique building. Well worth spending your time and money on this visit.

Great Self-Guided Tour. Wonderful self-guided tour of the beautiful building. Make sure to buy tickets in advance to avoid the long lines to get in. You can just show the receipt from your cell phone.
Gaudi first- worth a visit. Gaudi the master architecture, colorful naughtiness, just visually stunning, exploding your senses, worth a visit.

Lovely Gaudi building, less well known. This is one of Gaudi's earlier works. It is not nearly as flamboyant as places like Casa Batlo, but it has the same intense attention to detail and you can see the genesis of some of his style trademarks at this site. We stumbled upon this in a quest for other Gaudi buildings, since we had already been to the "big 3" last year. As with the others, book your tickets online ahead of time so you don't spend your day waiting for tickets. First thing in the morning is best.

Gaudi's 1st commission - well worth seeing to compare to his later works. It was brilliant to see Gaudi's first commission - still a totally radical design but a different feel to Casa Mila and Casa Batllo which came later in his career. Fantastic use of limited space and a real insight into the Guell family (Gaudi's main benefactors).
A fine piece of art. This 'house' where a family really lived in is gorgeous to see. What a wonderfull architect Gaudi was !
See if you have time.. Nice but over rated. I believe there are nicer places to see in Barcelona if you are pressed for time.

See the chimneys!. Not everyone seems to know about this one but it is a must-see for all Gaudi fans. The chimneys at the top are undoubtedly the best bit. We were told to get here early but it really didn't matter when we went, was no queue. Luck of the draw I think.
Iconic part of the city. stunning architecture. I love simply walking around here and do some great people watching. a truly iconic part of the city.

Amazing Gaudi without the queues. What an astonishing gem this is just off the crowded Ramblas!Amazing considering how Gaudi has been so exploited and discovered that this masterpiece is not too crowded. It has been lovingly restored. The audio guide is excellent alsoDon't miss it but keep it secret!

Always an amazing place to visit. Always an amazing place to visit. The architecture has inspired so many others that it is great to see the original. The buildings often seem to be alive, the way they have such organic forms. If you like Guadi at all, make sure you visit
Mommy and daughter. Excellent! you cannot miss this sight! It is amazing, Mr. Guell was brilliant! Now, buy tickets online straight from their website!

Worthwhile. It was raining the time I went, but it still had an interesting view and if the day was better as most days I am quite sure, picnic outdoors would be a great event. And the architecture and design were beautiful

Palau Guell. I have been to Barcelona many times but visited Palau Guell for the first time as it had been closed for restoration. This is what Gaudi designed before other places so even though the decor showed some organic qualities which Gaudi is famous for, was more traditional and was very interesting to compare it with other Gaudi houses, such as Casa Batillo.

Gaudi's. First of all, buy your tickets online. They have an especific time to get in. So, it's better pick a time not so early, because there is a park that you can walk around for free.Go there, have a walk and then get in on time to see Gaudi bench and Gaudi's house.

No line up. We were advised to visit by our walking tour guide. The audio tour is interesting and the admission fee is reasonable. Unfortunately the roof top was closed due to the rain. Definitely a must see.

Well worth a visit. It's so different it's great, the designer was certainly from another time. I didn't think I would get much out of the visit but with a good tour guide I found it extremely interesting.
Worth it. Very pretty area to explore. Takes a lot of time, but definitely worth it if you are interested in the architecture.

Another planet. If you want to feel like you're on another planet, this is the place to stop. Haha. A great visit and a interesting but of design. This was my introduction to Gaudi and I loved it. Worth the time.
Goudi. All Goudi establishments are worth viewing since each one is different from the last. These are good buildings for retired Architects to view.
Got to do in Barcelona. Be sure to "skip the lines" and tapa is amazing, we recommend Tapa Tapa! Do the "Barcelona Artistic Tour" with Julia. We cannot recommend it more highly.

So much more than expected!. I visited Palau Guell on the same day I visited Park Guell, and was amazed once more. this building had so much more than it looked outside. So many rooms, and so many things compiled in such small space. audio guide tour is must-do!
Gaudi!. We were not able to spend much time here, but it is a great sample of Gaudi's work and style. A great stop for architectural enthusiasts and non-enthusiasts alike!

Palácio Güell. The Palau Güell is designed by the architect Antoni Gaudí for the industrial tycoon Eusebi Güell, and built between 1886 and 1888. It is situated in the Carrer Nou de la Rambla. It is part of the UNESCO World Heritage.The home is centered on a main room for entertaining high society guests. Guests entered the home in horse-drawn carriages through the front iron gates, which featured a parabolic arch and intricate patterns of forged iron-work resembling seaweed and in some parts a horsewhip. Animals could be taken down a ramp and kept in the livery stable in the basement where the servants resided, while the guests went up the stairs to the receiving room.

If you love Gaudi, don't miss this gem. How often do you see a palace built in the middle of an urban neighborhood? The irony of the opulence of this inner city mansion designed by the famed architect Gaudi for the wealthy Guell family in the late 19th century literally next to small urban 21st century dwellings, with laundry hanging on their balconies, was not lost on us, but also didn't ruin the experience of seeing this architectural gem.This house is just amazing. The price of admission includes an audio tour that explains a tremendous amount about the construction and architecture of this amazing residence, which we Learned Senora Guell never liked and their family only lived in briefly before Señor Guell passed away.Be sure to make it all the way up to the roof, to see the brilliant Gaudi rooftop ornaments which are so colorful and original. Also, on he way out, note the think wrought iron gates that lead to the street that Gaudi has twisted in such a fashion that people on the inside can see out to the street, but not vice versa. We are not the types to go crazy over urban architecture - this was something special and well worth a 90 minute visit.

Last of Gaudi's works for us. Not far from La Rambla - it was the last Gaudi's site for us in Barcelona on our trip, so we remember it best. And maybe this is why we take it as the top site of them all. Long queues at ticket box prevented us from visiting this place on Sunday, on Monday Palau is closed. Definitely would recommend buying tickets online. Same inside as other Gaudi's works, fancy little chimneys on roof. The tour takes you to all floors right from the basement to the roof. On some floors small expositions of early 20th century life.

Don't miss this Gaudi building. It is situated a bit off the main track (la Rambla) and you could easily miss this building. We found it AS good as La Pedrera. and not as crowded. A great example of Gaudi's genius!

A must see!. Unbelievable, it's amazing how someone could even envision such an image. That said... the work and time this took makes it impossible to come up with an excuse to not visit! A total lifetime MUST SEE!
Has to be done. Remember to book tickets beforehand or risk queuing for hours, toilet facilities are poor, but it is a must do in Barcelona.
Barcelona Top 5. This was a highlight of our first trip to Barcelona! So fascinating, so different, so memorable! We loved the architecture, and the detailed models.

Beautiful and relaxing. Do not miss it. And go at the end of the day, when is not so hot and crowdy. It's a very relaxing place to spend the end of the afternoon appreciating another great art work of Gaudi.
Small fairy tale world. Well Gaudi was totally mad and probably took many drugs. Cause otherwise have no other explanation that someone can be so creative and build something like this.

Superb. It was a bit of a struggle to get to Palau Guell by public transport but we then realised that there was an easier way to get to it so be careful when planning your directions. Arriving to Palau Guell it was worth all the hassle. It was beautiful and a nice way to spend the morning. One down side was that the guy at the booth ticket was making us hurry to go inside and he didn't even let us use the bathroom because of the hurry he was in!

Good, but other Gaudi work is more magical. Having visited Casa Batllo on a previous visit to Barcelona we didn't feel that this had quite the same magic. They control the number of people who enter well so it doesn't feel crowded, and it was good value for money. We had a 30 minute return time after ticket purchase, which was acceptable. We felt the audio guide was quite dry, worth a visit if you are really into Gaudi's work, but otherwise try Casa Batllo first.
Nothing special. By tickets before you visit or else you will wait for a long time. We waited 3 hours to enter. Was rather disappointed after so long a wait.

Went in just to see.... ...and was blown away! Amazing architecture, art and furniture. Never had I thought it would be this cool inside. Lots of things to see, and lots of history. Get the audio guide. Well worth the ticket!

Impressive roof top. This place is such a gem. This is where the Gaudi family lived and is very rich in architecture. We went on a Sunday afternoon as they give free admission tickets so that was really positive.
Rooftop art.... It is a building with the unique architecture of Gaudi (the Sagrada familia Odd human like creatures are the airvents. Very interesting place to visit. Great example of his work.

Lovely house. This is the house of the Guell family that was designed by Gaudi, NOT the park!! I went early in the morning and there was no queue, but at other points of the day it was very busy. Go early or else pre-book!It was lovely inside, the attention to detail was outstanding! Well worth a look!

Great Gaudi at a domestic level. Beautiful and original detail everywhere you look. Innovative architectural solutions. Don't miss the roof chimneys. The explanations are interesting in the audio. A wow experience.
Book in advance! . We spent the best part of half a day cuing to get in here and whilst it is worth a visit we wished we had pre booked so we could have spent our time more wisely!
This is not Park guell!. So many reviews about Park guell here. This is Palau guell, a place designed by gaudi just off las rambles not the park!!
I just love anything that was designed by Gaudi. I just love anything that was designed by Gaudi. Palau Guell is amazing and if you are visiting Barcelona then it's a must to go and see.

Dark and Fascinating for a Gaudi Home. Hard to believe this is Gaudi architecture, but in a good way. Very dark with a medieval feel. While touring the home, you must look up, down, left and right so as to not miss anything. The ceilings alone are amazing. Fascinating that the ramp inside going down is where they would keep the animals at night.

A gem of architecture . This was a really beautiful palace. It is really amazing if you like art nuveau. There were no crowds when we visited and the audio guide was very useful. Costs half of other places and is an incredible place.

Informative and interesting. We did not see the other Gaudi house, so I can't compare it, but we felt Palau Guell in itself was enough. The self-guided tour was informative and not crowded because they limit the number of people allowed in at a time. You get to see the wild roof top, a mini-museum on Gaudi in the attic and an apartment furnished as it would have been in Gaudi's time. The history was dry (no old gossip). We also went on an architectural tour (separately) where we learned the wife of the Palau Guell didn't like the house and refused to move into it until after Gaudi's death.

Palau Guell not Park Guell. As others have noted, this is Palau Guell, the building located in the old city, not Park Guell. It seems Palau Guell is less frequently visited, but I highly recommend it. The woodwork throughout -especially the ceilings- is breathtaking. Don't miss it!

Go Go Gooooo! . If you are in Barcelona you have to go and see it. It is lovely to see how the palace is built in a practical way. The place is mostly self- explanatory and the audio guide helps you notice small and interesting details you wouldn't have noticed if you weren't listening.I'm impressed by how Gaudi made his own ventilation system and by how the great hall has great acoustic sound. Arrows and numbers guide you around the place and it is an approximately 1 hour long visit.Thank you,julie
need pre-reservation. Depending on the season, this place can be very busy. I recommend future visitors to make a reservation prior to the visit.

Nice place but not on my top list. It is a really cool place first because of its location, where you can get a cool view of the city (there are better ones, though), and of course because of the history and uniqueness of Gaudi. But I wouldn't say that this is the coolest place in Barcelona. It is culturally nice to see it but I wouldn't pay it again

Really inspiring worth visiting. I was leaving nearby but never bother to visit it. I just thought that 12 euro is too much for something that is not that well advertised. So I went on the first Sunday of the month when it was free from 5 to 7 and I was completely impressed! It is around one hour visit, the audio guide is included for free and it's really useful. The palace itself is amazing, the rooftop has a nice view for pictures as well. Now I definitely think it's worth the price!

If you have time, this is a good start to seeing Gaudi's work.. This is one of Gaudi's first works, so it's very interesting to see in comparison with his other buildings. BTW, this is not the park. It's not far from Casa Batllo, where there was a major line, so we went here instead. There was no line when we went in the late afternoon, a couple of hours before closing, and we got to see the playful roof just as the sun was getting low in the sky. The audio guide was very informative and worth it. Seeing this house first gave us a good foundation for seeing Gaudi's other work.

Amazing. An unique experience, as it is with every Gaudi building. You get lost in the intricate and fluid columns, stairs that seem to fall rather than lead and the frightening attention for detail. I cannot wait to go back.

Excellent Visit. What an excellent house (mansion) to visit. We fully enjoyed our time there. You can easily two to three hours there. Everything is beautiful, from the below ground level to the roof.
Straight out of a fairy tale book.. This place took us back to Hansel & Gretel days. The beautiful garden and terrace with a breathtaking view was the highlight of the place.

An amazing building. This is an amazing building. You do not have to be a Gaudi or architecture fan to visit. Just go and wonder at the amazing creativity. We booked tickets online - all very easy and straightforward. No queuing and very helpful staff. We went as soon as it opened and this was a great time to visit as we avoided huge crowds.
Colorful. You have to stop here, is like another planet, the architecture is amazing and colorful . Guell was a genius.

Palau Guell.. Must see if a Gaudi fan .Well maintained and doesn't take too long to explore. Attention to detail and imagination really fascinating. Easy to get to as just off the Ramblas. Closest metro stop is Drassanes I believe.

Another Gaudy masterpiece. Buy front of line tickets with the audio guide. An amazing masterpiece. This man knew how to turn heads. Staff were very helpful and friendly running around making sure you had everything and were going in the right direction. All we did was show the pass.

Well worth a visit, weird constructions but very creative. This place is well worth a visit, full of weird constructions but very creative.Loved the way the architect recycled old materials in his finishing of his creations and the way nothing is straight.

A not so ordinary structure. To experience the true beauty of Spain one must visit here. The architecture is very original and at first look does not appeal... Only when one has a closer look one is able to appreciate the work behind the structure

Nice and interesting after a great lunch. Well restored after hard times during the Franco years, this house was even more interesting than La Pedrera but less than the Batilo house.Especially interesting are the basement and the main reception room. Can be visited within 2 hours and there does not seem to be any line ups. We visited it early afternoon after a very nice lunch on Plaza Real at Quinze nits. The free audio guide was well done and helped us through this visit of many rooms and floors up to the spectacular roof overseeing the Gothic quarter
Genius with a whimsical vision. Delightful and a sure need to see! Plan ahead as they only allow so many in then it goes to a time slot system. We went at a very busy time and did not make it in.
must do if an architecture buff.. great place to visit just book online for early in the morning so as to avoid the hordes. interior is as good as the outside the better gaudi house.

A must see for anyone interested in Gaudi. We visited the palace and found it to be a fascinating example of Gaudi's work. It has been beautifully restored by the city. The attention to even the finest detail is fantastic. The audio guide is included in the entry price and explains the features in each room. It is very well worth the cost although is more suited to older children with broader interests.

Gaudi is a most, everything builing of his.. You must see everything that has Gaudi in it! The buildings, the park, Sagrada familia, etc. Make sure you have tickets ahead of time, you can buy them on the internet. Otherwise you may not be able to get in. You can always vivit the outside of the park Guell.

Palau Guel. Wonderful fantastic imaginative architecture at it's best. Wondering around the your mind expands in positive impressive ways which provide childlike fantasy in enjoying the inventiveness.

Sorry but personally wouldn't recommend . There's enough Gaudi and Gaudi inspired to see in the rest of Barcelona unless you love the stuff!It was smaller and less park like than I imagined. It was also far out for us and I personally would not go again or recommend. After an hour of waiting around in heavy rain with very little shelter, a total 30 mins of that queuing we were only there for 40 minutes or so.

Yet another Gaudí masterpiece. Less grand than some of his other creations, the city dwelling that Gaudí designed for his mentor's family provides yet another example of the architect's artistic genius and eye for detail and functionality, as well as a window into the everyday life of Barcelona's wealthy bourgeoisie. The explanations of the audio-guide are very helpful, providing historical background and drawing attention to important details and materials used in the construction. The chimneys are superb, as are the vistas from the roof. Certainly a fascinating visit!
Gaudi's splendour. Anything built by Gaudi is fascinating and well worth a visit.He was an architect of great design and one marvels at his work
Worth Seeing. A clear example of Gaudi's early works, maybe not as matured as his later works but still showing his genius. Worth a visit
A different type of Concept, Idea & Design. Did a walking tour which was really helpful in understanding the idea behind building the development. Truly amazing!!

Stunning and totally different design. I had walked by this place tons of times but I had the fortune of visiting a day without too many fellow tourists and therefore had time to look at all the small details in this awesome house. Just imagining the thoughts and the efforts in building this remarkable house is mind blowing. The rooms are almost to special to imagine that someone actually were living in this house. The house is a living experiment of what a free mind can do - some rooms were too dark for my mood but when you enter the roof and the colorful design up there you suddenly don't want to leave. If I had been brought up in a house like this I would have spent all my time there. It is just an amazing place.
A must see. An awesome experience . I would recommend to buy the tour book before hand so then you know exactly what is what . There's so much to see and understand each piece of design
Interesting Gaudi architecture. Interesting place, especially if you are in to Gaudi. In peak season, get your tickets ahead of time or be prepared to wait 2 hours before you get in.

The roof is the best part. This speciman of Gaudi's domestic architecture is worth seeing. It's tucked off the Rambla just south of the Opera House. It costs 12 euro to go in, but the roof view of Barcelona is fantastic and you get to be up close to Gaudi's tiled turrets.
Must see!. Love this place, it almost seems surreal when standing up there looking down at the spectacular architecture. We took a tour that this was included in and the entire tour enjoyed it.
The architecture and layout is amazing. very interesting to visit Gaudi's Park Guell, amazing sights and architecture. We toured with Barcelona Day Tours and our guide Marta was wonderful

MUST SEE - on everybodys list. MUST BE VISITED! something so amazing everybody has to visit it. Book half of the day to have possibiloity to taste and feel the atmosphere of this place, and not only run through it,

i just love the gaudi works!. I love the Gaudi works. And Guell Palace is no other. I arrived a bit in the afternoon and there was no line and easy to take tickets and visit without a lot of other people. If possible buy tickets online in advance.
Fantastical!. How could you not love this place? Every inch is a little piece of art! Learn a little about it before going to fully appreciate it while you are there.

Good place to visit Gaudi's earlier work, but pales in comparison to the church, casa Batllo or the Park. . If you have extra time, yes, go have a look at the palace, but don't expect works of later Gaudi like the park, church, or Casa Batllo.
Although this palace pales in comparison to his later works, it's still impressive.
If you can, book tickets online and save yourself the hassle of waiting in line.
Worth a visit. The palace doesn't appear to be as prominent amongst barcelona's sights to visit, but it really is a hidden jem and well worth visiting.

Why don't more people visit this place?. We sort of stumbled across Palau Guell while wandering La Rambla. There was very little activity out front, so we weren't sure it was open. It was open, and unlike every other place in Barcelona, we almost had the place to ourselves. This was Gaudi's first real commission, and seeing the evolution of his genius was really amazing. Plus we were treated to an organ concert in the middle of the tour! Visiting the roof with the amazing Gaudi chimneys was worth the admission price alone. The audio guide was a bit comprehensive for my taste, but others may enjoy that level of detail.

great (not the hill). ok so let me start by say the hill i had to face to get to the top was not great (trust me!). when i got to the top the view that i got was well worth it, also inside was amazing all the mosaics and and buildings around the place was also great t look at.

a must see. this was next to our appartment and we initialy did not wanted to visit it but since we had some time we decided to visit and it is realy a very nice building. same architect as the sagrada familia. a must see

A must see in Barcelona. The garden is so beautiful, and extreme. It is no way to visit Barcelona without visit the garden and enjoy the art, beauty, the atmosphere and hopefully ... good weather. It can be a little crowdy, and since they began to limit the access - you could have to wait until you can access (we waited for 1 1/2 hour after we bought the tickets)

Breath taking views. Our hotel booked on line for us which was great and we saving a 1 Euro per ticket - it was nice not having to line up to purchase the tickets when we got there. Lovely views of Barca from the top and we really enjoyed looking at another creation from Gaudi
You can't miss this. Loved it! It was exactly as I was imagining and a little more. You cannot miss this attraction while in Barcelona.
interesting & informative. not too overpriced for a change and was very informative , with an audio tour explaining the different features

What a house/Palace. From the stable to roof top chimney, every where you will see the natural theme of Gaudi. You will be impressed to see how detail an architect can think when he built this palace. Each room is something special. This is a real art piece and very well maintained museum.

Really impressive work of Antoni Gaudi. If you're in Barcelona and you're interested in architecture, then the Guell Palace is a must on your check list. It will easily take about 2 hours to explore it in detail, but it is worth the time.

Very Unique and Fascinating. A small group of us visited with our guide. Saudi was definitely out there with his artistic ability, but what a unique way to look at the world. His tile work is unbelievable! In addition, his caring for animals so that they could get shade from the sun was very interesting to me. Even though Gaudi's style isn't my style, I still have a great appreciation for his philosophy and how he developed such interesting buildings with his art. He is in a class by himself!
I tried 2 times to get there, my third attempt was lucky. Impressive, really differs from other Gaudi works, unfortunately no audoguide in Russian. Tichet price 12 euros, childen free

Amazing building. A lot of people have written about Parc Guell on here which is really confusing as this is for Palau Guell which is completely different. This is a building off las ramblas with an amazing roof terrace with differently designed chimneys. Beautiful inside and out and the free audioguide tells you so much about the history. Well worth a visit.

magnifico! enjoyable,agreeable space in the hert of a beatuiful city. this can be reached on foot, bus, or hop on off. this is a mansion built by Gaudi for the family named Guell. it is a "palace" that is what palau means. when commissioned the request was to distinguish the place from every other wealthy family, and there is no question this was achieved.the manipulation of space, angles, curves is voluptuous, sumptuous and worth enjoying. if enjoying architecture is your thang.

Many photo opportunities. We took the bus and it stopped directly in front of one of the entrances. There are at least 2 other entrances to the park depending on the transportation you take. We booked on line but still had to exchange the on line ticket with a real tickets because they could not scan it. Once inside, the building and the view provide a lot of backdrop for nice pictures. It is an interesting place to visit even before you go to the Sagrada de la familia to understand a little bit the background of Gaudi.

Great tour with our guide...a real look at a "regular" Gaudi building.. The last private building built by Gaudi, it's truly amazing to tour. Definitely worth the added cost of having a private guide since the story of the building and it's current status is best when explained. The views from the roof are spectacular. Be sure to wear your walking shoes.

Interesting contrast to other Gaudi buildings. Very different to the other Gaudi houses - Casa Batlo, Casa Mila. Lovely architecture, not entirely to my taste but interesting to see none the less. As ever with Gaudi, the roof is the best bit - that man and his chimneys!!!

Another Gaudi attraction. Park designed by famed Barcelona architect Gaudi. Unlike anything you have seen before. The creativity, and imagination of this man is remarkable. Get a guided tour or read up before. This mans association with nature and his creativity is something to marvel. Be prepared to walk. A must attraction when visiting Barcelona

Would have been nice if we could have gotten tickets. We were not able to get in because we did not realize you need to get advance tickets to get in. We did the hop on hop off bus which drops you at the bottom of a huge hill and you need to walk about a 1/2 mile up the hill to get to the attraction. Once there they will let you know when the next showing is. Unfortunately it happened to be at the same time our tickets were for the sagrada familia. It looked beautiful from the outside but we would have loved to see the inside. They need to mention the attractions that need advance tickets in the brochure for the hop on hop off bus because maybe people would think twice before attempting to waste their time rushing to get to an attraction that they may not get tickets too especially with the traffic.
Fascinating architecture. Cannot be beat for interesting design and architecture. Check this out for Catalan features and design that rivals Dr. Seuss.
Nice attraction. Nice walk around. Great view from the hill above on the city. Another Gaudi masterpiece. Lot of tourists.

Lovely to stroll around. well worth a visit even if you only go into the free park. Lots to see and great views. It is part of the hop on hop of bus route (red or blue can't remember which one as we used both)

A hidden gem . Blink and you'll miss it! The tour is really interesting. I went first thing in the morning and got tickets the morning of with no wait in the middle of July! Please note the majority of this tour has no ac, and it was very hot in the lower floors. As you ascended the higher floors were much cooler. Worth the visit, and don't go Mondays... They are closed.
A Must See In Barcelona. A gorgeous work of art...we had a great day here...so much to see and learn...He was a master artist and has a facinating history.

Wish I would have gone. We were walking Carrer Nou de la Rambla and went by to see the exterior. Loved looking at the ironwork and the gates. However we were busy and had only bought tickets to La Pedrera. When we took our Gaudi tour of Park Guell and Sagrada Familia ended, the guy only recommended two Gaudi homes, La Pedrera and Guell Palace. The reason for this site was that Guadi had not determined his style until after this building. Talking to people,going now, I totally recommend they go to see the interior of this building. Really enjoyed seeing the homes and buildings of Gaudi.

A Square Gaudi!!. For me, this building has a very different feel to it compared to other houses by Gaudi. I think that is mainly because it is very 'straight edged' with squares and rectangles. It reminded me very much of the interior of a mediaeval manor house in England with its ornate wooden ceilings and wood panelling.The main staircase is very impressive as is the main hall; a multi use space!The roof is very much Gaudi with ornate chimney pots. I much preferred Casa Batllo!!

Like a Fairy Tale Land. The time and effort to create this park is incredible. Way ahead of his time, Antoni Gaudi was a genius! We went with a Barcelona day tour, skipped the line and got right in. Tour guide explained all the history.....it's the best way to go!

Fascinating and Beautiful. Though smallish allow yourself hours to go round. As a wheelchair user access although challenging turned out to be OK. The staff were very helpful and kind in this regard. The Palau is a jewel in the heart of the town and not to be missed.

Not as impressed as others. You should absolutely buy your tickets in advance during high season to skip the lines! After going to Casa Batllo, I was underwhelmed by Park Guell. I felt there wasn't much to it.

There are no words. This was the first Gaudi piece I saw and I think for that reason will be the most striking. It also feels much more personal than Sagrada Familia which is heavy with the weight on the genius behind it.

A few things to keep in mind.. If you can't buy tickets online for the specified time, arrive super early to get them, especially if you want to do something else that day. Otherwise expect to spend your whole day waiting in line. For all the "only" English speaking visitors, keep in mind, there are no English signs. We didn't expect everyone and everywhere to speak English, and brushed up on our Spanish (Except that they speak Catalan... ) but for a major tourist attraction, we did expect some signs in English. But thankfully, the people working there had a grasp on English and were able to advise, and if not, then point to someone who could. As a whole, the park is nice, its huge and one could get lost before getting to the beautiful parts.

Long queues. We visited on a hot sunny day and had to wait for 2 hours to get in. Once we finally got in it was over in a short time. Although the tiles are amazing I don't think that the wait was worth it! An expensive mistake

Average. We booked tickets on line mosaic part. Was really average. Lack of washrooms is not acceptable. Looks nice but would not recommend. We used bus 116 to get there it dropped us right by the entrance. It's a big walk from metro( 700m) up the hill.

Wacky and interesting. My kid said it was neat, I thought buildings is was a bit wacky and weird again Goudi was a bit ahed of his time, prehistoric rock type buildings that look like space ships...but overall beautiful gardens

Another architectural masterpiece by Gaudi. The mansion itself is fantastic. My personal favorites were the horse stables under the Palau with magnificent stone columns and iron basins, and the absolutely incredible mosaic chimneys.

Fun to See!. What a cool place this would have been to live if Gaudi's concept of building a community here materialized! My advice would be to go in the morning if visiting in the summer. There are not a lot of places to escape the heat. The architecture is so much fun to see. You will probably recognize quite a few of the sites from pictures seen over time. It was cool to see them in person. The best part was sitting on the tile benches and taking it all in. It helps that they are cooling. :) Gaudi was true genius!!

The palace is NOT the park - don't confuse the two. Come on TA reviewers, pay attention and post your reviews in the right place. This is the listing for Palau Guell - a fabulous, grand house just off the Ramblas which Gaudi built for Guell and NOT the park in the north east of the city. Roughly 80% of reviews posted on this listing are for the wrong place.Palau Guell is one of the oldest of Gaudi's works and much less well known and well visited than Casa Batllo, La Padrera or the Sagrada Familla. It's on a side street off the lower Ramblas a couple of blocks south of the Liceu theatre. At €12 entrance it's a bargain compared to some of the other Gaudi houses and the lines are short and timed entrance on our tickets was for just 15 minutes later.There was plenty of space inside this extraordinary building and the audio tour was mostly well paced and interesting although repeated requests to look at the screen were a bit silly.The house shows a grandeur that's sometimes missed in the later houses in favour of whimsical and quirky touches. The top floor shows designs you'll recognise in the later houses and the chimneys on the roof show that Gaudi was doing weird stuff with vents long before his more popular buildings.Whilst I was dumbstruck by the architecture, I wasn't surprised to hear that Mrs Guell didn't much like living there.

Gaudi's first commission. It was very informative to see Gaudi's very first construction. The audio tour made all of the difference. My only suggestion would be to have more period furniture but that might be difficult with tourists walking through.

sit on the bench!. gaudi's genius shows in this lively lovely communal space. we kept remarking 'who would have thought?' but gaudi and his investor friends did. i'm so glad we took the trip up the hill to go see this.

Dr Suess!. Step in, and you will be in a world of curls and whirls like no other; it is as iff you live in a Dr. Suess's book. Buy tickets online as the time for visit of the monumnetal site is by reservation only, based on a a half-hour time-table. There are two restaurants, one in the free zone and one in the monumental zone. Shades can be scarce in mid day so take a hat and sunglassess and keep cool and wet at every fountain. You will need separate tickets to visit Gaudi's house.
When money is no object. Traveling though the Palau, you find one magnificent ceiling after another. Beautiful details everywhere. Early Gaudi and interesting when compared with later houses.
Surreal.. What an amazing place. Children and adults alike all seem to be a bit spellbound by the whole experience. It is so good to go somewhere that has no age limits.

Stunning . Gaudi early in his career was so inventive, practical and artistic! He plays with so many materials and forms of art to play with light and privacy. The carriage house & stables are my favorite!
Fantastic!. If you like Gaudi this is a great place to see his work in all it's glory. Steep area so be prepared to walk uphill a lot but so very worthwhile.

Worth a trip.. A fascinating place to visit especially if you are a Gaudi fan. An easy trip on the Metro but be prepared to walk up very steep hill!Public park built into the hillside with fantastic flowers and quite beautiful but almost 'spooky, hobbit' architecture. Buy tickets (timed) in advance online.

A must see but not necessarily for the reasons you might think.... I rated this place 3 stars but I think it is something that visitors to Barcelona should see if they have at least 3-4 days.Let me explain. Gaudi was clearly very creative and thought outside of the box in his design. I don't think his style is always that appealing but this palace of a house is a good example of how he developed his way of thinking about design. And he had great ideas about light that were put to great effect in his Sagrada Familia (which is still under construction many years after his deathThe problem with this house is that they paired an avant garde architect with an obscenely wealthy industrial magnate who wanted no expense spared in the construction of his monument to self. What results is a beautifully wrought but completely over the top example of architectural and design excess. Certain features such as the stable house and the vaulted ceiling in the main hall are clever and visually appealing but numerous little details (overwrought roof with carvings of unique hardwood and pearl inlays, a single room that features stained glass windows depicting Shakespeare characters for some odd reason) indicate to me that this house was really about cramming as much "luxury" into a space as possible, not necessarily in producing something that was aesthetically pleasing let alone tasteful.Some of this might be my own personal architectural biases talking and the work might appeal to many others. The space has been preserved nicely and it is something to see for sure, not like anything else I have ever seen for sure.
Amazing house, not to be missed. Incredible place to visit...what a place it must have been to live. Gaudi's magical touch is everywhere
I've never seen something like this. Great place, unusual. I quite bored attractions in Europe. Usually they look similar but not Palau Guell. During visit of Barcelona, you have to visit this place.
Brilliant. Amazing place and wonderful to view Gaudi's brilliance once again. A must see in Barcelona for everyone.
Gaudi...again!. When I tell you that this man was brilliant...I really mean he was brilliant. You have to see this for yourself!

First major work by the great Gaudi.. One of the first assigments of Gaudi, this former family home is in Nou La Rambla and if you don't look for it you will miss it. Walk down to the ocean in La Rambla to and bring a zoom lens if you want to shoot the roof. I did not inquire about going in to see it since i think is a government office, but not sure.... I just went and shot the roof with my photo lens. another great work by Gaudi.......

A bit confusing to see all that you want to see at this historical site.. The grounds are amazing, the colors are stunning, the artistry not like anything you may have seen. He was way ahead of his time for sure. The managing of the site could be better however. There were lines at different entrance points and it was confusing as to where the best place was to enter to see the entire park. That is the only negative thing I have to say. Otherwise I would recommend that you see this man's incredible architecture at this beautiful park with beautiful views of the city below.
A bit dark and depressing. If this was one of my first stops in Barcelona, I might have been impressed. It is a dark place, with the exception of the roof towers.

AMAZING!. This is one of my favorite places I have visited around the world! The architecture is unique and vibrant! You will never forget the images that will present themselves! Make sure to take your time looking... as there is so much detail- you will be AMAZED!

Wonderful outing. We spent half the morning exploring this delightful park that highlights the work of Gaudi. Do not miss! There is a long walk uphill from the Bus Tourista, and many hills in the park, so if you have mobility issues you may want to take a taxi to the park, and stay in the entry area where you can easily get to the wavy benches, etc.

An artistic surprise right off the La Rambla. This house is situated just near the most crowded street in Barcelona. It is very appealing and interesting, containing many cleverly and beautifully designed rooms. Furthermore, there's a lot to see there. Really recommended to for those wishing to see Gaudi's brilliance in action.

Somewhat Overrated, but worth a look. A day after being stunned by the Sagrada Familia, we visited Gaudi's other lauded design, Park Guell. Unfortunately, it is not quite on par, in my view, with his other creation. The climb is remarkably steep and I do not know how anyone with impaired mobility or a stroller would manage. Perhaps there is a way around that we were not aware of, but as five rather fit people, we were definitely out of breath. I should mention that we went on a very hot day...The park might be nicer if the staff were, too. Instead of being friendly and welcoming, we were told we would have to wait until our turn to enter came. Okay, makes sense, but when we sat down in the only self-service 'cafe', the staff was so rude to us and other patrons, actually patrolling around, making sure we had all purchased something, and speaking not a work of English. This admittedly soured the experience. The architecture and design is nice, but not magnificent. Go to La Sagrada instead if you want to be awed by Gaudi's work.

goudi's benifactorss house. well worth the visit. the area outside the house is busy with pickpockets and drug dealers safe but be carfull. The hotel Goudi oposite give fine view of the roof which is one of the highlights of the house
Gaudy not for us. As per review of Sagrada, same old, same old. Don't like the style, very busy, lots of tour groups etc. Much prettier buildings in many other areas of Barcelona.

wonderful little town castle with all Gaudi details. visiting this town castle will give you full insight in the start of Gaudi's work, a lot of information about his work during his years in Barcelona, and of course, th view over Barcelona from the Gaudi tiled roof. Just wonderful, and absolutely worth the money!
Must see. Gaudi was commissioned to build the house and park, among other places for the Guell family. It's spectacular even by his standards.
WOW!! Someone really live here!. Tremendously interesting interior space and design by Antonio Gaudi. A real example of his genius and not to be missed.

Whimsical. A neat unusual place to visit. The down side--not exactly easy to get to, there really is nothing to do once you get there other than walk around and look at the architecture.
Still the whole family age 10 and up found something neat to see
Would go once. But not a second time

Unique, must see!. It is an impressive park, the name "palace" is justified. The buildings even if not huge they are of unique architecture and style. Garden is very well taken care of and external spaces are also decorated in some parts with the famous Gaudi lizard statues and more. Would reccomend for sure as it is really an one of a kind..
Worth while a visit. Here you will find a small castle designed by Gaudí for his good friend Guell ( one of the most rich persons in the world for that time). We spend like 1 hour on the visit.

Amazing Gaudi. Worth the trip--this Gaudi park is terrific for a sense of his playfulness and vision. Great views from up here as well. A combination of train and bus and you can be dropped off right at the door. Make sure you buy your tickets online ahead of time--waits otherwise can be quite long. The people in front of us in line had waited most of the morning and half the afternoon to get in. We strolled up just a little while before our ticketed time and in we went. Plan ahead for most sights in Barcelona--it'll save you time and money.

spectacular place to spend the day. The park itself is absolutely beautiful, with several places to enjoy lunch. Located on the hill above the city the views are truly breathtaking, and often there is musicians within the park creating a lovely atmosphere.

Must see site of Barcelona. Unique and must see. What an imagination. The shapes and colours of Gaudi will not appeal to everyone, but works for me. The views over Barcelona down to the sea are spectacular. Make sure you book a time in advance. The best ways to get here are either the metro followed by ten-fifteen minute uphill walk or I think the number 24 bus from Catalunta.

Good Views. Do check for tickets prior as during high season tickets for the same timings are not available. We could not go inside but you can climb upto a hill where you enjoy the views of the city and its beautiful. Not many people are aware that you can go there even without a ticket.

Palau Guell is not to be missed - buy tickets ahead of time. The park is amazing - Please note there will be long lines for tickets - get them ahead of time. Also, the house on property tours stop at 8:15 p.m. A fact we were not told when we purchased our tickets or I would have gone there first. The park is beautiful and has spectacular features around every turn. Be sure to stop at the roof top view of hte Ocean while admiring Gaudi's work at this UNESCO World Heritage site.

Not the most breathtaking but the best executed. You know this place might not look as impressive as the other Gaudí monuments, but I have to say that it was by far my favourite. The interiors are very interesting with their use of light and the combination of wood carving and different kinds of stone (multicoloured limestone, marble..). Furthermore in this case, the audio-guide is really worth listening to: the descriptions are detailed, yet not too long and work naturally with the way your tour progresses. The film about Gaudi's and Güell's lives is captivating. And the rooftop terrace breathtaking. Can't wait to come back.

Boring & terribly sign posted . We walked around in 40 degree heat going round & round. We didn't prebook tickets & the queues were crazy. They really should consider a few more sign posts in English. Waste of time.

So Bizarre! I wandered for hours. What a bizarre place and an amazing artist that built it. You absolutely cannot miss Park Guell by Gaudi. For me, the second best thing to see in Barcelona after La Sagrade de Famila. It's just fun wandering around and marvelling at the bizarre structures.

Another Gaudi Masterpiece. I wouldn't rank this a the number place to see Gaudi's work. There are seven properties listed on the UNESCO list: Parque Güell; Palacio Güell; Casa Mila; Casa Vicens; Gaudí’s work on the Nativity façade and Crypt of La Sagrada Familia; Casa Batlló; Crypt in Colonia Güell.
Awesome!. During the summer time the park is free after 9:00pm and it's still plenty of time to enjoy the beauty of this place. The employees were very polite and knew about the story of Gaudi.

Book before you go. I didn't realise I would have to wait 90 minutes to enter the paid bit. It's worth booking on line before you head out on the day you plan to visit. There are big groups of children and tourists. There is no where much to wait.

Overhyped, kind of boring- I can see this being more fun for kids.. We went here after Sagrada Familia with high expectations as it is designed by Gaudi- but to be honest, it was kind of boring and smaller than we expected. If you have extra time, go, but overall not worth the hype.

Colorful roof top chimneys. I see confusion in reviews between Palau Guell (on Rambla) and Park Guell (north west of the city, a bit far from other attractions). Palau Guell has the most colorful roof top chimneys and is well worth a visit, even after seeing Case Batllo and Casa Mila. As most museums, it's closed on Monday.

Beautiful views and Stunning Architecture. Another must see on any trip around Barca. The architecture is strange and feels wonderful to see. The place was clean and although busy, was also relaxing. Plan carefully so you can relax and soak up the free atmosphere and sunshine.

Really interesting to visit - few tourists. Very central near the Rambla
Few tourists - quiet place
Interesting place were Gaudi's dad and Gaudi's sister used to live
Nice architecture

Great place for photos.. Full of wild design and mixtures of color. It is a nice place for photos and so interesting to see. We spent the better part of 2 hours just slowly absorbing all the details. Not a place to see when you are short of time or in a rush if you want to see everything.

great design and very innovation areas. you must read the design idea before you go, otherwise, it's hard for you to understand why Gaudi design something unique. After you understand the design behind, then you will enjoy it and realize we are still very behind him.

Stunning, complex and mind blowing design!. Please do not miss this site when visiting Barcelona! Antonio Gaudi was an amazing architect and Barcelona is filled with his works, but this one in particular is spectacular and mesmerizing. I still can't get my head around the design technique and difficulty of creating this mansion so long ago. The pictures do not do justice to the size and amazing beauty of this palace. It recently reopened after complete renovations and is probably my favorite attraction in Barcelona.

Another of Gaudí's works. A beautiful palace, very close to La Rambla. The visit will cost you 12 euros that will include a self guided tour offered in several languages, set your own pace and enjoy the beautiful rooms, paintings, etc. There is not much furniture but if you like Gaudí's works, you will enjoy it.

Excellent Gaudi building. This building is well worth visiting. It is very different from Gaudi's other buildings and it provides a look at a more traditional building. The interior details are beautiful and show outstanding workmanship.

A must not miss experience.. A long walk from the Metro, and the last bit uphill. The free access parts are infested with bag and trinket sellers, constantly chased by cops on bicycles. The Gaudi sections are a little disappointing, but still very well worth visiting.
great view around BCN, darkest creation of Gaudi. The darkest palace among creations of Gaudi, be aware of limited amount (up to 300) of free tickets on Sunday from 3pm

The Legacy Of A Visionary. Palau Gruell is indeed a legacy to the vision of Gaudi it was a magical whimsical architecture depicting the vision of this man. We visited as part of a day tour with Barcelona day tours. It was easy to walk around and had disabled walkways. A great place to visit.

Amazing. This place blew me away with every single part of it. The attention to detail with every last bit. Even the walk through guide was good and informative which I thought was going to be boring and long winded but was soon proved wrong. Would definitely go again
Mesmerizing.. Dope! I wish I could live there. Like in a cartoon. No place like this, what to say here? No special lifehacks, just enjoy the beauty of this place.

A Gaudi triumph. This Palau is not as famous as others but it is astonishing inside and well worth visiting. It is an early Gaudi work and the architectural detail is amazingly creative. Well worth a visit.
A must in Barcelona. Do you like strange architecture? Well, then this is the place for you. This has it all and it's fun to see what creative people can get done.
Do it!. Get on the bus and go up to the park. You will never get the chance to ever do it again and it is worth the trip.

Beautiful Artful Structures. The art that is held in this park will take you to another place! The artist has his own style and is evident by his architecture and landscapes which are kept in tact. Try to find the cats that hide between the walls!

The Mosiac Walls are Inspiring!. This was a must see for me, as I love mosaics. Absolutely amazing. The buildings are covered in mosaics and there's a view of the ocean. the walk up to the park was a bit hot and difficult for me as I had been out the night before, but once I got up there I took endless photos!

Don't miss anything by Gaudí!. One of my favorite experiences while in Barcelona, this was almost a fantasy land. I recommend any or all of Gaudí's fabulous architecture examples while visiting this magnificent city!
Great space. Lovely big open space with pLenny of room for lots of visitors. The uphill walk is tough in the heat. But well worth it

Barcelona at it's best ---Art. Every aspect of this place is an art exhibit. It's very impressive how much of his life he put into this city. This is just one of many buildings and parks that makes visiting Barcelona an unforgettable experieince.

A visit to Gaudí's best friends Palace!. A must see for any Gaudí fan. This house is absolutely beautiful inside and out, delightful to wander round and take in all the amazing decor.Eusebi Güell and Gaudí became best friends following this masterpiece and no wonder, the detailing and design of the house is just stunning and really original. The ironwork and woodwork throughout the house is so detailed. The roof space is as wonderful as many of Gaudí's work on many of his buildings, the chimneys are delightful, so colourful and even a lizard thrown in for good measure. The family eventually moved out and moved into Park Güell and thankfully his youngest daughter transferred the Palace to the Council for cultural use.A must see, take the audio tour and listen out for the music :)

Not bad for a wander round if you have some free time. Generally a confusing layout, we ended up walking round in circles for a while, and after a few hours inside, we managed to miss the best bits which are always shown in the pictures!

Purchase Tickets online, paid admission needed to see landmarks. On busy days, there are limited time slots when you can enter. Therefore I recommend purchasing tickets online. We went later in the day, so it was quite crowded. Took a cab here from our hotel and they dropped us off right in front of the main entrance. A civic park created by Gaudi really showcases the ergonomic and practical design. Sit on the undulating park benches, there is lumbar support and the tiles are not hot from the beating sun! Makes you wonder how one accomplished that. After ward drop by a local eatery outside the park walls for a small ensalada or sandwich. Note must be made once you leave, you can't go back in.
Great architectural treat. A fanciful, farcical, exquisite architectural gem. Well worth the time to visit and absorb the vibe.
Unusual looking. To me, the place is little bit overrated. Although it is nice to walk there and it's unusual architecture impresses, the place itself is quite little small and very crowded

Splendid with a big crowd. If you are visiting Barcelona as a tourist, you should definitely go and visit Palau Guell. It is the meeting point of art and nature. But having a visit to Palau Guell just for one time is enough if you do not enjoy crowded places.

Hmmm a must see, if you don’t mind lines and overpaying. I don’t like waiting on lines on a holiday. The way they set up the timing to enter the Parc feels over organized and the “guards” seem to have control issues. The view from the Parc of course is vast, that’s why it was built on a hill. the entire area walk to and from the bus is Gaudi souvenirs. The snack bar gets you with high prices, everyone is making a selfie, tourism at it’s most annoying. The art is Gaudi, that’s why you are there, spectacular, decorative, colourful, fantasy imagery.
Nice visit. Worth visiting only if you have already visited the top places in Barcelona. The roof is great for pictures!
Top-rated Gaudi Tour. A magnificent home designed by Gaudi and the audio tour makes this an architectural must see when in Barcelona.

WOW, Awe inspiring Gaudi.. If you weren't a fan of Gaudi before I guarantee you will be after you've wandered through this house. It is well worth listening to the provided (as part of the entry fee) audio as it walks you around the house (at your own pace), the explanations aren't too long and are very insightful. We hadn't realised before how functional Gaudi's work was as well as creatively breathtaking and fun. If only we could all live somewhere like this...

Lovely. A lovely example of Gaudi's early works. It is, however, lacking in furnishings, something I found does take away from the realism of the place. Make sure you go up to the roof for a wonderful view of Barcelona.

Gaudi.....more Gaudi. When you think that this man died at the start of the previous century, then you realise her was an absolute genius, and no wonder that the spanish people keep his legacy alive by continuing the projects he started or designed prior to his passing. I would have just loved to see this in a different moment, with a lot less people around.
Amazing. This is a great palace. It can be difficult to see it from the street if you don't know its there. But once you get in and get to the roof it is great and very special and beautiful
It's Alright. It wasnt the funnest place, the art is beautiful but it is much smaller than you would imagine. Quite hot, wear a hat and take cold water with you.
Great place to visit, close to centre. This is small but very elegant. It you like Gaudi, come here. Beautiful ceilings and windows. Trip was guided but guide was fine and informed.

slowly look around. When you buy your ticket you also get a guide tour (in many languages- so do not worry- it´s i the price). you can wlak around the place and listen to the guide tour, so you can spend there a lot of time, you do not need to hurry up. there is a beautiful view from the top of the building. and inside of the building there is a really nice golden roof, so do not miss it.

Gaudi Genious. I truly believe Dr. Suess must have visited Palau Guell, some of the ideas in his books remind me of the imagination and genius of Gaudi. The monument (the colorful mosaics and structures seen on postcards) is an expression of Gaudi's genius as an artist, engineer and mathematician. One of the most interesting and beautiful experiences in the world. First, entrance to the park is free, but to the "monuments" there is a fee, and your entrance is timed. We arrived at 1 pm and our entrance time (they do not deviate) was 330 pm. The two and half ours was barely enough time to walk the park and then sit down grab a glass of sangria and tortilla, before visiting the monuments. Side Note: Bring Cash, sometimes the ticket machines do not accept credit cards and it works faster in the two cafes (one in the park above the monument entrance and the other inside the monument itself.)The park will require a significant amount of walking, with some moderate inclines. There are plenty of people selling water bottles along the path (legally and illegally). Take the time to climb to the top of the small cross at the top of the park, the view of Barcelona is breathtaking.

Gaudi's Stamp All Over It.. Book ahead on the Internet or you might have to wait hours to get in. Numbers are very strictly controlled. Too much so if you ask me. There is a long steep walk from both Metro stations so be warned. A taxi is a better option. Great views over the city. The most quirky but interesting parks in the world. It's more about the architecture in the park than the park itself. A must visit.

Beautiful part of Barcelona. This park is really worth seeing. You can tour the "outside" area for free or pay to go "inside" which we did. We paid for skip the line tickets and felt like it was really worth it. Just beautiful

Magnificent!. Loved this place! Huge grounds, so, put on comfy shoes! Timed visits to monument area, but well organised staff keep you moving in the queue. Highly recommend, especially if you are a Gaudi admirer.
views and art are a1. hard to beat the views from this area and the art is breathtaking. it's a must see when in barcelona

impressive but overcrowded. it is impressive but overcrowded.
we went with kids, I was there once alone, hoping it will not be such rush, but I was wrong.
We saw a few rats under us, it was interesting but spoiled our experience.
Gaudi's incomplete project. The visit is nice especially that the architecture is very unique. You have to go to see Gaudi's dragon so a visit is a must.

Lovely but €€€. Personally, I prefer the surrounding park. The admittedly beautiful view from the highest point can also be seen from the park, for free. While I enjoyed the Palau, I felt that €8 was too expensive for what it was. The architecture and displays were very fascinating, but not enough to occupy me for more than an hour. Don't bother queuing for the Porter House, there is very little in it to capture interest. Prebooking tickets is a must. I arrived at 11am and the next available slot was 2pm. That was a long wait! Food was reasonably priced for a tourist attraction.

Architectural Uniqueness. It's a great site to see -- no doubt about it. Here Gaudi is all about exteriors and the interiors of the buildings pale in comparison. Going inside the Museum and the 2 houses is not essential. Seeing the mosaics and works of architectural uniqueness is like nothing else you will ever find. Though I found the prices for the park and for the museum to be steep. I felt the price to get into the park should also include the museum. Plus I really can't believe there isn't a shuttle bus running from Sagrada Família to the park. Take a cab since it is a long walk uphill.

Gaudi completed. After visiting Sagrada, Pedrera, Batllo and Park Guell, this was another Gaudi's place on the list. Well worth visiting, big place and nice spaces inside. Lovely roof with Gaudi's chimneys. Gaudi rlz!
Gaudy Gaudi. After the Sagrada Familia this must be the next most wonderful Gaudi piece of architectural fantasy. A tour, including a visit to the roof is worth the time. Enjoy!
Wonderful!. Very beautiful place! It is seen a Unique view of Barcelona! It's wonderful!One of my favorite places!
Worth the Visit!!!. Definitely worth the visit! Beautiful Gaudi architecture. I walked up the hill through the park to get to Palau Guell and I took to the streets to get back to my hotel.
Who needs disneyland?. What a riot! Such imagination and character - so practical yet so beautiful. It would be a brilliant place to spend an afternoon with children. Gorgeous.

Palau Guell. Nice experience. Not as deep as Casa Battlo or La Sagrada Familia, but worth of being discovered for Gaudi "fans". It gives a more complete view of his whole work, and helps to better understand this incredible genius.

must see if visiting barcelona. Would recommend booking tickets in advance - we arrived at three o'clock in afternoon and the next available ticket was 5:00 but you can walk around the park area for free - this allowed us to have a stroll around the park and the Museum whilst waiting for our slot to visit the central monument

a beautiful home. Designed by Gaudi for his benefactor/employer as his personal home. too much to see inside to list, and if you find that you are all "Gaudi"d Out" after seeing so much of the architecture in the city, know that this attraction is free after 5pm on Sundays.

Breathtaking. After deciding to go on foot it took longer than usual to get up there, but was worth it as there are many small cafes worth seeing around. The top is stunning and gives you the best view of the city and some nice panorama pics.
Very expensive, very long queue. We found it more interesting to wander round the surrounding streets, than pay a fortune to get in and wait for hors
Amazing. everything....the entire experience was amazing! It's a complete must see when in Barcelona...get a bike up there and enjoy the views
Another must see location. You must visit to really get the Gaudy and Guell relationship. The creative genius and scale can't be captured with just a photo, it needs to be experienced

Nothing like it!. Can be quite crowded and why not? This whimsical place is so worth seeing. The question to be asked is "Why are there not more buildings around the world like this". What a delightful place to visit.
Interesting. An exceptional park worth visiting but suggest to check schedule and book in advance. It's easy and comfortable to walk in the park. Nice visit.

Hot and Bothered. This is one of the view Gaudi attractions that you not have to queue for. It is easy to get to and unlike otheres you have full access to the whole house not just certain areas. However I would still recommend going early in the morning due to how hot the house is. I full appreciate that they do not want people eating or drinking but we went early afternoon and after only 30 mins were feeling the affect of the heat in the building, there are very few seats and after a short while felt the need to get out of the buidling. which is a really shame as it deserves to be savoured.
Not worth visiting. I believe this attraction is over rated and expensive. I expected more as the whole visit took 20 minutes.

make sure you book in advance. loved this area. so pretty and great to take pictures in. only problem- its pretty far from the main city. we went out around 3pm on a train (very hotel) because it was a few miles away. got to guell and there werent tickets available until 6pm so we left. bought tickets and went back the next morning but this time took a cab. kind of expensive getting out there in cab. definitely buy tickets in advance and take the subway as its a cheap alternative to cabs

A fun home tour followed by a visit to an enchanting rooftop. We had read that this was second to the Casa Mila/La Pedrera, so,we went there first. It was okay, not great, with. Splendid rooftop collection of goblinesque chimney tops. But this house is far. Ore interesting, especially the central hall. You wrap up the tour with a visit to the rooftop, where chimney caps look like bejeweled, upside-down ice cream cones and surely never fail to draw a smile. We thought this was a much better use of time than Casa Mila.
Early Gaudi work. Worth a visit, but not as colourful as his later works. Architecturally impressive Gaudi as always. Great roof top
Very good view. It was an amazing view of the city but once you got up there you had to pay an additional 8 euro to see the Guadi park not worth the money

Out of the way, but worth the trip. Another beautiful site of Barcelona. It is a lovely park, which, however, was not it's original design goal. Leave yourself plenty of time to get there and I recommend a pre-purchase to skip the long lines for any Gaudi spot.We did a self-guided tour and spent about an hour at the park.

Only for Diehard Gaudí Afictionados. If you like the overblown self-conscious and (the pun is irresistible) gaudy style of Gaudí, then the long waiting line to purchase overpriced tickets to the center of this area is worth it for you. If you are not among his fans, save your money and walk for free around the exterior ramparts. Watch out for pickpockets and the high-pressure (and illegal) sidewalk vendors, and you can enjoy what there is to enjoy of Gaudí's structures at no cost.
Barcelona Autumn. Youve got to see the chimmneys a really different and the view into the backyards of other houses almost as intersting!!

Well worth trip to outskirts of Barcelona to visit. Great visit, BUT note that you must get your tickets for inside the paid area AHEAD of time or you will be in for a long wait to get inside that area. THe outside area is not as impressive, you really want to tour the house also. SO go online and get your tickets in advance, you have 1/2 hour leeway to get there. Bring your camera as there are photo ops everywhere. The imaginative and whimsical terra cotta mosaics are beautiful. You can get there via Hop on Hop off bus, or subway but it is a walk from subway stop.

Go Because It's Cool BUT..... VERY CROWDED. And, BUY TICKETS IN ADVANCE. GO early and visit the house and then the Parc. The mosaics are great. There is a little cafe that has great food and clean bathrooms but I am sad to say that we paid a lot of money for those tickets and I was not fulfilled. NOTE: Buy tickets online before you go. Believe it or not, they limit the number of people in the parc and you could get all of the way up there and have to wait a few hours before your ticket time.

Nice park & great view of the city.. Be prepare to walk. We visited in the beginning of June and the weather was hot, but there are vendors selling ice cold water bottles and drinks all around. There were several musicians playing their music and have their CDs for sell.

Buy tickets online and get there on time!!. We bought tickets online (great idea) but were so rushed getting there that we almost missed our entrance time! Definitely worth a go but give yourself time to get there. It's on top of a huge hill and, while you can take escalators, there is still some hiking. And it was HOT so wear a hat if you go in the summer. I'd also recommend going later so you don't get mixed up with the tour groups. Although, we did get to piggyback on one tour a learned a lot!
Gaudi. Way over rated. A very bid disappointment. We expected more. The whole visit if you take your time will take 20 minutes.

Incredible Arcitecture. This place is truly a work of art! What Gaudi was able to do here is inspitational. Cost 12 euros per person but you get an audio guide to give you everything you need to know as you tour the house. I can honestly say that i have never seen a building like this! Well worth the visit.
Brilliant. Absolute attention to detail, magnificently built and preserved. This is an abolute must see. Highly recommended.

Quite a climb up. We had a lovely sunny day. The streets to get to the entrance are uphill but thankfully there are a couple of OUTSIDE escalators which helped. Once IN the park you walk up higher and higher. The view of the city is worth it. We came back another day to see the Gaudi buildings because there was a long lineup to get into that section of the park. Another visit to the tourist bureau --to get time-specific tickets to bypass the waiting line (to buy tickets). I had thought there were more buildings to see but what was there was amazing.

Wonderful place to stroll!. Admire the brilliance of Gaudi's works as you journey through the entire space; simply amazed by the creative designs. You will spot some musicians whilst exploring the place so enjoy the music and the beauty of the place.
Amazing. Beautiful place, amazing views over the town! Can be a bit busy during the day. A must see in Barcelona.

Fantasy comes to life. Gaudi makes a rooftop into a world of joy. His architecture is nothing like you've seen anywhere else and this execution is a perfect example.They accommodated my difficulty walking by taking me to the front of the line, allowing me to take the elevator and were very pleasant.
Very Good. Great work of Gaudi in open space, a nice place to spend couple of hours with your family. Highly recommended!

Fabulous Gaudí building bursting with imagination. Palau Güell is situated in Raval just a hundred meters or so from Ramblas. Gaudi planned it for industrialist and factory owner Eusebi Güell who liked the building so much that Güell ordered many more architectural works (for example Park Güell) from Gaudí.It is advisable to order your tickets beforehand with a time slot to avoid queues. The entrance fee is reasonable (12 €) when compared to entrance fees to some other Gaudí buildings in Barcelona, for example to La Pedrera (20,50 €) and Casa Battló (21,50 €). The building is in pristine condition after restauration and the audio-guide is very good. The tour begins from stalls and ends high up in the roof between chimneys that look like some sci-fi tree species in wonderland. It is strange to thing that usually only the servants visited the roof to dry the laundry. Gaudí used first time his famous arch in Palau Güell and you can see a lot of Arabic influence in the use of space and light and patios. The most recommended visit to the world and to the endless imagination of Gaudí.

The best architecture in Barcelona, bar none!. Amazing views, crazy architecture and colours to amaze and dazzle. It was one of the best afternoons I have had in Barcelona walking around this area. Must see!

a marvelous creation. i think this place summarizes Gaudi's works.
the structures are fabulous.
the garden is huge, and could be there for hours, If we weren't sore legs...
Beautiful. Just amazing... When I can I will come back. Every place there is so much beautiful . I have been there with my friends and we have a great time

Hectic and disorganised.. Not a massive fan of this part, they've changed the outlay so you need to book tickets / a time slot to go in. We walked round the periphery for free because the next available slot for 3 hours away. May have been my fault for assuming it would be the same as last time I visited. This area has a lot of tacky souvenir stores around, and was probably my least favourite part of my weekend. Views were wonderful though.
Beautiful. Lovely architecture, fab views. Be careful what train stop you get off as we had to walk up a massive big hill.

Nice house, worth a visit. This was a great site to visit, but honestly, I like Casa Batllo better. I'm still glad that I visited. The line was short and it took about an hour to take the audio tour through the house. Not the best, but very good. Nice views from the rooftop.

School Trip. Great fun. Plenty to see and do and buy even if some of it is from the "looky looky" guys. We got caught out a little by the new system of entry to the terrace and the trencadis so some of our kids did not get to the lower part of the park. All in all a good day out.

Plan Ahead. We had planned to visit the Gaudi structures in the large park, but on arrival in the late morning we discovered that all tickets were booked until after 6:00 pm. There is a strict limit on the number of visitors that can enter. We strolled around the rest of the park and had some lovely views of the city, but felt that we had missed out on something. Next time we are in Barcelona we will book ahead, on line, so we can be sure to have a spot. It is true that there is quite a climb to the park, but it is not unmanageable if you take it slowly.
Worth the Trek. Incredible place to visit and walk around. Fantastic views and take the escalators to ease the journey!

Great Outdoor Musuem. Be prepared for lots of tourists but it is worth it to see the unusual architecture and see the house where Gaudy lived in . See the unique teacups in the ceilings, the salamander. Be Leary of pickpockets.

Wonderful Day. We went here eagerly waiting to take photographs and we were spoiled for choice. It was very busy but we booked our tickets online.
