You could spend a good couple of hours here looking at the gardens and buildings, was definitely worth the trip but glad we took a taxi, it only cost 15 Euros there but funnily enought it was only 7 euros on the way back

An Absolute Treasure. Looking through some of the previous reviews, they appear to be for Park Guell not Palau Guell. There are no escalators or long walks to the top so don't let those comments put you off. The house is just off La Rambla and if you were going to see one thing in Barcelona, make it this. Gaudi was a genius in the way he manages to find solutions to problems, creates wonderful view lines throughout the house to other rooms and floors, and uses only the best artisans and materials in his buildings. Almost moved me to tears and well worth every euro.

An elegant site. It is worth a stop. Designed by Gaudi for the Guell family it is an elegant building with it's own chapel and pipe organ. There are little windows for the family to view what is happening below. The rooms are mostly unfurnished but if you get the audio it gives you pictures of what they looked like at that time. Get up to the roof for a wonderful view of Barcelona and the colorful chimneys
Up there with Central and Hyde. As a major park in a major city this ranks with the best. Maybe not as large as some but more interesting for all the Gaudi about the place.

Very nice Gaudi work. But don't confuse with Park Guell. I see that many people confuse this place with the Park Guell. The Palau Guell is a very nice villa, a Gaudi work near La Rambla. I strongly recommend visiting it, but only after you visited the Casa Battlo, Sagrada Familia or Park Guell. Gaudi's hand is more subtle in this place than in other of his marsterpieces, but it's a villa that I really enjoyed.
Incredible!!!. Audio guide was really helpful to make it informative and fun. Also the restoration process info was interesting, great view from the roof, and the organ played every half hour.

Enjoyed the park for free.... Last time I visited Barcelona the park was free. I was surprised when our group of 5 showed and needed tickets to see the Gaudi area... you must book ahead online for specific times. They limit the number of people that have access to the Gaudi area. We hiked the other areas of the park. The views of the city were great. We got beautiful pictures from outside of the pay area from above. The kids were happy enough with what they saw and we saved some money! It is a hike but the way we arrived had an escalator going up.... not down... Use a bathroom outside the park.. the line inside was very long for women!

its ok. Its nice that they built escalators for you to reach the top of the hill. but considering the price and if the weather to be hot. I d rather do something else. The view from the top was enough for me
More Gaudi. Wonderful time and info on Gaudi. Be sure to buy tickets on line before you go. Parkguellonline.cat. Take a paper copy my I pad was hard to scan in the sun

Beautiful, Genius!. Gaudi was truly a genius. It is not expensive to go and it does not take long - but is a must see. One word of advice use bus to go the last distance. We used metro and were told to get off at Vallcarra only to find out that one has to do an extensive climb to get to the park. We took the bus back and it was much easier.

Not to be mistaken as the Park - this is a house and is amazing!. As many reviews describe this being the park with stupid opening times and long walks up the hill this is not that! This is a tour of a house made by Gaudi himself for the Guell family.Well worth a visit especially when you get to the top if the house (weather permitting so go on a nice day) as you get fantastic views of the city plus a first hand view of the excellent design work on the exterior of the house.

Very interesting if you are a Gaudi's fan!. Take the free audio guide and spend some time to listen to the history and background, very interesting and informative. Walk to the top to get a good view fro, the city.
weird but beautiful!. one of the attractions in Barcelona where every visitor must go and see. very unusual but beautiful at the same time.
Good veiws of the city from here.. The park is huge; lots of walking paths: with Antono Gaudi's influence. A home and Grotto. The park is set up high above the city of Barcelona.

Do homework before you pay to go inside. Partly it could have been the cloudy day.....but paying to walk a small area inside this park didn't seem like it was worth the money. It is a long hike up hill from the bus drop - if you are mobility impared it will be difficult. You can pretty much see everything that you pay to walk through from walking around the park - but if you do want to go inside pre-purchase the tickets or the wait, for some unknown reason to us, can be hours long or sold out for days

Huge disappointment - did not get in!. Previous visits were excellent - we were much looking forward to visiting on a hot sunny day. Entrance moved to a higher level. Now requires tickets and timed entry - arrived at 1.30pm but no entry possible until 4.30pm. Had to abort visit. Check whether tickets are available on-line.
For Gaudi fans. If you like the works of Gaudi, than it is a must to visit. The whole house in one style - pure Gaudi. Even the top of the building is worth to visit
Interesting Building.. This was the first Gaudi building we had been into and it did not disappoint. his man truly was a genius.

Another Gaudi classic. This is yet another work from Gaudi, more humble than Casa Mila and Casa Batllo, but noteworthy whatsoever. Upon visiting you get an audioguide for free.You may skip this one if you don't have much time in your hands.
Best perspective on Barcelona. This park sets a standard I have not seen in parks anywhere else in the world. Gaudi design of the walkways, arches and homes was stunning in the middle of the city.

100% worth a visit if you have time. Although this is a little bit out of the main area of town it's really easy to get here by Metro (only 2 stops from just off the Ramblas). It's a bit of a trek up the steep hill from the metro stations so be prepared if it's hot. however it's definitely worth the effort. It's a beautiful park, fantastic views out over the city and stunningly designed. The most famous parts of this now cost to get into 7 Euro if book ticket online, and like most places entry it time slot specific. The Gaudi influence is everywhere from the beautiful house (and small museum) to the statues and design of the square etc. Really worth a visit just for the views.
Lovely views.. Fanciful buildings and sculptures. Very hilly, but at the higher places wonderful views of the Mediterranean and Barcelona.

An Absolute Must. Whatever the cost of the entrance fee, PAY IT. This is an amazing architectural feat designed and built by Gaudi for a very wealthy Barcelona business man. You must be able to climb steps and have a degree of fitness.

huge and beautiful. set aside the day to climb/weave your way around this fantastic natural beauty. take the time to visit Gaudi's studio and climb your way to the peak for an incredible view of the city
Palau Guell. Palau Guell is quite a surprise tucked away in a side street. I am amazed at the genius of Antoni Gaudi.

Looks like Jurassic Park!. Absolutely magnificent. The main entrance is breathtaking! With the 2 houses for the gatesman - looks like mushrooms made of mosaic. Excellent views of the ocean. Gaudi was a genius!
PREBOOK. we walked up the hill from the sightseeing bus stop only to find it would be 3 hrs before we could get in to the main area.Can't review any more but take my advice.

A must see inside!. Tickets can be bought on the spot as it was not very crowded when we went in May. The audio guide is definitely worth the entrance price and the interior has a lot of information on both Gaudi and Guell.
Great views. We took a public bus to the park. We enjoyed the views and took a lot of pictures. It is worth to walk up all the way to the top.
Dr. Suess, Tim Burton must have been here. This is a must see. Get your tickets ahead of time on line. You will not be disappointed. This is so much fun. It is magical.

Palau Guell a fantastic experience. we had been to Barcelona many times, but had not visited this attraction before. What an experience! We spent more than 4 hours there and I am sure that if ,no when, we return we will still see things that we missed on this visit

Overrated. I went to the park today. It is a long 25 minutes walk from the metro under the scorching sun despite the fact I bring umbrella. There are a lot of street peddlers within the park and there are certain areas which are off limit to the park. Although I like Gaudi artwork, I think the local municipal goverment must be dying to make money by making certain areas segregrated. It´s not a bad thing but it is best to make the whole park off limit as there are way too many street peddlers. The only saving grace is the view of Barcelona city. I don´t see a lot of Gaudi artworks as much as Casa Batlo. I personally think you will not miss anything by not visiting the park, seriously...

Amazing Palace - DO NOT confuse it with Park Guell!. We stumbled across Palau Guell in a book on Gaudi architecture and, as it was not far from where we were staying, we decided to visit one evening. We arrived at about 18:30 and were able to go in immediatelyWe were already Gaudi fans and were not disappointed - it was absolutely amazing inside! There was lots to see as you seemed to be able to look at every floor and most of the rooms.It is very sparsely furnished and we found this enabled us to look at the architecture and dimensions of the rooms. I particularly liked the roof although, as with many other Gaudi buildings, I understand it may be closed on a rainy day so if looking at it is vital to your visit I recommend you go on a sunny day as we did.I can't find any fault with my visit. It was worth every cent and is definitely my favourite sight in Barcelona. If you like looking at houses and architecture, I guarantee you will not be disappointed!We visited it on the same day as Park Guell and there really is no comparison between the two. The park is more about grand scale external architecture and this is a house. Whilst I enjoyed the park, I felt Palau Guell was much better value for money. I feel very sorry for the staff and management of Palau Guell as almost all of the poor reviews on this site are about Park Guell and not Palau Guell!
Hidden gem. Tucked away on a street off of Las Ramblas, this little mansion is well worth a visit to marvel at the skill wielded by Gaudi during it's design and construction.
Mansions Dream. A nice place also an architectural piece of Gaudi for his friends request. Having a guide or not will do for an interesting visit.
A must-see. Beautiful place, definitely one of the must-see attractions in Barcelona. Worth going early, as soon as it opens , before it gets too busy.

A great home. Built early in Gaudi's career and shows just how he understood the dynamics of space and the interaction of people with their built environment.A first impression may be that it is overdone but in fact it musts melds into a magnificent oneness.

Huge park with trails and plenty to enjoy. We loved our visit to Parc Guell in May 2015. We hiked most of the trails and enjoyed the interesting architecture of Gaudi. You have to pay 8 euros to see the monument area of the park, but I'm glad we did. It was beautiful and they controlled the number of people in that area at one time so that it doesn't get too crowded.

Imaginative and thought provoking. Amazing architecture. It's worth having an experienced guide to get the most out of it as there are many hidden gems that may be missed by a casual visit. Though busy it was still possible to enjoy the sheer lunacy and brilliance of the place.

You need to pre-book. Having planned a short break to Barcelona in minute detail never expected to turn up at Park Guell during the morning to buy tickets to be told they were booking tickets for 2pm entry! Not had this before on previous visit. Gave up as too long to wait! The only plus side was the escalators part of the way up from the bus stop. Will pre-book online next time!
Beautiful. So many items to see. You begin to see all the works of Gaudi with all the venues offered in Barcelona
Gaudi at his best. Fascinating architecture and really wonderful guide. Really a worthwhile stop in Barcelona. Gaudi was very prolific and you will not see any architecture like this anywhere else

pre book tickets. Went on a very hot day, and enjoyed having a mooch around. however, you now have to pay to see the best bits as they are only allowing a certain amount of people around the best bits to help preserve it. we didnt do that last time, and so didnt prebook. that meant we would of had to wait 3.5 hours before we could get a time slot. so definitely book. it gets very busy and there arnt that many places to get food, so take a picnic too.
Awesome!. Park Güell is a nice place to see Gaudi's work. I suggest booking ahead. Bring water and sunscreen because it gets hot walking around the park. Highly recommended.

Amazing! A must see! Incredible. We can't believe Rick steves gives this one star out of three. He's nuts. One of the most interesting and jaw dropping places we have ever seen. Everything about it is incredible. Don't forget the basement!

Lots of mosaics. Problem here, we took the on off bus assuming they stop in front of the park, they do not. It's about 1/2 mile UPHILL and very difficult to walk. So by the time I got to the Top of the hill, I was already too tired to climb up to the top to see the serpent . Oh well, I still got to see the mosaics under the dome. Make sure you buy the book, very interesting.

Wonderful unique place. This is a must see in Barcelona. A lot of walking on different surfaces. has amazing things to see. The buildings are unique. Kind of reminded us of Dr. Sues stories. The mosaic work is beautiful.

Wear your walking shoes!. Part of the adventure was getting there. We took the hop on hop off bus. It leaves you off at the bottom of a very steep hill. The steep hill is only the beginning. Once you make it up the hill there are stairs and escalators leading to the park. Once you are in the park, there are more steps. This tour is filled with walking/hiking/climbing. It is worth it! What a beautiful park. We spent 3 hours exploring and I am sure we didn't see even half of what it has to offer. Beautiful landscaping and architecture. There a many free areas so you can have an enjoyable day without spending any money.

Free audio guide on a lazy Sunday. It is definitely worth a visit, and even more so if it's free! On Sunday afternoons, you can wait in line to get free tickets (limited entry). The entry comes with an audio guide that takes you through the whole palace, explaining all the intricate designs and reasonings for the elaborate, playful structures. I've already been twice and would definitely go again.

beautiful piece of architecture: a MUST see. The building and the work of Gaudi are worth a visit. One can walk on the roof amongst pieces of sculpture while viewing Barcelona at the same time from high up.I took high school students as well as adults to see this marvelous piece of archicture. DO NOT MISS IT !

NOT to be missed Gaudi gem !!!!. My guide book did not even mention this Palace Gaudi created for the Guell family. It is spectacular - better than the other Gaudi wonders, if I can even say that. We wandered upon it 20 minutes before closing so only had time to literally run from room to room. It is a master piece. Guadi is a genius. Must not be missed

Great details. Palau Güell was built between 1886-1890 for industrialist, Eusebi Güell, by Antoni Gaudí. The style of the palace is Art Nouveau. It was declared as a historic site in 1969. I really enjoyed all the beautiful and ornate ceilings, the woodwork, the use of wrought iron in various places and of course the very interesting rooftop.You can see the pictures at: https://travel4foodnart.wordpress.com/2015/06/02/palau-guell/

Put this on your list. After 4 visits to this great city I eventaully managed to visit Palau Guell. So glad I did. It's a great building, an interesting house,to visit and makes me realise how truly amazing Gaudimwas as an architect

A must with children!. Our daughter loved this park! Interesting for us adults too. It was clean and so well kept. Only thing I didn't like was that we had to buy tickets in advance, slightly inconveniente. However, the walking paths and mosaics were amazing. Good place to take pictures with the view too!

What a Beauty!. Another magical work of Gaudi. A good hiking area & beautiful building! Is a very interesting building, look like a candy with icing building to me. Not to be missed.One note: Park does not have not much WC around. Apply Sunblock!

Beautiful, but get ready for a hike!. Incredible park with great views of the city and signature Gaudi architecture on full display. Be prepared - you are in essence climbing up a mountain that is broken up into various levels either by moderate inclines or uneven, rocky stairs. Be prepared to ascend a lot of stairs, but worth the work! MANY photo opportunities. Advice: You have full access to the park - if you want to see the exclusive Gaudi portion, buy your tickets (you more than likely will be assigned a time that you can enter) and just see the rest of the park and then come back when it's your time.

Nice park with great views of Barcelona. We visited the "free" part first then paid for the other section. To me the free part was more impressive than the paid section. The paid section was just a house with historical film running in each room.
Quieter in the evenings. Stopped off on the bus city tour then a walk up the hill (escalators help a lot). Try and get into the restricted area (timed entry) - otherwise just a nice park.
Palau Güell - must visit!. A great masterpiece o Gaudi, a must visit when in Barcelona! We spent a few hours wondering around and we had great time, definitely recomended!
Gaudi Masterpiece. Don't miss this beautiful park. Take a bus from the city center and go early in the day to avoid the crowds.

Really Overrated. The park is mediocre, the view was really nice to be honest. But when it came to all the Gaudi attractions, they were cool, but just limited. It was also a bit obnoxious to house a gift shop inside one of the famous Gaudi houses. Perhaps if architecture is your bread and butter, you should go.

Must-see attraction in Barcelona. I recommend taking a taxi to see this to save walking up the hill, that way I saved some energy for the rest of the day, and was able to get there early before it got too crowded.Not as much to see here as I had expected. Its is very pretty and you have to take the classic selfie at the top of the monument but apart from that not loads to see.

Stunning. Second time I've been & it still impresses. Buy tickets online in advance - they only let in 400(?) people per hour to the monuments & it saves a queue. If you've got health or fitness issues, get a taxi - not from the centre, but from the tube station.
Really loved it!. This is the best place to check in Barcelona. Beautiful big park with unusual architecture and ni e views.

Worth a visit. The park is beautiful and from its top part there's a great view of the city. There two parts that require admission - the Gaudi Museum and the monumental part and these are separate - need to stand twice in line. You might want to get your tickets in advance online. Lines are quite long...

More Gaudi. This was the third place I visited with my 85 year old father. We were so well looked after. The staff provided a wheelchair and took my father in the lift to every floor. An excellent visit. Thank you very much

Impressive - and eerie. This early building was (and still is) in a not-too-elegant area. The interior is dark, rich and pious. The carriage entrance to protect Sra Guell from the street when she went out is a superb idea. She did not like living there - and I wouldn't. But it was very impressive to visit as part of an understanding of the development of Gaudi. Guell and Gaudi did well to find each other.

An overlooked Gaudi gem. We didn't even mean to visit this site in Barcelona we stumbled across it really as it was raining and we wanted to get of Las Ramblas. It cost €24... Perhaps a little steep but a really interesting place to visit and see one of Gaudi's early buildings. You can see where some of his signature architecturally motifs are used early on in his career in the Guell Palace. As well as being another opportunity to see the unique Gaudi architecture in this amazing city, the Palace is also a chance to see how the other half once lived. The Guell family lived here before the Spanish Civil War and the rooms include a basement coach house which has some incredible brickwork, piano recital rooms, tiled bathrooms, lounge rooms and the main concert salon which the entire palace is centred around. The central performing space is vast and spans several floors over which there are mezzanine floors and viewing galleries that over look it. There is also a gold and tortoiseshell guided chapel inside, a full organ and higher performance space for a choir. The main spectacle of the room is the roof which features Gaudi's first use of the hexagonal tile pattern and features holes which at night time give the effect of shimmering stars in the night sky. I am no history expert, I learned this information from the audio guide handset which was included in the price and was really handy in guiding me around the many rooms. I actually found myself looking at things more closely because of the guide rather than just glancing and going "mm, that's nice". There is also a roof terrace that can be viewed but was unfortunately closed due to the weather when we visited. If you like your tourist attractions on the quieter side and have an interest in Gaudi architecture, Palau Guell could be for you. It has the Barcelona history and hallmarks of the Gaudi style but is less busy than La Pedrera and Casa Battló. In a future visit I would be interested to see how these two Gaudi buildings are different and how his style had developed later on.

Cool house that shows Gaudi's domestic talents. Another Gaudi site worth a visit. Relatively modest 12 euro admission buys you a free audio tour of a private home located off the Rambla. The coffered ceilings alone are worth the price. Wish it had more of the original furnishings. The roof and chimneys were a treat.

A beautiful site!. Just another fabulous Gaudi piece of work. Of the beaten path but well worth it. We were there late afternoon and it was very crowded. My guess is the earlier you get there, the fewer tourists. Allow some time just to hang out. We only went to the section where you pay. Much of the park is free. Knowing what I know now I would have gone to the local markets and purchased a lunch to take to the park and hang out, relax (vs our power non-stop sightseeing frenzy! If you go to the pay to enter portion, I suggest buying tickets on-line in advance so you don't have to wait in line (as is true for all Barcelona exhibits. It was so nice just to walk up and enter without the wait.
Great Park. Gaudi outside, put on your walking shoes,lots of stairs and walking, but a look at the way Gaudi uses nature as a setting for his work.

the best thing to see in barcelona. I am so pleased that I have seen this, it was beautiful and unique. We took a taxi there - save your legs for walking around the park, especially if it is warm! There is a large area of the park that is free and that includes layers of amazing viaducts and great views over the city, and lush vegetation, cacti etc. There is a good playground, a picnic area, there was a busker playing a guitar under one of the viaducts and a cafe at the bottom. If you don't need time/ can't get a ticket for the other part of the park it is still completely worthwhile going, however, the paying section of the park is the famous bit with the mosaics in it. Without a ticket you can see the mosaic bit from the street a little bit. The mosaic section is not expensive but tickets are limited each day. We arrived at quarter past ten and the next available ticket was for 12:30. It was actually easy to spend 2 hours in the free part waiting for our slot but there is obviously a risk of a much longer wait or no tickets at all so I would recommend buying tickets online in advance. The type of art and architecture was appealing to the children so it was a good day out to suit everyone. The shop had some good sticker books for them to make their own mosaic patterns.

Dont like going uphill - dont go !. had to leave my husband in a nearby cafe as although we had taken a taxi to the entrance almost all the part was uphill and he couldnt manage it. We didnt realise this before we went. Also, had we manged to go round the park to get in Gaudi house etc. we would have had to hang around for two and a half hours !and it was very hot. Shame as it looked beautiful.

A walk in the park. This is a wonderful place to take children to run around safely or to walk off a fabulous meal - so much to see - the 100 columns, the vistas over the city, great photo opportunities, beautiful flowers. There are a number of different paths to follow - we enjoyed being outdoors and yet away from the traffic noises. It is a quick cab ride from downtown and is worth the fare. The buildings are also very decorative and great examples of Gaudi's work.

Travel back in time. We visited Palau Guell in May 2015. There was practically no queue outside the ticket office, and we entered the Palau directly after purchasing the tickets. The building is well preserved, with many rooms open for access and lots of details to see. Start in the cellar and work your way up to the spectacular roof terrace, using the audio guide for assistance. The only reason I don't give it top marks is because a lot of the furniture is missing, so many rooms are empty. Still an interesting place to see.

Gaudi's parc!. A must see. This is the part of the parc you have to pre-book and pay for and well worth it. Such imagination. Another awesome place. Take your time to wander and take it all in. Once again, satff extremely helpful and speak many languages.

A unique park. Guadi built this park and then donated it to the city. He created this on his property. The mosiac work is composed of several hundred different pieces of tile quite unique. If you don't come in through the main gate the walk up hill from the train can be quite grueling.

Gaudi's beautiful works!. BUY YOUR TICKETS IN ADVANCE! The park only lets so many visitors in per hour. Don't waste money on a cab ride to this park. Take the subway. Bring along your camera and take some beautiful pictures at the top part of the park.
Worth the climb up the Steps!. Right on top of the hills overlooking the city. Gaudi architecture at it's most bizarre and exciting.

Take a taxi. Nice park but a bit tough to get to take a taxi. The park is free, but there is a section that charges admission (monuments). Like Sagada Familia try to get your tickets ahead of time. The monuments section is nice but to me I thought it would have more of Gaudi's art work. Still a pleasant time to spend an afternoon.
it is a nice place. the arquitecture of the place, it is small but beauty. you have an amazing viewer of Barcelona from the mirador
My girl just loved this. My daughter studied about this artist just before we went so for her it was a big treat to go and visit it, Highly recommend

A sort of picturesque Solent Green with crockery. First off if you are thinking about visiting the Park and plan to get the metro to Vallcarca, be aware that you are in for a steep climb. Most of the way is via escalator but not all of it, anyone with dodgy legs may find themselves in trouble. Parc Guell itself is indeed picturesque, although it would be if not jammed packed with tourists like me. We wandered around the free bit for a while, and although the views are great and there’s the odd charming discovery, you start to wonder if it was worth the effort. Since we bought tickets online for the paid part we didn’t have to queue for those, thank God, so we were eventually released into the bits you see in all the photographs. Well the immediate area has the longest bench in the world (in the form of a sea serpent apparently) with a great view of the city, which you have to enjoy while all those who have dived onto the bench for photos try to work around everyone else. Down the stairs takes you to the Gaudi’s Tiled Mosaics on the pillared ceiling which holds the aforementioned part up, and the salamander fountain (it might be some other creature, a newt or something) with tiled stairs. All very nice but well… for a Philistine like me it was just a load of glued crockery and tiles. The best part was the old nursery area to the left when you walk down the stairs; lovely garden and actually quite quiet. The heaving mass of humanity on the stairs didn’t seem to care for this part.The gatehouse at the main entrance contains a very interesting exhibition on the history of the park and Gaudi’s work. A must see this part.All in all worth a visit if you enjoy architectural design and the history of Barcelona, not to mention some great views and enjoyable quiet spots. If, however, you get rather ruffled due to having to constantly dodge selfie sticks then you might want to give it a miss.

A night tour is a must!. Palau Guell is an extraordinary site. For the architecture and history of Gaudi it is a must, but to be on the rooftop at night, WOW. We were a small group with no others behind us so the time to visit was ample. The tour guides are excellent and well-versed in building timelines and the current residents. You can also tour an apartment which puts a better perspective on the original dwellers. The opportunity was one we will not forget.
What a great building. This is worth going to see pretty unbelivable how progrerssive things were when this was built. worth seeing and right in the middle of town.

One of the great Barcelona visit.. This is a fantastic place to visit and enjoy the views. However make sure you book in advance, if you don't you will purchase a ticket and they return at a later time, and given the fairly impressive climb to get there you could ave yourself a double climb.

Have a picnic here. This park is very large and it's a great place if you have a large group or a family. It allows all the kids to roam around. The outer layer of the park is free however to enter to the centre area where you'll find most of the neat Gaudi structures costs about 8 Euros. If you book online you can save 1 Euro however you need to specify the date/time you want to enter the park. If you don't want to book online you can also buy the ticket at the subway station. There was a city representative to help us with the machine. This avoids the hassle of queuing at the park ticket booths. The park doesn't have a lot of seating area with shade but if you can get a spot, you should pack a lunch (careful of the pigeons that may swarm you) and enjoy the buskers.

Gaudi park. We booked tour in uk which was well worth it and got local bus tour to get their. The park is very big and you can not do it justice in a few hours. It's well worth paying to see the Gaudi house and museum.

Overrated, Underwhelming, and Crowded. The pictures you see on the internet are not really branded truly, as you can even see the main attraction from the entrance! There's absolutely no reason to pay six euros a person to go into the "Monuments Zone," which is basically a cattle pen for tourists wishing to see the city. Skip this attraction and go spend a free day at the beach instead.
Crowds ........ Loved the monuments, but far too crowded, they will get destroyed unless they limit the crowds! We had to wait three hours for a ticket, so, tip, book online before you go.
Spanish surrealism. Park Guell is not like any other park, it's a quirky little place in Barcelona. Loved visiting but it's also very VERY crowded.

Must visit when you're in Barcelona!. We went there with a private guide. It is a really interesting place to visit. Guell was a multi-gazillionaire who hired an architect named Gaudi to build a new kind of exclusive neighborhood. It has all these cool architectural designs. It's also a really nice place to walk around. Tip: Enter through the upper gate if you can. It's easier to visit the place if you can walk downhill.

A beautiful insight to how the rich lived in 19th century Barcelona. One of Gaudis masterpieces. The architecture was unique. The entrance passage is tiled in wood so that the sound of the horses hooves would be muffled and not disturb the occupants of the house.

Do it for the done thing. when I tried to book a slot online I found it was an unsecured site so I decided to buy tickets at the venue. The downside to this is that I pay one euro more and end up waiting 2 hours to get in. Not worth the wait.

Interesting site. Booked tickets in advance. After taking the escalators up the hill, it notifies you that you are in the park, but it takes some time wandering dusty paths to actually get to the paid portion of the park (much of it is free). by the time we found the official entrance to the park where they accept tickets, it was passed our assigned entrance time and they would not allow us in. We went later and it was an interesting Gaudi site. okay for the price as long as you find an entrance that is easy to access.
Hols. Amazing house, fantastic inside, a must see. the building work, also the chimmneys outside on the roof top ect.

Nice place to visit with children. One of Gaudi's gems in Barcelona. Nice place to visit if you are lucky with weather. Guide's comments appreciated so this park has complicated story of creation. It was planned as real estate development project for 50 or 60 villas but without success about hundred years ago. So it became wonderful park. The only problem - clouds of people here. So it's a good enough way to buy off line tickets. It costs extra Euro 5,- if you are traveling with Barcelona Days tour (recommended by Trip Adviser). Enjoy!

Interesting but not what i expected. Tickets were bought online prior to holiday which made life a lot easier. We got a taxi to drop us of at the top of the park so we could walk down rather than up! If you want to see both the public (free) and private( fee) parts of the Parc and you have bought tickets, then leave plenty of time before your timed ticket and see the public part first. There are small cafes in both parts. The private part was nowhere as big as I expected hence my review title. Saying that we did enjoy it and the mosaics were stunning. Do watch out for pick pockets. A gang of 3 were feeding pigeons, offering peanuts to people to distract them and then were using that to steal. We saw 2 of them being caught and lead away, while the 3rd jumped a 8-9 foot gate and escaped into the public area. Plenty of taxis at the bottom entrance for those needing it. It cost 12 euros to get back to Ramblas.

Gaudi, again and again !. Every work of Gaudi gives way to new and unsuspected universe. Here, close links between Nature and artefact are wonderfully expressed. Shape, colors and disposition conspire to build an island of beauty and peace.
Glad I went here. Personally I found this more interesting to view than Casa Batllo. I suspect that in many ways this place seemed more like a home than Batllo but it was every bit a visual treat.

Amazing building. The front of the building looks good, but it isn't all that imposing. When you get in the place blows your mind. It is a genuine palace designed by Gaudi for his patron. Gaudi's eccentric style is combined with brilliant engineering and extremely high quality materials to produce a unique palace right in the centre of the city. Just amazing and well worth a visit.

Gorgeous!. A UNESCO World Heritage, Gaudi's Palau Güell is not to be missed if you love architecture/design/art. It costs 12 Euro pp & is open from 1000- 1730 from Nov-March & 1000-2000 from April to October. It is CLOSED on Mondays, except public holidays & on 1 Jan, 6-13 Jan & 25-26 Dec. The phone number is (in Barcelona, otherwise put the country code in) 934 725 775; email: palauguell@diba.cat; website: www.palauguell.cat It was not crowded when we went (in the morning), but began to get that way before we left. There are lockers inside for your backpacks etc. The whole building is a treasure trove of art/design/architecture culminating on the roof with the colorfully, odd-shaped chimneys. It seemed much bigger on the inside that it appeared on the outside--take your time, there is a lot to see & it is all beautiful...from the ornate stair cases, etched/stained windows, carved ceilings, various furniture pieces/rooms & whimsical/fun chimneys. The roof with all of its enticement also gives a stunning view around the area. Definitely enjoyed this exploration! If you have knee trouble, there are a lot of stairs & even on the bottom floors, the floors seem more like ramps. If you can do it, the roof is definitely worth it!

Early Sunday morning treasure. This palace shows all you have to know about Mr Guell and Mr Gaudi's friendship. The artwork on the terrasse is worth the while... and you have a beautiful view of Barcelona. The palace is a bit off the Las Ramblas. Look for it on a map

Amazing building. While some may find this house moody and grim, it does offer insight into the great architect Antoni Gaudi as well as his patron, Eusebi Guell. How many private homes have a chapel hiding behind the doors of a reception room? This was also the first house in Barcelona to have a basement" garage" for the family's horses and carriages as well as those of their visitors? Don;t let the dark, dungeon-like expanses of wrought-iron the at entrance fool you -- capping this building is an orchard of brightly colored ceramic "trees" acting a chimney covers -- a Gaudi trademark. Visitors can tour most of the house and get a glimpse of how the Palau family lived while they were there. At the gift shop, I mentioned to the young cashier that it must have been quite something to live in such a house. She agreed, but added that Guell's children didn't like it -- they found it creepy - she said with a smile.This house is located off of the Ramblas,not far from the huge market -- and well worth the visit. When I was there, there were few visitors, so I could enjoy the tour at my leisure.

It is okay. Never go there on official holidays, you'll be crushed by the masses of tourists. Guess it will be always the same all year round. We would have liked a little bit more tranquility for adoring the artworks.
AMAZING!!. Loved this place. We spent a happy few hours here and could have spend more. Beautiful in the extreme.

Tourist-y but worth it.. Really interesting and cheap compared to the other tourist sites in town. There isn't a lot to see inside the part of the park that you spend 8 Euro to get in to, but it is really beautiful and worth the time.

Great views. Quirky park with great views of the city and more examples of Gaudi's unique architecture. The aqueducts/viaducts were really interesting to see. This is quite a tourist trap with junk sellers and crowds. Be sure to take a bus from the city into the park as you would not want to get off the Metro and walk up this hill!

Astonishing . We visited this amazing palace. Gaudi's early work for the Guell family shows such creativity and opulence. The audio guide worked well- the information enhanced the experience and helped to put each room into the context of the life of the Guell family. Gaudi's use of different materials and forms had created and amazing built environment. And the roof and its creative chimneys- jaw dropping!
Park Guell is a must. This is well worth a visit, but again very long queues. Antoni Gaudi was an absolutely genious. All his buildings are a must no matter how long the queues are!!!

Amazing. There is an outdoor escalator to take you up the hill from the metro to the park. From there be prepared to do some walking and bring water. The park is gorgeous and gives you an amazing view of the city. The houses in the park and all of the mosaics and bridges are stunning. One of the best parts of my visit to Barcelona.
pretty. park gull is really pretty. the view of barcelona from park guell is majestic and amazing. we had a nice spring afternoon there and makes a good spot for photographs.

Another Gaudi Treasure. Timed tour throughout this Gaudi classic was perfectly orchestrated by listening to an informative and well-paced audio guide. Gorgeous structural and decorative decor. Barely a 45-minute wait after purchasing tickets at the window on a tourist-filled Sunday morning. Time for cafe con lechwe on La Rambla.

Worthwhile trip to Parc Guell. Lovely views. Quite scenic view over the city. Very reasonable to see some of the architecture which is the bit you pay for. You can walk around some parts of PARC for free. A couple of cafés to eat in. If going partially by foot and not taxi to door, the road up is quite steep, even using some of the escalators.
A must see. This is a must see in Barcelona , the living art in this park is magnificent it tells allot of the love of Art and colours in Barcelona
amazing. went to visit it as my daughter asked about it and spent most of my camera memory with photos of this place- was a feast for all the senses and can only hope i can translate this to her
Gaudi park in Barcelona. Definitely worth visiting. Popular stop on hop-on hop-off bus. Choose good weather for your visit. Many sites within the park are free, but some require fee.
fantastic. Once I got over the very steep climb to the escalators, park guell gorgeous , well worth a visit, really beautiful, we were there for three hrs but you could go all day as so much to see.
You can Skip this. very little to see here and visiting can be done in 15 minutes. save your $ for other tours and structures.

It is unique. It is a long walk up hill from the L3 metro as suggested by their web site and the signs are very confusing not to mention that no persons are there to ask the where about of the Monumental Zone . But when you got in with your time reserved tickets, you will enjoy it because it is unique. If you have mobility problems, I suggest joining a tour and enter from the front gate.

Stunning Palau Guell. Guell was a friend and patron of Antonio Gaudi. From the unique wrought iron entrance to the beautifully decorated rooms, some with 'built in' wood furniture crafted to Gaudi's specifications the Palau is a delight. There is also a suite of Gaudi designed and custom built furniture. Certainly worth a visit.

Brilliant, take comfortable shoes and be prepared to do a lot of walking!. We spent all day here walking around this huge park, it was great! The walk UP from the metro station nearly finished us off ahead of our planned walk around the park. Steepest hill ever! We paid to go into the museum which was disappointing, the displays invite you to touch yet the museum staff tell you off for doing so....there are some no touch signs around the place, but these are not obvious/easy to spot.
Great Picnic Venue. Spend the afternoon viewing the sites (Gaudi's House is worth seeing if you have time) and walk around the park. You need a ticket for the various attractions in the Park.
Another brilliant building. It is a good example of the type of Catalan architecture that is such a delight to the eye and the heart.

Another Gaudi Marvel. A fabulous park designed by Gaudi. Whimsical , beautiful and practical all at the same time. Gaudi was a genius when it came to architecture and design. We went with a guide from Barcelona Day Tours. It makes all the difference in the world. Her name was Marta and she was marvelous. Don't miss the park but go with a small guided tour so everything can be pointed out and explained.
Stunning Park. Spent 5 hours in the park, it was brilliant. Bus #92 takes you to the gates. Took about 200 photographs!!!!
Football paradise. We'll worth the money a really good tour round all parts of the stadium changing rooms, press box, and the museum so many trophies very good
A Wonderland!. A feast for the eyes. This park is simply magical. I suppose some people walk through quickly but take time to look at all the details. They are amazing!

Worth a visit and easy to get to. The walk to the park is steep in places but there are roads with escalators going upwards to make the journey easier. I used Metro L3 and got off at Vallcarca and the park was well signposted from this station. The park is a must see. Whilst parts of the park are free and you could easily spend a couple of hours looking at the works a ticket to the monument section is recommended. The tickets are timed entry and you queue according to your time slot. Worth buying your ticket online in advance to secure the time slot you want and you can therefore plan your day around it. The cost is minimal and well worth a visit.
Amazing architecture. I'm not much on old houses, but this is different. It is amazing how he designed the building. Even more amazing was that he figured out how to build them.

30 minute time frame to enter the park. The park is beautiful, but you have to pay for the small section of the park where all the architecture is. And that small section is indeed small. The worst part of it is that they have occupancy limits and if you want to buy the tickets online, you have to know exactly what time you're going to be there because they only give you a 30 minute time frame. For instance if you buy the ticket online to enter the park at 10 am, you have to be there between 10 to 10:30. On the other hand if you decide to buy the ticket at the park, which we did, you may have to wait hours to enter the park, which we waited 2 hours for. The general admission is 7 euros which isn't bad. Just gotta keep in mind of how you want to buy the tickets.
No crowds. We went to this house rather than wait on the long lines found at the other Gaudi locations and it was worth the walk. Beautiful home with plenty to see and no crowds.

Another Gaudi Spectacular. I am not really into art but I love spectacular architecture and great gardens - The mosaics and architecture are fantastic and it is a place to go and sit and soak up the atmosphere - Fantastic
Architecture is gorgeous.. Fantastic views of the city from this beautiful park. Architecture is gorgeous. It's better to buy your tickets online before you get there as the lines are incredible.

One of the highlights of our trip. We visit a lot of houses and stately homes when we're home in England and Palau Guell is one of the most spectacular houses I've seen. The audio guide is excellent (and I normally switch off audio guides after 10mins). Entry is timed so it's not too busy but you can take your time once in and there is plenty to see. If you only have time to see one Gaudi building in Barcelona make it this one.

Another Gaudi treat. Like the others, a must see to experience the design, the vision and the reality. The rooftop is amazing, and the interior is very interesting and amazing in its structure. You will be astonished.

Majestic inspiration. Give a great mind, an environmentalist, a superbly creative artist a project, and go see Parc Guell! Stunning public spaces and walkways reminiscent of waves and trees. This is a not to be missed site in Barcelone. Book your entry time early! There could be better signage to get into gates from garden entrances.

Pleasant walk, crowded. Hard to get to as not near a metro stop, however taxis are very cheap throughout the city. Well worth a visit, many street traders inside public park, also central area is timed tickets only. Found a delightful restaurant and bar just outside the gates, cafeteria inside only does sandwiches and drinks.

Palau Güell‬. Another unusual building designed by Gaudi, very interesting to see the building Inside.There is an audio guide that explains everything very well.To me the least impressive building of Gaudi, but still worth a visit.
Later in the afternoon.... Visit later in the afternoon, when the crowds disperse a bit. Another of Gaudi's architectural gems from the basement to the rooftop.

A Free tour!. Whilst very happy to pay for our tour we were delighted to learn that as it was the Equivalent of St. Valentines Day in Barcelona our tour would be FREE. As we are both 77 lifts would have been very welcome so we were dismayed that the only one we located< which was only for descending> was not working but nonetheless we much enjoyed our tour.

Interesting. This was one of Gaudi's initial work. It's interesting to visit this place and then be able to compare with Casa Batllo, Sagrada Familia. You can see the artist evolution. I bought my ticket at he actual house (not in advance or part of any tour) I don't remember the price but its reasonably price. Palau Guell location is great, you could walk down Las Ramblas to many resturants including La Boqueria Market. Flamenco show Tablao Cordoba is nearby as well.
Palau Guell. Beautiful park to see. If you take the metro it is a long long walk to the top of the mountain. Even the hop on hop off bus drops you at the bottom and you have to walk up the hill.

Beautiful mosaics by Gaudi. It was hard to find since we came in at a side entrance,,,had to ride a very steep escalator and climb a lot of stairs to get there. People at gate were great. We were late but they let us exchange our tickets for later ones. The famous mosaic dragon was, in reality, much smaller then i anticipated with all uts hype. Still would not have wanted to miss it. My supposedly current guide book said it was free except for the house, but this changed in 2012.
Gaudy. Wonder why only one house was built here. Lots of infrastructure for prospective home owners that never came.
Beautiful. So beautiful, I swear. So interesting, beautiful, colorful...absolutely amazing. Indeed worth visiting. P.S. Buy tickets in advance online.
Beautiful. The place is stunning, buy your tickets in advance and I`d recomend to go in the morning (though it might be beautiful if you can get the sunset view from the top patio)

Good to see..... If you are fond of architecture and loves Gaudi's work then this place is must go for you. You'll get some good clicks. If you want some souvenirs then there are lot of Asian migrants who sells items inside the park, which you can purchase and pls. pls. do good bargain. :) for good deal

Understated on the outside,but inside and the roof wow!!!. Really interesting building just off on a side street, beautiful ceilings and carvings everywhere,the roof top is full of tall chimney shape structures all different and covered in mosaics, good views above the city,well worth it.
Palau Guell. The park is absolutely amazing. Gaudi's designs are beautiful,each one more incredible than the next.

Interesting. It is indeed a very interesting place to see, freshly renovated and has so many details. However, the rooms are empty, it is only walls that anyone would see inside and ceiling which are the arts. If you expect to see the life how it was by the inhabitants you will be disappointed.Do not miss the rooftop with the view.Make the booking online to beat the line as the tickets are sold per 15 min slots.

Appreciate the thought that has gone in, but did not find it to our liking.. Well to me certainly not the best way to spend your time in Barcelona. Especially not worth paying the entry for the monumental area, it was a bit of let down really. If the entry was 5 euros instead of the 18-20 or how much ever we payed it would have probably been worth it. It is a long walk from the metro, so take a cab,

Gaudi's first big commission and beginning of the Guell/Gaudi collaboration. They say, "The child is the father of the man." This early work of Gaudi was my favorite of the Gaudi residences. It's furnished, at least in part. Do not miss the basement stables and its columns and arches. Enjoy finely detailed craftsmanship; many surprising features and nuances not covered in the audio tour (which is well worth your attention). Go early in the day to enjoy the feel of the rooms and the soaring spaces in this compact palace.

Wonderful park...make sure you book ahead to avoid being disappointed!. It has been nearly 20 years since I last visited here, and the concept of this part still impresses. The only problem is that the central part of the park with Guadi's famous artwork now requires a ticket...and you have to book in advance! We arrived at the park, only to find all the day session tickets were sold out until late evening (which didnt suit us). You can still work around the park which is ideallic, however you dont get to see the main areas. Sad they now do this...I would rather they ask all people to contribute a 1 or 2 euro gold coin for the experience.

Worth the entrance fee. Once again: buy tickets in advance online. Without it can happen you have to wait 2-3 hours to get inside, as we did.After waiting untill our entrance time we entered the center of the park where we came directly to the great terrace with the mosaic bench on the outline. And it is really beautifull, all the forms you see are naturall and colorful. The arcades are also very interessting as it is built up like some organic and mysterious system of maybe dragon bones or something like that. All looks naturally grown. Really beautfull. And worth the visit.

Well worth a visit - but be organised. This park has changed somewhat in the past few years and you now have to book a ticket to get into the 'inner' part of the Park. Having spoken to a few people during our visit, they were being faced with a 3 hour wait, which can be off - putting. We had a couple of hours, but found it passed quickly when we went round the outer part of the park, which has plenty to interest you an has many artists and performers, who are keen to please and provided good entertainment.Be aware that the steps around the park are quite challenging if you have any mobility issues, but it is well worth the effort if you can make it.Once inside the main part of the park, you are once again confronted by Gaudi's incredible imagination and his love of curves is plain for all to see. The Monumental zone provides a great platform for viewing the surrounding area and to admire the many mosaic areas set in the seating around the zone.it is 7 euros to get in, you can book online and there is a great little bar across the road that serves up very palatable food at good prices. Get organised, get your ticket and go!

The first commission. An amazing first opportunity, from this to the Sagrada...what a body of work. The craftmanship of this building is exquisite. One of the few Gaudi buildings that you can view in its entirity. Each room has so many facets you really need to take the time to absorb it all. Do a gaudi walking tour first then visit to really appreciate the magnitude of this commission.

Gaudi's dream housing. First of all we were disappointed to find that when we got there at 11a.m. we couldn't get into the Gaudi part of Parc Guell until 1 p.m. due to the limit on visitors at any one time.However, we looked around the Parc itself and were surprised at how the time passed so quickly.The buildings and designs in Parc Guell are well worth a visit an its interesting to learn about Gaudi's dream of a housing development within the parc. The 'gingerbread house' at the entrance is stunning and typical of Gaudi's quirky design ideas. Well worth a visit but may be better to pre-book your tickets to save time.

A glimpse of the early Gaudi. This gives a glimpse of Gaudi at the beginning of his career before he expressed himself fully at Casa Batllo and Sagrada. The audio tour is nice and tells the story very nicely. Not as impressive as Casa Batllo but well worth it.

This is stunning early work in the heart of Raval. away from the rest of the Gaudi areas, its in the up and coming area close to the Old Port and is simply stunning. Allow an hour and a half; it's light on furniture but high on the detail synonymous with the Catalan master. The atrium ceiling will blow you away, G

Fascinating building. We stumbled upon Palau Guell when exploring La Ramblas on our first day in Barcelona & decided to visit. As it was Sunday afternoon it turned out to be free entry. This was our first taste of Gaudi and we were very impressed. There was so much to see & every aspect was unusual & fascinating. Every little detail had been considered. The audio guide was very informative (also free). The pinnacle of the tour was the roof - for its own sake not for the view - and instantly recognisable from photos we had already seen. Well worth a visit particularly on a Sunday.

a beautifully ornate house tucked into a very narrow street. I didn't quite make it to the roof top (suffer from vertigo) but seeing the rest of the place was sufficient to enthrall me. The pillars holding up the ceiling in the basement stables were given the same architectural treatment. A must to visit!
Did not care for it. This was a waste of my time. The best part of going here was taking the cable car ride. The views from it were spectacular.
Don't miss the roof. Lovely place for 1-2 hours visit. The audio guide is really interesting and helps to understand the story of this building

Intricately Marvelous!. You can not help but wonder how Gaudi was able to create such a house. The level of detail is mind blowing. There must have been hundreds of master craftsmen (and women) that were involved in the creation of this masterpiece.The audio tour was very helpful and interesting. My wife and I switch off while the other tended to our two year old. It is not the best place for young kids but if you tour with a bit of haste you can see and experience everything in about an hour and then take some awesome pics with the kids on the roof in front of all the colorful chimneys. That is the main event and a must see!

A place to relax. We did not queue to pay to go into the 'monument' part of the park. Instead we wondered around the free park area where there was enough 'Gaudi'' to keep us happy. There was some great views over Barcelona. We wondered around, sat and had a coffee, generally relaxed and took some great photos. Precisely what you need on a City break type holiday.

Timing is key.. The foot traffic going through Palau Guell is overwhelming, to say the least, so timing is key. The Park sells tickets all day for entry with the latest being 7:30pm. (check website, times change depending on the season) Pick the last available entry into the Park. 30 minutes after the last entry the Park is free for everyone. Most people just wait the additional 30 minutes so they don't have to pay the entry fee. The Park is almost completely yours to explore for 30 minutes, worth the entry price. This makes taking photos a dream come true. Once the free entry happens, get out of there, it becomes crazy again.

Awesome work. Visited Palau Guell in March 2015. It's definitely an awesome work from Gaudi's collection in Spain. it is situated in the district of Raval, just a few steps off the Rambla. Parts of the façade of the Palau Güell resemble a Venetian palace, the oval portals at the front are conspicuous. I would recommend everyone to visit here when you are in Barcelona.

Worth a visit.. This park is worth a visit, if you want to spend some time outdoors, and you have had enough of indoor museums, art galleries and cathedrals. It was very busy even though it was not high season, it would be easier to book a time to enter online,so as not to waste time.
Situated in a great part of town. Views are fantastic. Can see the Med from the terraces. Fantastic Gaudi . Quest can be long. Buy tickets on line to save waiting.

Amazing house in now busy, slightly disheveled block. . The audio guide is a great help understanding the confusing layout (confusing meaning jam packed house). The first thing you visit is the basement which are stables! Hard to imagine the place back then with livestock descending the ramp. The home is so minutely detailed; gorgeous woodwork ceilings. I would have like to have learned what became of Guell's father-in-law's adjoining home next door. It's odd to go out on the back porch of this "palace" and see the laundry hanging everywhere outside the neighbors' windows.

Dwell at Guell. We made a mistake and didn't book for the tour of Gaudi's house and museum. But you can wander around the grounds, avoid the touts selling rubbish.If you arrive by the tourist buses - if is a fairly strenuous uphill walk to the park!

Beautiful Park. Worth the 700000000000 steps to get to!!!! Actually, a lovely gentleman saved us from climbing all the way up, as we were one street away from the escalators that help shorten the climb. You do still have to climb some. The park is beautiful and worth the visit. I am 50-50 on buying the tickets for the inner section of the park. You can choose not to pay to get into the Gaudi section, and just walk around the outside of it and get a good feel for it. We did pay to go in, and were only in there for 15 to 20 mins, but enjoyed being in there. Either way, it's fine. As with most popular sights, try to get tickets online ahead. Great views of Barcelona from up there.

Early Gaudi brilliance. It's a good job that Eusebi Guell had deep pockets. The sheer extravagance of Gaudi's work on Palau Guell is breathtaking, as is his imagination. It is interesting to see that this was one of Gaudi first commissions and he had yet to develop his dislike of straight lines.

Take a nice walk and see the sites. This park is awesome. If you want to go into the park itself buy tickets online. We spent a couple of hours walking around and above the park seeing the view over Barcelona and seeing the excellent architecture and how it is blended into nature ... Go see it ...
Not your typical Gaudi. Beautiful house, with much to look at. But not that much jumped out and screamed "Gaudi" other than the roof- but still you can see his touches here and there.

Timing is everything. My daughter and I took the Metro to Palau Guell. We had a hard time finding the entrance to the park from the Metro because we did not expect quite the length of the walk from the Metro. We also did not expect the hills that were so steep they had escalators, although it was rather fun to ride on outdoor escalators up residential streets. The park itself is very pleasant. Inside the free part of the park, at the top of a hill, there is a very disturbing "street musician performer" who is aggressive and loud. When we found our way to the Gaudi section of the park, we were told that it had exceeded its capacity and we would have to wait for 1.5 hours to enter. By the time we got into the Gaudi section, the lines were too long to be able to see the inside of the buildings. We did get the iconic photos from the roof, and the view is very good. My advice it to get good directions (or take a cab) and get there early before the Gaudi section has reached capacity, or buy tickets in advance if you can.

Amazing Gaudi's work. We went really early so we could enjoy the day there. It was sunny and just the perfect day to be out in the park. It's very pretty and serene. The roof is beautiful and when you see the view from up there you will know why. There is some construction work going on around but I decided to filter that out and just see the beauty of the place. Gaudi really made me feel alive in that park. Do take pictures!
Worth a Visit. Great example of Gaudis work. Very interesting tour. So well designed a must see in Barcelona.Tickets can be bought outside. So clean and well kept. Easy to find just of Las Ramblas.

A hidden gem. The best historic building we visited in Barcelona.Small queues, few tourists, plenty of fantastic photo opportunities.Spectacular furniture, exquisite architecture, amazing depth of quality throughout. Wait till you get to the roof area....You won't be disappointed!

A "must see" in Barcelona!!!. The park is really nice! The monument area is just unique!! The 2 buildings of Gaudi and the "crazy" area around it makes you feel you are in a fairy tail!!!
I would recommend to buy the tickets before you go there! We had to wait almost 2 hours!!

Need to plan ahead - buy ticket before coming!. More Gaudi. There is a public access and another area that needs a ticket and is timed access. Chances are you will need to wait 2-3hours if you don't buy before hand. It's interesting but not a must see. The views of Barcelona from the city are great if you come from the east entrance.

Wow!!!. Palau Guell entranced us from the first moment we entered the basement level stables. The palace incorporates innovation in all areas: design, space and light. We used the audio guide and visited the stables, vestibule, dining room, terrace and rear facade, billiard room, painting and sculpture studio, visitors' hall, the musicians' gallery, the servants' quarters, three bedrooms, bathrooms, and the roof terrace. Gaudi's architecture and decorative details are amazing. Palau Guell is now a world heritage UNESCO sight - a real WOW!!!

Another masterpiece by Antoni Gaudi. We came upon this very interesting palace on a walk from our hotel (TRYP Apolo). This was built between 1886 and 1890 and was commissioned to Gaudi by an industrialist and politician, Eusebl Guell. Gaudi's project centered around an entirely new concept of space, treatment of light, along with rich decorative details in wrought iron, glass, pottery, stone and wood. All of the rooms in the palace had fireplaces with very unique chimneys for all up on the roof of the palace. A very interesting place with lots of stairs. On the basement level were stables that are very unique. I highly recommend visiting this palace to further get a feeling of Gaudi's work.

Truly Magical Place. The Gaudi design is so beautiful -- like walking inside a piece of art. And the setting overlooking Barcelona is unbeatable. Cost to enter the Gaudi section of the park was reasonable and the timed entry meant that the place never felt crowded. The colorful setting seemed to make everyone there happy and friendly and the experience was one of our most relaxing and memorable in the city. A triumph of one artist's imagination.

Another Gaudi design. What an amazing architect Gaudi was. What appears to be a small building from outside is transformed inside on several floors from cellar to the chimneys on the roof top. Just off La Ramblas it is a very central Palau to visit.
really pretty. definitely worth a visit, wear comfy shoes because its a long walk up! very beautiful, highly recommend it!

Gaudi Exhibit. Very unusual and interesting place. Great opportunity to view Gaudi's work. Don't wait in line for a visit to the porter's house. It has empty rooms with slide presentations--interesting but disappointing. Spend your time viewing the exteriors.

Gaudi's first major commission is worth a vusit. Plan ahead. They sell so many tickets and control admission per hour. Very nice because the museum is not overrun. If you only have time to see one home by Gaudi, go to Casa Batllo. It's by far my favorite. However, if you visit Palau Guell first and then visit Casa Batllo, you will see how his early ideas evolved and influenced his later work. The more I see if Gaudi's work, the more I appreciate his genius.

An amazing historical house. We were lucky enough to be staying at a nearby hotel and we visited the home of Guell and his family which is one of the most stunning of Gaudi's creations of architecture. The house is a glorious mix of colour and textures and is a joy to visit. A definite sight for anyone visiting Barcelona.

Parc Guell. Have been before 2 year ago, no issues, but this time timed entry meant an 11/2 hr. wait as they only allow 400 people on the square at any one time and entry to the house was extra. well worth the visit if you can avoid the school parties.

Magnificent. Oh, to be a Guell.... Our first immersion in Gaudi in Barcelona. What a great experience. Only fully reopened to the public since 2011, this amazingly restored one time home of the Guell family blows your mind. The boldest mix of Moorish and Art Deco themes, even the stables which are reminiscent of palaces in Granada. We bought tickets at the door, and had a 1 hour delay between time of purchase and entry. No problem - grabbed a coffee on Las Ramblas. The audio guide is very helpful. Take the time to listen to each explanation. Very interesting with insights into both the Guell family and Antonio Gaudi himself.
A wonderful place to visit. A great way to spend an afternoon in Barcelona, gives you an appreciation of Gaudi's amazing works..
GAUDI!!. A great attraction for both adults and kids alike. We went in February in a sunny day and it was busy, so expect crowds.

A different Gaudi. This Gaudi work has a relatively cheaper entrance fee (8€ for students and 12€ for adults) compared to the architect's other works. The audioguide is free and is available in different languages. The design of the palace's interior is filled with wood and iron works, which shows how talented Gaudi was. It made me realize how lucky the architect was that he'd got a patron and friend in Eusebi Guell. He could literally do whatever he wanted and it showed in the luxurios and elaborate interiors of the house. I was able to appreciate Gaudi's form and functionality concept with the chimney tops found at the palace's rooftop. They are really nice and pretty. The trencadis technique is apparent and welldone.
Loved it!. Well organized tour with your own language guide. A beautiful Gaudi building well preserved. This site should not be missed!

Thank you for free tour. I'm not sure why I could get free ticket here, but it might because it was Sunday... also free audio guide:)Inside, it was very nice and really bigger than I thought. It was old but I thought that 'it is Gaudi's!!' Especially, I liked the organ in the main hall.

Beautiful architecture in the city center . We went as two families with teenagers without buying tickets in advance. We just happened upon it and there were no lines. Audio tour included with admission and the building has been kept up very nicely. The rooftop view is superb. We enjoyed it with not many people there as it was closer end of day. We saw it in about an hour and a half.

amazing place. We walked from valcarra metro station. Beware this route HSS massive hills. We loved this route as you walked all the way round this way. Meeting different artists and stalls along the way. We had a great day and the buildings in the part which you pay €8 to visit are unbelievably amazing. One of our best days in Barcelona.

Unexpected surprises. I thought the lines for Casa Battlo and Casa Ametller were too long, and the price too high for what I was expecting to see. Instead, I wandered around back towards La Rambla and stumbled upon Palau Guell. Figuring it was a sign from Fate, telling me I needed to see at least ONE Gaudi residence before I left the city, I waited behind only one person in line, and handed over a reasonable amount of Euros for my ticket. In return? A wealth of information, a "free" audio guide, a long unrushed time to enjoy the residence, and beautiful city views from the top. The quality and amount of detail that went into building this was amazing. The stone-, wood-, and tile-work was gorgeous (and I really loved the basement!)Literal crowning glory of the place though is the roof. Who knew chimneys could be so gorgeous?!Definitely recommend! It's literally off La Rambla, pretty close to La Boqueria, so fit it into your day.
Check. I got to see the famous bench and check seeing that off of my bucket list! It was great to see the view of Barcelona (down to the Mediterranean Sea) which was breathtaking!
Great park. This is a very enjoyable park if you like somewhere nice to walk. Full of lots of Gaudi works and attractions. Would recommend.

a very original park. There is a great pleasure to walk all the way up and around the park, even when it is warm. from the flat area, the view of the city is beautiful.
It is a very popular place with thousands of tourists now.
Another Gaudi must see!. Another one of Gaudi's masterpieces. If for nothing else, Gaudi's buildings alone, are worth a visit to Barcelona, as I call it, the city that sparkles.

Make a reservation!. If you go on line you can just walk right in and see the fabulous park at your own pace...and avoid most of the crowds. It is wonderful to see in the sunshine...we had gone several years ago in the rain and it does not look the same!! What a shame that the "development" didn't go ahead at the time...but what a gift the family gave the city as a wonderful park!...unique I'm sure in the world!!
palau guell. very expensive as everything else and if you must choose what to see then I'd skip this one. It is very dark, not at all other Gaudi works, a bit of a disappointment
Gaudi must see. what a contrast to the later Gaudi creations - another rooftop to be experienced and explored, very close to La Rambla

Amazing Gaudi´s park. A bit far from the Barcelona centre but with metro/underground and cca. 15-20min. walk reachable. For the small "typical Gaudi" part you have to pay entrance fee (book it in advance via web) for exact time. But the rest of the park is free of charge and you can walk up on the hill to get one of the most beautiful views on Barcelona city.

Best of the three main Gaudi houses. Fascinating place, darker, more industrial style than the others, loads to see. Plus much cheaper and less crowded than pedrera & batilo. If I only had time for one Gaudi house it would be this one.
well worth it. pre booked tickets but wasn't necessary as there was no queue. Free audio guides were great, lovely restoration project and great views from the roof.

very different form other Gaudi buildings. this is a great experience and a good supplement to Parc Güell, Casa Battlo, La Sagrada and Casa Mila - it is very different and demonstrate other features of Gaudís thinking and great sense for use of the space - quite interesting with the main room and the space for concerts -would love to experience that! and offcourse the rooftop demonstrates a bit of what you know of Gaudi - the rest of the house was rather surprising.
Worth The Visit If You Have Time. Glad we visited...do not buy a ticket...just walk the park. The panoramic views of the city are wonderful.

Colorful!. I really enjoyed my trip here; the employees were all so great, the architecture was incredible, and the colors were so vivid and eye pleasing. We went right during sunset, which I highly recommend because of the view at that time. The entrance fee for the day was around 7€, and if you buy online you can skip the lines. You have to buy the ticket for a certain time and have a 30-minute period to enter after your time starts. Definitely worth the money! And the surrounding park is free.

Money and a mad genius!!. Palau Güell is kind of awesome, you really don't expect it to be, but it kind of is. 12€ gets you a guidebook, audio guide and entry. If you love the mad genius of Antoni Gaudi and want to see the home he built for his friend and patrol Güell, this is pretty fantastic! It was really a little Diamond in the rough!

Average enjoyment. We travelled off season and still the park was packed with people enjoying the weather. I can't even imagine what it must be like during the summer. I was disappointed that the actual garden aspect of the park is so limited and the park shows such overuse. If I had a choice I would go to Casa Battlo to get the real Gaudi imagination at its best.

great scenery. I could stare in to space for hours up there. the park was amazing. make sure you grab yourself a drink at guell sandwhich bar which is just at the entrance. Take comfortable clothing and a selfie stick for those landscape shots ;)
Gaudí, Gaudí. Once you're in Barcelona, you'll see Gaudí everywhere. But nothing compares to being inside of the Park Guell and see so close the details of all this works. Totally worth it!

Much more impressive on the inside. You can't appreciate this building from the outside as it's quite plain. The audioguide is excellent and explains the impressive design of each room. The view from the roof is also nice. It's quite expensive but is interesting if you are interested in architecture or Gaudi in general.

Favourite place. We loved this parc and if I were to visit again I would definitely go armed with a picnic of local food and a bottle of chilled cava! A place to spend a sunny afternoon for sure, really beautful

Amazing architecture . Amazing architecture. You get a tape with guiding, so that you know what the rooms was used too. Gaudi has a lot of great architecture that you just must see when you are in Barcelona!

Very busy - buy your ticket online before. It is worth buying tickets online to get into the special area where there are amazing views of the park and architecture. It was really busy in the park and I would recommend taking a picnic or eating outside of the park. We paid to look at Gaudi's house and that was not really worth the money tho it was in the shade if it is a hot day.

Awesome example of Gaudi's genius. This was my third visit and was a little saddened to find that The Guel family's gift to the city is accessible by ticket only ( the monument section), this was always free now, you have to book and you get a time slot .. still go for it but book your tickets online before you go to avoid the 2 hour, I wish we'd done this but remember the rest of the park is fantastic so killing a couple of hours wait is no hardship.

Beautiful view over the city. A great place to visit early morning and enjoy your breakfast on the terrace whilst looking over the City of Barcelona as it awakens. Be prepared for some steep climbing (not for the faint hearted). Good walking shoes highly recommended. j
Majestically. Mysterious and majestic castle.I felt like a historical film! Castle made a lasting impression!I recommend a visit.
Lots of Gaudi's genius and ingenious to appreciate. I and my wife like very much Barcelona and the inherent Gaudi's work. This park is a richful environment to appreciate Gaudi.
WOW. Wow, just fantastic architecture by Gardi, beyond belief, get there early to beet the crowds as it does fill really quick.

My favorite sight in Barcelona - and there are many. You can be entertained here all day, there is so much to see. Just the mosaics alone will occupy your time! The buildings and gardens are fascinating and there is a high, broad, open area where street entertainers perform and you can just sit on the undulating mosaic benches and look out into the Barcelona distance.
Uncommonly. Uncommonly. A unique place. Unusual and beautiful.Great atmosphere. I want to come back here again and again.

Impressive!. The crown jewel of Parc Guell and really of Barcelona as far as artsy architecture goes! We were amazed by the beauty of the area! An absolute must-see, so be sure to buy your tickets online and get there a few minutes early!
