Tourists every where. This was a very nice place to visit....I had hoped foe some peace and tranquility!!.....but this doesn't happen here, or many places in Barcelona ...all the same, it's a beautiful spot, and shouldn't be missed
Loved the viaducts in the park.. This is such an attractive and unique place. I loved especially the wonderful viaducts which blended so perfectly into the landscape. I loved the Gaudi architecture.

Nice afternoon. Well kept obviously busy but the timed entrance helps a bit. Only time we had to queue was to enter one of the gate houses. Got to say this is the first time we failed to get decent refreshments the café was poorly stocked and just basic water was well over priced. Bit of advice take your own water there are plenty of local shops between the park and metro to pick up what you need. But the park is fantastic.

Fascinating insight to gaudi's early style. Palau Guell is one of Gaudi's earlier Modernist designs and illustrates his developing style. It is and extensive richly decorated home with many wonderful features and amazing attention to detail. It is probably advisable to book ahead online and allow plenty of time to appreciate this exceptional piece of architecture. the audio tour is very informative and included in the admission price.

Worth the trip, but plan ahead. About a year and a half ago they started charging for access to all of the park sites you see in pictures and movies. It's a logistical pain - you buy tickets at the entrance (or one of several points, none of which will be near you when you realize you have to go back and get tickets). The tickets are time-stamped allotting you a certain window, and depending on crowds, you may have to wait a while before you get in. There is not a lot to do in the park otherwise, once you have walked around and enjoyed the outdoors and the jewelry vendors. Not many conveniently located restaurants nearby to kill time either. If you have small or tired kids, it is important to plan ahead and get tickets early or in advance. Still worth it and on a clear day there is nothing like it in the world.

Stunning, interesting and quiet. This is not as exuberant and quirky as Gaudi's Casa Batllo. However,don't let that put you off. It's the only house Gaudi designed and it was for a mega rich businessman who by today's standards would be worth €70,000,000,000. Wow! A real view of how the other half live. We visited at 11am, no queue, we went straight in and had an audio guide with 20+ features explained in good detail. Great views of the house from different angles, the planned route is very well thought out. For some reason, this house is missed off the main tourist guides, bus tours etc so it's quieter than the "big ones" but still very entertaining and worth a visit. Good opportunities for photos with very few people walking around. They space out the tours and limit numbers, thank goodness. Do visit. It's a remarkable house with interesting explanations of the Guell-Gaudi partnership.

An Impressive Facade.. This was another of the buildings visited on our Gaudi walking tour. Once again a very striking exterior with the signature exotic chimneys, although not quite as exotic as Casa Batllo or Casa Mila. This was a whistle stop viewing and we didn't get to see the interior, which is reputed to be splendid.Apparently the building was bequethed to the City many years ago. Well worth visiting just to see the exterior.
Amazing. Another must-see as an example of Gaudi's influence on a great scale comes alive! Originally planned as a housing development, this Park is an opportunity to see the magic of Gaudi'

Very enjoyable and indepth tour of palace Gaudi designed, incredible attention to details. The tour is very nice. You must get the audio guide to really get the full appreciation of what Gaudi accomplished with this palace. There is great attention to making each floor and each room wonderful. Even the basement where horses and cars were kept is beautifully done and appropriate for its function. They call it a palace but it is really just a large house.

A must!. So worth hopping of the bus to walk around! Amazing architecture by Gaudi, plenty of places to sit and soak in atmosphere. I imagine would be packed in the summer though, we travelled in March and still long queues for the loo! But don't leave Barcelona without seeing it.

where the genius begin.. First I have to warn you that the palace is in the bad area of barcelona. So becareful and it look dangerous if you will go out from the palace at evening or night time.The Guell family is base there. that is why they still build their palace in that area. This is also where the master begin the journey. Guadi has a chance to design this as a first project. It will look lot different from latter work. It will be great to understand where Guadi start. the Genius not just happen but through many work and experience.So this is great to learn and the place is beautiful. I did a guide tour in english. it is great and the tour last 1 hour. after the tour finish you have a chance to look the palace by yourself.

Different & Fun. Different & Fun
One incredible palace in one incredible garden where we can find the maxim exponent of Gaudí's art.

nice view. the parc itself was beautiful with a lot of people playing music and we could find some relax spots to sit and hear the music with the beautiful view of barcelona! you can also see the sea!

Concept Neighborhood Before It's Time. Features of this park, designed by Gaudi, are iconic. Gaudi's use of broken tile to add color to the playful designs is distinct. Known for integrating architecture and nature, he was planning a suburban neighborhood. Walk the park that is the monument, then head up the hill to see a wonderful City to Med view from above. Great stop on a Barcelona highlights tour.

A nice walk around. We did't pay to get in becouse my teens were not that interested. You can walk around the park which I was able to force my kids to do and area was nice. A good view from the hills to the city.
Not much to see inside.. Its a beautiful place but if you re interested in architecture you can see everything outside. Theres not much difference.
Interesting. Located in the “Born” area there’s Palau Guell. Austere but impressive. The ticket costs 12€ but it’s worth it!
Hidden surprise!. This Palau is Gaudi's first commission and the only one he ever completed. Its a must for Gaudi fans. Bonus is the roof terrace with great views & Gaudi chimneys
You have to go, but.... You have to go, but after La Pedrera or Casa Batllo, this is too dark and empty inside.But it is part of Gaudi's history so it is a must

Ehh. This park was pretty neat but with everything else to do in Barcelone I would not recommend it. There are plenty of other sites and attractions in the city center. It's more of a personal taste but Gaudi's house/park pale in comparison to the Sangrada.
fantatic. This is a great attraction for both adults and kids alike. We went in February and it was busy, so expect crowds. Buy your tickets online, much easier.

Not your typical Gaudi- you could give it a pass. First impression is this is a very un-Gaudi like building but it is what his benefactor wanted. The architecture is heavy & dark. It seems more like a fortress than a home. Very closed in & not much light, this is my least favorite Gaudi building. The stable area is more interesting architecturally than the rest of the dull rooms. The saving grace is the rooftop, here is classic Gaudi beautiful , fun, fanciful chimneys. The video guide is difficult to see the screen is so tiny so you stop looking at it , the narration is uninspired. This is not the first Gaudi building to see, you will be disappointed, it is kind of a let down until you get to the rooftop.

Fascinating architecture. Interesting characters, Guell and Gaudi. Enjoyed this immensely. Allow plenty of time to go through the floors. We saw a couple of bus tours allow about an hour for the people to view it. You will miss so many lovely details if you have to rush it. It is very quirky and can quite understand how it must have seemed like madness at the time of construction. The quality of the work and the design is staggering and it has been magnificently restored. Don't miss this in favour of Gaudi's other houses!
Amazing architecture. The detail of Antonio work is outstanding from the roof tops to the park beautiful mosaques.Definitely worth a visit his work is outstanding.

"The Chimney Pots"!!. This was our first taste of Gaudi and remains my favourite. What a visionary was Eusebio Guell to commission Gaudi to design this building. This is the only example of domestic architecture that Gaudi completed and has not undergone significant alteration in the 120 years since it was built. Not as busy or well known as Casa Batllo, but a must for a visitor to Barcelona

Palacio Güell. Alternative to Casa Batlló. The Palacio Güell is not the most famous of all the Gaudí buildings in Barcelona but it is definitely worth a visit. There are less tourist than in any of the other buildings what makes it easy to walk up and down the different floors (basement to roof) enjoying the great architecture of this place and the explanations from the audio guide. Although not as spectacular as Casa Batlló, it offers a better understanding of Gaudí's work (and the entrance fee is half). The roof is simply amazing.
Beautiful design. Many beautiful rooms with fascinating architecture. The roof with the designed chimneys is also very interesting.

Please do go and explore the beauty... mindblowing place. Make sure everyone is ready to walk and talk.. Yes there is a lot to walk for those who cant walk much.. but few spots are so beautiful that all your pain is gone for a toss.. :)

not for the faint hearted.. After a walk up a rather steep hill you can continue on the escalator to the top. A good price and if you have done the bus tour use your voucher. The PARC is delightful, find the laundry lady!

It's OK.. Thought there would be more to see, not really worth the hours walk and 8 euros each. There was only a very small part you could actually walk around. We we're in and bored within half hour.
Fantastic personal residence. Although some architectural sites in Barcelona get more press,this former personal residence is incredibly beautiful--you will be amazed.
Fabulous views from here. Steep walk to get there but worth it for the view from the terrace. Could have spent longer there as the gardens are very pretty

Unbelievably Cool. It's not the twisting, organic examples of Gaudi's signature style, but it is magnificent in it's own right. It was one of Gaudi's earlier designs, before he created his recognizable style. It is breathtaking. The audio guide is also really informative.

I loved it. Recommended to me by a friend, I ended up here and found it to be far more interestting if only because there were very few people when I went, the price was reasonable (which is more than can be said for La Pedrera and Casa Battlo at 27 and 21 Euros respectively!) The roof of course is the best as the chimneys are stunning.

Good treat for a rainy day. It was raining so I decided to check out Palau Guell rather than wander in the rain. I feel that many of the reviews here are for the park, not the palau which is quite different. This is a building built between 1886 and 1890 which was a home to the Guell family, which the park is also named after. With admission you get a personalized tour via headset which makes the place vastly more interesting. I was upset that the rooftop was closed due to rain, as most of the house lacks the flair that is typical of the Gaudi style.

unusual but intresting. Was very intresting very relaxing and I felt totally destressed walking around so much so I lost my phone !but incredably som eone found it and handed it in how amazing was that! I was very lucky thank you .Park is lovely look for the parakeets amazing
End of the Day Treat. It was the end of the day (walked from sagrada Familia). It was pretty far, but you can do it.We didn't pay for the tour, but probably should have. I'd go again.

A beautiful place to spend an afternoon!. A short walk uphill is well worth the effort as the experience is outstanding! At only 11 euros to enter the parc it's worth every "penny" The landscaping design is stunning with wonderfully thought out areas to relax and spend some time to yourself, though given the amount of tourists it may be difficult at times. One of the houses was being restored so lots of scaffolding but I'm sure it'll be worth all the restoration for everyone in the future. The view over Barcelona is amazing even though the day wasn't sunny, it is March afterall!
Fun and Fanciful. Another Gaudi delight. Small and walkable. Certainly worth your time in Barcelona! I would put it on my top ten Barcelona list. Take a taxi to get here.

Magnificent Art Nouveau Palace!. Just saw a few reviews but this attraction is the palace and not the park! Anyway this museum is right off the Ramblas and also well worth seeing. The Palau was constructed between 1886 and 1890 for aristocrat and industrial tycoon Eusebi Guell by Gaudi and was the family home before moving to Park Guell. The place kind of reminds me of a Venetian palace as it was planned to be a glamorous and functional Catalan art nouveau mansion with a surface of only 400 m2. The oval portals were the entrance for the horse drawn carriages into the stunning basement where the servants also lived. The elevated ground floor contains the magnificent entry hall with a 17 m. high dome, party and dining room. The second floor with the bedrooms, bathroom and toilet are rather conventional. The roof terrace is more startling with 20 chimney's decorated with mosaics of broken pottery. It also affords a great view of the residential surroundings. Guell Palace became a museum in 1945 and was declared a world heritage site by UNESCO in 1984.

Spectacular views!!!. A park up a hill!! Quite stunning. Unfortunately it was a very cold day we visited, so did not see so much of the park. We took in the wonderful views, and walked through some of the amazing Gaudi architecture. A place to visit in the summer I would think.
Beautiful view. Clean and interesting, Parc Guell is a MUST DO when visiting Barcelona. The architecture and view over Barcelona is simply stunning. Bus 24 takes you straight to the entrance.

I have seen it from the fifth floor of Hotel Gaudi. It was interesting experience that my hotel was just opposite to the Palau Güel and I have seen its face, roof in any time of the day. It is terrifically distinctive...

Disappointed. We were disappointed as there were long queues and the areas were restricted as to where you could go. Once you left one section you couldn't go back if you wanted a second look at something else. There were a lot of people there but it was far from crowded, so what it is like in high season I don't know. The best part was the wonderful view over Barcelona to the sea and the architecture you could see without queuing.
Fantastic Palace!. What a beautiful place, unbelievable, painstaking restoration of one of Gaudi's early residential works. Just off the Rambla, take the detour and spend an hour here!

A "Must See" in Barcelona. There is a lot of ground to cover, so plan to spend some time here. If you only have limited time its still worth the visit I think admission about 12-15 euros, and when I went the admission was free after 5:00 (I believe it was 5:00 may have been 6:00), however, the sun would be setting by then so to really enjoy it I would go early. My trip was in February so it is cold and this is an outdoor experience. I think I would have enjoyed it more had t not been so cold. Still, beautiful architecture, sculptures, and gardens. Worth making a visit to see.
no Reservation, long wait. It was free entrance, for sereral years. Nowsday, you have better to make reservation before, I waited more than three hours!

Worth the visit. We chose the Palau Guell, honestly, because the 12 EUR price tag was much lower than ~20 EUR for the Casa Batllo and La Pedrera. And it was worth the money, especially because we were able to book at English guided tour (Fridays at 2 PM). The house is gorgeous (including the bits not designed by Gaudi) and the roof with its chimneys is the cherry on top.

So much scaffolding. An interesting experience, now you have to pay to get in, but much of the best of the gardens is surrounded by scaffolding. We know it has to be done to preserve the curiosity, but even when you have paid to get into the 'constructed part', there is yet more payment to get into buildings.OK but wont be back
Very interesting!. Very interesting and way-out day! Nice walking around master of architecture lovely gardens. It is like you appears in other world...

Wonderful Hospitality. All architectures Gaudi has created are so marvelous. Especially, the ceiling which we can see from the main floor is mysterious so that we can’t leave this place soon. I was so impressed by the all wonderful staffs working here, as well as the architecture and the decoration at Palau Güell . I asked them for using the elevator, since my old parents don’t prefer the long stairs. So, the staffs agreed pleasantly to using it, stopped it at each floor, and showed us there lightly so that we could observe freely and slowly to the rooftop. Thanks to the very kind Spanish staffs, we could look at many precious things and have a very good time. I offered some tips to them. But they declined my offer politely and didn’t receive them. A couple years ago, although the rate of the unemployment and GDP in Spain were in the news, Spanish people is so kind, gentle and respectable, I thought. Japanese hospitality (Omotenashi) is highly appreciated all over the world.However, Spanish hospitality was also wonderful ! I greatly appreciate your kindness.

Don't confuse with park Guell!. This place is lovely, a fair bit cheaper to get into than other places and definitely worth the money. You get your own free handheld tour guide to walk you around the building, the architecture is beautiful as well as the outside. A lot of is is not original which is something they do state, although they have restored and replaced items from the same era to keep the feel. At 12 euros, it's definately work the look

Very impressed!. Fantastic restoration on this building - once you get upstairs into the house you really get to see how amazing Gaudi was - and how great it was that some one like Guell supported his vision

Gothic at it's best. I came across the palau Guell on my last visit to Barcelona about 12 years ago and made my way back this time. The building has undergone some its straight out of Batmans Gotham city whoever created the set for Batmans house must have been a fan of Gaudi . Amazing

nothing much unless you are a hardcore Gaudi fan. It is a nice park set at the top of the mountain with a great view of the city. When we were there there was a queue for tickets to explore the 'house/museum' and there were designated timeslots for people to enter to basically take photos of a better view of the city below.Overall good place to spend some time walking about, but entry to the museum is not worth the wait for us.

Just amazing architecture. We must have spent at least 1/12 hours walking around. Gaudi's imagination is incredible. The amount of thought and effort and craftsmanship that went into building this house is breathtaking.Well worth the 12 Euros entrance and that includes the electronic tour guide.

GAUDI'S EXCELLENT MASTERPIECE!. This is the first architecture of the great Antoni Gaudi. Actually a palace for a rich businessmen, designed by Gaudi, after more than 125 years still the beauty of the palace mesmerising everyone! I already visited most of the Gaudi's great architectural masterpieces all over Barcelona, including Sagrada familia, la pedrera, park guell, casa batllo, most of the designs some sort of common appearance there. For an example, the chimnies. Mosaic work also when we are looking each other, same pattern there. But here again the fundamental designs same, the beautiful decorations completely breathtaking! Tickets bit over priced, 12 euros.

beautiful but get there early to see the monuments. Its a bit of an uphill walk from the tourist bus to the entrance but worth it. Cost 8 euros to get into the monuments bit but the park itself is free. We got there about midday and had to wait an hour to get to see the Gaudi section but it was worth it - once you had fought past the hoards of people with selfie sticks down by the lizard!! The views are fantastic and its nice only a set number of poeple are let in at a time so the scenery and setting can be appreciated.but if you can get advance tickets do so.
beautiful!. I typically don't care for art, but I love coming here! Beautiful park with great views. Definitely worth a visit!

Lovely views over the city. You can access most of the park without a ticket and it's a beautiful place to have a picnic. The ticket allows you access to the central area with the iconic Gaudi structures, you have a strict half hour slot to enter this area. Book online to save a lot of hassle. Beautiful view of the city.
Gaudi Masterpiece...... Sunny weather on a visit to this place could make a huge difference to enjoy the beauty of this placee.....one of the best places in barcelona.
Great Views. Great Views, touristy but large enough to have space. You can see the whole city from the park. I would say montjuistic is a better park across town.
Beautiful . This was one of the highlights of my trip. We were blessed with beautiful weather & were able to wonder around the huge park for hours. I would definitely recommend.
Great tribute to Gaudi. Make sure to give yourself plenty of time to enjoy the park and attractions. Art requires time and contemplation to appreciate.
Wow. It is one of my highlights of barcalona. The park and all the amazing structures are worth at least 3 hours of your time. Remember to pet the dragon.

Don't miss it!. I can't believe we almost didn't fit this onto our (groaning) Barcelona list. This place is just beautiful. The level of craftsmanship and vision to create something like this is amazing. And weirdly it was relatively quiet - we wandered straight in (middle of tourist season!) and had many of the rooms to ourselves. It's calm and cool and probably our favourite place to worship at the alter of Gaudi in Barcelona. And just off La Rambla! What more could you want.

Beautiful. Incredible. Walk around and enjoy.. Barcelona is loaded with Gaudi this and that. This park is beautiful. it is interesting and detailed. every way you take a picture, something interesting will be in the background.

How the other half lived.... This was a relatively early building for the archiect Antoni Gaudi, commissioned by a ealthy industrialist. It is just a few yards off La Rambla and well-worth a visit.There is nothing here that you are likely to find in a "normal" home of the wealthy, Gaudi has placed his mark on everything here from the layout and more importantly all of the interior decoration and design. You start off in the underground stables - a work of art in themslves, and climb up through the building through magnificent rooms, all decorated in individual styles relevant to the owner at the time that it was built.By the time that you get to the top of the building you will have an idea what it might have been like to inhabit such a place, but as you look out now towards the rear you are reminded that normal people don't live that way. The surrounding buildings are no-where near as grand with washing hanging off the balconies etc... I am not sure if it applies every Sunday but we got in for free, usual price 11 Euros - but we would happily have paid that to see around this unique and fascinating building.
Beautiful. Lovely beautiful historic place , lovely place to visit for a day out in Barcelona , well recommended .
Beautiful. This is another important landmark of barcelona, expressing the contribution of the well known Spanish artist.
beautiful little palace. beautiful little palace , nice building front, made by antoni gauli, and its amazing, inside and out
Must seeing!. I went inside with my father and we got amazed with this place. In our opinion it worth better than casa Batlo, it is not crowded of tourists and even cheaper... Dont miss it!
Wonderful architecture. What a wonderful and surprising building. Every corner reveals a different aspect. I would definitely recommend a visit.

Gaudi's first. The first building built by Gaudi. It was an opulent building, and you could see elements of all of the creations he would go on to complete. Again, the beautiful chimneys on the roof overlooked another lovely Barcelona day.
Impressive. One of the most Impressive experience in Barcelona. A lot of people wainting in the queue. But be smart And buy ticket on line for exact hour. Works excelently.

mad, strange, out of this world. This was the hightlight of my stay. The place made me smile at every turn. Worth every euro. Staggered entrance times means you may wait up to 45mins to get in. and be warned of 1hr queues to the museum tower, so its a bit chunk out of your time there.

Another Gaudi site!. Gaudi created a fantasy land that seamlessly combines the natural with the man made, as well as offering great views of the city.
Admission is 8€ each.

A fantastic housing concept !. I just loved how Gaudi departed from the norm for the time.
The park demonstrates his forward thinking and vision. It was my second visit here and still contained interest .
Entry was well controlled. There were facilities for a snack in the Park. One of the 'musts' when visiting Barcelona .

Fabulous, well worth a visit. This happened by chance to be one of the first things we did on our three day stint in Barcelona. Keen to see as much Gaudi as possible, this was first due to its location at the bottom of La Rambla. We visited on a Friday morning and it was quiet. To be fair it was February but I got the impression it was a lesser known gem. But I have to say it was one of my favourite houses. More gothic in style than La Pedrera and Casa Batllo but still with a wonderful roof terrace.Definitely worth a visit!

Amazing hidden gem.. Firstly, if you read a bad review about this place and they mention a park or a fountain... then they were at Guell Park, not at the Palau! This place is amazing! I highly recommend it. It wasn't too crowded (although it was February when we went), it's near the old town so easy to get to and was crammed full of things to wonder at. Definitely go here!

Save your 8 Euros. The grounds are well worth a visit! But the charge of 8 Euros for going out on the "beach" and in the 86 columns area probably isn't worth the charge. You can see much of the same in photos. When I visited there were two ensembles playing music which was very pleasant. Guell liked palm trees and the columns holding up the elevated driveway are designed to look like trees. Enjoy!
little hidden gem. Must visit place and well worth the admission fee to really see the genius that the architect was. A walk around the gardens within in the complex are a must
nice afternoon walk. some very interesting Gaudi structures/buildings set in a pretty parkland. A nice walk around for a couple of hours with amazing views of the city.

Fab. Well, made it at last and it wasn't a disappointment. It's worth the 8 € to get into the main exhibits and a walk around the rest of the park also gives great views. Go for a true Gaudi experience and the best views of the city.

Must see in Barcelona. This is off the beaten path as it is not close to the gothic quarter and other tourist sights but is a must see. We took the train to the closest stop and walked the rest of the way. Really unique plants and architecture and it was nice to see the city and sea from the vantage points of the park. We saw another overlook with a cross on it in the distance and would have liked to try and get over there by one of the trails in the park but it was getting dark and the park was closing. We recognized this park from a movie we had seen at was shot in Barcelona.

Nice hour or two and good value!. Definitely a cool place, especially given that it's free on Sundays. Be prepared to wait half an hour or a bit longer in line for a ticket, and then receive a time to return about 45 minutes from then.The house was vacated by the Güells after several years, so it's missing a lot of furniture and the like. However, there are pictures throughout, including on the free audio tour, which was pretty nice.Overall probably not as cool or elaborate as one of Gaudi's other houses, but for the price (and free on Sundays) it can't be beat , especially for a traveling student such as myself.
Very nice. A fun place to learn about the history of Barcelona. Everything was tidy and the people were very nice
Must see!. Quite interesting, And impressive for me! also Try to walk up to the park - it's for free and you could find good view to the city!

Quirky. The park is large and there are the obvious Gaudi attractions to view if you can see them behind the crowds of school kids who tend to cluster around the main features. Unfortunately there's s separate fee to enter Gaudi's home. You can save money if you buy a combination ticket at the Basilica de la Sagrada Familia in town. Unfortunately you can't buy the combination ticket at the main gate to the park. the ticket will give you access to the park, Gaudi's house and the bascilica.

Excellent view of the city. This is the most beautiful park of Barcelona, there are quite few Gaudi's building that are always beautiful to admire, plus, you got an incredible view of the city!Better come here for sunrises than sunsets.

To Pay or Not to Pay?. We paid for the restricted area entry and felt cheated. Booking online incur additional fee (thought we could skip the queue by doing so but if you enter from the side entrance, the queue is almost none - in January!). We could see much more from the free park area (higher and better views), and can view the walkway (with the salamander and the 2 towers) from the main entrance. There were also some architecture sculptures in the free area. If we are ever in the area again, we will just enjoy it from the free area, the fee was too expensive. But then again if this is the first Gaudi piece you see you may feel "wow"ed. It was the last one we saw and we did have a huge expectation. Not that we were disappointed with the architecture, I think the overpriced entrance fee (for the minimal area they covered) spoiled the mood. The best thing I saw from there was the school kids playing soccer when a young boy ran around waving at imaginary crowd and blowing kisses after he scored a goal! Goal Barcelona! :)warning: don't be misled when you buy the combined ticket with the sagrada familia - that's only to the museum in the park, not the entrance fee itself!
Long Lines. Beautiful park but the lines are very long. We visited the park next to it which was free, just a fee to enter the house that Gaudi lived in. The park itself was beautiful!
Don't miss this!. If you like Gaudi, do not miss this place. Great tour well worth the time. Antonio Gaudi is truly amazing and so much a part of what Barcelona is all about.

Chill out. Lovely afternoon to chill out in a lovely landscape
Really loved the setting and atmosphere, the grounds were so pretty, loved just walking around for hours. Easily accessible by most people and definitely worth the trip to the outskirts of Barcelona.

Don't hesitate, go see!. These buildings from Antonio Gaudi are beautifull. The style is very recognizable and gives you a feeling of creativity and peace of mind at the same time. Also great views on the city and sea!

fantastic views. Guadi at his best. You can visit his creation of the guards house as well as all the other buildings
It is quite a long way from main city centre but easily reached by public transport or taxis.
Must See. another wonderful example of Gaudi's work and well worth taking the time to visit here. Whimsical and beautiful!
If you like Gaudi.... ...this is a must! Walk around the Park to appreciate the landscape and design, but definitely visit the house, too.

Lovely Gaudi place. THe park is totally worth seeing. Plan some time to walk around and enjoy the combination of surrealistic toy-like peices by Gaudi and rich mediterrenean nature. THe park will surprise you with all kinds of street musicians, high spots offering excellent panorama of the city (some of them quite scary when it comes to getting down with no rails).It has very diferrent areas, from touristy and crowded ones - like the ones with Gaudi works to very remote and calm. You will be also reqarded with fresh pine tree scented air.

Must See. The Palau Guell is clearly one of the most interesting places you would visit in BCN, the other three also were designed by - yes, you perhaps guessed it: Antoni Gaudi! This is actually a palace, and the reason to visit would be to admire the rather quirky, unique and completely-different-from-normal aesthetics/ design of this place. It is fascinating to understand how a simple object like a 'chain' and influence design so much. Gaudi was clearly an enormously gifted architect/ designer, and his genius shines through in almost anything and everything that's contained within or a part of this magnificent building. Take a guided group-tour if possible. Access is open to the public only for some areas and not the entire building, which is acceptable. If you are not a stickler for details, it is also possible to do a quick tour in less than an hour or so. If you are a design/ architecture student, you're likely to ask for an annual pass!!
One of the musts. Gaudi at his best with a feel that cost is not an issue. A little different than the rest of his work so should see and should also go to the free to enter park next to it...
Amazing. Another wonderful Gaudi masterpiece! The chimneys on the rooftop are spectacular.Reasonably priced and an audio guide is included which is very interesting.

Beautiful. A beautiful and mystical place to wander around. The walk to the very top was definitely worth the effort as the views across the whole of Barcelona and on to the Mediterranean were breathtaking.

Hansel and gratel house!. You never expect to see such buildings in a city. Situated in a park a little further from the city centre, it's a long hike up to the park from the train station. But there are outdoor escalators to help (not sure if they operate while it rains).The place is packed with tourist. And there are only 2 of the Gaudi designed houses.

Gaudi...but not as you know him. Having visited Casa Battlo and Parc Guell - both teeming with colour and light, I found the Palau Guell dark and austere in comparison. However, there is no shortage of the man's talent for beauty of design coupled with practicality and brilliant engineering. If you are a real Gaudi fan, definitely include this, but for others, maybe not at the top of the 'must see' list.
Uniquely fascinating. The park is large but the key feature is the ticketed entry to Gaudi's work which is not to be missed.

Worth a visit. Gardens are free around Gaudis stairway to see the mosaiics and buildings is 8 euros. The architecture is so modern and contemporary despite being over a 100 years old. We took a taxi as there was four of us and was 10 euros from the centre of town, a lot easier than walking and taking the bus. We went in January 2015 and by 12 it was heaving - sadly every photo has a 100 tourists in it.... but i guess i was one of them.

Brilliant. My first Gaudi museum/gallery on this trip and I am very happy it was. Really well done, excellent audio guide included in the price of admission that was comprehensive but not over kill on the information. I did notice it was closing from tomorrow for restoration work so check the website if you are planning on visiting in the next week or so.

Fantastic view. To start with - book your ticket online and you get a fast line in awoiding very long waiting time.Its a fantastic place to visit. What a incredible person and designer. We had a lovely time at the roof. The rest of the house has some nice items to but its the incredible roof thats impress.

Interesting but why is there a fee. This is a beautiful park but if you want to enter the main attraction then you must pay a fee. They only allow a certain number of people in at a time (it tells you on your ticket when you can enter). You can exit whenever you wish but they try to slow down the traffic by doing this. If you wish not to enter the part that charges then I would still say it is worth going because the park itself is set up on a huge hill and you can see the entire city.

Nice enough. We didn't realise that we would have to pay to get into the central 'pretty' area, which was heaving with visitors and choose to just walk around the outer park area.some good music from buskers and a great view over the city from the lookout.
Really cool. the way up is a lot, but they build an escalator, which was handy. A lot of nature,beautiful views and monuments, a huge square where you can just sit and enjoy the view
Palau Guell. While reading these reviews, be aware that many of them are for Parc Guell, not Palau Guell. There is a big difference between the two sites.
Early Gaudi..Wise to See first. Dark…somewhat gloomy….nevertheless Gaudi's genuis nearly overwhelms. The audio guide is most informative.

Gaudi Magic. Beautiful grounds and interesting architecture. Be prepared to walk a lot! If you don't want to pay to go in you can walk around the surrounding grounds for free, there are interesting things throughout and you can still see inside the pay area. :)
Worth the trip. It takes about 15 minutes from La Rambla to the train station near Parc Guell. It's worth the trip. The views are amazing and Gaudi's architecture is great.

Had to book in advance. When we visited 5 years ago it was open to the public and a true gift. Now the mosaics are all blocked off with long lines to get into the work of Gaudi. I was very bummed we didn't get to see what we had come for. The outer gardens are still stunning, but we came for Gaudi.
Place for Gaudi's fans. Another Gaudi's work, not as amazing as sagrada familia, but still worth seeing. One of the main building was under renovation when we were there...very dissapointed
Rather expensive but beautiful. This is very interesting but do only if you have sufficient time. A combination ticket with the Sagrada Familia makes it a bit more affordable.

Not to be missed. The park is a lot bigger than I had imagined. Allow lots of time to get around, not only the area with mosaics, but also the wider park. There are musician buskers, some good, some not so, but it always livens things up. The mosaics are amazing, it is such a beautiful space. Just need to be patient with an noting people wanting to take photos, and of course there are the selfies. It is quite hilly, so wear your walking shoes, but whatever, don't miss it.

Gaudi with space to relax. Amazing park location and short trip from town in a lovely Park. We got there mid morning and only had short queues. Kids 7 to 14 loved the Gaudi style and the many ways it comes to life in the park. We walked back to town which was great.

Definitively Gaudi. If you like Gaudi and his way of thinking architecture you will definitively love this place.
It's cheaper to book your ticket from internet than at the booth at the entrance.
Be carreful because the capacity of visitor is very limited so it's better to take your tickets in advance

Gaudi without the crowds. We went in early January, with lots of locals on holiday, Sagrada Famillia and Guell Park were both too crowded, Palau Guell is ideally situated next to the Rambla and the Mercat de la Boueria which combined to make a lovely morning exploring
Very cool!. Got out tickets in advanced and didn't need to wait to get in. Cool park with strange and very interesting Gaudi designs! Liked it a lot!
very nice place. very nice place to spend time in. nice view over Barcelona from the top.good looking bridges and houses

Amazing. This an amazing place....a true folly.....to think the whole upper level is held up by the pillars and arches below is a great feat of engineering...everywhere you look you see there amazing mosaics,arches,stone,paving,plantings.....it's just amazing....we spent hours here and look forward to returning...nice bookstore there
Unusual architecture. Bought our tickets on line which we would recommend as queues can be quite long. A superb park which you could easily spend 3-4hrs in.

A nice walk but not nearly as impressive or stunning as other Gaudi. I made a quick trip out to Palau Guell while visiting Barcelona last October, and based on some of the photos I had seen I was very excited to see and explore such an interesting park. You're able to see most of what makes this park interesting without paying the tour fee to go into the restricted area. I spent most of my time walking the hillside trails exploring but I finally chose to pay the 7 euros and found myself exhausting this restricted touring area in less than 30 minutes. I'm glad I checked it out but it's not something I'll return to like most of the other Gaudi exhibits.
Beautiful views. We were there in December and it was cold so the experience was muted somewhat but still offers some of the greatest views of the city. Well worth visiting.
very nice creation. the park it self are fantastic wow so great to be there the arts and archetectural views are amazing ...its a worth to visit and very reasonable price

Mr. Guell's residence, good to visit if you're near La Ramblas. It is not as well known I guess in comparison to the other works of GAudi but this is just on one of the streets near La Ramblas. It is good to visit and see a different work by Gaudi to the man who really gave Gaudi the canvass to work on Mr. Guell. This is his residence and the roof top is quite a display of chimney and colors...

Disappointed. My family and I were disappointed. It's not as big nor interesting as I would think it is. Once you paid (7 euros) and got in, you could have covered all that you want to see in less than 30 mins. It's okay to see this once when in Barcelona but don't place too high expectation on this.

Nice walk in the park. nice to do when all the other attractions are closed.Involves a lot of walking.not stroller friendly. there are escalators which help.Felt a bit lost as we did not do enough research about the layout and the thought process behind the park.

Amazing building!!. We did this on the spur of the moment as we walked past. The building is amazing. I wanted to see the chimneys but once inside the whole building is great. You wear a audio tour as you go around each room which is very comprehensive.

Barcelonas jewelery. This park is the celebration of the art genius Gaudi. In the park can tourist see the beautiful sculptures, colorfull monuments and beautiful nature. Best choice for the family afternoon in Barcelona.

Designed by Gaudi. This formerly owned palace residence is now a museum. The former owner hired Gaudi to design the interior and exterior of this palace and what a beautiful creation he did! Intricately carved ceiling and banisters the stain glass, it is really beautiful. The rooftop shows his creation of transforming chimney pipes to works of art with the famous Gaudi mosaic designs. It's a good museum to visit.

Very interesting. This is one of Gaudi's first works for Guell. It shows his design as well as his attention to details that would make life easier, e.g. allowing natural light to enter everywhere. It's very interesting and the audio guide gives lots of valuable information. We ended up not going into La Pedrera or Calla Batllo after seeing this.

Loved it!. This was a surprise for me after seeing much of Gaudi's later work. The palace does not appear typical of Gaudi's work yet it is interesting in itself. When you get to the roof, that is when Gaudi really comes to light! A great place to visit.
If you dont have anything to do.... Okay to see, real Gaudi stuff. But put it last on your list.... and you must pay to enter ... 7.00 Euro p/p
Amazing!. This was a real treat and better than we thought it would be. The views from the roof were great and the architecture amazing.

Classic. The walk in the park was very pleasing and finally ended with a tour of Gaudi's apartment. The park is in a great location that give a great view of Barcelona. It is high up and you can keep walking in for hours on and the view keeps getting better. Gaudi has something for curves and is very evident in his design.

Another Interesting Gaudi Building, not to be confused with Parc Guell. This is another stunning Gaudi building just off Las Ramblas. Decorated in dark stone tones, this is in stark contrast to the brightness of Casa Batlo. It is also a good place to get out of the heat outside.As with most attractions in Barelona it is beneficial to book a time in advance to avoid the queues, but I found them a lot shorter than other attractions.
"Arch-lesson". Amazing masterpiece of the begining of this architectural genious Gaudi. Such a great design and amazing materials puted into a small place to make it appear huge. Great museum.

Well worth a visit. A little removed from the Gaudi "top hits" in the Eixample, this early commission from the Guell family is worth the visit. It is located just steps off La Rambla. The restoration completed in 2011 really showcases the beauty of the house, and you can see Gaudi's early ideas that were more fully formed in Casa Batllo and Casa Mila. The audio guide is complimentary with admission. BTW, the Palau Guell is NOT Park Guell (which some of the reviews discuss)

Long lines to get in, free to see the outside. Another place that, if you really want to see the interior, it would be worth booking a timed ticket the day before. We enjoyed looking at the façade from across the street and that was enough for us.

Why did you come to Barcelona!?!. By the ticket in advance and go to the monument area. Yes, it's free to explore the rest of the park (and definitely make time to wander around), but don't come all this way and skip the Gaudi mosaics. BTW, there are playgrounds for young children in Parc Guell - a nice relief for them.
Fun trip!. Amazing trip to the mind of a talented architect. Beautiful park surrounding amazing buildings. Buy tickets before you go! And take the bus-very easy from Plaza Catalunya! Bus 24~

Disappointed. I had high expectation before visiting Park Guell, I had heard so much good stuff about this park, however, when I got there, I was immediately disappointed. The only part I loved about Park Guell was when I walked all the way to the top of the park and saw the Barcelona city, the view was very beautiful.
Very gothic!. Loved how the main front was built. Can't believe that Gaudi had to rebuilt that 2 times which, shows how much of perfectionist he was.
Amazing !. I like travellers who stroll and walk quietly. I don't like travellers who dixcover a place running quickly !
Magical. A much quieter museum than others in the city, we were able to walk in without queueing. Get up to the roof and take your camera.

An unexpected hidden gem. I have visited this palace 3 times and i have loved it every time. On my first visit we just happen to pass it whilst out and about and loved it. This time it went with family with 2 children (6&11), who also loved it.The building is very gothic and the rooms bar 1 have no furniture to look at but the rooms decor action is so detailed you don't miss it much.The roof top gives you views around the city and the amazing chimneys to photograph.Disabled access is very limited although there was lifts but not sure if you could access all of the rooms.Price was not too bad either and you were given slotted times to get in, so we went for a coffee before our entrance.A must see visit.

Gaudi with an open cheque book.. I have never been a huge fan of Gaudi, but it was in the guide book and around the corner from my hotel. There was free entry and it wasn't crowded. The staff were helpful and polite and the audio guide was good. The house is sensational, built without regard to cost. It is all open, from the basement to the roof terrace, and includes one floor which is now a display area. The quality and ingenuity of the workmanship is amazing. There is very little furniture on display, but with the richness of the decoration, this is hardly obvious and may well be a bonus. I would strongly recommend a visit to anyone who wants to see a "house" museum with a difference.
A must. You'll be stunned by Gaudi's work in an intimate setting. It's nice to see how people lived in such a comfortable space. - Rob & Jeanne
Great Fun. Lots to see. Mime artists galore, buskers, amazing vistas, and architecture to "blow your mind" ! A fantasy land - A MUST SEE for all ages

interesting place. even if you don't want to see the lizard, this place is worth a visit. the park if free to enter and will be open before 8.00 in the morning. a very good place to visit early morning and walking around.. you have to pay if you want to visit a small part of the park. and the gaudi's house is open at 10..

Brilliant. First - all those 1 star reviews - YOU WERE REVIEWING THE WRONG THING!! This is Palau Guell NOT Parc Guell etc..It's not a 15 minute visit - took us 95 minutesThis place was closed until about 18 months ago so we've never beenIt was worth the waitThe craftsmanship and sheer decorativeness (such a word??) is fabulous; to think it was a family home......but Mrs Guell didn't like it!!Treat yourself and come to see

A highlight of my visit to Barcelona. A wonderful place where we can see what Gaudi could do with a sympathetic patron and money no object. A palace constructed to meet the demands of a family that loved music and was very relgious. The organ is amazing. This palu also reminds us of the history of Barcelona: the place waas "confiscated" by the Republicans in 1936. It is now a public building, beautifully restored.

Well Worth a Visit. Unfortunately we did not have enough time to do this place justice. Fantastic park and buildings in Gaudi style. Next time we come to Barcelona we will try to dedicate more time for thi venue.

A very tiny park, not worth the entrance fee. Yes, it is yet another work byGaudi/ Guell. However, it is a really small place which you can finish in an hour's time. Not really a place to rest and relax as there will be many tourists waiting for some hot spots to snap pictures.

Second time and Still as Stunned!. Be prepared for a steep ascent up to the park and bring water; you can get a little tired before you reach the top. I would highly recommend - if you have trouble walking - that you drive up to the park or get a bus/taxi, as you don't want to be out of breath and unable to explore the park itself.The park is absolutely mesmorising; it is worth paying to enter so that you can admire the stunning mosaics and the Gaudi architecture. This is the second time I have visited the park and the salamander fountain is just as breathtaking. We sat on the mosaic benches and admired the panoramic view out over Barcelona. If you want to explore the two houses, be prepared to wait: we visited mid-December on a cloudy day and there were people still queuing to the "45minute wait" mark.

Fantastic. This is not the Park Guell. It is in a different part of the city (just off La Ramblas) and is a house, not a park. Some reviews here are for the wrong location!This was one of our favourite locations in Barcelona. Make sure you listen to the audio guide- it is actually really interesting. The architecture is spectacular, especially the roof terrace. Highly recommend an afternoon spent here.

Gaudi's first effort. This was Gaudi's first big assignment for his benefactor - Guell. You won't believe that it is built on a relative small piece of land. It is very impressive. If you visit on Sunday afternoon and if you are lucky, you can even visit it from free!
beautiful to visit. barcelona is known for its architecture and this is no exception. fascinating to visit. and well located, but a little hard to find.

Another Gaudi masterpiece. Another Gaudi marvel - more of his 'catenary arches' - and truly amazing sculpture/architecture throughout the house. Along with Gaudi's wonderfully decorated chimneys on the rooftop.
Overated. Free portions will give you the same views of downtown, the paid portions of the park are not anything overly special.

Nice day out. Having been here twice, it's a nice day out on a sunny clear day. Make sure you find a route that has escalators to take you up the hill! It's a nice walk down the hill though to the metro though, about 30mins.You will get lovely views of the city here. If you want to go to the park itself to see the artwork, you will need to pay a fee! I wouldn't recommend paying unless you are a big fan but if you stand from the entrance, you can equally appreciate the artwork there.

Too commercialized lately. I've visited this iconic park in the past and must say this time around I find the allure gone. Fees are charged now but nothing has been added to protect the serenity it was meant to provide visitors to Barcelona. Gaudi must be restless at what has been done to his dream.

Palau Guell is the mansion, not the park (Parc Guell). We spent an interesting 2-hour at this place with the kids. We were just in time to join an English speaking tour guide who was very passionate about Gaudi and gave a good explanation on how Gaudi envisioned and planned the family mansion. Went from the basement all the way up to the roof top where the colourful whimsical chimneys are. You get a nice view of the city and Sagrada Familia basilica. This is a much more worthwhile visit than La Pedrera or Casa Mila.

a must see in barcelona. this park is quite impressive and a wonderful place to visit on a sunny day. gaudi really did outdo himself in creating a wow park. a nice place to see the overview of the city.

Walt Disney got his inspiration here. Wow... Felt like Disney. Magical. Gaudi at his best. Wish we had more time to spend here. Will defend visit again on our next visit to the wonderful city of Barcelona.

Guell Palau/Palace - not the same as Park/Parc Guell !. The Palau Guell, located not far from Las Ramblas in Raval, is an early work of Gaudi’s career, a spectacular home for the prominent Guell Family (who later commissioned Gaudi for the Parc Guell in a more outlying part of Barcelona).This baronial residence was designed for and lived in by a family with three young children; father was an industrialist and mother a socialite with artistic aspirations. Money was no object and Gaudi made full use of his freedom to create awe-inspiring spaces using the most lavish of materials. You can see the public rooms of the palace as well as the intimate family areas, including the private chapel, monumental reception rooms and grand stairway, and separate bedrooms for each family member upstairs. How interesting that even these privileged members of the 1% had just one small toilet (exquisitely tiled and crowned with a finely enameled porcelain chamber pot) to share! The roof area, with its many whimsically tiled chimneys, is a sunny and playful contrast to the darker, more formal interiors below.We think visitors will enjoy this early example of Gaudi’s genius that also provides a glimpse into the historic lifestyle of Barcelona’s rich and famous.
Awesome. The views from the city were fantastic, the air was so fresh. The main area is absolutely amazing, the perfect place if you wanna see both natural beauty and outstanding art.
to take a photo. nice building near rambla str. It s nice to take a photo at the front of it but no need to pay to see inside.Expensive for budget travellers...

Awesome spot with great views. We spent about 3 hours at the park walking around and taking pictures. You have to pay if you want to see the mosaic work right after you enter the park but it is well worth it, gotta spend the money. But the park is free other than that and there are awesome street performers around every corner. Great spots for pictures and an amazing view.

Amazing if you make it early and get to enjoy the place a bit more!. Amazing if you make it early and get to enjoy the place a bit more! When visiting in 2005 my family and I walked around this wonderful park early in the morning before major tourist crowds arrived.It was a sight to behold with all of the super weird architectural formations. Nice!

This is a Palace... Not a park!!! Many inaccurate reviews on here.. Visited the Guell family's palace near La Rambla today (for 12 euros). I want to make an important clarification regarding the numerous reviews and pictures posted to the wrong location here: "Palau" is the Catalan word for palace, not park. This is the same family that commissioned Gaudi for their park, and they chose Gaudi to work on their home as well. After seeing two of the homes on the block of discord (Casa Batllo and Casa Lleo Morera), the Sagrada Familia basilica, Parc Guell, and the Picasso Museum, I would rate this as the next best attraction in Barcelona. It was definitely more worthwhile than La Pedrera-Casa Milo and a nice complement to Parc Guell, but I would only make a point of seeing it after the first five attractions I listed or if you have extra time to kill around La Rambla one afternoon. (You need almost an hour for the audio-guided tour.) The style of the palace is "neo-gothic"... It is gloomy inside compared to Gaudi's other delights but some of the details were still very impressive (tortoise shell and gold leaf in doors and panels, Gaudi's typical colorful, festive chimneys, the acoustics he considered when he built the family's chapel and attic, etc.) Overall, it serves as a nice contrast to Gaudi's other work and I found the background on the Guell family on the audio tour to be quite informative, but I wouldn't rate it as one of my top 5 "must sees" in Barcelona.

Disappointing. After his other works I found it to be disappointing but the idea of it was solid. Especially when you walk around and it is peaceful (if you get there before all the bus loads of people)

Part of our Honeymoon. I absolutely loved the cultural side of this beautiful place. Was such a great feeling walking up those steps and through the buildings. Would recommend it to anyone visiting Barcelona, Spain!!

Interesting area to say the least. take the time to see this area. very interesting. the mosaic work is extraordinary. there is a fair bit of climbing stairs and uneven areas to walk. worth the effort

So Many Photo Opportunities. Plan at least a half day for Park Guell. As the only Gaudi home designed for a working class family the gate keeper house, with its arches, curves, and angles is worth seeing even if there was no park. But there is a magnificent park with interesting mosaics and the most intriguing shapes. Be sure to walk around the sides and see the curving structures that hold everything in place, not just the large columns.The view, even on a cloudy day, stretches to the sea with all of Barcelona laid out in front of you; Sagrada Familia can be seen too. After walking around the park I enjoyed a glass of cava from the cafeteria while doing a bit of late afternoon people watching.
Fall in love with this park!. Fall in love with this park and the gift shop. You can easily spend 2-3 hours at this park. Get tickets online and go early!!

Another "mad master pice". It´s like entering another world. Everything is compleatly different from what you are use to, in a very facinating way.It is really an experiance to visit the palace.When you see all the details, in design, functionallity and when you think of the huge task of running such an project my impression is that Mr Guell, the creator of the palace, must have been a mad geniuous.It is a very interesting attraction both from pure technical point of view and artistic point of view.
Beautiful. you do not have to go to the paid part of this park to enjoy the beauty. This is well worth a visit. Spectacular buildings and park design...should be one of the top 5 to see

Marvelous place to visit. We were lucky because today Sunday 7-12-2014 entrance was free. We couldn't discover it other Gaudi locations were also free today as we couldn't understand if Palau Guell is free only this Sunday or every Sunday. Unbelievable interesting place to visit for people who like architectrue , who like original things " out of the box " . I very warmly recommend .

Fantastic!. The major of my wife and me in University was Spanish and Latin american literature and culture. 17 years after graduated from University, we visited Barcelona with our children. Thanks to the advice of my spanish colleague, we booked the ticket of Park Guell and Sagrada Familia in advance. Palau Guell was also fantastic! Beyond any description! We took very early flight from Brussels and very late flight from Barcelona. During one and half days, we could visit almost all the monuments of Gaudi. Metro in Barcelona was very convenient. Taxi is also rather economical compared with other western european cities.

Amazing. A work of art, beautiful place to visit and if I lived here, I would go every weekend. Beautiful views of the city and even the Mediterranean, the park itself is gorgeous in every way and well maintained. Avoid the ridiculous lines though and get tickets to the main section of the park online.
Beautiful. Staff is very helpful if you have a party member in a weelchair,. they even ask what could make things better !The place is worth seeing.

Magical!. Visiting this Gaudi treasure is much more enjoyable since a new policy of limiting ticket sales to 400 every half hour was instituted. Touch El Drac (the dragon), marvel at the forest of Doric columns in the Sala Hipostile, relax and socialize on the serpentine bench on the vast terrace

Luxury with no limits. 15 yrs ago when we visited we were only permitted on the roof. Now the entire interior is restored. Gaudi was brilliant and the world is fortunate that Barcelona allowed his creativity, that Guells valued his creativity and that Barcelona recognized the importance of maintaining it. If you love art and architecture - don't miss this building.

Great for the art lover. It is an architectural marvel, looks very impressive but... I like historical places and military places. If you don't appreciate art, don't spend your money which is costly in comparison to US attractions.
Fascinating. Palau Guell is not mentioned as often as most of the other Gaudi designed houses but it is spectacular , especially the roof and chimneys

On a nice day -- visit Park Guell. The Gaudi abode and beautiful structures and park area were fantastic. Great place for photo ops! This Park needs to be on your top 10 list of things to do in Barcelona.
Barcelona visit. Park Guell is a fine park, masterminded by Gaudi, originally intended for a housing development. The park is well worth visiting with fine views over the city of Barcelona

One of the best sites in Barcelona. There is great views to be seen from the balcony here. The entrance fee is very reasonable but it you go late in the down its normally free however you're likely to miss the sunset if you do wait.

Amazing. What a beautiful building hidden away in the back streets but a must to see. if its rating you can't go on the roof it is tiled so very slippery. The building itself is amazing what a clever man Gaudi was. Lots of rooms to see they are all left as they was at that time. Beautifully restored really enjoyed our time here.

Best of the Gaudi Homes. Best time to visit is a Sunday morning (not surprising, right). We were there around 10:30 or 10:45 AM, and were able to spend time without being jostled by crowds. Gaudi's attention to detail is remarkable, and well worth taking the time to appreciate. We had a guide who was very familiar with the property and was able to point out details that we otherwise might have missed. This suggests to me that renting the acoustic guide will really add to your appreciation of his work. We did rent the acoustic guide for the Casa Batllo, and it was indeed worth it. I suspect that it would be easy to overload on Gaudi's buildings, so we limited ourselves to just three, including of course La Sagrada Familia, although we observed some others from the street. These three buildings seemed sufficient to us, but your interest level may be different.

Stunning!. As another reviewer has said the terraces are closed in adverse weather and on the day we went it had been raining. There were signs saying terraces would be closed in adverse weather but no signs saying they were actually closed and the ticket office didn't inform us until after we had bought our tickets. That aside, it is an amazing building and the audio commentary was interesting. It was quiet when we visited and we did not have to queue or struggle to see anything.

Beautiful. Gorgeous from basement to attic. Must see while in Barcelona. I highly recommend doing the audio tour and trying to stay in the main hall for a listen to the organ play, its goes on every 30 minutes on the hour and the half.*Free admission on Sunday, even for tourists (while I was there anyways so don't take this as the law!!)
Worth the walking. Palau Guell is another must for anyone who had toured the Sagrada Familia. You will see where the designer lived and his other works of art....furniture. Enjoy
Another great Gaudi property. An early Gaudi property, but still well worth a visit. The roof is the pinnacle of the visit. Cheaper than most and one to do at the beginning of a trip.

Mixed feelings. In terms of interesting architectural design this is an interesting place. However the fact that they let hawkers into the park to annoy you whilst trying to take in the sights is highly annoying. Particularly when they are selling loud squeaky mouth pieces. Also the park has a neglected feeling and it could be so much better with some landscaped gardens. I was a bit disappointed.

Good example of a classic Gaudi residential building, opulent and spacious. An interesting example of a very spacious residence for the upper classes in the early 20th century. The imposing central hall is 4 stories tall with an organ built-in. Impressive internal spaces and the familiar Gaudi rooftop terrace.

Doors, windows, ceilings, chimneys, all magnificent. This was the sixth of the Gaudi buildings that we visited. Sagrada familia is obviously his masterpiece and I'd rank this joint second with casa Batlio. The doors, windows, fireplaces are grander than in later buildings.

Don't assume you will be able to get onto the roof. At the ticket window (12 Euro each) we were deeply disappointed to be told (after we had paid) that the terrace was closed because of the weather. Ok, it was raining off and on and presumably there was a risk to be managed, but we would have happily signed a waiver just to get up there. After all, most of the publicity images are of the roof terrace. Anyway, it wasn't an option. So we went in, in a somewhat negative frame of mind. We did get audio guides at no extra charge and the extraordinary opulence of the interior soon won us over.
Free the Day I Went!. Normally, the tariff is €12, but it was free the Sunday afternoon I went! I enjoyed this audioguided tour as much as La Sagrada Familia and Casa Batlló.
Beutifull. Nice building and an example of Gaudi's special architectural style representative for the city.close to the undregroung of Liceau, just a minute walk from las Ramblas

Stunning !. Lovely park. it is very easy to get there by local transport. Sadly you have to pay to get to the main area of the park however you get stunning and great views from outside. Another must see of Barcelona

Amazing. We booked our tickets online, the 10.15am entry slot. It was very quiet, and we really enjoyed it. We left our bags in a locker in the courtyard, took the audio guide and spent an amazing hour and a half in this little Gaudiesque gem. I highly recommend it! The renovations really restored the original qualities of the palace. Go!
Need to visit. The Palau Güell was designed by the young Gaudí and is a wonderful blend of medieval opulence and the architect's unique exuberant style.

Gaudis work. if your into art and long walks you will like to visit park guell. i think it will take you whole day if you wanted to visit all the areas. unfortunately we have a limited time. we only spent almost 4 hours inside and we missed the other areas like the frog and other nice places. will definately come back to see the frog. i am fond of Gaudis works so its really nice unique not a typical spanish design.
Beautiful . I loved every minute of walking around the park with its beautiful birds in the tree's and all the colourful architecture. And it's amazing views great day out.
Wish it was my house. This is a fantastic modernist house that is worth a visit. The attention to detail and design is amazing. A unique space that will make you wish it was your house.

A subtler Gaudi work. This former family home, made mostly of wood and wrought iron, was interesting and enjoyable, but definitely not as "wowing" as Gaudi's other works in the city. Definitely cool to explore, with some interesting features and design work. The audio guide was helpful and informative, but I would have preferred to just take in the art itself, and have a few informative signs here and there. It was raining when we went, so they closed the roof! The roof was the part I really wanted to see, so I was disappointed that they closed this off but still charged full price. Be sure to visit on a clear day.I would recommend this as a secondary site to see, after the more known sites. Overall it was an enjoyable visit.

Should be on every Barcelona visitor's "short list". After visiting Casa Batllo, La Pedrera, and La Sagrada Familia on the previous, "all Gaudi" day of our Barcelona vacation, we thought we'd hit all the highlights. Our visit to Palau Guell proved us wrong. We found this building contributed greatly to our understanding of and appreciation for, Gaudi's handling of space, light, and texture. Perhaps because we weren't surrounded by a huge crowd (which meant, incidentally, that we were able to walk right up and obtain entrance tickets), we were able to explore each room from various vantage points, and soak in the ambiance of this stunning home. Our pleasure may have been enhanced by the fact that didn't have the same high expectations we brought to the "big three" Gaudi sites--we simple didn't know what to expect. Every corner of every floor, from functional areas like the stable to the private rooms and main social space in the interior, merits attention. "Breathtaking" may be an overused term, but you can hear visitors literally catch their breath as they step onto the roof terrace, graced with 20 chimneys covered with ceramic and glass fragments (the trencadis ceramic work so familiar from Guell Park). Palau Guell should not be regarded as a brief detour from La Rambla--it is a destination not to be missed.

Beautiful building decorated by Gaudí.. It's a nice option to visit in Barcelona, there you have a whole decorated building with an amazing architecture and on the roofing there is a view of Barcelona! Maybe you'll pass by some queue to get inside...

Slightly overrated. I wont say this is a must see but if you have time and want to know how the rich lived, thats the place.The entrance fee includes the audio guide so is good to understand Gaudi's thoughts better. Every detail has been attended to. Truly impressive designer!
Wow!. Design down to the very smallest detail. Gaudi didn't leave anything to chance. Lots and lots of rooms and a great view over the Barcelona rooftops. Nice (small) museum shop.

good but..... I was here last year May 2013, was no need to pay. Now need to pay Euro 11I mean yes is really nice but not really worth it. I don't really understand why everything have to pay in Barcelona. I trust Gaudi wanted people to appreciate his work instead of use him for earning that much money. BTW: when you come out from Guell park, there are so many gift shop. do not go right hand side basement one, which owned by indian. We went in after one second, he said everything 50% off. we were not interested after enquiries (bad materials), he said "fxxk off and get out" super rude!!!

Astonishing. Right off La Rambla, this Gaudi masterpiece is jaw-dropping, perhaps more amazing than Casa Mila. The detail and craftsmanship are just astonishing, and the acoustics are amazing. They may have an organ performance during your visit. If you are in Barcelona to see Modernista masterpieces, this is a must. We were here in the off-season and did not have advance tickets (but, unlike the other Gaudi sites, there was no queue). We were able to go right in.

Highly Recommended. I would highly recommend visiting this house. It is breathtaking/highly impressive as were all of the Gaudi buildings/sites I visited in Barcelona: Sagrada Familia, Casa Batllo, Casa Mila (aka Pedrera), Park Guell.
A 30 min visit. The park is okay and do not make this a must see. Its okay to visit with the fee, but not very impressive.

Visit after 6:30pm is free entrance. I can only give it an average score as we didn't have time to go through the lovely park. We got there around 5pm, but would also want to do the magical fountain too, so did not pay to go in the extra bits.But just by walking around the outside park was already super nice. Very big, so didn't finish our walk. There are a small little cafe there too for people to rest.The details and decor was amazing! Just remember to get a pair of good walking shoes ;)

Worth the Visit. Just off La Rambla, Palau Guell is easy to miss on the street but a very interesting tourist spot. The highlight was definitely the roof terrace, where Gaudí designed a beautiful collection of mosaic "chimneys" (my word, not theirs). My husband said that it was absolutely worth the €12 just to see the roof. The house itself is also quite interesting (not as exciting as the roof, but still artistically designed, with careful detail put into each room). The large parlor was my favorite (after the roof), with the ceiling Gaudí designed to look like a starry night. Hope you get the chance to see it!
Awesome. one of the best places we visited, well worth the entry fee into the monumental area, breathtaking views and an insight to Gaudi himself.

A Must See for the Gaudi Enthusiast. Palau Guell provides many examples of how nature inspired Gaudi's architecture. Focus your time on the Monumental Zone and the walkways. Gaudi's house is interesting but if you have limited time, it can be skipped.
Getting to know Gaudi. As I've been told by my AirBnB host - Xavier, who happens to be an architect - "If you must see only one Gaudi building from the inside, then this is the one."

Unusual Genius. Very unusual building the style of which actually gives an insight into the daily life of a wealthy family from the city at the time. The underground garage (!) and the roof were obvious highlights for me. Very organic in design, if you're a fan of Gaudi or interested in Local history this is a must

Great house from Gaudi. very interesting visit to this house near the ramblas.This is not the gardens!Great small detail regarding light and ventilation.Very interesting to understand how people lived and very interesting artistic and engineering detailsVistit it!

Interesting visit!. Visit to palau guell was interesting, and fascinating to learn more about the friendship between gaudi and guell. Certainly a lot of thought and details went into designing the place.

Worth the visit just for the roof!. We decided to visit Palau Guell on the basis that it was close to our hotel and we needed something to do prior to heading to the airport on our last day. It is the cheapest attraction in relation to Gaudi and also comes with audio guide included in the price so we learn't loads and got a good sense of the architecture and history. The roof is the best bit so worth the visit just for that.

worth a visit but don't pay to enter the central park. It's a great view point so go late afternoon, but there are entry fees everywhere...we went into the tiny Gaudi museum which was ok at best...we skipped the central park area. You can see it well enough from the walkway near the museum up top.

A wonderful family day out. This park is an absolute Barca must. There is amazing scenery, brilliant architecture and breathtaking views of the city. We spent quite a few hours wondering around this gorgeous space. Just beware of the HUGE hill to get to it. Well worth the climb though!

A must.. This is an incredible experience that truly takes you back in time to a golden era of architecture and a way of life. I would not miss this if you are visiting Barcelona, gives you a side of Gaudi that you don't get to see in other of his work. Also getting to see how the Guell family lived was an experience in itself, they were at the time one the richest families in the world. Stunning.

Gotta see it!. Amazing example of Gaudi architecture in this home built for family living. Each level is eye candy, with tile, woods, nooks and crannies. Then to,arrive at the roof level and see that elaborate setting of colorful tiled cone shapes - incredible! A must see when in Barcelona.

A little Silly Gaudi... This park was developed as a residential area for Barcelona's wealthy during Gaudi's influence. He was commissioned to design this park for make it a nice escape for the merchants who were to live there.. No one bought .. but one woman who lived at the very top of the park.. Interesting design.. amazing engineering ideas for the time.. figure out the water system if you can..
park. Entrance to the park, where the buildings are located Gaudi charge. Not cheap. For such a value would like to see much more.

Hidden treasure. This place is almost hidden and yet you wonder how when you look inside , the architecture and workmanship is superb and a pleasure to see. The craftsmanship and painstaking detail leave you wanting more, the signature features of the building found in a few more of the sites in Barcelona lend to its appeal.
Buy your tickets in advance. So you won't be in line for 2 hours. The visit time is fixed, so buy your tickets in advance. The site is beautiful!
Beautiful and fun place to do a self guided tour. Probably my favorite place in Barcelona. Price and busy factor helped. Amazing architecture and great that admittance price included an audio tour.

Do not confuse with Parc Guell as quite a few of the reviewers have. Just off the Ramblas best to buy your tickets on line as tge queues can be long as they sensibly moderate how many peopke can visit at once. The audio guide brings the palace alive and is free with the cost of entry. Lots of floors and rooms to see and do not misstge roof its spectacular

A must visit to get a glimpse of Gaudi's genius.. Apart from Familia Segrada, we feel that this is the most intimate and personal work of Gaudi's.
