The rest of the park is nice. Make sure to see the three crosses.

Guell Palace. After reading the glowing reviews on TripAdvisor and then going to visit I felt as though this palace has been over-hyped.
It's a good way to spend an hour or so and see something different, the audio guide was also pretty informative. 3/5 good but not great.

Our first stop set the mood. Palacio Guell was our first stop and the audio guide was informative. Since this was Gaudi's first big project out of architecture school, we were able to get a fine appreciation of his creative genius at a very young age. We were fascinated with Guell as well, and how he enable Gaudi to thrive in his career.
Worth a look. Interesting, but not my favorite spot in Barcelona. That goes to La Sagrada. Husband is an art fan, so he enjoyed it.

Much more interesting than expected. While the front facade of this Gaudi-designed building is much less interesting than other popular tourist haunts (e.g. Casa Batllo, Le Pedrera), the inside of this building is absolutely fascinating. The audio tour is very informative, and really very interesting in terms of the many innovative things Gaudi did to design this urban home. The central chamber with its church organ, chapel and soaring high roof topped with a dome is incredible - and totally unexpected! Also, this is the least busy of the central Barcelona Gaudi attractions - great if you're tired of crowds.

Gaudi Genius Again!. Recycled tiles, recycled water system that doubles as irrigation, whimsical architecture, great people watching, relaxing park, beautiful flowering gardens, wish we had spent more time here!

Interesting place. Interesting place to visit. Park is beautiful place and colourful. We walked a long way to get there and were so tired that we perhaps didnt enjoy it to the full ...the last 10mins steep uphill was too much on top of the 1 hour walk before

Best value, intriguing and impressive. We casually read that entrance to Park Guell was free, which it is however, there is a small fee to enter the wonder and greatness that is the Monument.For (pre-purchase online) euro7 it is by far the best value and experience we had in visiting and learning the history, architecture, and talent of Gaudi and of the culture of Catalonia in the late/early century.We stopped in one afternoon and learned the in-line ticket purchase, next entrance time available was a couple hours later than current time. We were so impressed and enjoying the park and information area that we chose to return to the flat, purchase online for a specific time the next day and return.For a hot summer day, we arrived for a 10a time and with much of the park and monument still shaded by location and trees it was a cool and enjoyable morning to see the sights and a leisure pace and a pleasant breeze.We learned a great deal from the shared information, guides and historians onsite. Having thoroughly enjoyed our time at Park Guell we highly recommend this visit as one of our most favorite areas in all Barcelona
Best value Gaudi house!!. This is the best value Gaudi house to tour and by far the most interesting inside. Almost half the price of the other ones!! The chimney adorned roof is spectacular!!

The Guell park that surronds the place is a treat. The whole Guell complex from the park to the palace are fantastic. There is just so much character and charm to the layout and placement of everything. It is quite unlike anything you will see in terms of parks and the architecture of the palace is fabulous.
Buy your tix online and then GO!. Very beautiful and shows Gaudi's talents, whimsy and oddness!Take a cab as it's up the hill. We spent a couple of hours there and loved it.
Amazing. Beautiful park, fantastic day out and despite being just a park,there is plenty to do and a full day to be made.

Really great. This is a great attraction. It is much cheaper than other Gaudi houses bit just as good. I spent about an hour there using the audio guide which is free. There are great views of barcelona from the roof.
Nice museum/house. Another one of Gaudi's creations. Off on a quieter side street. Nice to see. Beautiful decorations and history of the place.

This was magic!. Words cannot express the wonder and the variety of Gaudí's inspiration in this wonderful building. It's a masterpiece by a very great genius, but also full of quirky elements that almost make you laugh aloud with joy. The woodwork, the ironwork, the windows - they're all awe-inspiring. The audio-guide is also brilliantly informative. In the shop afterwards I spoke with a very knowledgeable and charming young assistant. I was particularly interested in the composers mentioned in the commentary and she recommended a CD featuring works by Catalan composers - all women - who were contemporaries of Güell and Gaudí. Fascinating. I cannot remember any private house that has overwhelmed me to the extent that Palacio Güell has.

Wonderful piece of Art!!!. Long lines to get in! :-( Worth the wait !! Be ready and dressed to walk A LOT, to be surprised by incredible Art and the most Beautiful vertical garden walls. A MUST SEE!!!

BEAUTIFUL!. Parc Guell is the most beautiful and unique park I have every seen. Every inch of it is aesthetically inspiring. It is quite an uphill journey to get there, so I would definitely go by bus. Walking would be tough. Give yourself a few hours to roam around this magical place!

buy tickets online!. we actually had to come twice...the first time we actually lined up to find out that there is a limited number of people that can enter during a time period, which is very good because even with that restriction we thought there was a lot of people!!! But after lining and waiting for 20 minutes in the sun and heat, we were told that our tickets were only for an hour and a half later!!! and we had already done the public area of the pard!!!... so we left... bought tickets online and came back the next day at the proper time....An then, it was fabulous!! Every structure was psychedelic, all the pieces of mosaic, the details in the curves, the water gutters, the colour choices...WAOW!!! Mr Gaudi was indeed a great mind!Summer season does bring a lot of people though...But definitely worth the wait and the time.Downside: smokers.. they smoke on the restaurants terrace and have absolutely no respect for the non smokers, even children...
Don't Overlook. This may be the highlight of any Gaudi tour of Barcelona. Great views of Barcelona - amazing concept of a housing development!

Put aside a whole day. We tried to do this in one afternoon and sadly you will need the good part of a day to see everything in this park. Summer is the busiest time but well worth the trip. Good walking shoes, sunblock and lots of water will ensure that your day will be successful.

AMAZING : you have to go. bucolic visit in this park even if there are many tourists, don't miss. Go in the morning, get ticket (you'll probably have to wait 1 hour to came in) and share this hour all around the place in the park. Beautiful view of Barcelona and appreciate Gaudi's genious

Wonderful, dark, inspirational. 6pm Tuesday and no queue. Started the visit at 6.30 and totally blown away. It's a more intimate space than La Pedrera despite the grandeur of the public rooms. Gaudi's genius shines through. Completely and totally worth making time to see. Enjoy and find inspiration!

Stunning!. Loved the free tour - Ellie was great, and we had free time at the end to look around. The Palace is just amazing and I was delighted to visit on this occasion as when I was last in Barcelona (2010) it was being renovated.Some of the features created by Gaudi were soooooo ahead of their time it's untrue.When you buy your ticket at the ticket window (I queued for just 10 mins) you are giving a timed entry ticket which makes queuing much more pleasant. You do need to say you want to do the tour (the one I did was at 2pm and in English) when buying your ticket though - you get a special sticker and a ten minute prior to the tour entry time.Another of Gaudi's wonderful creations and thank heavens for Mr Guell for providing the money to make Gaudi's ideas come alive.
Beautiful park with great views but a little packed. views of the city. plenty of walkways and places to chill.Definitely order your tickets to the Palace ahead of time.stunning scenery

Gaudi at his best. Started in 1900, this estate for the wealthy families of Barcelona that Guell entrusted to Gaudi to complete is a wonderful place to visit. This UNESCO site features the longest continual tiled seat in the world. The whole estate is a riot of curves and colours. Visit with a guide for the best information on the construction.Also a early morning start in peak times is essential due to it's popularity. See photos attached

A glimpse of what life was like for the rich and proud. This place is another of Gaudi's works. It has not long been open to the public I believe. I love the stables and the fact that the horses came into the palace through the main doors with the people. I find it too dark and dingy for my liking, a bit like a church really rather than a family home. Check out the his and hers rooms!
Guell Palace. Park is beautiful. Paid for access to the village area. Was very crowded. Guidi's work is plentiful to see at this location.
Beautiful gardens. This is well worth a visit as Gaudi designed this and it is a beautiful park with a lot of his mosaics work easy to see.
Gaudi is genius. There is a great view on the city. You can fell the Gaudi's talent one more time. You should book the tickets online to skip the line.

Not like Batllo or Sagrada Familia. I have been studying the Art Nouveau movement for several years. This example of Gaudi's work does not have the same feel as other places he designed. It feels very dark and Gothic which suits the neighborhood. Just do not expect it to be like Casa Batllo or Guell Park.

The most cost effective Gaudi. 12 Euros, or wait in a long line for a free entrance (if I recall correct, there's a special day in June, they let you in for free at 1700 but they don't say it in their site). We chose to pay, and out of all Gaudis residential creations, this was the best place to visit - much cheaper than the other locations, and much more to see. After visiting Palacio Guell, there's nothing more to see in a place like Casa Mila (there you can see that turn of the century apartment, that can be seen in museums all over Europe). There's also a small museum inside that explains about Gaudis vision, you'll see this kind of museum in other Gaudi creations (there's one to in the Segarda Familia, but it is quite different). The Photos I added speak for themselves. I recommend taking the audio guide - at most places, they audio guide is a drag, speaking about subjects that are not always interesting, but in PG it is very interesting and to the point. Right near the Rambla, well worth a visit. If you're short on time, after visiting it you can skip other Gaudi residential houses - most of them are (while highly rated here) are expensive tourists traps.
Amazing. We were walking and stumbled upon this amazing house. Well worth a visit. Cost for 6: 64 Euro. This included discounts for two students.

Interesting place. I am amazed that people so warmly embraced Gaudi's architectural style as it clearly differed from anything I have seen. The examples around Barcelona and particularly in this park are amazing. If you go in the summer be carful as it gets very HOT

Very beautiful - had a great day. We were traveling with three generations, so we took in the park as half of our day. We walked slowly around. Sat in the shade and just enjoyed the beautiful plants; park layout and structures. We made it a very low key effort and since we were there about 3 hours, I felt it was worth the fee to get in.

Nice home. People often miss this place but you should visit it. It was the home of the Güell Family for a short time. Hard to imagine such great work around 1900. Once you get on the roof you can see the guests at the hotel across the street. During our visit, one of those guests was basking under the sun without inhibition!

Lovely work by Gaudí. We went on a Saturday around 2 and we had no problem getting in. I do advice trying to get as many tickets online as you can, one Mai reason is you know what time you will be getting in and don't have to waste a lot if time waiting in lines or waiting for your time to go in. The actual house is pretty lovely, nice work all around, amazing architecture. Do be careful when going to the roof due to the stairs being a little short. Amazing view of Montjüic from the roof. Must see. A little expensive.

Must see but not for everyone!. It is at the top of a hill and so if you were already tired, take a bus or cab to reach there. One who does not like nature or parks may consider to skip this place but it is a must see if it is your first visit to Barcelona. An important part of the Gaudi puzzle in the city and try to enjoy the park slowly without rushing.

Gaudi's first masterpiece. When you visit this place, you will understand how genius was Antoni Gaudi. The museum is definitely worth visiting, because you will fell the atmosphere of Modernism epoch. Especially I like the cheimneys on the roof, which are beautifully decorated in Gaudi's special technic. Btw, every Sunday from 5pm to 7pm the entrance is free, but you should come in advance (maybe 30 min), cause the queue is quite big.

Guell fan must see place!. I spent hours looking every part of Guell Palace, it was so interesting!! If you're a Guell fan like me, this is a must see, and you will enjoy it very much! I really enjoyed the rooftop colorful chimneys and overlooking the city view of Barcelona downtown. I'd love to go back there again!

get tickets on line. It was wonderful but we didn't know there was such a line so when we came we were told that it was too full and we could only go in another 3 hours, so we got tickets for the next day. So get advance tickets on line and then you just go right in but you have to specify the time and date.
Impresive place.. Lovely palace and park. Some of Gaudi masterpieces, amphitheatre with a-capella chorus, the famous bench and profusion of flora.
Example of collaboration Guell and Gaudi. Not to be missed Gaudi architectural creation. Amazing exploration from the bottom stables to top of the palace chimneys .

timed ticket entry warning. Wanted to repeat visit of 3 yrs ago. Arrived at 11 am to be told next entry was 13.00 pm. Too long to wait as no where to fill in that time,as had used hop on hop off bus. Very disappointed as no prior information of timed ticket entry. Assume this is new or high season system. Book in advance is our tip or go earlier,though hop on buses do take about an hour+ to get here

Well Worth It-But Don't Overdo. Definitely worth the trip from downtown--public bus transport is quiet easy. The park is beautiful and the real winners, as is usual for Barcelona is the Gaudi buildings. The place is a tribute to modern urban planning done over 100 years ago. Great place to take children and their guardians will enjoy it as well.

Neat Place. My wife and I came here on our first day in Barcelona, and it was definitely one of our highlights. The palace is beautiful, and the audio guide provided a nice historical context for what everything was. It wasn't crowded when we visited, but I would purchase my ticket online before going just to be safe.

Vintage Gaudi, brilliant roof terrace. Vintage (early) Gaudi. The wait to get in was a little bit shorter than for the Casa Batlo and the Casa Mila, which is a bonus. The inside is a beautiful, in a bit dark and gloomy way which makes the amazing, brilliant and cheerful roof terrace all the more attractive.
Barcelona. If youre in Barcelona you simply can't miss this place.Even if you have no thoughts of Gaudi you have to come here. In one word. Devine
good place - dont waste a lot of time. it is interesting to make a quick tour inside. but if you take your time to listen to the audio guide you will loose almost a day there. so visit in a hurry.

Well worth a visit. Park Guell is definitely worth a visit when staying in Barcelona. It offers stunning, picturesqure views out over Barcelona and a chance to view some of Gaudi's most famous work. We would recommend you buy tickets in advance for access to the monumental zone, as only a certain amount of people are let in at a time and you are assigned a time zone for when you can enter. In our experience this time zone was quite a bit later than when we actually arrived at the park (around 1.30pm, and we couldn't enter until 4.30pm). But it was well worth the wait and you're free to explore the free bit of the park and take in the views. The Gaudi architecture in the monumental zone is beautiful and intricate, with plenty to see, so we felt it was worth the admission price. As one last tip, we would recommend taking your own food and drinks as the food offered inside the park is limited and extremely pricey!

Pretty but not worth it. The park is pretty but you have to pay to get in as of 2014 and try to book your tickets ahead of time. I had an extra day so I went up for lunch in the park but I probably wouldn't go back.

Best of all of the Gaudi buildings. We stumbled on this building and we were amazed at the detail and beauty of this apartment. We went to the other Gaudi buildings but this one was our favorite by far as it was more detailed and pristine then the others.
Favorite spot. One of our favourite places in Barcelona. Take at least 2 hours to appreciate all the details of this fantastic place.

Nice . The design is magnificent. The entrance fee is a bit over priced as I could see the whole paid areas from the outside (although you have to walk around the park to see the main entrance ). And there's not enough toilet at the site so you have to make sure you get it by the bus station.

Skip if you don't have a lot of time in Barcelona. I wasn't too impressed with this place. It could be that I visited in November, so the garden looked brown and sparse to me. I didn't think the visit was worthwhile.

Interesting buildings. Lovely gardens. A long hot climb (although there are outdoor escalators on the worst bit) to get to this Park but worth it for the Gaudi buildings, the gardens and the views of the city and out to sea.
Timed entry tickets essential.

Beautiful. Beautiful buildings and park. Lovely to wander around. The designs and attention to details are amazing. However beware, that if you turn up without booking, you pay for your ticket to enter the park and given a time to enter. For us we had to come back in an hour, so we ended up finding a café outside the park, to have something to eat. It’s quite a long walk from the metro station to get here, so also not ideal for the less active, especially if you then have to wait to enter.
Excellent. Audioguide is really helpful and tells a lot about the history and life of Gaudi as well. This is a great site to discover, one of the best in Barcelona.

Worth a visit. Slightly down the pecking order when it comes to Gaudi list but this building is well worth the effort. Not only does it seem not to have the issues of pre-booking and long queues of Casa Mila and Casa Battlo, but the entry fee is also less steep.Audioguide had a wealth of information and overall you left feeling that you had seen the complete house, from the basement to the (undulating) roof - and everything in between.
Pretty cool park. Lots to walk around and see. The wait time to get into the Monument Area was 2 hours for us. Enter the park w/ some sandwiches and drinks and enjoy the views above the city.
Book tickets. Make sure you book tickets ahead to see the beautiful mosaics. We got there at 11am, and there were no availabilities until 5pm! Lunch in the park is nice though.

Parc Guell. It is unfortunate that they now charge to enter a particular portion of this park. We were hoping that this part of the park was larger but it was still impressive to see Gaudi's work and we all enjoyed the Park. Recommend you buy your timed tickets in advance, online to prevent you from standing around all day until your time is allowed in.
Dont miss this. What a super place, we enjoyed this very much, plenty to see and walk around, another must to do and not to miss if you have the time.

So interesting, but the audio guide is too wordy. Gaudi was such an imaginative man. He really thought of everything in the buildings he designed. Each room is unique, but functional at the same time. They were having organist auditions during our visit. Yes, there is an organ in the house! The roof of this house is spellbinding. Tip: We went on a Sunday afternoon and walked right in. There was no crowd to contend with at all. Also, don't feel obligated to listen to the whole audio guide. They make their point and then some.

Loved it. There are several outdoor facades and park quell to enjoy the work of Gaudí, but many are outdoors. This small palace had one of the best Gaudí interiors to explore. Very interesting and unique.

great park, entrance restricted so tickets required in advance. great park, entrance restricted so tickets required in advance; in a typical Spanish way, the line to get the tickets moves very slowly. However, if you're there BEFORE 08:30 entrance is free...

really intriguing visit. Doesn’t appear to be anything special from the outside, but all is revealed when entering and visiting the rooms. Very well organised and very informative (audio guide). We were there in the morning and wasn’t at all busy, allowing more time to try and absorb the detail and thought process involved in creating this dwelling. The details are quite amazing, the workmanship, etc. are of the highest level.Certainly worth a visit, and it is just off Las Ramblas.
Excellent place!. Have you ever seen a home with stables for horses in the basement? And a circular slanted ramp from street level down to the stables? This is truly a unique home, in many ways
Mosaics and great views of Barcelona. A must see in Barcelona from the stone work, the gardens and the mosaics around the whole area are fascinating. Make sure you take sunscreen and water.
booking to view this park eccential. we went all the way to this park only to realize we had to book the vist it or wait two hours to entre.

Like no Park you can imagine!. DIY touring...look past the crowds and do take time to look at the details in ceilings, fences, drainage systems, mosaics. Recommend taking a taxi to the park...it is quite a walk uphill on a hot day otherwise (HOHO bus stop is at bottom of the hill)

So interesting. Have you ever seen a home with stables for horses in the basement? And a circular slanted ramp from street level down to the stables? This is truly a unique home, in many ways. Don't miss walking out on the roof!
Paying to enter a park. There's only one part that it's "protected" bu you have to pay either way. Was dissapointed to have to pay to see nature in the city.

Okay but nothing great.. I would say the place was just okay but amazingly expensive! Look at the pictures.
It is pretty but I just can't see why the queuing was so long for such an average place.
A Gaudi experience. This building is a perfect example of Gaui's work. The hop on bus stops on the corner. The subway stop is also nearby.
Lively and unique. A gorgeous park with the magic and inspiration of Gaudi and a view of the city. It even has good quality buskers. Can be crowded though.
Gingerbread houses. You see Gaudi's masterpieces as you enter, his ceramic work has a charm of its own, the gingerbread houses were gorgeous, we loved our tour there

Interesting. This was the first of the Gaudi works that we saw in Barcelona and it was really interesting. It appeared a bit dark to us, but that may have been because we saw it later in the afternoon. This is definitely worth seeing. The way that Gaudi forms things is unique and it was interesting to see some of the interesting innovations he came up with in design.

Where it all started in a way. If you are interested in the history of Gaudi and his biggest fan, but like to avoid much of the crowds in the more famous points of interest, this is a good museum to visit. Quieter, very informative audio guide tour, a good introduction to Gaudi and an insight into the life of Güell and his family we'll worth a visit.

Beautiful. although it was busy with tourists, and there was quite a bit of walking, it was amazing to see. The structures and overall impression is awe inspiring. Musicians playing added to the mood of the walk.The gardens need some more tending.
Worth the price. I was hesitant to pay to go in this structure, but the kid begged. I'm so glad I sprung for the admission. The inside is magnificant, but the rooftop is simply indescribable.
Gourgeous. I was there and I was really excited. Beautiful architeture. :D Sure, I wanna come back there... :D I hope to come back next year.

Well worth going - prebook online. No waiting, we went straight in. It includes an audioguide. We went here after going to La Pedrera, so we were somewhat educated a little on Gaudí. The audioguide continued to teach us. The history of the house is fantastic and the guide helped us to notice such subtle but remarkable things that we would not have otherwise noticed.

Lovely Park. Guell palace is nice park to chill out nice celling and amazing decoration.
Love to see and would highly recommend this place.

Beautiful gardens!. Beautiful park with more Guadi influence. You have to buy tickets and there was a lot of people. If you don't have time to wait, there is a large area that you don't need a ticket for and the views of the city are beautiful.

Remarkable, unbelievable not to be missed. We took the tour and found the history fascinating. The ceiling were most impressive and the imagination and skill to create this masterpiece is beyond belief. If I could pick someone from history to have dinner with it would be Gaudi and I would pepper him with questions throughout the night. You don't have to be an architecture buff to fall in love with this magnificent building. Please don't miss this!
beautiful. The park and all the landmarks in the park are beautiful. Buy tickets early because they limit the amount of visitors into the park.

A hidden gem of Gaudi work. I am not really a fan of architecture but after visiting all sites of Gaudi's legacy and with this museum, I am in love with his imagination skill. Don't rush and explore the area and place yourself living here. WOW ....... AND THE roof top is must.....so colourful and vibrant. Highly recomended.

Gaudi's Park. A must see in Barca. Wild landscapes, stone arches, wandering paths and great views of the city. There are two parts - the free area and the paid areas. The paid area fill quickly so if you elect this option - go early. We opted for the free areas after our visit to Sagrada Familia and enjoyed several hours strolling through the park and enjoying the killer views of the city. Note - it's a hike to get up to the park but well worth every step!

Fantastic place. €12 each but money well spent. No queues when we went about 10am but I think this is a fairly new attraction that many haven't found yet. The building has been lovingly restored and really gives you a feel for how this affluent Spanish family lived. And of course the gaudi architecture is just amazing. Go on a sunny day and enjoy the roof top view of Barcelona through Gaudi's fantastic chimney landscape.

Must-see!. Whether you like the "art-deco" or not, this place is a must-go. The buildings inside are amazing and one of the most popular Gaudi's creations, but what you cannot miss is the view of Barcelona and the sea from the "Plaça de la Natura", specially in the evening.

A perfect introduction to Gaudi. Well situated just steps off the Rambla, this museum is housed in a palace designed by Gaudi. Despite it's opulence it is not very big and makes for a perfect tour. Included with admission is a recorded guide that walks you through all the floors, ending outside on the roof top where you'll not only get to see some of the more whimsical chimney designs, but also get a terrific view of Barcelona. A short admission line makes visiting this a no brainier. Go!
great place. Great place and less busy than some of the other Guell attractions in the city. Nice and cool inside on a hot day too.

Waste of time. If you have little time in Barcelona, give this a miss. If you have plenty of time to stroll in the gardens, then it is probably worth the time and it is free entry. We did not pay to go into the monument part, and that may have been worth pre-booking, but we didn't have time.

Not to be missed. Absolutely amazing architecture! Sit on the longest park bench ever and admire the mosaic works. To think that drainage was taken into consideration back then, the small gutter behind the bench seats is well thought out. Walk under the tilted and helicoidal columns. The front entrance is not to be missed. Lots more to see. Visits are timed so buy tickets on line for a specific entry time or stand and queue as limited to 400 people at one time.

Palau Guell. Well worth the entry fee. This is the only Gaudi house you can see in its entirety and it is spectacular from the stores below to the top floor. Even if you are not a particular lover of art or architecture you will appreciate this building's beauty.

great insight of the family home with amazing use off materials and light. you would have walked passed this and not known it was there! but of course it was built and used in the centre for the family and horses !...2 adults cost us 20 euros and had 4 discount...worth it to see the interesting use of metals, woods, glass and light amongst the twists and nooks in the property.....this was nice because it wasn't full of ostentatious metals but a focus on texture patterns and light right to the tip of the building and certainly makes it interesting as you walk up and through rooms all the way to the roof with 13 chimneys all with their own unique style ! fascinating building and worth the visit.go early to avoid queues though not as bad as familia sagrada of course !

Greatly Overrated. disorganised and a complete waste of time and money --YOU DO NOT HAVE TO DO THIS PLACEit seems - form the entry assistants words - this year they have just started charging to visit - hence the disorganisation - add to that they are also limiting the numbers of visitors per day - I have no idea why as there is really nothing to seewe got there at 11am and the next tickets available were for 1.30pm entrance !! Hmmmm - but having got there we decided to get the tickets - HINT - there is a place on the left as you walk back down the street from the main ticket entrance - it looks horrible/ typical tourist signs etc - STOP HERE - great patio / garden and meal out back - if you have to wait this is the place to do it.Other gripes - why pay for the ticket - after doing the tour we realised you can see 90% just by walking round the gardens and around the main entrance towers - believe me - the rest inside is not worth a single dime or a spent minute Next warning- be aware if you are using either tour bus route - the bus stop is on the main street and this place is a long walk up hill in the sun and heat - so those with older / infirm / small kids / pushchairs be aware of this - maybe look at it on the internet instead of visiting and save time / money and grief - if you really must - I mean really really must go - still DON'T

This is a must!. Don't miss out on this park if you're visiting Barcelona....The Best Spectacular View I have seen in Barcelona. Mosaic designs by Gaudi are phenomenal and park itself is great too. You can stop here if you're doing the hop-on, hop-off Bus tour....Highly recommended & hope you found this helpful!
Amazing!. Beautiful like all the things Gaudí had done. It's next to Las Ramblas. Take the audio and enjoy the visit!

Gaudi was a genius!. We hadn't planned this tour and were so very happy that we went. An amazing park - architecture astounding. Vendors were plentiful but not annoying. Very affordable earrings made wonderful gifts for young friends back in the states!

Don't miss. Palace Guell is located on the La Rambla, very easy to reach by metro. But if you have time it is better to walk around the surrounding, very nice things to see, great atmosphere. Audioguide is included in the entrance free and it explains the history of the building very well. Beautiful rooms, furniture and lot to know about Gaudi’s artwork. Pay attention to the details, they are really amazing. Don’t miss to visit when in Barcelona.

It's not at all timewasting.... I loved the park and the monumental area, as well as the Gaudi house/museum, but I didn't like the queues for entrance and also the bad timing between the entrances, which make you lose some time. But it worths.

Well worth the Tour. We purchased the guided tour of the palace and it was great. The tour guide was very informative. She supplied facts and details we found interesting, would have missed on our own. The palace is very grand and showcases Gaudi's early work as an architect.

Cute:). By going to this place, you will understand Gaudi better than going to Sagrada familia. His design is so cute and advance. I don't know design and art, but I have a feeling, designers nowadays are still inspired by his work, maybe some designs are even copy of his. He is such an amazing person. ps the outter walls are under restoration, can't take a photo of the building from the outside:(

You can see half of the space for free/take bus 92. To see the famous lizard and mosaics you need to pay, but the area around "the park" is a beautiful park and it is free. You can walk past one of the Gaudi designed houses and see a fantastic view of Barcelona. Put your walking shoes on. We went at 5:30 pm and walked right up to the ticket booth. I know you can prepay also. A guide at Sangrada Familia told us to walk to walk to St. Pau's Hospital (4 blocks on a tree line street with outdoor restaurants) and catch bus 92. Use you T10 pass and the bus drops you off right in front of the park! If you pre-buy your tickets for both (the park and the church) it can be a full day of Gaudi architecture with limited standing in lines.

Guell Palace is a Real Trip!. I have visited many interesting places and Guell Palace ranks up there in my list. The whole time there I felt like I was in a cross between the Wizard of Oz & Mickey Town at Disneyland. It is a must see in Barcelona and makes the Gaudi experience complete. What a brilliant and interesting person. Glad that I discovered him and his world!

Go to the top...with champagne!. We grabbed a few small bottles of champagne to enjoy once at the top & it was perfection--sat under one of the trees, listened to a guy with a guitar & enjoyed the beautiful view! Wear tennis shoes & take water if going during warm season.
Ostentatious. But well worth your time! Can hardly believe how much money is spent by some families on their quarters!
If you are more interested to see the Guell Park from the front. Well, interesting architecture, but not stunning.It is just located infront of the Guell Park, designed of course by Gaudi...

Lovely afternoon. Had prepaid entry tickets so no queuing spent a a wonderful afternoon here, the atmosphere was very serene, staff were very helpful and we have some wonderful photographs to remember it by
Unexpected. Wow, the use of space and thought provoking decor of this place blew us away! Certainly worth a visit
Fabulous. Every aspect is fascinating. Wasn't a fan before but am now. You can prebook which saves you waiting in long queues

Gaudi Made a Place that People Lived in.. We were thrilled to spend time in the Guell Palace, a stately home in the middle of the City a real family lived in, designed for them by Gaudi. From the lower area where the horses and supplies were kept to the rooftop with its fanciful chimney pieces, there is not a space in this palace that is not wonderful. Well worth the traveler's time.

Not worth the climb. Having jumped of the hop-on circular bus we looked forward to seeing one of the main tourist sights in Barcelona, having only a short time in the city. At the entrace to the park was a chaotic scene and we were directed to a que for tickets, after15mins we found out we had to wait over 2hours to see tbe monuments, which was too long for our day. We walked in a little and did see some tiling, took some snaps and came straight out.Very, very disappointing.

Don't waste your money.. In and out within 15 minutes, the photo shot on top of the mosaic chimneys on the roof is the only drawcard (Definately not worth the 12 euro though). I recommend spending your money exploring the inside of Basilica of the Sagrada Familia, this attraction inside and out is incredible.
Another great Gaudi building. We loved everything Gaudi! This was another amazing design, bringing light and air through the center of the building.
Park Guell - Gaudi. What a legend, Antoni Gaudi.So worth heading up to this landmark in Barcelona.Great views of the city!

Amazing. The Parc is a distance out of the centre of Barcelona, you will to catch the metro. It is an interesting park, originally intended as a housing estate. There is a limited number of people they let into the park at one time so as soon as you arrive go to the ticket office and book the next time available. The gardens are more bush like on the outside and you can see these anytime for free. Once inside the parc, there is a queue to view the house, but is doesn't have many of the "Gaudi" features. The parc has fountains and buildings which have the true Gaudi influence. You will need to spend a couple of hours here to see it all.

They have started charging to see the monuments.... I went here 3 years ago and it was amazing. On the same date I returned 3 years later and the queues were enormous and an entry charge for the monuments. I would not object to paying this but the wait was 2.5 hours... They only allow a certain amount of people in at any given time and they have ruined this for me. This park is amazing (a mega walk but still amazing) but the queue for the toilets (2 toilets) was 30 minutes and the charge for the monuments and the wait should be better publicised.

Not to be confused with Parc Guelle...... Many of the reviews in this listing are actually talking about Parc Guelle (which we absolutely hated) but the actual Palacio Guell is fabulous. We just loved this Gaudi castle - done miss the roof!!!

Great view on Barcelona. Amazing. I did not go and pay for the Gaudi palace and museum and I did not feel like I was missing something. Take the bus that will take you to the upper side of the park (you have to walk down after !)
Gaudi enthusiasts can't miss this. If you like architecture then this is well worth a visit. Recently totally refurbished, this is a stunning example of Gaudi's work.
Not impressed. Not really as special as they say it is. The concept was great but they did a really sloppy job to actually tell you the story. No where near as good as Casa de Batllo.

Guadi's Central Park. A lovely breath of fresh air in the hillsides of Barcelona. A fantastic trip through an enchanted idea of Gaudi. You can imagine what this should have been like, Alice in Wonderland!
Very Detailed. Loved this! The attention to detail is crazy! Be sure to get the audio tour and you can go at your own pace.

Unique respite . Once you find your way here, on this bus or that, you won't regret your visit. After walking quite a distance uphill from our bus stop to find this park, we were really pleased with all it had to offer. At the entrance, we were quite taken with the mosaics. They are playful and beautiful. I felt kind of like I had walked into candyland. We were overwhelmed by the number of people and how well the park contained them all. We walked around for a while and found ourselves feeling more comfortable here than anywhere else in the city. All of the sudden, we were just in a park spending time as a family. We went on the swings. We relaxed on the park benches. We were happy to sit too, because this is a huge park. Wear comfortable shoes!!

Beautiful, amazingly restored. I thought that calling it a "palace" might be exaggerated, but it wasn't! Incredible architecture made of beautiful natural materials with amazing creativity... we were captivated all the way up to the rooftop, which was out of this world! Plus the audioguide is included in the entrance fee, and they don't let it get too crowded inside. It looked new - the restoration work was amazing. We loved it and spent a couple hours there!

wear comfy shoes and walk around. what no one mentions is that this is a big place, make sure to wear comfy shoes and walk around it. it's a very nice place and it has lots to see. the view is great. oh and lots of street artists play music there.

The Serious Side of Gaudi. This home designed by Gaudi is very dark and heavy in appearance, but solid and secure are well. Given the era and location of the home and the occupation of its owner, it is very fitting. If you want to see a variety of Gaudi's work, do see this home.

Fantastic house and garden grounds. An amazing park (designed for an English style, so "park" not "parc"), but only two houses visible from main grounds. The park itself is wonderful to visit - be prepared to walk a good distance and climb elevation, but nothing too severe for the average person. Here is where the famous multi-colored salamander is located. Well worth the admission price. Hint: Visit the museum located just downhill from the main gate and see the video - you can get a discounted combined ticket to both this and the park, and the amazing information provided there via computer displays and a 4-D (effects like moisture and puffs of air when the video has rain and wind) video prepare you well to learn the elements of Gaudi's designs.
Worth visiting. It's a long way up but extremely worth the trek! The views are breathtaking as are the grounds and Gaudi's house.

Try to book this in advance- Parc Guell. The guidebook says this is free but to see Gaudi's actual part it is not. Its only 6 euro so not expensive, but if is busy you may have to purchase a ticket for a time later that day. We therefore, didn't have time to go into the main part to see this.If its hot, make sure you take water there, some of the shops on the way up are actually cheaper than where the tourist bus drops you off.
Beautiful. We spent a few hours here and was a good addition to our trip. Watch out for the birds in the trees as I ended up with bird droppings all over me..

A Barcelona must!. If you're in Barcelona and you love Gaudi, make the effort to get to Guell Palace. It's centrally located, near La Boqueria and Las Ramblas, and you can do the tour in about an hour. The audio tour explains the architectural and decorative features, as well a history of the relationship between Gaudi and Guell.The roof is the highlight, of course! We did not have to wait in a long queue like some of the other attractions in Barcelona. It's not crowded with tourists, and it is really nice to take your time going through the palace.

Like walking around in a dreamland. Gaudi was a true genius and fortunately Barcelona understands his greatness and keeps parc güel in a tremendous condition. I come here every time I go to Barcelona, and every time I discover something new. Can be extremely hot in the summer though, the cloudy days are the best!
From outside it didn't seem attractive. From outside is not attractive and we didn't entered inside, but I saw some pictures from the roof top and I think it is worthy to visit it.

Barcelona Must Do. We almost missed the best part of the park. Get your ticket when you enter for the part of the park where there are all the mosaics, unusual buildings, etc. See the park but don't miss the best part.

A.M.A.Z.I.N.G. Antoni Gaudi, Barcelona's most famous architect, designed this incredibly futuristic housing estate. I felt like Alice in Wonderland the minute I stepped through the gates. There was not a single straight line to be seen, anywhere. The 'houses' were highly decorated with Gaudi's hallmark - colourful, mosaic tiles and fluid lines. There were hanging gardens, mosaic covered seating and fountains with the most amazing mosaic lizard. It simply has to be seen to be enjoyed thoroughly. Another Must See!

Interesting tour off La Ramblas. We stumbled upon this little treasure will strolling with the masses down Las Ramblas. It is worth the tour. Audio provided for free. Supposedly, this is the least visited of the Guell buildings. The view from the roof is worth paying for alone. The chimneys were incredible!

My first Gaudi visit. OK... I would have given this place a 5 if I hadn't checked out the Casa Botell at the same time. Wonderful story & includes the recorded tour... take it... beautiful photos from the roof at the end! Save your battery!

Worth seeing, near Ramblas.. If You are foud of Gaudi's beautiful works, you must visit this site. It's in the old town, very close to La Ramblas and offers a nice option of a tour. Tickets come with free audio guides. Visit take apx 2 hours.
Quirky but nice. A little on the quirky side but fun. We visited on a private tour and really enjoyed it! Would highly recommend a visit.

Definitely a must do. Liked everything, a lovely day out, took a picnic and totally enjoyed our day out. We walked the 1hour trip from our hotel to the park and took in some beautiful views and buildings on route.

Beware Bird Poo Scam. The palace was being prepared for a concert when we arrived so there was little to see.We were lucky not to be robbed.We were squirted from behind by a man and 2 women with a green liquid. They made it out to be bird poo and offered to clean up the mess, but what bird poo smells of mint? They miraculously produced copious quantities of tissues and offered to clean up the mess but they were obviously trying to pick our pockets in the process.
visit. Architect was awesome to look at .outside of the building had lots to see in the area with shopping and things to see

Very interesting stop in Barcelona. We enjoyed the tour of the Guell Palace, perhaps as much for the story of the relationship between Guell and Gaudi as for the house itself. Audio guide didn't work great, but we managed. Be sure to go to the nearby Mercat while you're there!

Very interesting, Gaudi!. Tickets weren't that expensive and you get a guided tour through the whole Palace. Especially on the roof you can really see the iconic Gaudi architecture. Very interesting and worth the time!

Another Gaudi site. This place is a bit out of the way, but definitely worth seeing. There are two Gaudi buildings and a large "courtyard" that he constructed as sort of a town square-type place. Be sure to sit on the long bench that surrounds most of it. It looks hard, but it's ergonomically correct and fits one's back perfectly.

Best gaudi for many reasons. You get to see an entire building here, and one where Guadi had full reign. That made it more satisfying than La Pedrera. Also a good feeling for life of wealthy persons home. Visited afternoon in June on Wed, and no waiting/ very uncrowded. Audio guide is free and explained a lot about Guell and why so many things were named after him. Amazing job of restorationI saw a wheelchair get to several floors. It's not totally accessible, but still worth seeing. Note that other reviews discussing the "park" are not talking about Guell Palace, but about Guell park!
need to see it. not easy to find, but worth to see it. All the rooms and see how this big artist lived is great experience

Interesting, but not the big deal you might think. Everyone says to go, and I am not sorry that I did, but the place did not match the hype. The adjoining restaurant is decidedly mediocre, and we were somewhat forced to cool our heels there for over an hour waiting for our time slot to enter the park. There are some well-known sights where everyone has the compunction to take their photos and then you're done. I might have preferred using that time hanging out longer in the Gothic area or hitting the beach, personally.
Wow!. Talk about a home remodel. Wow! The attention to detail...and the number of details...makes this palace a world-class must see.

Best attraction in Barcelona. While Barcelona has many landmarks that other cities can offer (there are better cathedrals in Europe than La Sagrada Familia and marinas with clearer waters than Barceloneta), Parc Guell is not one of them. This park undoubtedly affords you the best views in town and has the most unique architecture you'll ever witness. It's a great maze to get lost in, and the symbol of this park is Guell Palace, which overlooks the entire city. Take the metro to arrive here and walk up a long flight of stairs before you enter the park, but the hike is well worth it!

Second Best Gaudi Attraction!. Beautiful and ornate interior, worth entry fee! More spectacular from the inside than the outside. Especially appreciated the free audio tour, which made the whole visit more enjoyable.

All natural ..equally spectacular. Free on Sundays from 5-7. Get there early to get your tickets ahead of time. Another Gaudi masterpiece. Allow at least 2-3 hours to ensure you get to the roof. I fell in love with his work that I have purchased several books to learn more. Good to see This as well as Casa Battlio and Casa Mila to prepare you for his Magnum Opus La Sagrada. You will see how he experimented various sculptures to achieve his greatest work that is still being built.

Beautiful building. Not only is this a relatively cheap attraction, but it is yet another of Gaudi's masterpieces. It is also in such a central location, and as we were staying on las ramblas, it only took about two minutes to walk there. Our whole visit only lasted about an hour, but it was very enjoyable. There is a beautiful organ inside which plays every hour, and this really set the atmosphere for the building. Free audio guides with plenty of information also a bonus!

Excellent Gaudi early architecture. We visited this place first among all the Gaudi creations. And we were happy that we did it first, coz we got a glimpse of the early Gaudi style- loved the whole house from the basement for the horses- right up to the roof.The audio guide was wonderful and walked us through all the different creations in the house and the architecture that we cudnt have appreciated other wise.Best part was that this is off the usual tourist map- so hardly any people to buy the tickets as well as inside- so much more tranquil.We loved this house.

Nice Appartment in Gothic Quarter. Unlike the two other Gaudi apartments, this is located right off the ramblas. The interior is nice, and the rooftop is great. I would say this is probably the least interesting of the three apartments to visit, and could be skipped if you're visiting a different one.
A Gaudi Masterpiece. This place is beautiful and shows what a great artist/architect Gaudi was. There are free audio guides which was a big bonus and helped to connect the history with the building.

An awesome artist masterpiece. A beautiful residential house, and a masterpiece by Gaudi. The simplest house furniture becomes a gorgeous piece of art. See the stain glass, the banisters, the ceilings and the rooftop chimneys - and much more.

Go early. Try to get there when the place opens. I took a Taxi which was a great idea on a Sunday morning. Taxi's are very cheap in Barcelona and very easy to use. I took a bus back, which was also a good way to go when you have more time.

Quick visit, amazing architecture. You are going to spend 15€ to go inside this little palace. With the ticket comes an audioguide for you to visit every room, so you can appreciate every detail of the construction. Its another great work from the famous architect Gaudí. Worth the visit for the roof chimenies. The work gaudi and Guell did together was obviously ahead of their time.

Stylish luxury. Not to be confused with Guell Park, this is a mansion near La Rambla designed by Gaudi for the Guell family. Informative audioguide and interesting look into luxury from a century ago.

The best attraction in Barcelona. Honestly, this was the best experience of our entire 6 days in Barcelona. It is a beautiful attraction and the organization of the tour with the free audio guide was incredible. Very informative and the guide gives so much insight into the relationship between Guell and Gaudi. The rooftop turrets alone are worth the trip!

Interesting. If you like to learn about history and architecture, this is the place for you. It's not really what i expected, but the history is interesting. Each room (although empty) have a story and if you have some time to spend in Barcelona, you can spend an hour there.

Great view!. How refreshing it was to find this little gem..... fresh air, space to roam around at our leisure, an amazing panoramic view of Barcelona and free to enter! Highly recommend if you have children so they can run around and burn some energy.

Parc Guell is a must see. Easy to get to Parc Guell using the Hop on - hop off buses. You will be assigned a time to enter when you buy your tickets, so walk the park while you wait. The Gaudi buildings are quite interesting and beautiful. The ceramics are a sight to see.

Must see. Take a few hours to see this park and its buskers. Get there by the hop on hop off red bus. Its well worth the effort and if the climb is too much then the hospital is right at the bottom :)

Beautiful biscuit houses. Parc Guell is a characteristic ART Nuevo master piece,covered with colorful mosaics that look like puzzle pieces. In front of the park there are two small beatiful houses that seems like biscuit house. Very interesting and beautiful to be seen.

Interesting. Great park with some amazing sights. It is a great way to experience Gaudi's work and passion.
Get a good view of the city by stepping out of it for a while!

Worth seeing if you don't have to wait in line. When we went, there was a 10 minute waiting time. We were told we were lucky because it's sometimes 3 hours. It's not worth 3 hours. You see enough Gaudi styles from the outside and in surrounding platforms. Everything else you can sort of get from a picture.If you have a few days and are going to a few sight seeing places, it's worth going to, but if you're only going to a few, save it for La Sagrada Familia which is much more expensive, but totally worth it.

Great place, but not like Sagrada Familia :). We arived in 13.00h, and on the enterance we were told that we can enter in 16.00. It was too much time to wait on that sun, doing nothing. So we walked around the monumental( the main atraction), we walked in the park, which is magical, but we couldn see the thing that we came for. So if u r goin there, u must plan that u must wait.

Really beautiful!. So grateful that I had the chance to see this. ALL museums are free on Monday after 3 pm! The Palace was amazing in every way. The view from the roof and the mosaic chimneys were awe inspiring.
wear your walking shoes. ...or at least not your heels. It's a bit of a trek and it'd be a shame to miss big sections of the park because of footwear!
Fanatastic. If you're interested in extraordinary architecture you should spend the money and visit this building. I'm still impressed about the ideas Gaudi realized. Wonderful and very exciting.

Entry Times sell out. The park itself is free and there are no lines, But,if you want to see the architecture, you must buy a ticket, which sets your entry time. The day we were there, entry times were strictly enforced. Buying a ticket on site was confusing as there were 3 different lines for tickets. The park itself is mediocre, to be done only if you have nothing else to see. I was expecting more architectural elements than were included in the price. This was not in our top 10 for Barcelona.

Amassing place!. Unique architecture, unique park, many visitors on the entrance and a lot of different plants in the garden, near the Nou Camp football stadium and few minutes walking from the metro station!
Really nice view. We had to hike a long hill but the views from the top were rewarding. The monument zone had amazing works by Gaudi.

An unexpected gem in Barcelona. One of the most fascinating things in Barcelona is all the work by Gaudi. Sagrada Familia is a must see and absolutely blew away my whole family. But after Sagrada Famila, our favorite work we saw by Gaudi was Guell Palace. We also visited La Pedrera, but found it was not as dense a Gaudi experience as was Guell Palace.Guell Palace is big by the standards of a home, but is small enough that every room and every space could be done in a style that just oozes Gaudi. The best part is that things keep getting better as you go higher in the house through your tour. We didn't know what was coming when we reached the roof, but suffice it to say, it was a delightful surprise.You should definitely make a stop here when you come to Barcelona.

Fantastic !. We spent a very nice time in the park and in the palace. it is a place out of time the garden are very pleasant. It's like walking in a child dream but it was made by a a relly great architect.

Outstanding! You must visit this place. We are so glad we visited this remarkable building, designed by Gaudi. Even if you Are not into architecture, it's definitely worth a visit. One of the highlights of our week in Barcelona.
Wonderful. A fascinating building packed full of Gaudi treasures. Splendid colours and shapes throughout and the mosaic chimneys on the roof.

A glimpse of Gaudi's learning curve. It is fascinating to see the push-pull of influences at work on this building. You can feel that he was constrained by certain design requirements of his time, but when you look up, you see him reach towards his personal vision. Compare with one of his later works, like Casa Batllo, for a nicely balanced view.

Worth a stop while visiting La Rambla. Went early on a Saturday in which we planned to check out La Rambla. Interesting tour with audio guide plus a cool roof and not that expensive took less than 2 hours.We had purchased our tickets online in advance but the queue wasn't that long anyway. Wouldn't make a special trip just for it but coupled with a few other things in the area makes it worth a visit.

Another Fabulous Gaudi Creation!. Amazingly gorgeous....we luckily arrived about 6 pm, so had enough time to view before closing, and not many tourists. Gaudi was so amazing, and as one of his early works you can see the difference from his later more fantastical creations. It definitely felt like I was visiting an amazing palace from another time and could imagine how wonderful it would have been to live here for a fleeting time in history!

Whoa! Awesome. No ticket sales online and we just walked right up to buy ours. 12 euro per person and much less expensive that La Padrera and Casa Batilo. The roof is famous but we enjoyed the inside just as much. Fantastic audio guide. Definitely do this in Barça!
Take a camera. Other side if the city but worth the travel. Some great examples of Gaudi work. Very big place great for photos. Take a camera

Incredible. You have to see it to believe it. Its beautiful and just something unique. You also get great views over the city. Only down side is the access, you have to walk for a while since there is no metro station near by and this can be hard on the summer time, we caught 43°c . But its worth the effort

Barcelona's Ornate House. This was one of Gaudi's first major designs at the start of his career. If you go to see other Gaudi buildings during your stay such as casa batllo or the Sagrida Familia it is interesting to see just how much his style developed while retaining some core features. This is a great self guided tour. The house is located just off Las Rambles and is well worth the €12 entrance and the 2 hours required to see the full house. The tour is well designed and keeps the listener engaged throughout. Like all of gaudi's works the building is meticulously designed - from the domineering facade to the ornate metal work on the banisters of the stairs every single element of the house is crafted in detail.This attraction is well worth a go especially if you enjoyed the other Gaudi buildings. Overall, well worth a trip and ideally located!

A crazy wonderland amongst beautiful woodland. This is a must if you're in Barcelona. You can just wander round the huge park for free and you do get many good views of the 'monument park' that is one of Gaudi's most colourful creations. But if you want to see the most beautiful areas up close you need to pay for entry - you choose a 30 min slot to enter but once you're in you can stay as long as you want. It is well worth the investment!Climb to the top of the hill and get great views, stop for a nice snack and refreshments just behind the monument area and take your time to soak in this experience.Highly recommended.
do not pay. beautifull parc. dont pay to visit the tourist attraction at the front of the parc, if you clib the steps you can get an even better view from the top of the mountain. gorgeous day out.

Almost mind-blowingly incredible. The sheer imagination of Antoni Gaudi leaves one breathless. This building is several years earlier than the equally wonderful Casa Mila and has more of a medieval/gothic feeling. The spiral ramp to the basement stables is one of Gaudi's innovations, we believe, as is the spiral ramp down to the car park at Casa Mila! Palau Guell has much in the way of fine ironwork, stained glass, paintings, decorative woodwork etc. The rooftop, though not as amazing as Casa Mila, is still worth the climb to the top, with its fantasy roofscape of mosaic chimneys. Don't miss the tiny windows which let light into the domed central reception room with its organ and side chapel.Alan and Jenny Paul

Amazing Rooftop. This was one of the less publicised Gaudi houses, situated just off La Rambla. A lot of people mistake this for Guell Park - it is nowhere NEAR Guell Park, and completely separate! This house didn't have a lot of the curved, undulating walls and ceilings of Casa Batllo and La Pedrera. A lot of it is quite dark, ornate wooden decorated ceilings and ironwork. The best part ( for me, anyway), was the mosaic - covered pillars on the rooftop. Completely different to the rest of the house, and worth the entrance fee. Tip - ticket window is 29 metres down from the building. I couldn't find a way to pre- book or " skip the queue".
Nice to see. The building is beautiful and I'm glad I visited but it was expensive. I do wish they offered a less expensive ticket without the audio guide as I could have done without it.

good but expensive. on the whole be prepared to spend a lot of money if you go inside the buildings. most of them are TOO EXPENSIVE (as in this case) but they are worth seeing. try to come early in the morning to avoid the lines.

“Peaceful afternoon at Guell Palace”. A real palace whose renovation has lasted 21 years and recently completed. Beautiful building from the beginning of Gaudi, Guell for the wealthy family. Audio provided. Purchase tickets at few meters on the same sidewalk for a specific time slot, which avoids queuing for hours.

Boring. It's a Palace, but it's just as tall as everything else. You go out to the roof top and you can't see over the block of flats next to you. It's supposed to be good because it's a work of Gaudi's that's actually finished - can't remember too many book reviews that read that way? It's a building that's old, if you like that you might have fun - but after going on the tour I'm still none the wiser than the 90 seconds I spent on google before I went. The place is entirely hypothetical, the tour says "image what it would have looked like when the table is set." Why do I have to imagine? why not set it up to look like that?I felt like an estate agent was taking me round a house and asking me to think of the potential - it's an empty shell without any furniture and ultimately I was just bored.

A beautiful mansion. I got in free on Sunday evening but on reflection would have been happy to pay the 12 euro entry fee. The audio guide was excellent. The building is beautiful. It's nice that the whole building is accessible (unlike Casa Batllo).

You can get in free on Sunday nights.. The Palace let's a limited group of tourists in each Sunday night from 5-7:00 pm for free. You need to show up at the ticket office around 4:30 and get in line. They will then hand out tickets (all you have to do is tell them where you are from) with time stamped entry times for a free tour.
Not as big as you think. Love Gaudi, great views, but thought there would be more to see. What there is, is great. Very interesting and creative especially the tile work and the supports.

Overrun with tourists but worth a visit.. Gaudi's architecture is unusual but being around so many tourists all gawking at the same thing detracts from the experience. Park Guell and Gaudi's house is definitely a place to visit, but if you are planning a trip to Barcelona, go "off-season". You'll enjoy it more.

Gaudi's hidden jewel in Barcelona. If the Sagreda Familia is Gaudi's masterpiece and La Pedrera his tourist trap, Palau Güell is so far ignored by most of the tourists, and his probably his maddest and yet most classic creation. You enter in a mad cross between an art deco house and a Lovecraftian nightmare, and any Agatha Christie murder story would be well at home.Unlike the Pedrera, you visit the whole house from the stables to the attic and the roof, and I really recommend the Audio guided tour (available in many languages), without which you'd probably miss most of what makes this building unique.Crazy, megalomaniac, and strangely appealing, Palau Güell is truly one of Barcelona's yet hidden architectural treasures.

worth the look but not the highest on must see list. After seeing La Sagrada Familia in the day, was looking for another cool Gaudi building to see. Showed up and got the last tickets of the day, paying full price. We technically had an hour in the museum and the audio guide was 40 mins long. So, we should have had plenty of time to see everything with the guide before the museum closed, but the staff pretty much rushed us through closing each floor one by one so that we finished everything in like 35 minutes. It was kind of ridiculous and not worth the full admission price for that. That said, however, it was a relatively interesting house. The main floor and basement are quite impressive, however the rest of the rooms were not really furnished the way I thought they might be had the family been living there. Maybe try to see Casa Batllo or La Pedrera instead if you only have a few days in Barcelona.

Free tickets distributed on Sunday afternoons. I wasn't able to go, however, the owners distribute free tickets to the first 300 or so people at 4:30 on Sundays. This used to be a free attraction (as will a lot in Barcelona that no longer are, i.e. Park Guell, Montjuic Castle, Caixa Forum)

More amazing work!. After walking through Park Guell wondering if we were in the Palace until we stumbled on to the entrance of it. Was pretty cool designs inside but i think the entrance price was a bit steep for what it was....

Not just another Gaudi building. We had already seen the Casa Batllo and La Pedrera as well as Park Guell, so we weren't sure the Guell Palace was going to be worth seeing. Luckily, we were wrong! This building is really quite amazing and there's a lot to see here. The roof designs alone were worth the price of admission. Definitely worth the visit!

An early Gaudi masterpiece. This is one of Gaudi's buildings that we missed during our previous visit to Barcelona, so we jumped at the chance to see it this time.Even in this early building Gaudi's genius and attention to detail is visible. The audio guide was very informative, although frustratingly we couldn't access the extra snippets that it occasionally offered us.The main hall in particular is beautiful: relatively small, due to the small footprint available for the building, but perfectly formed. During a recent restoration the existing pipe organ was replaced and occasionally during our visit it burst into life to give visitors an idea of the excellent acoustic of the space and what it might have been like to attend a recital here during the building's heyday.

beautiful hike and views of madrid. There's a lot to see, without buying the tickets to go into the pay area or museum. The only downside is all the crappy souvenir stations set up that our small children are drawn to like flies ;).

Brilliant. Well anything gaudi is amazing and really I could not get enough of it. This just topped it off with a very interesting audio tour (which left the audio on the grey line hop on hop off bus a lot to be desired). It is simply incredible how guell lived and his relationship with gaudi allowing places like this to come to life.

Whimsy gives vent to creative imagination and blow- your- socks- off creativity. The last place one would expect to find a magnificent town villa is in the middle of the somewhat oppressive darkness of the Carrier Nou de la rambla. I am pleased,nevertheless,that Mr. Guell decided to build one here and for choosing Gaudi as his architect with complete freedom to creative licence. One can only imagine what it felt like to arrive in a coach and ride through the gateway,to be blown away by the visual splendour and imaginative style awaiting your senses. Stepping out of your imaginary carriage,you would have been bowled over by the amazing,mystical domed hall that rises through the floors,shrouded in darkness,reminiscent of a medieval inner courtyard This is a home of someone at once religious yet avant-garde. The dome was engineered so that light penetrates slightly through minute apertures,creating a star- filled firmament. the living space is more intimate but hardly less grand. Gaudi pulled out all stops here,combining artistic and imaginative innovation with an interesting Arts & Crafts form. The interior has canopies,arched galleries,decorative window glass and wall coverings.... carvings and extravagant furniture fill the inexhaustible creative imagination at play here. The roof is probably the most well known due to its amusing ventilation shafts and biomorphic decorations. Loved this whimsy and imaginative concept,to bits

Enough to miss a flight for?? Almost!. I stumbled upon Guell Palace when it was closed and would only be open the day of my departure and I thought, "ok I'll pop by for a quick look before I fly out". Famous last words when I found myself trampling maniacally over everyone precariously descending the umpteen flights of stairs to get out - so carried away had I gotten inside of this majestic, opulent, grandiose house. The defining moment was when I arrived at the roof and was confronted by a totally incongruous, insane "mini-park-Guell" type environment, that I actually found myself considering missing my flight...Gaudi. Damn him and his mesmerizing ways...

Fascinating - but pre-book and. The Gaudi architecture makes this a park like no other. Don't queue, pre-book on the Parc Guell website - it's cheaper too. We booked an entry slot (half-hourly) 1 hour in advance, although I'm not sure if that's always possible.There's a free part of the park and the pay-for Gaudi part. If you enter via the free part, follow signs to C 'Olot (Carrer d'Olot) or just look around for the Gaudi mosaic-clad buildings to get your bearings.We found it hard to find the pre-book line so, if in doubt, ask a staff member. In summary, Carrer d'Olot has a big flight of steps at one end, two Gaudi buildings in the middle, and big gates at the other end. Enter via the gates and turn hard left. Also, we came from Vallcarca Metro station, which has escalators up the very steep approach to the park, but not much in the way of sign-posting, so take a good streetmap.Possibly the navigation to the park is more straightforward from Lesseps Metro station, but I've heard the walk may be steeper.
Relaxing afternoon at Guell Palace. Went with a tour and walked to the front of the line. Very relaxing with beautiful views. The colors of the original marble were breath taking.

Long uphill walk!!!!!!!!. If you go here on the tourist bus you will have a half mile walk up a steep hill to get to the park and massive queues to get in.we didn't bother and walked back down and carried on to Camp Nou.

Worth visiting. We went there around 2.50pm and get our tickets on the spot. I was expecting a long queue but there was not many people waiting. We used our student IDs and paid €8 per person instead of normal adult fees. The entrance fee includes an audio guide. There are lockers to store our bags but be prepared to bring €1 coin to use the locker. The whole place was beautiful, especially the roof and the chimney. There were also a mini exhibition which explained how restoration took place.

Long wait, expensive. this used to be a free site to visit, but recently an entry was established. You must a time to visit, preferably on-line. Visit times are fixed so you must choose from those offered. We had not selected a visit time, so we were told we'd have to wait 3 hours before we could get in. We didn't bother.

Excellent view. The view of the city from the parc guell is well worth walking up there. Get your tickets as soon as you arrive as these are often for later on in the day. This will allow you time to explore the 'free' section first!Gaudi's mosaics are 'must see's too!
wow. this place was truly amazing. get the audio tour, well worth it… Gaudi was a genius… really pretty and beyond the years in design

Worth a detour to explore. To beat the crowds I booked my ticket online for an early morning entrance and judging by the line-up when I arrived I was glad I got a little ahead of many others. This early Gaudi work is worth touring and the made all the more so by the excellent audio guide that explains the rooms and corridors as you start at the bottom and work your way to the exterior roof with Gaudi's trademark unique chimneys. The building has many interesting design features including the street level wrought iron grating which is very intricate but is almost overlooked by the crowds waiting to enter on the sidewalk outside the Palau.With so many sights nearby it's easy to link several together such as the nearby Ramblas, Hotel Espana and Liceu Theatre.

Relaxing and beautiful way to see the entire city and peek into the mastery of Gaudi. This is a site not to be missed. The ingenuity of Gaudi comes through again and again in Barcelona, and this parc and set of aquaduct systems that were designed as a neighborhood site are remarkable. The views of the city from the top are breathtaking and well worth the trip.

Fascinating. We went at 5.30pm and there was no queue ( it is open until 8 in summer). This place was completely worth the entrance fee which included a useful audio guide. The whole house was amazing, but the roof is the most special part. Incredible views and chimneys that will make you smile.

A building full of function and arts. Material used are so good that it's not seen popular until now. Lots of marble, cast iron and wood were used in this house. There is even a big organ was installed inside, often this can only be seen in the church. Roof is again with the same taste as Casa Mila, turning the ugly chimney into beautiful shapes of arts.
Green and mystic. Take enough time to have a quit walk, some time to sit on the famous benches, look around , feel the pilars of the ballroom and smell the view over barcelona
Very nice mansion. Very cool Gaudi designed residence in his earlier style (not so whimsical) - ticket line was not too long earlier in the day.

Just Amazing!!!. So many of the works of Gaudi here, it so worth the cash to get in. YOU MUST GO!
It takes a bit of time to wander too it and in the heat and summer there isnt much shade. I would totally go check it out. :D

Early Gaudi. Close to the Ramblas Boulvard
First renovation of a palace of the rich Jose Goell who discovered the young archiitect Gaudi and let him use a big budget to make a statement of modern luxury.
A must to understand the evelution of the art by Gaudi.
Visit first and then Casa Batilio and Casa Milla and finish in Sagrada Familia.

Fun for all the family. We started the visit in the playground - several for different age groups, and a shady and not too crowded place to sit when we were there. Then we explored some of the free gardens (and popped out to the free loos - not at the main entrance with the gate houses, but up and right from them as you look at the map of the park (or up and straight on from the ticket office) and out of the next gate you find). Wonderful bizarre architecture, wonderful views of the city, lots of chances to play hide and seek around the places that you find.We paid to go and see the wonderful 'monumental' part - and loved the iconic mosaics, and being able to go into the gatehouses. I'd recommend it!

Mystical. . A great day in the park and opportunity to visit Gaudi's works of art. Yes .... These buildings are works of art. Walk through the park with a guide if possible. Will gain insight on the entire area and history. Loved this tour!!

Finally re-opened. I've been waiting 10 years to see the inside after the restoration of the building...well worth the wait. It is amazing to see what money combined with imagination and genius can produce. There are too many great details to mention. It has to be experienced.

Excellent. Park Guell is very interesting. The architecture of park Guell was different yet fascinating. There were many places to explore so it was worth the cost. There were many beautiful mosaics and sculptures. Even in the area where you don't have to pay it was a good place to spend time. I would really recommend this to anyone.
Very unique, interesting home. One of Gaudi's earlier works, very interesting approach to materials, liked how the upper floors overlooked the first floor main room, loved the roof top!
A lovely afternoon. Beautiful, you need a few hours here, not so easy to get to. The hop on hop off bus stops but you will need to have the time. Always something going on, musicians etc.

Great 1900's residence of a wealthy businessman. The finishings are fantastic. Gaudi did a great job styling the walls and other built-in elements. Easy to get into (long lines at other Gaudi locations like the Sagrada Familiar and Park Guell) unless a cruise ship has just disgorged its passengers. But you can buy a ticket for a later day and time in advance.

Guell Park. Like Disneyland without the annoying crowds. Lots to see and wander around.
However, I found the people on duty at the entrance officious and unnecessarily abrupt. Once free of the "what time is your ticket for?" police we had fun!

fab place. amazing loved it, bought tickets the day before so to avoid the queue but the staff on the counter seemed to take ages to sort it out and would have made us wait behind a large school group however let us in in the end. As a place it is marvellous
