Nothing like it. A must see, do the tour here to see inside and the mosaics on the roof..the wrought iron gates t the front is true Gaudi style
Just Perfect. A beautiful and strange work from Gaudi. Do not stay on the outside, you should enter and see all the crazy stuff on the inside.
Blah. Ok. It looks a little like Disneyland. I came away thinking that at least I knew why he died broke. This is just the work of a crazy person. And then someone called it art.

gaudi but not as you know him. I camne away thinking Guell must have been a depressingly austere man. Gaudi shone on the roof and in the chinmney pots where perhaps Guell didnt venture but this house built 20 years before Casa Batllo was gloomy and oppresive. I doubt Mrs Guell enjoyed living there?
My Favourite Gaudi. This is my favourite Gaudi piece. Get to the roof for some great photo opportunities and great views of the city. Stunning

Nice View. Grab a gelato, 1 or 2 scoops then sit down at the bench while you watching people ( most of them Catalan's) passing by then look up for a better view of Gaudi's finest work, we didn't go inside we just enjoyed its beauty while eating my favorite chocolate & pecan flavors at the bench.

Worth the climb. Once we had climbed the steps and steep incline to get to the park from the Metro we enjoyed the park and the beautiful views of Barcelona. The escalators would have made the climb easier if they had been working! We enjoyed the museum very much, Gaudi seems to have been a lovely, happy man. Our only disappointment was the graffiti expressing the 'artist's' dislike of tourist, bemoaning the fact that Barcelona doesn't need them.

A masterpiece of Gaudi. It was great to see an architect's vision bloom into fruition in this surreal park. The attention to each small detail was the most impressive aspect of the park. This is one of the most memorable places to visit in Barcelona.

Gway way for half a day. This is a must on your tour of Barcelona as it has so many of Gaudi's ideas of nature and spirit. I would recommend a guided tour so that many of the items there can be defined as to Gaudi's thought process.

very interesting. It is not the prime attraction, but its very interesting for the Gaudi's architecture and decoration. All the Gaudi's attractions are very expensive. Casa Batllo 21 euros per person is extreme.
Outstanding Gaudi. Brilliant design and decoration, very innovative an example for our Architects who seem to be old age compare to what Gaudi did end of 19th century

Beautiful views and design. Definitely worth going to if you have the time -- if just to see a side of Gracia that you wouldn't otherwise see.
Going with a tour guide would be helpful but otherwise it's a great place to visit!

nice interesting place. we didnt book ticket online which was bad decision but fortunately enough that we still manage to get ticket on the same day we plan to (have to wait for afew hour after we buy ticket so went to the market to kill some time). totally love this place if you have to pick between casa batlo and this place, i totally put my money on guell palace.

Park Guell. Put on your hiking shoes. The Park sits atop the hill El Carmel. There are escalators that help you along the way. For the more energetic type like my son, you can run up the steps. It's in the district of Gracia. Once at you are there, you have a perfect view of all of Barcelona. The park is beautifully designed by Antoni Gaudi and well worth the visit.

Did not need Audioguide. They sell you the Audioguide with admission, which is why it is pricy (12€ for adults and 8€ for students) but still a good experience. Cheapest Modernisme admission if I remember correctly.

Interesting difference from Gaudi's other famous works. We visited Guell Palace after we've been to Parc Guell and Casa Batllo and found it more serious in mood/atmosphere created. For us, it was interesting to see how an architect could be so different in style. The place also made us more appreciative of Gaudi's talent in furniture design. Sat on a bench (think it was the only one you could sit on) in the main hall and immediately noticed how comfortable it was, tilting at just the right angle to support the lower back etc.
Gaudi's design with the Guell fortune. Go, see and experience what this genius designed for the Guell family and learn about the Guell family accomplishments. You won't regret it.
Piece of nice architecture. I was surprised how well designed this house was, all pieced of counstruction match to each other and none of them was made by accident.
Another of Gaudi's artworks. The ticket comes with an excellent audioguide. It gives a good insight of the relationship between Gaudi and Guell, and how the rich lived in those days.
you cannot visit Barcelona without going here. right beside the end of La Rambla you see the 3 large lizards at the water fountain. Brillant art/architecture once again.

Don't miss this!. Palacio Guell is off the Ramblas. Buy a ticket and then enter at the designated time. I was there in the late morning and waited about 20 minutes to enter. There is an audio guide for the tour and plan to stay at least an hour. I toured here at then went to Casa Batillo. The later was really over the top, so start here at Palacio Guell and then go on to the others. Amazing stuff.

worth the visit. Palau Guell is the mansion designed by Gaudi for the Guell family that is located off Las Ramblas. Some reviewers are confusing it with Park Guell. Visitors to Palau Guell pay 12 euro to tour the inside of this beautiful home as well as walk its rooftop with many interesting chimneys. The interior design is elegant while the exterior is more fanciful. We walked up to the ticket office and were assigned an entrance time only 20 minutes later; time touring Guell Palace was about one hour.

Gaudi's luxurious family home in the city centre. The house has had extensive renovation. The guided tour is excelent with staff who know their subject. The chimneys on the roof are amazing structures and are well worth the climb to the roof. Tickets are timed for small groups to enter. Once the tour is over you have the opportunity to go back and tour any rooms you would like to spend more time in.

place to visit in barcelona. when i was visiting Barcelona last time this park was free to get in. Now you have to pay e8 and best way is book ticket online - its happen they`re sold out! pay area is the lizard, mozaik bench and 2 houses of gaudi. one is a souvenir shop and the second you can entrance free of charge but in my opinion not worth to get in and waist your time in the line waiting. looks much better from outside. free part of park is lovely and views is very nice as well.

This is not a free park to see Gaudi's work. We had read this park was a must to see Gaudi's work and was free. After paying over 40 Euro to see other Gaudi work we thought this would be great. The park is free to enter but if you want to see Gaudi's work you have to pay to enter those sections of the park. Bloody ridiculous and really disappointing. The park has some good views but is not very well cared for, not helped by the huge amount of people coming through. Give this one a miss

Well worth the price, don't confuse it with the parc. The Palau Güell mixes two great persons, Eusebi Güell and Antoni Gaudi. This is the palace which was built/planned by Gaudi for the Güell family. The audioguide is included in the small price (which is well worth it compared to other Gaudi buildings like la Sagrada Familia, la Casa Battlò or La Pedrera) and is essential to understand the visit and the use of each room. At first, the palace seems more simple and down to earth than other Gaudi creations, but as you reach the upper floors and the roof, you realize that the style becomes more and more Gaudi-crazy. The palace itself is in a pristine state and well maintained, parts of the roof are in renovation, but nothing too bad. Don't rush past the main room or you'll miss the organ playing every few minutes.

An impressive piece of history. Like all Guadi buildings on the tourist trail, this place is an impressive piece of history. I would recommend booking online with all top sites in Europe and this is no different. It will save you time and frustration.The location is walking distance from the central market and La Ramblas so I would say it's a must if you are in the area and making a day of the old town in Barcelona. I would put aside 2 hours for this site which you can do with the heavily used audio system throughout Spain and Europe - these are great and provide enough detail to learn something if you want or just skip through if you are time limited.Tip- take your own head phones with you as many are hand held so you hold it to your ear but can plug I. Head phones if you have them with you.The a palace itself is a stunning piece of architecture that you can. Explore for yourself but if you are interested in history, architecture, Gaudi, design or art - you will love this place.They appear to have time slots every 15 minutes that enter as marked on your ticket so turn up about 15 minutes prior to your time slot and you should get through easily enough.It costs a few Euro, I can't recall exactly but it's cheap and worth it.

worth the visit. Guell Palace is one of Gaudi's first's works. I am not sure why it isn't as popular as his other works. It is worth the visit. If you are interested in Gaudi's architecture, visit this palace first, to appreciate the evolution of his work. Plan to spend about 2hours here.

Marvelous to see Gaudi's palace for the Guell family. Right off the Las Ramblas, Guell Palace is an audio guided visit and you can stay as much time in each room or area as you wish, which I like. We enjoyed our visit very much. Go at opening time to avoid crowds.

Amazing, Amazing, Amazing. Wow, this area is truly stunning. The walk to the top of the park area is fab, with breathtaking views over Barcelona at the top, also book ahead as it is always booked out if you arrive with no ticket.

A little known Gaudi work. I studied Gaudi many years ago and had never heard of this house before finding it on trip advisor! It is an imposing place, I don't know how practical it was as a home and is certainly worlds away from Casa Battlo and Casa Mila but it's interesting to see how Gaudi developed from this Palace into his more recognised works. We went early and got timed tickets for an hour later but this was fine as a wander around the Gothic quarter is a perfect way to pass an hour. It was an interesting place and the roof is a must with the more recognisable Gaudi chimneys. It's not a place I'd rush back to but I was glad I got to see it and was worth the entrance fee.

Nice, but not as nice as Sagrada de Familia. If you have to choose, pick the Sagrada de Familia. This place is nice though, with interesting, well thought out architecture. What surprised me the most is that the whole place was set up for spying, so someone on another floor could watch what the person on the lower floors are doing. The pace of the audio guide was perfect.

Beautiful Art. The colour, expressiveness, and abstraction is fascinating. Both the interior and exterior are worth the visit. This is one of my favourite attractions in Barcelona. The view of Barcelona is spectacular. I could spend hours wandering around.

English guided tours available Tuesdays. Not to be confused with Guell park, the Palace Guell is well worth a visit. You will need to purchase a ticket on site ( not available online), and the queues can be quite long. We by chance were able to join the English guided tour, available Tuesdays at 2pm for no additional charge. The guide was friendly and very knowledgeable and able to answer all our questions. Following the tour we were able to return to areas that were moved through quickly with the guide.

Not a park, this is abuilding off la Rambla. Most reviewers here are mixed up with Park Guell. And posted photos of Park Guell. This is actually just the really gothic building with iron work outside, that's just off La Rambla. Though I should point that out. It's closed on Monday

Fascinating. This is not to be missed. I recommend reading up on the history as it enhances the trip. There is a app/tour available in iTunes. Book ahead of time and try to go early in the day. They limit the number of visitors and there are delays later in the day. You'll notice I have nothing to say about the park itself because I have no words to describe it. Pictures don't do it justice either. Just really cool!

Not much to see. The park was nice enough as a park, and the parts with mosaics were pretty but considering there were only a few areas with mosaics and decorative features I did not feel that it was worth the €9 entry fee.

Insight into Gaudi and Guell. This home, built by Gaudi without regard to cost, is a good way to learn about the man and his work. While somewhat costly (12 euros), the place is unique and magnificent. The audioguide and a short film assure that you understand what you are looking at. It also shows the lifestyle of the Guell family who lived there. As Gaudi's first house, it is not as over-the-top as Casa Batllo, and also does not have the long lines to get in. Located just off the Rambla and not far from the Bari Goti, it is well worth a quiet hour. There are lots of stairs and no elevators, so it is not suitable for the disabled.(Some recent reviews have this palace confused with Guell Park or the Sagreda Famila.)

Stunning interiors. The design of the interiors and all the details on each room are sumptuous and completely unbelievable. Every part of the building is entirely grand, and the audioguide is a really fabulous accompaniment to show you how much detail really went into the process of designing and building. It has info on the materials as well as the usage and history of components of the room. I really enjoyed it, but after a while it was almost difficult to look at all the fantastical structures. The beauty actually hurt my eyes! So if you find that sort of thing tiring, I would suggest doing a speedier tour of the rooms without listening for the entire audioguide for that section. It's definitely worth a visit, especially for the rooftop, just somewhat overwhelming.

Get advanced tickets!. They only except 400 people at a time so you can show up and not be able to go inside the actual park. But, the park outside is great with amazing views and cool street performers.
Worth the money. Had a great time in guell palace, it is easy to walk around with the audio guide. Beautiful place to see Gaudi's work.
Ceilings!!!!. I,m not sure if Gaudi was a genius or perhaps a bit mad. Construction of building is incredible. Do check out the ceilings they are amazing. The roof terrace is just terrific.
fairytale. queues were not too bad you could buy a ticket for two hours later. amazing building like a childs fairytale drawing magical!
Family Vacation II. Beautiful. Must do attraction in Barcelona. It is wonderful to be up close and personal with Gaudi's work. The colour and architecture are amazing.
whimsical day in Park Guell. This park feels like Candyland - it's whimsical and inspirational, and the views are outstanding. Book your tickets ahead of your arrival to avoid long lines!

Wow!!!. This park is utterly gorgeous! and full of Mr Gaudi !!! His house has been turned into a museum which has an acceptable fee,the monuments however the government recently decided to charge an entrance fee and at weekends you are easily looking at a 2 hour queue but this will not be to get into the monuments thats just to get tickets for a time zone for that day! so beware if you can book online do so.. otherwise you'll find that your missing out on the greatest barcelona attraction!However once in the Gaudi structures are awesome even by our childrens standards-this is a must when in Barcelona.

You must buy a ticket to see Gaudi works. The park itself is nice to walk, relax and see the whole Barcelona. It's free of charge, but when you want to see Gaudi works there, you must pay 7 euros/person - this part of the park is separated from the rest and you can't enter unless you have a ticket for a certain time. It's better to do it online a few hours before. We did it while we were in a park and showed the tickets on a mobile.The only annoying thing about the park was WC - there were only few toilets and you had to have 0,50 euro to get inside. The queue was long and it took about half an hour to get there - of course if you had coins. I didn't. :(

worth a visit. Wonderful way to really get an appreciation for the real genius of Gaudi. Conventiently located right at Las Ramblas, it is well worth a visit. The Audio Guide is very well done and it was a great tour.

Beautiful but a big climb to get there!. Whichever way you enter the park be prepared for a hill walk. Some entrances have escalators for part of the way so if it is likely to be a problem, check this out first. Its the third attraction on the hop on hop off bus so plan your day accordingly. Buy your ticket online as there are limited numbers allowed into the restricted area each hour.

Highly entertaining. I just wrote a review praising Gaudi as architect of a building, La Sagrada Familia, as a fervent prayer. The Guell palace and gardens are kind of like the personal and civic versions of that. If you go there and think only, "This is a cool house because it has such funky, alternative mosaics," then you're missing the point. These are poems, songs to the unrestrained joy of creating entirely new forms that still somehow seem intimately related to what came before them. They are colour, free of its referential function--pure expressive elements. The fascinating, spiralling vents are abstract sculpture. The undulating benches are serpentine meditations on the flow of water becoming utilitarian joy. No wonder Barcelona justly celebrates Gaudi. He has created the city AS art. Go. Go. It's almost like nothing else on earth.

Interesting. The cheapest of the Gaudi places to visit, probably because it's the least typical of what became his signature style but still impressive and interesting and the audio guide certainly helps. Also very easy to find just off the Rambla. If you're planning to also visit the other Gaudi residences, come here first.

To do in Barcelona. Let be honest . Barcelona is not Roma or any old historical city , so the interesting things to see are not that many ...Barcelona is a fantastic city for a few visit , food , party , some shopping and atmosphere .Palais Guell is one of the activity you have to do , and it's near Las Ramblas , THE STREET of Barcelona

Very Busy. Follow the droves of people from Vallcarca station, very hot and dusty, queue to get to top and view pretty good - if you manage to get photo without anyone else in it. Tranquil moments listening to soulful guitar playing in the park and other strange instrument under the walkways.Long queues to buy ticket (so we didnt) to the house, terraces and the mosaiced serpentine seat - am now sad that we only saw that from a distance which did not do it justice.Seems a little bit contrived.

Some quiet time. Park Guell is beautiful if you are looking for a place to relax especially as it is big enough to get away from the crowds. Book you tickets online and download the free app for a guided tour (they offer free Wifi for that)

Beautiful. This being the only Gaudi building we paid to get into mainly because it was our first stop in the morning and didn't expect very single Gaudi building to have a fee it was still a great experience. The walk through was well discussed and explained. The interior was absolutely beautiful for a small palace in the city. The Guell's were definitely living great.
Avoid it if it's raining. Avoid it if it's raining because most probably the terrace will be closed (that's the main part).Palace is really nice, take the free audioguide at the entrance!

Park Guell. On our last visit we did not have to pay but now you pay about 8 euros if you wish to visit the 'monuments'. The rest of the Park, which is huge, is free and you don't have to visit the monuments, however it is worth it to see the 'dragon' mosaic and the seating and Gaudi house, though be prepared for a wait at the latter. There are fantastic views from the Park over the whole of Barcelona and we visited on another day for a free walk around the gardens and picnic in the shade whilst listening to a man play Spanish guitar.The Park is at the top of a hill, there are street escalators, if you go via another walking route be aware that it is quite steep.

Beautiful. Is a beautiful place and a very interesting one. You learned a lot from Gaudi's inspirations by walking through the park.
Really nice!!

Beautiful House!. This is so much cheaper than other attractions in Barcelona, but not any less worth it. We didn't manage to get tickets online (I couldn't work out the ID number they wanted??). We got to the ticket booth a few doors down from the House around 9.45 (the booth opens at 10am) and we were 3rd in the queue - not bad! I recommend getting there early as we spent over 2 hours in the house and by the time we left, it was full of tourists. The audio guides are wonderful, bringing the house to life. I loved this as much as Casa Battlo, for different reasons. Casa Batllo is almost 'Disney' like, this is a more functional house, still beautiful but in a different way. I enjoyed hearing how the family Guell lived here. The roof terrace is beautiful and the chimneys, as always with Gaudi, magnificent.
Not what I expected. I expected it to "wow" me, which it didn't, but when we talked about it later there were a lot of things that were amazing. It grows on you with time.

Don't miss it!. This magnificent creation of Gaudi should not be missed. You will see incredible mosaics, lines and design marked with his unique and unmistakable signature. I've been here in the evening and was not crowded.

A step climb. Best advise, book online so you get a reasonable time slot. Allow about an hour. Best time late afternoon 4pm, gorgeous open views which you can enjoy more once the temperature drops slightly.
Unknown and breathtaking. Kind of hidden close to Las Ramblas, it seems to me one of the Gaudi's masterpieces. Casa Batllo is a rip-off compared to this

just amazing. it is just amazing. i spend there about 2h walking around this big house just next to la rambla. i think is much better then other buildings designed by Gaudi, cos you can see whole house not like at casa batllo (with is awesome too) and the enter tickets are much cheaper then to other places. the design of interiors are absolutely fantastic, the rooftop is just beautiful, you have to see it !!
very beauty. Need to be seen!Altough today with entrance fee ...Musicans playing ... pretty romantic! but pretty crowded ...

Must see!. This palace is the best experience for architecture loving people: there is the Gaudi's love for details, space modeling and colors, but... Fortunately, is not "too much Gaudi"!!! A place where You can actually live.
Amazing Details. Amazing details of work... The towers in the top floor were amazingly built and craft with so much care and detail. Top view is the best. Highly recommended!

Magnificent house!. Saw this after doing the free Runner Bean tours. Our curiosity was peaked, and after having been the Sagrada earlier in the day, we wanted to see something of Gaudi's on a slightly smaller scale. This is truly a magnificent house (though "house" sells it short) with its own chapel (with pipe organ) large public spaces, huge bedrooms, and even a horse stable in the basement. If you see the Sagrada, I do recommend you see at least one of his houses.
great view of barcelona, interesting park and buildings.. Liked: access to gaudi buildings close up.Disliked: Quite a lot of school kids 000's. Well behaved but made it busy.

Very interesting visit. Palais Guell is not famous as other Gaudi buildings in Barcelona on the Passeig de Gracia, but it is worth a visit. This large city center mansion is extremely interesting for someone willing to visit an example of the art of the end of the 19th century. There is a reduced price for seniors from EU. normal price is €12 which is ok.

Free version. We made our way to Guell Park by 1:30 pm and, as we arrived, were told that the next entrance tickets were at 4:00 pm, due to the large amount of people there that day (Thurs.) Unfortunately, we didn't have time to wait. However, there is a large portion of the park where you can walk around and get beautiful pics of the city of Barcelona,from the hilltop, all for free. This is a beautiful park and we enjoyed walking around, admiring the Spanish ornamentation, and the price was right--free! Perhaps, we'll go again one day and see the part we missed, but I doubt it.

OMG, the mosaics. even though I knew that there was amazing architecture nobody can imagine the power of the mosaics. The color, the delicate designs, the scope of the park. It blew my mind. Go early in the day, when you have knee issues especially as there are a lot of stairs.

More Chimneys than you could hope for.. An absolute must for anybody at all interested in Gaudi's works. This was his first major project and it shows off so many aspects of his skills and eye for detail. Go early and avoid the crowds and do allow yourself time to be stunned by the rooftop. The chimneys are like something out of Starwars and will feature heavily in your holiday photos - guaranteed!

Stunning!. Brilliant! Very different to some of the other Gaudi houses. The quality and detail of the restoration is incredible. Place was clearly built with money no object, as everything is of the highest possible standard. Highly recommended, a real highlight of our trip.

Interesting . It is really interesting if you are into architecture and pretty if you just want to take pictures. The price is 7 euros online and 8 euros if you buy there. However, after 20:30h the entrance is free. Worth wait if you its spring and summer cause the sky is still bright!
Gaudi park. Loved the architecture - awe-inspiring. Wheelchair friendly. Easy to get there by bus from the city or you could walk in 20 minutes.
Gaudi's residential development failure.. This place is a curiosity that you can preview on the internet. A visit is a pleasant way to pass time.

Wow!. Gaudi" imagination becomes more and more alive in his park and home. There are no right angles in this park and is simply stunning. Stay away from high priced cafe inside the shop. The gift shop is a little dull but it was not the reason for going.

Impressive. Came here as part of a tour of Barcelona.
Enjoyed the impressive views across Barcelona out to the sea.
Definitely worth a visit, the architecture was amazing!

Impressive detail once again. This is the building Gaudi designed for Guell, not to be confused with the huge Park he also designed, which some reviewers have written about below!Highly recommend a visit, if for the cellars alone. What a place to hold a party! The whole building is like a designer's dream. Apparently Guell's accountant was anxious as it was being built and when you see the gold on the ceiling of one room you can see why. Amazing building, with wonderful craftsmanship demonstrated in variety of materials and clearly no concerns about the costs to build it. Amazing and beautiful.
Nice park. This place is worth visiting. Come with good walking shoes, because it a hill site with a lot of paths crossing the area. Very nice views to the city and Gaudi architecture is unique!

Another discovery of Gaudi. What to do in Barcelona after some visits? Another hidden diamond found nearby La Rambla. Gaudi"s imagination guides us through the time of "art nouveau". An open mouth experience.
Gaudi again. Not nearly as impressive as the Sagrada Familia but nonetheless a spot well worth seeing if only for the stuff on the roof.

Masterful Gaudi Residence. This building is newly refurbished ( it was closed the last time I was in Barcelona)The self guided tour is breathtaking - the building delivers exquisite art- nouveau craftsmanship in a typical quirky style that Gaudi is famous for.Allow a couple of hours to get the most from the experience, now one of my favorite buildings!Tickets are bought on street in building closer to Ramblas via a hole in the wall windowUnmissable!

Amazing. It was hot and packed with tourists, but you could not help but be impressed by the whole place. A bit of a hike from the train and the uphill bit is a strain in hot weather but would go back again and I'm sure we would see lots of things overlooked this time around. Highly recommended

Space, Form and Function.. The Guell Palace is an experience to walk through the private palace or should it be called in another way well-designed townhouse. What Gaudi had created was an ideal habitats for the owner which preferred to live in the urban area next to the La Rambla but still had all the convenience and space for his family activities.The basement, the entrance, the reception area to the family hall, the wide opened area in the antic and finally the rooftop were stitched together to give the comfort in living town and the space to carry out daily activities with grace. The visit to Guell Palace is a must. If you have to see only one paid site, this is the one. The 12 Euro per person is well worth every penny. Finally the audio aid should be used to identify each space in question. Please do not run it numerically since it will distract you from the beauties of the place. Also allow more than an hour to slow walk through the palace and pretend how you can enjoy living here back in time.

Magnificent views!. When we started up the hill, I was very skeptical. We went in the "back" of the park and worked our way down to the actual park. I huffed and puffed to get up the steep hills (and there ARE escalators...use them!) but once we got to the top, we were rewarded with the most amazing views of the city. Just beautiful!

Another Gaudi work. This was another great work by Gaudi. The roof top is pretty cool as you can see a lot of the city. There is a lot of iron work and wood in this palace. The audio is included with the ticket pride so it's a nice tour.

Cultural stop along Las Ramblas . This was our first Gaudi stops unexpectedly during an exploration of Las Ramblas. Really enjoyed the audio guide in this one a day being able to explore a place where someone so prominent lived in the heart of the city. It was nice to see the dwelling and partnership between Gaudi and Guell and wish this place explained it more in the beginning. It's a beautiful home and worth going inside and up to the infamous chimneys.

Güell Palace. This was the house where Eusebi Güell Lived located at the end of ramblas and it is amazing Gaudí ´s work with a great fassade where he combined a build variety of materials , playing with the space and lines. When you go inside you can visit this great museum with the bedrooms, living room, office,,It i a great example of Gaudi ´s work

Weird but wonderful. A strange antiquity: another Gaudi-designed extravagance. Not a 20th century home but an indulgence, by the architect and his clients, the Guells. Fascinating but a completely anachronistic miniature urban fanatasy. Rather expensive as well.

Impressive building. We spent 1.5 hours going round the palace, but you could be in there much longer if you wanted.Only downside for me is that it isn't furnished - they could do with putting a little furniture in there just to give you an insight of how it may have looked.

Bravo Gaudi!. I bought my ticket online and just walked in. The amazing thing about the Palacio Guell is the iron work on the doors and gates. There is a one of a kind stable used for horses on the bottom that has a staircase and designs with arches that are great. When you finally make it to the roof. You are amazed by the simply beautiful chimneys that are so colorful and the view is worth the climb.
Nice views of Barcelona. Beautiful park to walk around with great views of Barcelona. There are some constructions of Gaudi. Good if you can go at sunset

Gorgeous building. This place is stunning - well worth a visit. The sinuous curves of door and window frames, the staircase, the way light is funneled down from the central skylight - it is an amazing experience.

Great value Gaudi. This is probably the least well known of Barcelona's Gaudi related attractions and is therefore the cheapest of the houses to enter but we found it the best value. There's a free audio guide which really helps you get the most from your visit, there are plenty of rooms to explore and photos of how the Guell family had it arranged as a home. The ubiquitous Gaudi roof terrace also has attractive tiled chimneys. This house is well worth a look!

Walk around. Catch the No 24 bus from Placa Catalunya and it drops you off right outside an entrance (saves you walking up the hills from the Metro). They now charge to access the plaza area in Parc Guell, and you have only a 30 mins slot to get there. So walk around it, have some refreshments at the cafe area that overlooks this, and just walk around the rest of Parc Guell to save yourself €8 per person!
Barcelona in a nutshell. Wonderful park with walks, views and lots of interesting architecture. Gaudi is Barcelona and this park captures the essence of the city.

Great way to spend a morning near La Ramblas.. By accident while walking along La Ramblas while looking for a computer center, I ran across the Palacio Guell. It was only a half a block of the main street. Fortunately, the line was short as it was early. Try to get there before 9:30 as the lines start to get long after that. The exterior was interesting but the interior was over the top. it was hard to understand the creativity and genious of Gaudi and his contemporaries. It is well worth your time when visiting Barcelona to visit the Guell House.
Gaudi is a geneous. Walking through this park is magnificent. Purchase your tickets in advance to avoid waiting in a queue.

first stop. Great way to get steeped in Gaudi --some downsides though:uphill -there is street escalator assistance but still considerable walking upstairs and around hilly park. admission? I didn't buy tickets - they charge to sit on the Gaudi benches in the middle of the park - seemed weird and unnecessary; one can walk around and get a pretty good view without a ticket.

Fascinating Gaudi insight. Excellent introduction to Gaudi in recently restored Palau Guell. The guide suggests it will take 40 minutes - only if you race through. This takes at least an hour and a half - but is worth the investment.
interesting place. very different from anything I have seen. Very interesting and a good look at what Gaudi created. Colorful And amazing
Amazing Place to Visit. Beautifully made by Gaudi!!! One of the best creations of Gaudi.... You will not regret make sure you have enough time to explore and learn about palace..
Wonderful place. Wonderful place very steep roads to get to it but worth it. Crazy Gaudi architecture, park lovely with lots of street music artists etc. well worth a visit

Amazing. Not one of Gaudi's most famous houses/creations in Barcelona - but totally worth the visit. The roof of the house is incredible with great views of the Gothic area of Barcelona! Worth a visit!

Great Gaudi Experience!. If you're like us, and you don't have too much time in Barcelona, definitely visit Guell Palace as a way to get a feel for the city's architecture. Considering Guell and Gaudi are two of the biggest names in the city, it's a great way to explore both. The Palace is gorgeous and really opens your eyes to Gaudi's style and Guell's living conditions. Views of the city from the roof are spectacular.
Interesting. If you are visiting Las Ramblas, this building is just a short walk away.The audio guides were informative and easy to operate.

Great little place to look around. Walked over to the palace for a nose around, was nice and quiet even though it was a Saturday. The audio guides are included in the entry price so you may as well have one. Worth going to look around at some of Gaudi's work. If you don't want to pay then there are plenty of houses you can look at from the outside though.

Beautiful for a sunny afternoon!. Park Guell - a beautiful park full of history, creation & colour. Walk right to the top for panoramic views across Barcelona. The Turistic bus dropped us off at the bottom of the hill & we walked up hill for about 10 mins until reaching the gates. There is no fee to enter the park, but there is a €8 fee if you want to enter the "village" area for better views of Gaudi's work. Would not be suitable for those with walking difficulties as there are lots of steps & hills. A beautiful place to visit on a sunny afternoon!
Grand. This is another amazing Gaudi house. Built for Gaudi's main sponsor. It shouts money and power, but the house has style. Not ostentatious. The roof is a surprise.

be careful about theft. While we visited Guell Palace we were warned by some people who told a bird has pooped on my brother. The same three people with napkins on their hand asked him to take of his jacket and offered help to clean it. (Later we understood that they had sprayed paint on him) As we had recently read an article just exactly on this in Tripadvisor, we understood that they are thieves. There were also two other victoms just next to us (two senior ladies). We warned the ladies and tried to get away. There were some other people from the gang chatting around with phones. One of them got very angry and pushed my brother. Please be very careful and have a look at this tripadvisor article for safety in Barcelona before you go. http://www.tripadvisor.com/Travel-g187497-s206/Barcelona:Spain:Health.And.Safety.html

A charge too many. I loved the experience and the architecture is surreal to say the least. Free entry into the park but a charge for the gardens of the main house, then much to my surprise, another charge of you wanted to enter the house. Amazing but one charge too many and we didn't bother with yet more queues.

A must for Gaudi fans. We visited this on our most recent visit to barcelona. This place offers an audio guide that is essential. Be prepared to climb stairs. The rooftop is spectacular and offers some nice views.

Outstanding Place! Must see!. Beautiful place! Deffenitely must see it! Gaudi architesture is something you you cann't miss. View from top of the Gardens is outstanding you can see whole Barcelona from there!

One more masterpiece of Antoni Gaudi. If you want to see more of Gaudi's beautiful works, you must visit this site. It's in the old town, very close to La Ramblas and offers a nice option of a tour. Tickets come with free audio guides.

A favourite. Great park an essential but now you have to buy tickets to go into the core parts of the park and these are timed tickets -can see why due to the volume of people - now it becomes a queue to get the ticket then another queue to enter the park - just be prepared for this but it definitely should not deter you.
Beautiful. Beautiful views of the city and Gaudi's amazing tilework. Worth the entrance fee and the hike up the hill!

Dr. Seuss on a Sunday!. Buy a picnic and head on up the hill to Park Guell. Nice to go early and enjoy the layout before the crowds. A curiously planned "gated community" that never took off, but gives you a look inside Antonio Gaudi's mind.
Rip off. Standing in line to buy an expensive entrance ticket. Then waiting half hour to reach the slot time for the ticket entrance, then line up to get into the park.

Stunning. Very good for walking disabled - got good discount and informed us what was the best way in and out to avoid the stairs. Simply stunning with amazing views over barcelona. If you have a nice sunny day, change your plans and go here as you will need a nice day as its all in the open. We changed our plans when we had a stunning day weather wise and so glad we did. Just avoid the onsite cafes as they are just so expensive!

The Great Gaudí. We ran into the Palace while walking down the Ramblas and decided to pay the fee, knowing that Gaudí would never disappoint us. We were right. The visit includes an audio guide, which is great because you get to learn a lot about the history of the place as well as the architect´s. This Palace was entrusted to Gaudí by Eusebius Guell, a millionaire in the 1930s. It has the typical touch of the genius, strange and beautiful. The woodden ceilings, the round benches, the corridors full of light. A true masterpiece, one of the many from the Gaudí legacy. I absolutely recommend it.

To think someone lived here? Amazing!. My final day in the Catalan centre, I visited the Palace Guell (Palau Güell) as I read this was one Gaudi’s most famous masterpiece after the Sagrada Familia.With my luggage in hand, and ready to leave the sunny city, I squeezed this visit into my itinerary and I’m so glad I did. Just off the lower part of ‘La Rambla’ this place is truly an epic achievement by Gaudi. The ticket office is located in the adjacent building and I was lucky as the visit is FREE for the first Sunday of the month! Maybe it was a Sunday afternoon, but the crowds or queue was next to nothing at all.I received a free guide and paid the €1 euro for lockers, got on my way in this dark mystical yet slightly gothic masterpiece of a tour. The attention to details in the architecture from the ceiling in the rooms to the intricate design of the doors paves an exhilarating journey through Gaudi’s imagination. The organ situated in the heart, which I heard pulse a few of its chord, of the building is an impressive feature but the whole design is just impeccable. To be fair, having not been entirely blown away by the ‘Sagrada Familia’ I found my respect manifest twofold in Gaudi’s vision and raw capability as an architect. You get to climb right onto the roof top for some ‘interesting’ designs, I must say – a bit untoward and not really flowing with the overall feel of the interior. It’s also a contrast to see, from the rooftop, the nearby terrace and how unprivileged the neighbours seem to be living. Take a flash, as the lighting conditions are quite dark and be sure not to miss the cellar which is a bizarre experience in itself.All in all, I am grateful to have listened to my gut and made the effort to stop by. Even from the outside, you get a sneak peek through wonderfully designed windows but the only justice is entering and witnessing it yourself!

Overhyped place. I felt the place was overhyped everywhere. The park has two parts, one that you can explore with ticket Euro 8 (without much walking) and other on foot via gardens. We felt it was not worth the purchasing ticket, however enjoyed the evening there.
Colorful. Interesting. A must see in the city. There are many things to appreciate. The buildings, the gardens, the architecture, the colors, the design

fascinating. visited here in Jan 2014. Lots to see, the lighting and design is truly fascinating. You are given a handset which tells you all about each of the rooms you visit. I enjoyed the rooftop visit with the Gaudi design and overlooking Barcelona. Taking your camera is a must as there is lots to photograph. Its a fair climb although there is a lift but worth walking if you can. An enjoyable visit.
Cold. Gaudi's architecture in this one is a bit "cold"; and would prefer to visit the three Gaudi places you must see: Casa Batllo, Segrada Familia and Park Guell.
Brilliant. a really lovely place to go, fascinating you will take a lot of photos here. Some great designs features
gaudi. A park designed by Gaudi was worth the visit but we did not pay the 15 euros to see a minimal Gaudi display. enjoyed walking thru the park. Be prepared for a fairly strenuous walk

A must place to visit, and well invested!. The visual tour (with Ipad) is perfect and guides you round this fascinating house with all the elaborate decoration and gaudi marks. My wife and I enjoyed this place very much. Well worth for Heavy Hearing peoples for the visual tour. We recommend this place very much.

True design talent. Gaudi is famous for his somewhat unusual designs and in places the Guell Palace demonstrates his idiosyncratic approach but what particularly appealed to me was his more classical use of materials to produce a family home that was truly wonderful in appearance and function. The Great Hall is incredible.
The Lap of Luxury. This was Gaudi's first commission and the family spared no expense. It is worth the few hours that we spent here and was good value for the money.

It was just OK. So it was Gaudi, in was interesting, it wasn't very crowded. What more can I say? It's easy to get to, certainly good value for U18s and students. The roof is closed if it's raining so worth knowing this before you pay to go in.
Beware..... We were robbed in the gardens...!!!!4pm - robbed - all cash removed from our wallets...This place has NO security (public or private)
Interesting but Disneyland does a better job. it is certainly an interesting place to spend your afternoon, but Disneyland would likely be a better option for your young kids...

Take the Metro. The best way there is by metro and walk to avoid traffic, its a bit of a climb to the top but well worth the strain - who know why it was built as it is but its amazing yet strange.The little shop opposite the entrance is also well stocked for trinkets and friendly

Beautiful. After seeing Sagrada Familia and Park Guell you almost feel like you have to see Guell Palace. But after those two sites, this palace pales a little bit by comparison. It is grand on the inside, and beautiful but doesn't have the feeling of care and craftsmanship that the other two sites radiate.For the most part it is a nice mansion, with care and details being seen too. But when you get to the roof you can definitely see some of Gaudi's touch in the chimneas. They are definitely a worth the visit. If you have time I would recommend seeing this palace, but you should definitely see the park or Sagrada Familia first if you're on a limited time schedule. I found both of them to be much more stunning.

Nice big park but i expected more art to be seen. Nice big park but i expected more art to be seen , i didn't understand that we must pay to see the house where Gaudi stayed in as it's a "2mn" visit on 2 floors
Don't miss it. The audio tour is perfect and guides you round this fascinating house with all the elaborate decoration and gaudi marks.

Most colerful place. The view, the tiles, the piece of arte that it is. You look around and you are always surprised. It's a very touristic place, many people always visiting. I took the most amazing photos there.It has banks made out of tiles, very beautiful!
interesting place. this is one of touristic place in barcelona in guell park. you need to see that to understand gaudi.. he is a creator..

barcelona. This was our second visit loved it as much as the first time, loved the open space.
Wasnt anything that we didnt like

The most Guadi for your money. I really, really enjoyed this tour. If you only have time for one Guadi house, I'd recommend this.The first architectural commission for the Guell family by Guadi, designed in his impressive modernist style. You can definitely tell this is the beginning of his architectural journey, the Palau isn't as out-landish as the other houses you can visit in the block of discord.Unlike some of the other Guadi houses you can visit, this recently renovated building allows you to tour practically every room/floor, from the basement stables to the roof. It has a fantastic roof with the mosaic chimneys of Guadi you'd expect. It isn't as colourful on the inside as Casa Batlló and as based on form as La Pedrera perhaps a little mor fussy in decoration.Included in the price there was an audio guide, a small 5min video presentation And whilst we were there we got to hear the organ play. In comparison to some of the other houses it is a little cheaper to visit.Within the attic space is an exhibition on construction/renovation of the building, with touchscreen info. Plenty to read if you have the time/inclination.
Beautiful. Amazing and a must visit, beautiful place and worth the trip and entrance fee, it was also a lovely sunny day when we visited and this made it all the better
great place. must see in Barcelona just don't come too early to pick up the tickets.It's open from 10 o'clock but they like to open 10 past.

Amazed. My preferred Gaudi's work in Barcelona. The audioguide is included in the ticket price and it definitely worth it! the architecture is quite unique and every piece has a story. I was amazed by the ceiling covered by gold leaf in one room and of course the ceiling of the main party room.The tickets cannot be purchased online but we didn't wait much at the entrance!

Gruel palace was good tour. I recommend renting the heads phones as you walk from room to room. The Guell palace has a fascinating history and to see the home situated between the other homes, imagining how it came to be, gives you pause! The mosaic chimneys are beautiful and the details throughout the home are really unique, and made me want to replace all of my door handles! Great tour if visiting alone or as a couple. I don't recommend children, they will be bored.
Ppalau Guell. Amazing house, such detail in the design! Particularly loved the chimneys and the audio guide which added lots of extras.
Interesting. The listening guided tour gives so much information you miss in any written literature and once again the roof is worth waiting for!

Ticket 8 Euros avoid it. You may walk around the palace and still enjoy more the sights besides saving money and time. Lovely architecture. Gaudi is really unimaginable.
If you have time and inclination the price although steep maybe paid.

OK but expensive.. Gaudi is one of my most favorite architects but standing from the gates for free to take a pictures is all you need.
I regret not visiting the Gaudi house instead.

Very interesting place, cheaper than other Gaudi attractions. We went here on our first day in Barcelona. It was only 8 Euros to get in or something - which was a lot less than the 22 euros + being asked at places like Casa Battlo and so on. I would definitely recommend this place to see some of Gaudi's earlier work - it's really interesting and well worth a visit.
Unique Gaudi Work. We weren't sure if we should make time for this palace, as we had already seen much of Gaudi's work, but this was different-- a must see when in Barcelona! Don't miss it!
Dont pay!. Great to view.Expensive to enter.Walk around the park and view all u need to there.Inside the ticket area is great for pictures and to touch. To see stay back and drinknit all in.Save £40.

A beautiful place!. Amazing view and beautiful construction! It makes you imagine how would it be to live there and have that view, amazing gardens and colouful buildings just for yourself.Very worth the visit!!
Priceless view. Probably my favorite attraction. The view from the top is priceless and the detailed architecture is breathtaking.
Artistic. Everything done by this sculptor is amazing! How the art could be so natural, so fluent and magical. Its all there: the beauty and the usefulness.
Fasinating. Outstanding craftsmanship and design with loads of details to study, the roof with its fancy chimneys is outstanding
Stunning tiling. The park contains amazing stone structures stunning tiling and fascinating buildings. The vibrant colours of the tiles are truly breathtaking.
Parc Guell. Once in Barcelona, you must have seen this. Segrada Familia is well known, but this is a hidden treasure. A fairy tail. Gaudi at his second best.

Cool but a tad overpriced. This place was cool, and I suppose I recommend it, but it is really pricey. If you have to choose between here and Casa Batllo, choose this place. Definitely don't do both because you'll go broke.
Parc Guell. Unbeleivable lovely place to visit for many hours. You can eat and buy here. And learn too much about Gaudi and Guell's life....

A lovely way to spend a morning. Lots of interesting architecture and a nice place to take a stroll. Lovely views right down to the sea. No need to pre book this one as we paid on the day and could enter within half an hour leaving time to pop for a hot chocolate over the road!

Morning tour of lovely mansion. This unique home was a nice stop on our tour of Barcelona. Near the Christopher Columbus statute. Not cheap to enter but lots to see and the day we visited it was not crowded. If you are interested in old world architecture, interior design, or just enjoy seeing unique homes, this is the place to do it. Friendly patient staff.

Better to not buy the ticket. there's a long queue for the ticket and the price is a bit too expensive for entering the Parc Guell because there's not so much to see inside. You can probably have satisfied to look from the outside and walk around the Parc Guell. I queue around 30 min to enter the House of Servant (if i'm not mistaken) and there's nothing there, i'm a little bit dissapointed.
Did not go inside. Part of the walking tour. Interesting to see. We opted to go inside the Casa Battlo; which we thoroughly enjoyed.
A must!!. I have been to this palace with low expectations. I must say that this place is to die for!! Gardens are amazing and very well kept keeping in mind all the tourists that visit.

very unique and pretty. This place was so unique and beautiful. Don't miss it while in Spain!
*Very clean and just be cautious of who is around you and the pick pockets will leave you alone

Good, rather than great Gaudi. In my mind there is no greater architect than Gaudi, so I still rate this work highly. In comparison to much of his other work however there is less use of colour in Guell. Nevertheless his amazing use of light and contrasting materials is much evident. Worth the entrance fee to soak in the Gaudi genius.
Lovely House. Another great display of Gaudi's genius at work. Located very close to the Ramblas. They give you an audio pager that plays out the important facts as you go from room to room.

Darkly foreboding....a weird place to have lived in. Of all the Gaudi designs this is my least favourite. The place is so dark that it is quite weird. I appreciate Gaudi was commissioned to design the palace by the Guell family, however for me it was way over the top on the word extravagant. The architecture is of course breathtaking but for me it was too dark and looked a little like an over done funeral home....if you like that sort of thing then you will love it. I am just giving my opinion. Enjoy either way as it is still quite interesting....
MUST SEE. Favorite part of the trip. You get the feel of being in a magical world with the color and curves. Great view of the city from here as well and very easy to get to.

Insanity made stylish. There are loads of far better, detailed and entertaining reviews. Guell Palace has a problem for some of us - you are wisked by express elevator from the ground floor to the magnificent roof top ... and then you have to step out onto the rooftop. The walls/parapets are waist height and for anyone with vertigo the experience is bowel activating. Once you manage to stop screaming and are led to the stairs to the next level down it all gets a lot calmer since you are now safely inside. So, go there, enjoy but if someone in your party hates heights SERIOUSLY think about buying them a coffee somewhere and leaving them there.

Calm, serene place. Best seen in spring or early fall.. In spring and fall, beautiful flowers. Wide open space designed by Gaudi. Really nice outdoor park. Best to get their by taxi as parking is impossible. Leaving the park, you can walk down the hill in 10 minutes to a subway station to get back to town. This is an impressive park!
A must in Barcelona. Great experience out in the open. Even if you don't pay to see the Monumental zone, a walk around it is a great way to spend your time, plenty to see.

Interesting and Informative Audio Tour. Head over early to avoid the massive tour groups that pour into the Guell Palace. Fine details and creative design to be expected with all Gaudi constructions. Audio tour is helpful as a guide, however functionality is sporadic.

A special park. I guess this park is a must see when one visits Barcelona. The two buildings at its entrance are brand marks of the Gaudi architecture. The day we went there the weather was drizzling, so we could not walk too much around. We took the number 24 bus to go there and came near enough although we still had to climb the last mile.

Gaudi's Vision. The treck up the hill to reach Guell Park is well worth the effort. Incredible view of Barcelona and the sea. Lots to visit once inside the Park. You can also have lunch at a little restaurant situated to the right of the entrance, on a shady terrace - good food at a reasonable price.

So impressed!. We had toured the Casa Batlo, Sagrada Familia and also had gone to the Park Guell prior to the Guell Palace. Since it was very close to our hotel, we decided to tour another Gaudi creation. The palace is less than a block off the La Rambla and is not on a scary street. We went in the morning and there were few tourists which was wonderful. The entry fee is 12 euros but there are discounts for students and professors but you do need proof. The audioguide is included in the fee. Guell was a wealthy businessman and a patron of Gaudi. Gaudi was commissioned to build a luxurious palace in a relatively small area boxed in with other buildings in the old part of Barcelona. Underground there are unique horse stables in true Gaudi style. The 3 story central hall is absolutely exquisite. There is more detail in this palace than at the Casa Batlo. The roof is colorful with the different tiled chimneys. I would highly recommend going to this palace. We bought the guidebook in their small gift shop which is very descriptive and a real keepsake.
Awesome place. Learn a lot of Gaudi's genius. One the "must to visit" places in Barcelona. Listen carefully to the guide and you'll learn a lot of Gaudi's genius.

Another Gaudi Classic. We were lucky on the day we visited as the entrance line was short. We had passed on another days when the line was quite long. Again there was a self-guided audio tour. Two ways to the top of the building and roof: elevator and stars. Somehow we were placed on the stairs and had a lengthy climb to the attic where the tour begins. The attic is not really an "attic" but a common user floor for the building occupants. Now the "attic" is the museum. On the day of our visit, a high school class came through the building. Again this building has current occupants. The roof is spectacular, not to be missed.
Average. In a scary street, this palace has nothing to fo with the beautifull Park Guell. It is ok, but I would not reccomend if you have few days to spend in Barcelona
Fantastic. Parc Güell is so cool and I really got inspired of the beautiful architecture. A lot of tourists. Though that easy to find a place where it is not so crowded. A must see when in Barcelona!

Visit only if you have a lot of time or have kids. If I were constrained of time, I would see the Sagrada Familia and cut this other Gaudi monument out. This is a wonderful spot but a bit too out of the way and a bit too crowded.
Neverland. Fantastic place, you feel in the middle of a fairytale. Great to hang out for some time, there is people playing music in the plaza. A bit psychodelic but great. Never seen before
Worth an entire day!. This park is amazing. The buildings are something else. The gardens are so beautiful. The park is always crowded so allow time to linger and see all the sites!

Another look at the Guell Palace. This is an often overlooked Gaudier site. I have visited it several to mess including when it was required to go through with a group and guide. The new acoustaguide self-guided tour is a delight and the looped video about the house and Guadi's relationship with his patron is foundation for viewing the other Barcelona Guadi's sites. even without the furnishings, everywhere you look is a work of art and deign. Don't miss it,

Quiet find in the city - not a park!. Reviews for this are getting jumbled. A great building in an easy street to access. This is not a park as some of the other reviews are for a different venue.Tip: the wine shop just down the road is amazing. There is also a laundromat that you can drop your laundry off while you go through guell palace. (90 min turnaround for wash/dry).

One of my favorites!!. This palace was one of my favorite places to see in Barcelona! The detail and awe of the palace alone is breathtaking. It's amazing how one could miss it if you weren't looking for it. Must See!!

The best of Gaudi, why don't more people go here?. Sure as you'll eat a lot of tapas, when in Barcelona you'll see long queues tailing back from the doors of Gaudi's La Segrada Familia, La Pedrera and Casa Batllo. Puzzlingly, you won't find them at Palau Guell, another Gaudi-designed building that, to my taste, is the best of all his domestic architecture.The Guell Palace is just off the Rambla, a short walk from the Boqueria Market. If anything, it's closer to the main tourist flight path, and therefore more convenient, than the the more famous buildings. There are other reasons it should be higher on the tourist hit list. It was his first significant, complete house design, created in his mid-30s. You can see both the young genius, and the roots of the style that would stretch through his whole career. It's the grandest and most complete of his domestic buildings open to the public. La Pedrera is an apartment building with only one middle-class dwelling restored and open (described in my entry last year), and Batllo is a house that had apartments on upper floors (not part of your tour). Guell is an urban palace, all of its floors and rooms devoted to the life of one family, and all recently restored and laid open for you to wander about.It's wonderful from the very beginning, when you're greeted by sinuous ironwork on the doors and come into a a ground floor that's essentially a big, integrated port cochere. Carriages came in one side, and out the other. Between them an impressive dark marble staircase ascending to the formal door. (Pictured above.) Behind that, a turning space and a circular ramp descending to basement stables, beautiful in their own right for their unusual brick columns.The tour, which comes with an excellent audio guide, takes you from bottom to top. First, the processional entry that brought guests to the exquisite entertainment rooms. Gaudi's naturalistic, modernist style is evident in tendrils of ironwork wrapping around light standards, early appearances of his catenary arches and the strange curves of wood and stone. But there's more traditional Arts and Crafts style here in glazed tiles, faux Medieval carving, stained glass and impressive Arabic-style ceilings. The most impressive room here is the central hall, at least three times higher than it was wide, creeping heavenward with those distinctive arches. Gaudi punched holes in the dome to let light through, used a lot of gold, built in an organ and inset a gold-encrusted chapel on one side behind folding doors. Party space, concert hall and heaven-looking church, all in one.Then you get to clamber up to the family rooms, where the vine-and-leaf inspired decor around the arches of the master suite turns the rooms into an outdoor bower. Though the house is mostly empty of furniture, the recent restoration places photos in many rooms showing what they were like when occupied. Revealing an interesting truth about Gaudi. Stripped down to the bare architecture, his rooms are exquisite. Filled with late Victorian furniture, rugs, pot plants and ephemera, they're just too much. I doubt any other architect has been done such a big favour by having his work emptied of its original furnishings.Any good Gaudi building leads you to the roof. The man was obsessed with bizarre chimney pots, after all, and the Guell Palace offers a riot of colour on a Disney scale. More than anything else in the house, the roof points towards the dramatic departure from the norm that the rest of his work would take. The finials of La Segrada Familia, still under construction today, are here at Palau Guell … finished 140 years ago.
Odd shapes well built. Gaudis fav to shape in odd designs seems to be catchy and porportionate. Must see for Gaudis ethusiast, which not really mine.
we did enjoy this. not exactly a homely place! very clever architechture. most impressive. loved the wood work. worth a visit.
Best value Gaudi Site. I believe the best value for your money ..if you choose to pay admission to only one Gaudi site $12 euros here is a real bargain

a masterpiece not to be missed. we found this place as part of the open bus tour stops. it is such a unique place which epitomises Gaudi's artistic genuis. ONe can only wonder in great awe at how in his time Gaudi managed to create such beautiful designs which may be considered radical in his day. The mosaics gave my daughter the inspiration and has now modified her artwork in some ways. It is a must for all architechture inthusiasts, and they may start "thinking "outside the square"
Guell Palace. Was expecting a bit more, although interesting not too much to see and you pay to get in then have to pay to look at the house as well

Ugly but splendid.. I cannot say that I actually liked this place as in thought, wow, I would have like to live here. It was rather dark and forboding with heavy woodwork and ironwork dominating the whole place. But as a place of interest and intrigue and to admire the magnificent work of this crafted artist, it is totally wonderful. Check out the silky texture of the wood....remarkable...and the gorgeous designs and detail of things like door handles and hinges. The ceilings are quite quite extraudinary. And for those who think the entrance fee at the other Gaudi houses is rather steep, this is definitely a lot less expensive.
What an imagination. We were able to visit this. Love his imagination. Want to design my home like that. We lucked out on getting in when the lines were small. A must to see.
A Gem. This is the former home of Guell, a benefactor of Gaudi. An amazing combination of architecture, form, function and art. If you like Gaudi, don't miss Guell Palace.
Guell Park. Definitely not to be missed. A great afternoon enjoying the autumn sun in a very imaginative environment.

A must. When visiting gaudi's houses, most people would go to casa mila, but in my opinion guell palace is much nicer. It is not as striking from the outside as casa mila, but its insane on the inside. gives you idea of how super rich used to live.

Okay. Palace Guell is not what I expected. It is also in a part of the city that should be closed to traffic. Ir gives the idea, by having so much traffic and so little space to walk, that the building is not in the top priorities of preservation and promotion.

A fantasy come to life in a "home" !. It was fantastic to see how they lived a hundred years ago.
Clearly a ´Castle´ in the City. Jugend-Style. The roof was an orgie in Mosaic.
bit disappointing. Nice Place but overcrowded. Didn0't really have to enjoy, maybe also because it was sunday morning. Would go there on a week day

Great day out. This is a great day out. Book your tickets in advance or when facing the main entrance, turn to the right and walk through the arch way to buy your tickets at the kiosk.
Gaudi's house is also worth the extra money and the onsite cafe is pretty good too.

More Gaudi rubbish. For me there is so much more to Barcelona than Gaudi's gawdy designs. This is expensive to see, and generally over-crowded. Only pay if you actually like this stuff. I found it taxing on the eyeballs.

Well worth the hike to get there. It was a trek to get to but don't Miss this wonderful park, another of Gaudi's wonderful creations. It took us ages to get to from the metro and the stop we go off on made us walk up some very steep step, with some escalators en route just to help out, but you will feel it and need a rest and a drink at the top.Worth it though, a wonderful park, great views over the city, and Gaudi at his best.If you go down to the bottom gate when you are done, take a right and then left, you will happen on the Gaudi centre which has a 4D experience, which was very good.In a word, a must visit whilst in Barcelona

ANOTHER MASTERPIECE BY GAUDI SITUATED JUST OF LAS RAMBLAS. If you are interested in unique and interesting architecture - this amazing building that was designed and build as a residence for Gaudi's friend - Eusebi Guell is a must to view. The opulence of the amazing wood - iron and tile work is pure bliss to see. Another highlight is the roof terrace - an explosion of colorful mosaics and playful chimneys awaits you. Stunning views of Barcelona from the rooftop.

Cool place but overcrowded. It is a very "cool" place that seemingly came from some childhood fantasies. We spent several hours sunning on the colorful roof and walking around. It must be wonderful to enjoy the park sharing it with reasonable number of people. But in reality, it is overrun with crowds: when one enters the park from the side, he/she encounters multiple souvenirs peddlers, all of them Northern Africans, who occupy the center of the alley.The front entrance is even more crowded, And there are lines and hoards of people everywhere,. Unfortunately, I happen to see a leisurely trotting rat. Only closer to 6 pm, when a lot of visitors were leaving, it became bearable. I recommend visiting it just after opening or late in afternoon.To visit, take bus#24 from Passaig de Gracia.

What a Palace. So stunning they did such a great job of restoration ! Its really cool, exspeically the roof wow. Have to see because theres nothing like this in the world. Little pricy the entre, people on a budget see this one day and rest of Gaudi building over a few days
Funky roof. Another of Gaudis masterpieces. Easy to reach just off Las Ramblas. The real gem for me is the roof!
A must see!. This was one of Gaudi's major accomplishments. The park in amazing, likewise the buildings in the park. Highly suggest you go with a guide or on a tour, to get the full benefit.

Another Gaudi masterpiece. You just fall in love more and more in every single step. Cheap entrance, just make sure to ask for discount if you are a student because they will not remind you of this. The highlight is the chimneys. PS: it stinks a bit at the balcony but you soon forget about it as the palace is breathtaking on its own

Guell Guell Guell. Another stunning building from basement to roof top.with design by Gaudi. Really liked the curved ramps and pillars in the basement and the small golden chapel inside one of the rooms. There is a great mix of lovely furniture and truly delightful use of stone, wood and wrought ironwork. We had plenty of time to wander at our own pace using the helpful audio guide. The roof top is magical with the mix of mosaic chimneys and the central tower. Look out for the bat and the lizard. Good views around Barcelona from the rooftop. We were so impressed we bought a miniature of one of the colourful chimneys as a souvenir. Now to decide what to do with it!!Tricky to decide which of the Gaudi buildings we have seen is best - they all offer so much. If pushed I'd go for Sagrada Familia, Casa Batllo, La Pedrera then Guell Palace but they are all fantastic and this one had the shortest queues and is closest to the centre of the tourist area being just off La Rambla.
Omg. This place is literally the coolest place I have ever been. If you don't go here you are missing out. Spend a good 2 hours hiking the views are incredible. DO NOT MISS THIS

Worth seeing. There is so much to see in good weather. Parrots, ruins, architecture and even plants. Grab your walking shows, a picnic set and a camera. You will surely love it! I liked the park being friendly to disabled people. I did not like the beggars, though.

Easy Gaudi visit. Guell palace is at an easy to reach location walking through from La Rambla. There were no huge queues to visit nor too many visitors at one time. The audio guide was useful and the building is lovely. We visited this palace as well as sagrada familia and decided this was sufficient in terms of Gaudi visits apart from exterior of buildings as you walk around the city. It is amazing to tour from basement to the roof.
A must in Barcelona. A beautiful walk with lots to see, It´s a shame they have just started charging to get in the Park. Still worth a visit.
Dont forget your ticket. Now you have to pay to get in - book on line with your smart phone and show the QR code to access - really easy - use one of the side entrances not the one at the front

A place to get lost. ...and we did but just kept heading toward the harbor to find our way to our hotel. Love the old town areas of Europe and am so glad that they are being kept in their Medieval charm.
Sensational.. An outstanding example of Gaudi's work. To see what was conceived and built as a private residence makes one appreciate the opulence of the period.

Guell Palace. This is a must see Gaudi work. It's open from 8am and its well worth getting there early as you get the place to yourself. I think its worth the entrance fee. The roof and attic are great.

Guadi must-see. If you enjoy architecture, this should not be missed. Clearly early in Guadi's career, yet seeds of what was to come are completely visible. The tour is not too long and the house is great. I recommend going toward end of day, after the line dies down.

Really inspiring. Another Gaudi jewel, located in the very center of Barcelona. It is less known, so generally the queues here will be smaller than in the others Gaudi sites. Don't make the confusion between the Palace and the Park - despite the fact that they have been both commissioned by the same person (Mr. Guell), they are not at all close to each other and they are totally different things :)It is important to visit Palace Guell, in order to understand better Gaudi's future work. Don't skip it.
OMG. I cannot beleive it took me four visits to the city before i went, just go you will be so pleased. We did this as part of a bus tour where we hopped off, no enterance fee at the moment.

perfect entrance to Gaudi work. This is real jewel in Gaudi work. The first palace he designed in Barcelona, the details here are basics for his work. We admired the perfection of craft work! The palace is perfectly reconstructed. I would like to recommend you to skip audioguide and try to discover every piece of art by your senses without disturbation of too many words...

Uniquely different but very Gaudy !. Amazing Park located on the side of a mountain. UNESCO site and worth a visit. There are steep stairs to climb and its highly suggested that you buy your ticket on line and avoid the 1+ hour line up. Gaudi designed houses.... a must see in Barcelona.

awesome parc guell. everything is wonderful and fantastic going around this parc. this is not an ordinary parc where children play. this is the place to admire the beauty of the surroundings and admire every inch of the building or views. it is breathtaking having pictures on the top of the parc, setting to a glittering broken mosaic benches and variety of the shaded canopy whatever they call it. first day that they started to charge entrance to the parc. It's time for them to charge to use for the maintenance and repairs for this lovely park to preserve and last more years for the next generations to admire and visit such extraordinary work of gauidi. rose from new jersey

excellent. You can get here for 2 Euros on the bus from the city centre ! It was a beautiful day so the brightly coloured mosaics were shown in all their splendour. They have just introduced a charge and ticket system which had long queues by the time we left. Well worth a visit to look at the way the structures defy gravity with leaning struts and supports.

Outstanding!. I have visited several Gaudi sites, some more than once. This was my first time at Palau Guell. It is not nearly as well publicized as CasaBatllo, La Pedrera, Sagrada Fanilia or Parc Guell. It is located very close to the Ramblas and Boqueria but not as busy. It is earlier work of Gaudi and gives hints at what's to come in his career. The self guided tour with audio pack is very well done. Good explanations with lots of detail and some pictures. We never felt rushed. You can revisit a room, lots of photo opportunities. While you can touch most thongs, you might be in such awe that you do it very reluctantly. The building is beautifully maintained.One caveat: In the entrance hall you are told how you can see out the door window but not in. If you go to check for yourself, don't get too close to the door - you will set off an alarm like I did. I wasn't hustled out quickly and they were nice in explaining what happened - still scares the devil out of you.

What a treat!. Attention to every little detail makes this site an unbelievably beautiful place. I don't know how anyone could live there and be able to do anything but gaze and sigh and gaze some more.

Nice to visit if you have the time. Although the Guell Palace wasn't my favorite from Gaudi, it's for sure worth going to if you have the time in Barcelona. I wouldn't rank it as my top 5 must-see places in Barcelona but I'm glad I got a chance to see it and I do recommend it.
A jewel on the doorstep. We stayed in the Hotel Gaudi which is on the opposite side of the street to Guell palace . We visited it on our last morning in Barcelona .. A fantastic end to our holiday !

Incredible. Beautiful and not as sectioned off as a Bational Trust house!Architecture is incredible, ornate and imaginativeAudio guide included in the entrance price well worth it but the roof terrace can e closed in rainy weather, so don't go then, you shouldn't miss it!

Güell Palace (not the Park!). Güell Palace (Palau Güell just off La Rambla) and Güell Park (in the Gràcia neighborhood) are not the same thing! Señor Güell was a very rich industrialist who commissioned Gaudí to do many works. One of the first was the Palau, the mansion for the Güell family in the heart of the old quarter of Barcelona. This is one of Gaudí's early works, in an almost austere modernista style. There are no multicolored broken mosaics here, no playful salamanders. It is a magnificent home, starkly beautiful, with a sometwhat somber atmosphere. There is splendid wrought iron work, wood work, tile work all throught the mansion.It is one of my favorite Gaudí works along with Casa Battló. There is often a long lineup, so arrive early. Use the audio guide to understand what you are seeing. It is well worth the visit.

so cool!. def used the audio guide, it was free. the whole experience took about 3 hours, which was longer than i though it would. it's a big place. all of it was interesting. we lost power towards the end, but i think it came back on pretty quickly. they told us we could come back with our ticket to get back to the gift shop. not sure if that's standard, but everyone there was very, very nice.
