Wonderful escape from the City. Spectacular example of modernist architecture. No visit to Barcelona would be complete with a visit here. Take a cab there and then walk back. A wonderful walk through the less touristy part of the city. They also have outdoor escalators if you want to walk to the facility. They recently started charging for admission. There are lines there. Not hard to get in, but at 6 Euros a ticket, expensive to basically just walk around a park. A quiet place to stop and rest

sucks, big rippoff, do not visit. very bad rip off, you pay 12 euros for the entry, i recommend paying 8 euros for some of parc güell instead, which gives you much more to see and enjoy, this palace really sucks, the roof has some nice small towers but thats all you will enjoy, i dont think it is worth 12 euros, staff is not always present at the door, they chat unless you shout and tell them to come let you in and see your ticket ( my experience )

Gaudi playground. this is a wonderful park HIGH ON A HILL. It is worth the hike and visit. it is Gaudi to the max at the entrance. great views of Barcelona. Interesting tiled bench. The Lizard Fountain is an icon of Barcelona. A MUST VISIT!
Amazing. Great house to visit. The inside is amazing. No need to book tickets as there was never much of a queue. Theres also an audio guide so its great to learn about Guadi

The roof top worth the visit. This building is located in a street just of La Rambla, we didn't pre purchase our tickets and stood in the queue for about 1 hour.
It's a "townhouse" that's got 6/7 levels, lots of stairs. Going up to the roof top is a must, here one finds Gaudi chimneys and they are all so colourful and beautiful.

Lovely park and Gaudi's house. Guadi designed a palace in Park Guell also he lived in the park from 1906 to 1926 in another house. The palace has magnificent ornaments and great balcony with very detailed ceramic works

Beautiful structures and park. Beware faint of heart! The climb into this beautiful park is a workout, but so worth it for the beauty of the gardens, and the view all the way to the coast from the top.
Rare. Rather rare and interesting architecture. A must see. I would visit again on my next trip. If you don't mind walking a lot this is a good opportunity.

DREAM PARK. It is a must while you are in Barcelona.You will fell in love once again with the Art of Gaudi.Do not forget to be there before 6 pm not to miss visiting the House of Gaudi.The only dissapointment was the cleanless of the park.There should be more cleaning staff and trash bins.

Early work of Gaudi. If you would like to see a snapshot of most of the work of Gaudi, please visit this charming palace just off La Rambla. This palace represents early work of Gaudi when he renovated this house for his long term friend Eusebi Guell. Do not forget to visit the roof offering spectacular views over Barcelona. The best time for a visit is on a sunny day, since the light coming into the palace will play an important role on displaying the palace in it's true magical way. Also it has the lowest entrance fees of all Gaudi's works in Barcelona except for the Park Guell, which was also a work for the same family.

disappointing. nice to visit only the terrace. the inside of the palace is empty. even with explainations, we have some issues in trying to imagine how was life when the palace was occupied by the Guell family.

Don't Miss. This one is a Gaudi freebie and one of our fave stops in Barca. So wonderful to wander around this gorgeous park, take in gorgeous city views and marvel up close at some of Gaudi's fantastical mosaic and concrete sculptural work.

One of a kind. This awesome hidden place is one of Gaudi's first designs, gothic and mixed compared to his latest designs. If you'd think back to how they lived back then you would appreciate its beauty. The line is not long and makes the visit even more pleasant it's wasn't busy. Had a great view as a benefit of the sunset time.

Breathtaking!. So glad we spent the 24 Euros to have a look inside this building. Couldn't stop taking photos as each part of the house you see is finished to such an exquisite standard. It wasn't too busy the day we went and there is an audio guide to help you round.The roof terrace is incredible although I wasn't too keen on the undulating surface!Well worth a visit.

fascinating. Lovely park to walk around even if you don't like architecture. If you are unfit get a taxi there as it is quite an uphill climb. Even though there were lots of tourists the park is so large that you can always find a shady spot to sit and contemplate or have a picnic!
Masterpiece. Just off La Rambla, this little 'palace' is just exquisite with clever design from cellars to rooftops, and extraordinary attention to detail.

Mystic Gaudi. Awesome architecture, Spanish guitarist strumming under the arches, what a beautiful place to visit. Walked all of it and wished I had a palace there overlooking the city and port of Barcelona.

Fantastic building, but entry fee is a bit steep. Wonderful building, which I'd really recommend. Gaudi is fantastic. The €12 entrance fee was worth it for me, but I can see how it would put people off. The audio tour is fairly good too, and is included in the price.
Gaudi masterpiece. Another visionary work of Gaudi just off the Ramblas. Look at the roof to see typical playful Gaudi touches. The inside is accessable for 15 eu and photography is allowed.
Park Guell. It's very nice place, full of Gaudi's art. You better take a bus to get there, we walked but quit 1/5 of the way. Lots to see and entrance is free.

Lovely. This is a free tourist attraction and so it does get very busy, but it is well worthy visit, after all Gaudi is Barcelona and Barcelona is Gaudi. The gardens are very beautiful and so is the view across the city. Go and enjoy.

Gaudi - Always amazing. The Palau Guell is a real treat. Just off La Rambla, you could easily walk past the end of the road without realising it's there.The entrance gates are amazing and the stables underneath the building are so cool and peaceful as well as architecturally fantastic. Go up out onto the roof and see the chimneys. Also when inside the building look up at the ceilings they are just so amazing and each one different. I'm not an architecture buff, but even I can appreciate Gaudi, he was truly a genius. As it is one of the less well advertised buildings there are no huge queues, which has got to be a plus.

Be prepare to walk and open your eyes. A huge park in the city. A lot of people. When we went it was raining but we appreciate so, I suppose when the sun is there it is surely splendid. Put good shoes on and bring your camera. It is an overlook place.

Don't visit with children. This is a lovely, pretty building, but the staff expect you to be absolutely silent as you visit. We visited with a really well behaved child who held our hand all the way round and asked questions about the shapes and animals he saw. We were 'ssshhh...d' by just about every guide and made to feel pretty unwelcome.
A jewel. Gaudí keeps amazing you. Go to the park and the palace of Güell and be stunned by the artist's imagination: colours, shapes, designs, animals.... it is a jewel!

Very Enjoyable Visit. Not a massive fan of Gaudi, the Guell Palace was none the less an amazing place to visit. Not too crowded due to a very sensible system of staggered entry. We really enjoyed exploring all floors of the building and found the audio guide informative without being overley wordy. The view from the roof is great , taking photos of the quirky chimneys a must!
a real feel for his brilliance. YES overcrowded, yes tourist hell, yes you cannot get photo without hoards of fellow tourists. still go see it and enjoy the magic that is Guadi.

A great place to visit. The walk up to the park is a bit tiring and at this time of year 1000s of people however enough room to enjoy everything. If you want to take photo of Gaudi works there are often poeple posing and impossible to get a shot of just the statue. The ceilings and architecture is lovely. The view outstanding.
Great art and architecture!. Amazing views of the city! The art throughout the park was beautiful and unique. Wear a good pair of walking shoes to get the most out of the park.

Another Amazing Gaudi. Enough with the Gaudi, you say? If you can only take so much architecture tours, then make sure you hit the trifecta: Sagrada Familia, of course; Park Guell; and Palau Guell. The audio tour is very good and the building is incredible: it's hard to believe it's just a rich man's home!

Easy to Miss. The Guell Palace is an early work of Gaudi, located somewhat out of the way near the foot of the Rambla. It's easy to overlook, but don't miss it. The interior is one of the most attractive domestic spaces anywhere. Even the underground stables are masterfully done. The domed central space is quite original and extremely dignified at the same time. Materials are superb; every detail on every floor is exquisite. And the roof is covered with Gaudi's bizarre and colorful chimneys.
Mind blowing. The guy was a true visionary, well before his time.... Highly recommend as a must do in Barcelona, did this in line with the hop on hop off bus.... Well worth it
Great park. I really liked the park since it is very unusual and was created by the immortal artist Antonio Gaudi! His imagination impresses a lot!

Interesting and very spread out. May be the only free place you can appreciate Gaudi's genius. Very very busy in September, I would hate to be there in peak season in the heat. There is an interesting house where Gaudi lived on display.
Best of Modenista. A great place from photographs and learn about the modernisme of Barcelona. Go there early to avoid the crowd. In a clear day, you can even have a beautiful view of Barcelona.

Perfect Restoration. An early Gaudi work, this palace is stunning. From the unexpected treatment of the stables in the basement, the ingenious manipulation of light and air, and the richness of the interiors make this by far my favorite of the Gaudi residential works. Don't miss it.

Amazing Gaudi. from the outside the building looks interesting, but when you go inside, the tour gently with the stables, and gets more fantastic with each step ! Each person gets a self guided audio tour, which corresponds with the number of each room. building has been conceived and created by the master Gaudi, with a blend of magnificent innovation and creativity. The interiors are jaw-dropping .The detail is incredible.
Young Gaudi house. Differnt from the other houses with more dark and rough materials , and less tourists (until now...)

Nice park to visit and hang out. This is a nice gift to the city with open space and views of the city. Gaudi lived here but did not design the house. He did design much of the park and having only seen photos of it before those do not do it justice. You really need to visit it to experience what Gaudi did.

Architectural experience. This was a nice little museum with audioguide included in the price. Unlike many other audioguides i found this one particulary informative. A must see for anyone interested in Gaudi or architecture. When you get to the top of the palace you are rewarded with a lovely view of the surrounding area and some rooftop designs.

All you'd expect from Gaudi. Although it may not be as exciting as Casa Battlo' which I visited a few years ago, this is still well worth a visit. Don't miss the roof, with the great views and the even more stunning chimneys - and the bat weathervane!
Amazing!. Literally right across the street from the Hotel Gaudi. It is one of Gaudi's earliest buildings so it's interesting to compare it to his other creations.

See this Gaudi Palace first. The Guell Palace was built before Casa Batllo and Casa Mila. It's interesting to see the progression of Gaudi's ideas, so I would recommend that you see this before Sagrada Familia and the aforementioned casas.

Interesting Dark Pocket Palace.. Sizewise "palace" is using artistic licence because really it's a large town house built on quite a small site. It's more likea pocket size medieval castle which seems to influence muchof the style of the halls and principal rooms. The ramps downto the former stables are just one touch of Gaudi's ingenuity.Dark wood panelling seems to dominate and no doubt it was what Mr Guell wanted, certainly not light. I guess the strongpoints are the layout between the main rooms with balconiesfor musicians etc. Unfortunately many of the upper family rooms lack furniture. Up on the roof (several floors/ stairs) there's anamazing array of Gaudi's trademark "trencadis" styledornamental chimneys and ventilation shafts.

Another Gaudi landmark. Palu Guell is a mansion in Barclona designed by Antoni Gaudi--it is part of the UNESCO site "Works of Antoni Gaudi". The home is centered on a main room for entertaining high society guests with a high ceiling with small holes. The ornate walls and ceilings of the receiving room are worth the trip.

Best park ever!. Guell Park is a maze of wonder and surprises around every corner. Wear your walking shoes and be ready to enjoy Gaudi's fun architecture. You can even see his Sagrada de Familia church from high above the city. A little challenging to get to without a car. Have good directions, follow signs from metro and be ready to walk up steep hill or take bus from metro. Don't "wing it like we did!" If visit in summer bring plenty of water. A fun afternoon!
Awesome parc. This you must see. The architecture is crazy, definitely take as much pictures as you can and try to walk the entire parc and missing nothing.
Part of tour. We saw the palace as part of a walking tour. Didn't go inside. Probably should have come back and seen the inside. The outside was quite interesting.
Fantastic Place. This place is beautiful but make sure you allow yourself a lot of time to explore it as it's massive and so much to see. Great view of the city too.
Amazing!!!. We queued for a long time to get in, but wow was it worth it! Beautiful and so interesting to visit. Best sight to see in Barcelona and there are some amazing ones!

For All Ages. I was so impressed with the walk up the huge hill towards the Parc, escalators halfway up there was quite surreal. The view was amazing and at every corner you turned there was something else to enthral you. It was truly like being in Alice's adventureland for young and old.you must see it.
Impressive home!. This is a beautiful home to tour right off the La Rambla. We went first thing in the morning to beat the crowd.

Worth the 20.30€ admission. I had my reservations about the 20.30€ admission charge but after visiting it was surprisingly worth it. The crazy architecture viewed from the outside of the house is just the beginning. Once you step inside you can see into Gaudi's mind and see his true genius. Each of his rooms is unique and all the architecture is just amazing. There are no straight lines or corners in the entire place.The tour starts with the amazing staircase and ends on top of the roof where you can see his crazy statues and a view of the city in all directions. Mind you most of the view on top is blocked by other buildings. However, it is still nice to look and imagine what this view looked like back in the day before some of the other buildings were built. The tour includes an audio guide. I think it's available in five different languages. One tip to avoid the line, you can buy your tickets online. But they do charge you an extra fee which is around five euros and that includes all the tickets you purchase ( I think )
Worth a visit. Not our favorite Gaudi piece. It is very dark and dungeony. But the roof chimneys are cool. If you are visiting Barcelona you might as well visit.
A Gaudi masterpeice. Indescribable! A most amazing building - one of Gaudi's earliest works. Excellent audio commentary. Very convenient location just off Ramblas.
"Nice view". nice view......good place....after a long walk we reached that place......on top of the floor u can see full of the city view.....lovely place.....acually it is a park.

A bit disappointing. There are several floors in the palace and not all of them are interesting. The most impressive is the main party room, where they also play music from time to time and which is really beautiful. That floor has other beautiful and interesting designs too. Other rooms (where people lived), especially on other floors, are less interesting, so not sure if the price is worth it (although probably it's a must see, if you're going to Barcelona).The palace is pretty much accessible for handicapped, except for the roof. There is a small elevator which can go to all floors, except for the roof. I say 'pretty much', because for some reason they have one step to enter the elevator on the ground floor. Don't know why they made it so, but it means you need help to enter the elevator.The staff there are friendly and helpful, although not all speak English and those who do, have difficulties understanding it.

unforgettable. a maze of walkways offering insights into Gaudi's surreal world and also breathtaking views of the park and Barcelona in the distance -try to make it to the cross on the hill-a bit scarey if you hate heights but what a view! it's a LONG walk from city centre so bus or metro suggested, then a 10 minute uphill walk to Park. Only downside-very popular with tourists so choose your time of day wisely.

If you can escape the crowds, it's a magnificent place to visit. A failed venture for the artist.... but the views from the 3 homes built are wonderful! Try to get away from the masses and explore - the house tour is so-so after visiting his other venues.Lots of walking and uneven surfaces - be careful!
Busy. It was so busy the day we went and it was a hot day. It was also a bit of a walk so we were pretty hot when we got to there. Make it an add on maybe part of a larger tour of Gaudi's work.

Don't miss this !. What a surprise, from the outside the building looks interesting, but when you go inside, the tour gently with the stables, and gets more fantastic with each step ! Each person gets a self guided audio tour, which corresponds with the number of each room. Take time to look at ceilings and decor, and take a camera ! The roof is incredible so make sure you go up !!!
A shining gem. The park is charming and whimsical with its colorful mosaics but it is also very crowded. There are paths to get to the top for people who can't use the stairs, but it's a long walk.

Impressive. Yes, very impressive indeed. No denial that Gaudi had an incredible capacity/vision for details, and it shows at Palau Guell. That was the work of a young man still in his twenties. Nevertheless, if I had to choose between the architectural style at Palau Guell and that of Sagrada Familia, the latter wins hands down. I prefer the graceful lines, the arches, the curves, the light effects at the basilica. At Palau Guell, things are more geometric, robust, muscular, in fact full of testosterone, and a bit dark. To each his own, I guess. All of the above notwithstanding, Palau Guell is a must see, to appreciate Gaudi when he was young and full of energy. Apparently, the visit is free on Tuesday, if you don't mind the mob. We had to pay to get in, and unlike the Picasso Museum and Foundation Joan Miro, you are allowed to take pictures at will.

Best rooftop of all the Gaudi buildings. We got one audio guide for me and my husband just wandered. He was bored until we got to the roof with all of the magical spires and curved areas. Some of the exhibits are supplemented with videos or I would have been as bored as my husband. We are both fans of Art Deco.

Not worth a visit. Better places to see Gaudi's work.. Most of the reviews here are for the Guell Park not the palace which is in a completely different area even. The house itself is pretty nice and the audio guide gives you good insight into Gaudi's work here. However, unless you are a hardcore Gaudi fan, I would not recommend a visit here. La Pedrera and Casa Battlo are far more impressive examples of Gaudi's work.
Beautiful example of Gaudi's genius. It was uncrowded and in wonderful restored condition ...the headset guides were great and the roof area provided an interesting view of neighborhood.

take a picnic. Guell park gets very busy but we still found a quiet spot for a picnic away from the crowds. It was very hot, especially having just walked up the hill but there was a cool breeze. Lots of artists playing music. Nice place to spend a few hours.

One of Gaudi's best. This private mansion is one of my favorite Gaudi houses: the entire building has been conceived and created by the master, with a blend of magnificent innovation and creativity. The interiors are jaw-dropping and the pinnacle of the visit is the roof, with a forest of artistic chimneys and a spectacular view over the roof tops of Barcelona.

excellent. well worth visit...go early to avoid crowds...we used tour bus ( green route) to get there...take camera..you can pay to go into gaudi house,,more like a miniture museum..if you have time go..

Hidden castle. Stayed in the neighborhood and discovered this gem of a intown castle. The design is unique with the horse stalls in the basement and the spectacular roof with the unusual chimneys. While it looks dark and uninviting from the street, it is something to see the inside.
GEM OF A PALACE. Beautiful palace right on the Rambla. The architecture, the woodwork, the art, the roof - wonderful visit.

Not worth it. I think this is not worth visiting because most of the palace is not even designed by Gaudi. In addition, you get a free audioguide but it was the most boring thing ever and it made me dislike my visit even more. There are some beautiful rooms in the palace, of course, but if you came there specifically to see some Gaudi you will be disappointed.

GENIUS. As honeymooners, we had so much fun walking around the park. It was gorgeous and so unique. The houses looked like ginger bread houses. The views of Barcelona and rhe Sea are breathtaking and lovely. We had such a great time. It is free and literally the most gorgeous nature walk i have ever taken.

a Barcelona Must See. Amazing example of a mansion in Barcelona,designed by the Antoni Gaudí for the Catalan industrial tycoon Eusebi Güell.
The innovations, architecture and engineering in this building is outstanding especially considering that it was built in 1888. This UNESCO site is a must see on your stop in Barcelona.
Free Entry, Always Full of People. Free Entry. The place is actuall pretty and unique, too bad it's always too busy with tourists or local people, even on the low season.

be early. No ticked needed, turn up very early. Around midday to many people are turning up. Mostly in the afternoon you can find some real good musicians in all this caves. Beware of the dealers with there cheap junk. You get the stuff in better quality down the road, too.

The best of the Gaudi Houses. An interesting half-day trip, the recently restored architecture is stunning and the rooms inside, especially the main hall, are well worth seeing. The audio guides were restrained and informative, and the gift shop was also excellently stocked at reasonable prices.

Gaudi town house. Show yourself around this typical Gaudi town house built for a wealthy manufacturer. Good information in each room. The interior surprisingly gloomy but some amazingly florid Gaudi chimneys on the rooftop, which has good views of the city.

Must see!. Take the public bus from the main square and go here about an hour before sunset- eveything looks absolutely beautiful at that time.
There is a little cafe built into the stone and they make a great cup of tea- theirchairs are in prime position to peoplewatch across the whole park.
Beautiful Beyond Words. Gaudi is a genius architect. Don't miss this beautiful palace. The detail is incredible. The view from the whimsical roof is to die for.

Best Gaudi house. Incomparably the best and most interesting of the Gaudi houses in Barcelona. There is so much beauty here from the cellars to the roof and the central hall makes spirits sing. It is a mystery how other reviewers can complain about about too much dark wood ~ this is full of the joy of creation.

Huge mansion, incredible Gaudi design. I would rate this place just a tad lower than Casa Mila. I really enjoyed it though. It’s awesome thinking that a super wealthy family actually lived in this crazy HUGE house! Some of the design elements are amazing. You really have to appreciate the details that went into this home. The one room with the insane wood ceiling blew me away, that was my favorite room. The rooftop is actually very nice and pleasant as well, I loved the crazy colored chimneys the most. This is a very unique mansion and something I would suggest you see.

Aristocratic heritage. This city palais of the Guëll family can be fully visited since the state-of-art renovation was completed in 2011! The audio-guide (incl. in the ticket price) is very informative. One of the 10-top picks if you have limited time to spent in Barcelona and interest in this type of attractions.

Beautiful views and architecture. The long hike up the hill was definitely worth going to Park Guell for a few hours. The views of the city from the top of the park are amazing. Plus there are tons of great shops around to stop in on the way up or the way back. Free admission, which is also a huge plus!

Guell of a place. What a great museum. Just off La Ramblas this mansion house recently restored is a great showcase of Gaudi's designs. Fantastic stained glass, wooden cielings and a great collection of chimneys on the roof terrace.
11 euro's including an audio guide, you'll get round in 90 minutes.

Quick stop. This quick stop can be be enjoyed with great views of it from the outside and for a fee you can go inside. Best to see it wait guide so that they can explain the significance of it. Not as famous as Gaudi 's other works but with a visit if you are interested.

Give yourself time for this one. While perhaps not as outwardly impressive as some of Gaudi's other works, the details found inside Guell will blow your mind. Make sure to listen to the audio tour and be prepared to look closely around corners and up light wells, what you find in the form of ingenious ventiliation and water management systems will fill you with wonder. And compared to other Gaudi locations, at 12 euros per person, this is a place that is definitely worth the cost of entry.

A Gaudi gem. The Palau Guell is one of Gaudi's architectural masterpieces and a must-see for anyone interested in architecture/art. It has been beautifully restored and is a UNESCO World Heritage site. The woodwork and wrought iron work there is particularly impressive. - Loved it!

Interesting but dont expect Gaudi at his best!. Interesting complement to other Gaudi work and good for a wet day. But its an early work in a dark city house and too much dark wood for our liking. Nice touches by Gaudi to make the best of the house but after Sagrada Familia and Parc Guell it felt almost oppressive in comparison.

Very touristic but a MUST visit!. From Metro station "Vallcarca" a stroll through the narrow streets with the many escalators up to the park and then a walk through the exotic gardens leads you to this amazing Gaudi architecture. For the walk back downhill the nearest Metro is Lesseps...but is a good 10mins walk!

A masterpiece. Getting a ticket is a bit of a "bunfight" on the pavement outside a small ticket office, but the visit is well worth it. Guell's wealth and Gaudi's art, and their combined imagination, created this palace of a diversity of styles. A miracle on a footprint of only 500m2. On the day I last visited, overcast, it did seem gloomy until the upper floors, but I can imagine that on hot, sunny days the coolness would have been welcome.
Beautiful building!. Great building, definitely worth going through, if interested in Gaudi! Discovered whenI went on Runner Bean walking tour, returned the following day and wasn't disappointed.

Great palace but beware that they close the terrace when it rains!. This was renovated to a high standard and is now open to visit for a not so cheap 12 euros.It seems like a good thing to do when the weather is a bit grey or when it rains however BEWARE: they are closing the 2 terraces when it rains! Not sure why as the casa la Perdrera and Batlo both have their terraces open in all kinds of weather. Of course, there's only a tiny sign at the ticket office so you only discover this when you queued for a while and of course, it's still 12 euros.Without the terrace the visit is quite monochromatic and a huge side of Gaudi's work is not visible as the chimney up there are fantastic and colourful so it is very bad value for money.
Last place we visited in Barcelona. Completely worth seeing! Very unique. The audioguide is very helpful in providing information about the architecture and the family. A Must-See!!

Right off La Ramblas in Barcelona. Gaudi built this palace for Mr Guell, his wife and 10 children as a family home. The audio tour is very good. The organ music features some compositions by one of Guell's daughters. The roof chimneys don't disappoint. Another Gaudi masterpiece!

Very different Gaudi. Guell Palace is very different from the other Gaudi buildings, rather castle like with great interior, when you consider that the granduer of the building is achieved on such a small parcel of land it is even more amazing.

Hidden gem off las ramblas. We visited guell palace about 10am hardly anyone else there. Cost 12 euros had an audio tour and it was amazing. The house is just beautiful and well worth visiting best bit was last when you go onto the roof and see all the beautiful chimmneys in a multitude of colours. It did help that the sun was shining too, but gaudi was a brilliant person with out of this world architecture. Well worth a visit.

This is a building not a parc. A lot of the reviews for this item are talking about Parc Guell, Casa Mila/La Pedrera and Casa Battlo, not Palau Guell - so if you see references to undulating roofs, views etc, bear that in mind.Palau Guell is one of Gaudi's earlier works and is about 100 feet from La Ramblas. It is a large mansion with some amazing details but is not as wild and wacky as some of the other Gaudi buildings. Gaudi designed the building as a home for his major benefactor, Eusebi Guell, and it has only recently been opened for tours.Tickets for the tour of the home are time-stamped - meaning that if it is busy, you may not be able to arrive, buy a ticket and start your visit immediately. When we went, we arrived at 5pm and the earliest ticket we could get was for 7pm. I therefore recommend that you combine your visit with a walk up the Ramblas or a visit to the Boqueria market - grab your ticket to Palau Guell first and if there is a wait, you can go look at other things in the meantime.Once inside the home, your ticket includes an audio tour that will guide you around the home explaining the history and pointing out the architectural details. As noted above, the design is not as wild as some of the other houses but still includes lots of amazing elements that show just how smart Gaudi was in his thinking - from cellars that kept the foods cool to stairways with special steps to climb on your horse or carriage to a stunning wood ceiling. The house has been wonderfully restored including the addition of a new organ which was being played while we toured.As a result of the less wild aspects, I'd say this is more of a location for people interested Gaudi or in interesting design and architecture and may be less interesting for young children.

i wish i would live there. Amazing place , called palau Guell.there is a fee for the attractionyou can take a photos of the palaceyou get a free wierless MP3 with instuctions and guidance about the rooms furniture etc.don't miss the roof... you have a good view to the landscape of the city.

Worth a visit. If you can't afford to see Gaudi's house this is a cheaper building to go and see. I don't really remember much of the inside of the building but the rooftop is an experience. You see these types of scupltures that look like heads with faces and you can take some great memorial photos that will last forever.

Gaudi at its best. If you like architecture and the modernism that Barcelona is renowned for, it's a must-see. Go to that place combined with the Museu del Modernism and Park Guell and you'll have a good over-view of this architectural-design movement that completely redefined our way of living since the early 19-hundreds.

...important piece of architecture.... get there early....crowds will spoil the experience !! didn't do the audio guide, but probably should have. i find it difficult to listen to those devices and do serious photography at the same time. and if you are serious about serious photography - arrive at opening time on a week day.the restoration is admirable and very well executed. fantastic effort. only comment - would have liked to have seen more original furnishings.i believe it best to have some prelim knowledge of this monument before visiting; http://www.gaudidesigner.com/uk

One of the reasons. If you are visiting Barcelona. You must see some places. This is the one of them. Its pretty far away from city centre. so its better to go there with a turistic trip or you need to check your map and make a plan before going. Don't forget to take some more films and sd cards with you.!
My favourite place. It's a really beautifully building. Love the architcture, and the rooftop terrace with it's views are amazing. A must when visiting Barcelona.

Gaudi's work!. The whole palace can be visited. Nice and impressive, although not as colorful as other works from Gaudi - but still interesting. I liked the fact that it was cheaper than other visits, while we could see much more of the inside of this place. Don't forget to check the basement (we only saw it because we wanted to check the basement)

Best Value Gaudi Building. The entrance fee for Palau Guell is a bit less than for Casa Mila or Casa Batllo. It is located just off of Las Ramblas near La Boqueria. The building is spectacular with a fun rooftop.

Amazing building and design inside. When you see this building outside it looks like other ones nearby. But when you are inside you can feel the life of previous centuries. You can see and feel Gaudi's genius by admiring all details inside. But the most interesting is when you finish the visit on the roof with 15 chimneys in Gaudi's style.For all the visitors audio guide is offered for free with very detailed explanations. Children under 16 enter for free of charge. Very friendly staff in the Palace.

A recently restored gem. This house was recently restored and open to the public. It features great ironwork doors, lovely banisters and stairs, a look at the large formal areas and the relatively small private rooms of the Guell home near Las Ramblas. A tiny gem, indeed.
Beautiful. Very beautiful place. The audio guide is included in the price of the ticket, it's very convenient. Queues are usually not as big as in Casa Batllo and La Pedrera.

Beautiful and informative. This place includes audioguides in the admission fee. The tour is informative and interesting and the place itself is just beautiful.The view from the roof is nothing worth mentioning so don't get disappointed when you get there :)

just amazing. After living in front of Palau Guell for 3 years, I went to visit it when it re-opened to the public. It is completely restored and shows the house and the culture of the Guell family. It is an audio guided tour, so you can walk around on your own speed and understand the completely history of the house. Especially the terrace is the most important part of the house, with the typical Gaudi style.I went on the first Sunday of the month, when it´s free entrance!

Fascinating. Loved the tour. We paid the extra to get the head set, which I found fascinating, and well worth the additinal $$ for an informative history lesson. Such intricate detail in the palace well worth a visit.

Early works and well worth a visit. We used this as our intro to Gaudi's works and its a fascinating place - it gets better as you go up the building until the beautiful roof top with the expected decorated chimney tops. Well worth the visit and not expensive.
fascinating. fascinating museum, good value. use the voucher from the open top bus tour . Great for people of all ages and interactive. Great views from roof.

Worth a visit. Although a bit on the pricey side (12 euros), the palace itself is very inpressive from the interior. The tour is also rather quick (only took me 1.5 hours), so it can easily be incorprated into any day at barcelona.
A new view of Gaudi. If you are a Gaudi fan, this is a must see. It's done more ornately than some of his other buildings. Not as light and airy. The roof top is a highlight.

Worth a visit. The palace is worth a visit. When you buy your entrance ticket there's a time printed on it so you may have to wait to enter - we went early (just after 10am) and got in immediately whereas when we came out there was a huge queue! Plenty to see and the audio guide is very descriptive and no silly photo restrictions. There was someone playing the organ when we were there not sure if that's regular or a one-off.
Awesome. Take the audio guide, it's worth every penny. Pay attention to the furniture - Gaudi was not only an incredible architecture but an awesome designer

Stunning, Gaudi's best piece. The best piece of Gaudi's architecture, showing what a genius he was. Well preserved, with the use of incredibly rare and expensive materials. Great, concise audio guide.
Barcelona sites to visit. Great place to visit. Try the museum on the way up. Fun motion ride and it has A/C. Great tourist shops along the way with lots of mosaic gifts. Amazing views

Beautifully different!. Enjoyed learning the history of the palace. The quality of the materials used in Guell's home is amazing. The palace is well preserved. Gaudi was an architect and designer ahead of his time.

Gaudi's early work reflections in this entralling Mansion: Very well Guided!. I had some time in the afternoon in Barcelona and headed straight for this Place near La Ramblas as I passed by this Mansion quite a few times. In the heart of La Ramblas, towards the left as you approach from Columbus Memorial is the Palau Guell. Bang opposite it is a Hotel, aptly named as Gaudi Hotel and all along you can see souvenir shops, all selling supposedly Gaudi works of Art and Design!The entry fee to this place is 12 Euros, which I felt is a little high considering most places have around 5 -6 Euros all around. The entry is also timed, so you might have to wait up in a queue for a while. I was lucky though to reach by 12 noon and by 12:15 am I got in. Once inside, they provide you with a handyphone and a booklet for the tour. You move ahead and there are lockers for you to store your things in while you go visiting the Mansion. Rest, the handphone guides you on its own! Every room, every area is marked and you just need to press the right number in the phone, the audio tour starts talking to you and tells you what you need to look at in every area and also understand its importance. I got quite a couple of shots! The Mansion is huge and spreads upwards floor after floor. Guell really spent a fortune and Gaudi spent no effort in utilizing every last bit of his penny!! Its a great place to start your Gaudi experience and the Palace leaves you with a lingering memory of abstract modernism and you are left asking for more!

Hidden Treasure. Stopped by this attraction to get out of the rain and I was completely in awe of my first experience with Gaudi Architecture!! The self guided tour was full of very informative information about the Guell family as well as the architecture of Gaudi. The beautiful stained glass, iron work and "starlight" ceiling are exquisite! The outdoor area was closed for renovation.

See Gaudi's earlier work. Stayed a few doors down from Palau Guell. A beautiful building where Gaudi had free rein to 'do his thing'! The rooftop is worth the climb - fantastic unique chimney pots and a great view of the city, despite being only a minute away from Las Ramblas.
Hidden gem. Newly renovated, and hidden just off las ramblas but one of the best examples of Gaudi's work there is. So complete and fascinating. Not busy which is a bonus.

Must do!. Visited this site because we are staying down the road from it and definitely wasn't disappointed. From the moment you see it's imposing façade curiosity gets the better of you and you must go in. €12, (€8 for students) gets your admission and an audio guide (I don't recommend looking at the palace without the audio guide) and you definitely get you money's worth. With the palace being very different to the rest of Gaudi's work around Spain (all of which are also must-sees) it is fascinating to learn about the man himself and how the architectural style of this building varies from his others. Highly recommend, just watch your head on the servants staircase!

A roof by Gaudi. The palace is a private home with an interior with many of the elements seen in the Familia. The curved lines and attention to detail are all here in Gaudi's early work. The roof is an amazing jumble of ceramic sculpture which probably validates the leaky roofs on IM Pei's buildings

Wonderful Old Gaudi Mansion. This mansion is a fine example of Gaudis brilliant worksItbwas build for a very wealthy friend of his and this man had no limits on the amount of money to spend.The wood work is especially outstanding. The audio that comes with the admission ticket is very well done.

If you have to chose only one Gaudi building to visit..... we suggest this one. I stumbled upon Palau Guell by chance, because it was in my Modernista walking tour book. On our previous visists to Barcelona it was shut, due to restauration, it came out beautifully!In the afternoon access was only for tourists who had booked in advance, so we came back early next morning. You pay €8 (2013)for an audiotour of nearly one hour, there is also a shorter version (e.g. for children). The audiotour gives loads of nice info, and you get to walk around in your own tempo, which I enjoy: stay longer in the rooms you like, and maybe skip the duller bits (hardly any.....!). I think the building really deserves at least one hour of your time.There is a lot of intricately decorated woodwork, beautiful arched windows, stained glass inside and outside, and lots more.Every half hour the organ plays a tune, you hear it throughout the building. Be sure to go all the way to the roof at the top of the building, for some lovely Gaudiesque chimneys. From the roof one can see how this very special building is completely surrounded by 'normal' apartments and offices. Weird.

Don't miss the chimneys. This was the first Gaudi building we visited, and it was a good introduction to his work. The chimneys are amazing. If you're only visiting one or two, see Casa Batllo and Sagrada Familia instead. I wish we had been able to see all of Gaudi's buildings, but time was limited.

Wonderful early Gaudi. Beautiful and fascinating building from early in Gaudi's career and his work for the wealthy Guell family. It is a different style than the later more organic style for which he is best known, and it's interesting for that reason. The lower floors have a "heavy" dark medieval feeling and then the colorful tilework of the roof is an astonishing contrast. The included audioguide is informative but a bit slow. Beware that the roof surface is very uneven.

Early Gaudi Masterpiece. We decided to get up quite early for this visit as to prevent queing to long in the sun. We only qued for about 20 minutes and got through the door at 10am. I would say that the venue was good value for money. We were given an audio guide which was informative. The palce is stunning with amazing features and details. Gaudi's attention to detail and his genius and practical application to features such as guttering, horse trophs and fire places is brilliant. Its also a fabulous way to experience what life would have been like for the guell family. I was initially hestitant to visit guell palce but having been i am glad that i did and i would recommend anyone to go.

One of the best Gaudi attractions. Fantastic building, worth the entrance fee!
Going in through the fabulous hyperbolic archway entrance, you get to work your way up the building, with a free audio guide, from the cavernous vaulted basements, up through furnished rooms (incredible) to the roof space with great views and beautiful chimneys.
Absolutely worth a visit. Stunning.

Extraordinary. Extraordinary house that is worth seeing! Amazing that floors, ceiling and walls are covered in limestone, and other expensive materials that demonstrate the genius and details of the artful mind of Gaudi.

A must to understand Gaudi. We lucked out - free entrance first Sunday of the month. The audio guide gives you a history of the artist and his work. It helps you to understand the rest. Plan to spend more than one hour once inside. Lines to get in also.

What a home from 1886! Amazing! And the foundation for the Masterpiece Sagrada Familia Church -. Everyone has taken great pictures! You can see how well this is preserved! 125yrs old.Note the "chimneys" and the spires at the Sagrada Familia Church. Come into the main lobby (upstairs) and look to the sky, then do the same at the main alter at the Sagrada Familia. Gaudi had this design in his head for 30 years....The Organ plays every hour and it's amazing, it made me cry it was so beautiful.My question is: where's the showers and tubs? And only 2 bathrooms? If you are staying on the La Rambla, this is only a block off the blvd. Kids get a 1/2 price discount as do single parents. 10E for dad and son.

Surprising. We came back from a cruise and stayed in a hotel close by, so entered just after opening (10:00). There are audio guides for a tour through this amazing house, from the cellar to the roof. If you have house renovation plans, do not miss this - great for ideas!

Worthwhile. Yet another Gaudi, not quite as interesting from the outside but the interior is worth a look. The included audio guide is very interesting. Smaller than Casa Mila or Casa Battlo but you are allowed access to more of this building, from the basement to the rooftop.

A really interesting, recently restored 'show home' to Gaudi.. I first visited the Palau Guell over ten years ago. It as been extended and very much restored since then. Recommended for the 'show case' of Gaudi's unique and extensive skills. It is also much quieter and therefore easier to get in to.

Well run tour. This was opposite our hotel and is well thought out with only a 10 euro charge. You get an audio guide device which explains all of Gaudi's design ideas in several languages. The best bit is the colourful chimney's on the roof. a fantastic photo opportunity for anyone.

Beautiful!. Our first attraction in Barcelona was Guell Palace. The Palace is incredibly orante. Pictures can hardly capture the detail. Its hard to describe the palace because of the immense detail in every aspect. Its a must see if you''re in the city. Especially if you are interested in Gaudi. A bonus we saw a naked man. No joke, there was a man next to the Palace taking a shower. Its was highly amusing!

A quieter example of Gaudi's work. It was an amazing building, lovely demonstration of Gaudi's work. It wasn't too busy when we went either in late afternoon. Really nice views from the rooftop. The audio tour wasn't brilliant, and was quite long.

Inside is much better than the exterior!. Our last thing in Barcelona we were very surprised by the interesting interior, well presented by the included audio tour. Arriving at opening time, we had no issue with crowds.
The building is recently renovated and not in many of the tour books .... Yet.

Interesting .... This is a pleasant detour from churches and demonstrates Gaudi's diversity well. However as any empty residence it becomes a bit droll by the time you get to the third floor. The rooftop is the highlight.

You must experience Gaudi. A remarkable few hours. We had a private guide which made it even better but a guide is not needed.
The highlight is the roof structures.
A phenomenal piece of architecture that has recently been restored. Do see the other Gaudi sites in Barcelona.

Stunning must-see place in Barcelona. If you time for just one more thing to see in Barcelona after La Sagrada Familia, make sure it is this other Gaudi's masterpiece in the Gothic Quarter. Indescribable, this palace continues to give my young daughters nightmares days after they visited; now if only other pieces of architecture can have that much impact on people!

Hidden Gem. Tucked down a side street it would be easy to miss. In fact we did and had to go back next day to find it! You are given a timed ticket when you book, as only so many people are allowed in at once, which is great as it didn't get too crowded and you were able to see everything properly. The rooms themselves are mainly furniture-less, allowing you to clearly see the work of Gaudi and to appreciate the skill he used in his design of the house.
Worth the money. Not as impressive outside as it is inside. Interesting home and furniture design and fun to imagine living there in the early 1900s.

A Fantastic Introduction to Gaudi. A really good introduction to Gaudi as many of his techniques were used here. Also easier to grasp architectural concepts seeing them as a home designed from start to finish rather than a block of apartments or Cathedral etc. Handy central location too.

Simply amazing. The Guell Palace has a very interesting architecture inside. You get a feeling of entering a fairytale place. I was mostly struck by its courtyard in the back part, the views are amazing. Audioguide is highly recommended to get the full potential of the visit.
Must see visit to Geull Palace. An amazing tour with audio tour, its a beautiful home and well done with the audio. you get to see the whole house from basement to the top bedrooms.
Amazing ceilings! A must! Kids free. My children 12 and 13, had there ears 'stuck' to the English recording as we walked round one of the most beautiful buildings we've ever seen.
FASCINATING!. The admission is rather steep, but definitely worth it. Walking through the palace is a visual treat as well as a glimpse into the genius of Gaudi, the architect.
Well worth the time. We loved the gaudi architecture, the history of the building and the talking tour recorders so we could move at our own pace.

worth it for the roof top. I loved the terrace and the rooftop chimneys although I found the rest of the building impressive it was way too hot to spend anytime in there so we were probably only there for 20 min which makes the £12 entrance seem expensive!

Great Site to See. We visited the Guell Palace on our last full day in Barcelona and glad we did. It doesn't look like much from the outside except for the awesome chimneys on the roof. It's an audio tour and well worth it. It's hard to imagine the wealth back in the day of Guell and Gaudi but the amount of money invested in this house is unbelieveable. The architectural design, the acoustics, the layout, the chimneys, and the thinking behind the design is a site you need to see.And, Guell's wife never liked it and they only lived in it for a short time. It's just off Las Ramblas and well worth the 1+ hr to walk through this amazing house.

Great intro into Gaudi's development as an architect. I recommend going to see Guell Palace, Gaudi's early work first before La Pedrera or Casa Batllo which are more known for his style. Guell Palace gives a good insight into art nouveau and the life of the Guell family. Shorter lineups too.

Palace? More like a fort.... Compared to the other Gaudi works this one left us cold. If, however, you have an interest in Gothic architecture, then you might like it. Not as delightful, artistic, etc as Batllo or Pradera.

Guell...Gaudi's Patron. Absolutely exquisite. We were there when the organs began playing and it was just beautiful. Eusebi Guell obviously was enthralled with Gaudi and gave him carte blanche in designing his home. A Must see when visiting Barcelona!

Don't Miss This. This amazing palace is a definite must see while in Barcelona. It was not crowded at all and the most amazing Palace. Very much Gaudi inspired, you can see Gaudi influence around every corner. A hidden gem.

Gorgeous halls inside. I just love the Gaudi architecture, so I loved this. My 21 y.o. not as much. The main halls were jaw dropping. We also ate at a restaurant next door that had Paella for a really good price.

A door to Gaudi's masterpiece. This attraction is located on Carrer Nou de la Ramblado not miss!The Guell Palace is one of the gems, It's a residence built between 1886 and 1888. Remarkable experience touring the residence, from the stable to roof top.. worth every visit
loved it. Nice calm place to see. Not crowded at all, so no waiting in line. You also get tourguide, it is included in the price of the ticket.
Best Gaudi experience. The interesting and FREE audio guide really made this worth the entry fee. I've never seen anything like it. By far the best visit of Gaudi attraction we went to.

Beautiful, hidden gem. we wandered past this not knowing it was there and - loving other Gaudi visits - decided to go back. It's beautiful and the audio guide was interesting. Even better if you can make it on a first Sunday of the month as then it is free!
City mansion. Exquisitely crafted in-city mansion, shows the genious of Gaudi. It gives you and idea of how the aristocracy lived. It's just off the Ramblas.
Awesome. A must see experience good value for euro bucks especially if you want to see Gaudi's complete works

The ultimate Gaudí palace. There seems to be some confusion in these reviews about whether this is Palau Güell or Park Güell, but I believe it's intended to be for the palace, not the park (which was also nice). This former home of industrialist Eusebi Güell, designed by famous Catalan architect Antoni Gaudí, is spectacular and not to be missed. Unlike other Gaudí buildings in Barcelona, this one was never packed with tourists when we visited on two occasions, perhaps because its renovation was completed not that long ago and people aren't aware that it's open. The soaring and domed main hall, the elaborate coffered ceilings, the exquisite windows and the fanciful chimneys and vents on the roof are simply breathtaking. One warning: The roof is closed in rainy weather, and it must be seen to be believed, so make sure you visit in good weather.
beautiful. lovely lovely lovely! Fit for everyone..family, friends or solo. Lots of oppertunities to take pictures.

Amazing. Didn't know anything about Guadi before the trip and became fascinated with his works/creations after touring this home. The audio guide is very educational. There was no waiting when we came, although I would recommend getting the tickets ahead of time as we did see lines later in the week. Guadi a true genius.
Guell Palace. Really good place to visit. Really interesting and different. Loved the chimney pots outside. Not to expensive either.

Intersting place to visit. The building is situated off La Ramblas and you will have to queue to pay and then get inside. You do not have a fixed time to view the place and numbers are limited. There are a lot of stairs to walk up and down and a sort of one way system exists to guide you. Audio guides are available to tell you what you are looking at and what to see in each room.There is not a lot of light in some of the rooms - as noticed by the number of flashes coming from peoples cameras.Up on the roof are are Gaudi's Chimneys which are different shapes and sizes and add to the place. The roof is uneven and some people might have difficulty with the narrow access stairs in the building. A lif is provided but operated by the staff.

Rooftop Fun. This is a great experience and should be included into any visit to Barcelona. Gaudi once again shows of his unique brilliance and it feels like the building is alive and has its only flows and characteristics. My favourite section was the rooftop. Functional chimneys make artistic.
Don't miss this. Amazing place to visit. Lots of people but plenty of space to walk around and enjoy Gaudi's amazing talents.

A must see -- after you see La Pedrera and Casa Batilo. Of the five essential Gaudi works to see in Barcelona, I would rate this 5th after the Sagrada Familia, Casa Batilo, La Pedrera, and Parc Guell. It is an earlier work (ca 1885-90) which shows some features later used in the other structures but overall is more conventional in terms of materials and design. E.g. the outside is rather plain except for the two parabolic arches and the wrought ironwork.By the way, many of the reviews here are actually for Parc (park) Guell and not for Palau (palace) Guell. TripAdvisor needs to get these reviews into the proper spots. Maybe that is why the Palau rates overall higher on the "to see" list. To be sure, it is definitely worth a visit, especially if you're already on La Ramblas. Figure at least two hours. Use the audio guide, otherwise you won't have a clue.The overall structure is surprisingly compact (area 500 sq meters but 6 floors counting the basement) and gives an idea of how the super rich lived in the late 19th century. The floors and ceilings are mostly wood (not the later elaborate stucco ceilings) and stone walls. Very ornate -- not in the sense of the King's palace in Madrid -- but ornate nonetheless. Hopefully, be there when the wonderful organ plays. A bit spooky -- like the Phantom of the opera!The overall plan is innovative and very much like the concepts of shape and lighting later expanded in Batilo and Pedrera. But I won't go into details. You need to discover it for yourself. Even though this is an earlier work, I think many visitors will be better seeing Batilo and Pedrera first because then they will appreciate some of the key elements of Gaudi's genius. I also liked La Pedrera more because it included period furniture and there is essentially a museum in the attic that explains much of his work. So, see at least La Pedrera first and Palau Guell after.
Amazing palace. Very nice palace with great rooms and halls, very pretty and one of the more darker gaudi designs. Worth the money to visit. Takes about 1,5 hours to visit.
A must see if you love Gaudi.. This was his first commissioned work. It's absolutely stunning and worth a visit. The rooftop alone is worth a visit.
ummmm. Well the building is good but it is not WOW as other buildings. You can have a visit as you go around the city. But I would recommend to visit other Gaudi building rather than this

Beautifully Designed. The Palau Guell is a gorgeous and elegant Gaudi-designed home, with incredible details (the woodwork in the ceilings alone is amazing!). It is hidden right off La Rambla, and many people miss it, unfortunately, The audio tour is great and gives interesting history on Gaudi, the Guell family, and the relationship between Gaudi and Guell. Unlike some of the other Gaudi-designed homes, you get to see and walk around most of the interior of Palau Guell. Double check the hours that it is open -- we stopped by a couple of times, and it was closed.

Beautiful sights of city. We made a stop here from the one day hop on hop off bus ticket we had. I am into art so that was a must see.Make sure you see that at a clear sunny day as the colors of Gaudi's art work are even more vibrant them. Also, when you walk to the top of the park you have a phenomenal view to the city. Must see!! This is one of a kind.Best probably to go in early morning and avoid the afternoon rush as this place gets really crowded.

Not to be missed. Many people seem to just walk past and glance up. Don't. This was the Gaudi highlight for me in Barcelona. It was Gaudi without any budget restraints to experiment and create a masterpiece. Even though there is no furniture you get a true feeling for what the palace would have been like to live in. It s unforgettable.

Gaudi highlight. What an amazing construction! The thought that went into every detail of the architecture and the family's lifestyle was awesome. Enjoyed the story of how Gaudi and Geuli were friends, and thought along similar lines. The family's apartments, the organ for musical events, the details will live with me forever. Even the stables were designed in an innovative way, with wooden cobbles in the entrance to muffle hoofbeats. If you see only one Gaudi in Barcelona, this should be it.

Great park. Guell Palace and park is a great place to see amazing views of Barcelona. There are plenty of street vendors in the area and I noticed that they sell a lot of souvenirs at a better place than other areas in Barcelona.

A designers treat!. Situated just off Las Ramblas, the Guell Palace is easy to find and whilst not a ‘palace’ is certainly a very large town house. Both the interior and exterior design work is phenomenal! The use of the materials is certainly awe-inspiring. A little dark inside, but a good and interesting visit.Be sure to use the hand held audio guides, as they have very interesting descriptions and photos that help during the tour. At €12, I think this was a little steep but this was our second visit to Barcelona and one of the sites we had not had the opportunity to visit previously.

Amazing!. I really didn't expect the Palace to be so amazing. Gaudi really was a genius and this is a shinning testimony to that. The hand held personal guided tour was great too, get all of the info without having to listen to some frustrated actor babble on for hours while you move about like a herd of cows ... Not for me. Just off la Rambla, you would be crazy not to include it on your itinerary.

Amazing Gaudi masterpiece. Recently opened the Guell Palace shows the excesses of the rich and the incredible mind of Gaudi. Guell hired Gaudi when he was young and was his major patron. From the front door, the interiors,, the hardware, the decoration, the acoustics, and lighting was designed by Gaudi with a lot detail, substance, and functionality. This is four story structure for a family of five with the bedrooms in the upper floors. It was only used for five years before Mrs. Guell complained and the family moved to a house in Parque Guell. By the pronunciation of Guell is similar to Way.

Great work of Gaudi. We selected to buy ticket to get into this Palau Guell instead of the Casa Batlo and Casa Mila (which we just viewed from the outside) and we didn't regret it. The Palace was very well maintained and reviewed the life style of a wealthy man in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The location was a bit hidden and easily missed though.
work of art. This palace is so beautiful, such detail, the workmanship is fabulous, I cant imagine living in such grandeur.

Lovely quiet visit. We enjoyed browsing Palace Guell. We took our time and soaked up the color and shapes. The roof was scary - there are "do not cross" white lines which made me nervous for people with children! Great view from the top.

amazing. This structure was the best example of the details Gaudi could accomplish. It was superior to seeing Casa Batllo. Not to be missed. If you get there first Sunday of the month it is free although you must get a ticket first.

A must see. Well worth a visit, a recorded tour for you to enjoy, explaining all the details of the palace from its restoration to date, visit the stables, vestibule with an amazing mezzanine floor, central hall and listen to the organ music, the beautiful marble that is throughout the palace, then there is the roof terrace, apart from the beautiful views, the chimneys decorated with broken tile shards, and the beautiful spire, well worth a visit

Remarkable architecture. Guell Palace is a complete surprise, while not very remarkable from the outside, the interiors take your breath away. It's hard to imagine how every single detail has been carefully thought of to maximise on the space in which it is built. The handicraft and workmanship is unsurpassed, and the effort is amazing. It would have been amazing to live here.

Didn't plan for it but is a MUST!. We were planning on the Gadi home and the church Sagrada Familia. This one we walked to and decided to try when in the neighborhood.
It best showcased Gaudi's work, I thought. Excellent!
Loved Guell Park. Very unique and enjoyed the experience and views from all the trails and look outs. Highly recommended.

early work but what a WOW. It was an earlier work by Gaudi, but I visited it the last. What a surprise! Compared to pedrera or even sagrada familia, the ornamentation and the richness of the materials is over-the-top. The craftsmanship is awesome. I would call this style arts & crafts meets art-nouveau. But the wonderful part is that underneath all the glitter, there is the practicality/simplicity/spirituality/functionality that Gaudi carries through all his works.
WORTH THE WALK!. great place, great architecture, great view ! love it ! WORTH IT!i came with some friends, we had a wonderful time !great for pictures !
High in the Hills. Another Gaudi inspired location.. don´t go, if you have trouble walking steep hills. A Small rest area selling cool drinks , and snacks is a relief ..
One more thing to see. Dont visit this one if you are in Barcelona less than 4 days. its very nice but not that nice if you want to save money or your time.

Hot and crowded. Gottta go there, lots of things to look at and lots to do. Very much the normal touristy and commercial 'medieval' thing but fun, and interesting. Poor Jewish people, they have been treated so badly...
Outstanding. This is a must see. Go here first, then to Park Guell. And find out whether you agree or not with Mrs. Guell about changing her residence.....
More Gaudi staff!. Gaudi's art is nice and colourful. Parc Güell in general is a great place to spend a sunny day (for example). The palace itself was a bit too crowded, but been there done that!
Symphony of Materials. You get shocked with the detailed work of each component. Especially on the ceilings. Also Gaudi used light through several passage to lighten main room.
Must see!!!. This place has the best views of the most beautiful city I've been to. The architecture is varied and often stunning in its details. Must see!

Amazing architecture!. In the afternoon we visited Guell Palace. For 12 euro's you can walk a tour through the house, guided by an audio tour. The last renovation finished in 2011 and lasted for 11 years: and that shows. It is now in a superb state. The tour is definitely worth it, despite the price. Also you can enjoy the organ, which was integrated in the house, playing a song every 30 minutes. My advice is to wait for that moment in the 'central hall', it sounds beautiful!! Opening times from April to October are till 8 o'clock, last admission is then at 7. We spent about one and a half hour there.
Park Guell. The park is a fantastic place, but crawling with tourists. Nice that there were public bathrooms available.

Worth a visit. This is a brilliant creation by Gaudi. The audio guide is very good. We went in the afternoon around 4 pm and there was no line and very few visitors. The library was closed due to restoration which was a pity.
Fabulous Guell. Less busy than other Gaudi sites (for now). Amazing Gaudi design and fine audio guide to lead you through it.

Impressive. Impressive palace. Be sure to go all the way up to the roof - great view and closeup of Gaudi's designs. Lines in the morning, but we stayed across the street at the Hotel Gaudi and noticed no lines in the afternoon.
Awe inspiring. Amazing. Jaw droppingly amazing. A reminder of how one mans genius can influence us all. Just go, youll be amazed.

Worth a visit. Earlier in the day I went to Sagrada Familia but the lines were so long I didn't go in, so I was pleased to have the opportunity to visit a Gaudi site on my one day in Barcelona. The cost was 12.5 Euros and that included an audio guide which was very good. They have lockers for 1 Euro and it was good to lighten my load. I set my own pace and skipped some rooms, but thoroughly enjoyed a view into the past. This is just a 1/2 block off of Las Ramblas so if you are walking north from the port area after viewing the Christopher Columbus Monument it's easy to get there.

More Gaudi. Different from Casa Batllo, earlier Gaudi, still brilliant. Views from the roof great, and the chimney pots are striking. Very ornate great hall, organ music playing helps with the atmosphere.

Simply brilliant.. Another wonderful Gaudi creation - a must see attraction. The audio guide is very good (there's even a separate one for kids) and a leisurely tour will take at least 2 hours. Value for money.

What rich culture. The architecture is phenomenal. Don't miss it and Parc Guell (in the same place). In back of palace are streets. Go down where all the shops are down to the end, make a right about a block or so there is a tappas restaurant where all the hospital staff/doctors eat. Food is excellent and so are the prices. Don't know the name, but there is a sign that says the name before you trun right.

Fabulous couple hours in wonderland. Gosh this place was so cool. A bit out of the way to get there but so worth the trip. As previously mentioned the site and park is such a fun an magical place. Definitely a must do and you can enjoy the park in under two hours
Very green and quiet park. It is very beautiful so green and quiet , it is free and no need to buy ticket to go inside the park ,

Nice little tourist thing to do in Barcelona. The house is a bit 'dark' compared to other Gaudi designs and parks, but still the free headphone tour is nice and it's a nice small touristy thing to do very close to the Rambla.
Interesting place with interesting story!. It is definitely worth visiting! Fantastic story about cooperation and friendship between Gaudi and Guell which resukted in breathtaking palace.

Definitely worth a visit. This park is definitely worth the trip whether you want to go for a picnic or sightseeing some great architecture. There are some steps to go up and down...just a warning to those with prams/pushchairs.
A Gaudi masterpiece. Really worth a visit - the entrance fees waived for teenagers made it much more affordable than we had anticipated

Wonderful place in the heart of the Gothic quarter. Great place that will take you back 100 years ago and will show you Gaudi (and Guell)'s art and genius.The audio guide is very helpful and included in the entrance fee (16e/person), with a good rythm; a very enriching experience!

Great Example of Gaudi's work. Honestly, I had never heard of Guell Palace, but my wife had done her research before we visited Barcelona. Not only was this a very impressive architectural site, but it has a great view from the roof. The entrance fee includes an audio tour that is very informative but not overwhelming. Certain days of the year Guell Palace is free to enter which just happened to be the day we visited, so I cannot tell you if it is a good value for the ticket price. I would not pay more than 20€ though to enter and even that would be steep if it was any other city than Barcelona where everything seemed to be more expensive.

Very impressive. Very impressive and fantastic designs by Antonio Gaudi.A bit "heavy" inside, when compared to the Pedrera or Batllo, but still a class in itself.the service for disabled people is excellent and free admission to the disabled person and his escort
Great. An architectural wonder by Gaudi. A lot of imagination and creativity. I love it. You need time to see everything.

Very interesting !. This tour was longer than I expected . The audio tour was great and fascinating. You really get the impression of what a skilled and genius craftsman and architect gaudis was. Highly recommended.

Impressive but austere!. First of all, there seems to be a bit of confusion on trip advisor between Guell Palace, which is a Gaudi commissioned house just off Las Ramblas, and Parc Guell, which is the unfinished housing development in the Northern suburbs of the city that Gaudi was later commissioned to build for the same family. Guell Palace is one of Gaudi's early commissions and has only recently been renovated and open to the public. Presumably, the fact that it's new to the Gaudi tourist itinerary accounts for the low admission price of 12 euros, which includes an audio guide. This is a bargain compared to the 20 euro plus admission for the other houses. The house is impressive in that it demonstrates the various functions of a central Barcelona town house in the early years of the 20th century - a stable for the horses, a chapel for the family, an office for the industrialist, a venue for socialising and entertaining, as well as living accommodation for the family and servants. The Gaudi style is unmistakeable and the attention to detail remarkable. Overall , though, the house feels quite cold and austere. Maybe its the lack of direct sunlight due to the city centre location, maybe its the lack of domestic furniture. Either way, whilst i admire Gaudi's style, I find it difficult to imagine a family actually living here in comfort, and it came as no surprise to hear on the audio guide that the mistress of the Guell household hated the place! For an example of an art nouveau house that is entirely liveable in, try the Modernista Museum in Novelda, which is a bit of the beaten track but is wonderful and has free admission!

Don't go if there's a danger of a spot of rain. My trip was ruined by a lack of seeing the roof top chimneys. While we where inside the house, a few drops of rain fell and it was closed off. Many other visitors were disappointed but the attendant would not allow access even though there was hardly any wet. The audio tour is good for the interior. When back outside the rain had dried. Another point to note is that the Palace is closed on a Monday.

What an amazing and surprising place !!!. We stayed at the Gaudi Hotel opposite and after seeing the roof chimneys from our room, had to make a visit. Wow !!!! What a surprise. Every room is different but spectacular. Then the icing on the cake(literally) is the roof , with numerous chimneys decorated in various colours and shapes. Well worth the 12 euro entrance fee.Take the FREE audio tour guide, lots of information. You can easily spend a couple of hours taking in the diverse decoration of the rooms and exterior.
Add this to your list. Put this building on you must see list. It is pure Gaudi and if you're going to Barcelona be sure to soak up all the Gaudi you can get.

An exceptional gem in the heart of the city. We had passed by the Guell Palace 4-5 times before deciding, almost on a whim, to make our visit. We are so happy we did! It is one of the most amazing homes of the era, and the story behind it is fascinating, also. Famed architect Antonio Gaudi designed and built it, and everything in the palace has significance and meaning. Don't miss this place! It is a must-see!
Too many tourists. And i was one of them, but it was rather crowded. With all that said, it was beautiful. I felt like i was in candy land.

Gorgeous and Relatively Crowd Free. Excellent example of Gaudi's early work. They only let in people at scheduled times so it was a more pleasant experience because I could actually look-linger & enjoy. We did not have to book ahead of time and the ticket price was much cheaper than some of the other Gaudi buildings.The audio guide is free with ticket purchase. The rooftop chimney’s are whimsical and the view of Las Rambles from the top is quite lovely.
Very Interesting. Very interesting place, had a private guide give us the tour and it was very good we thought, Guadi was an amazing man and his works were fantastic

very interesting well worth a visit. down a side street off of las ramblas this place doesn,t really look that interesting but wow once you<re inside you realise how magnificent it is.The staff are extremely helpful and the audio guide is easy to use and informative.one tip if you want to go up to the roof and the weather looks as though its going to rain go there first because they do shut it if it rains and to avoid dissapointment because the roof terrace is amazing.As are all the rooms in their own way.You can easily spend a couple of hours in this place.Even the gift shop is reasonable and not overpriced with a nice collection of souvenirs.A must to visist

Amazing and magical. This place is a must for your visit to Barcelona. Gaudi architecture and design totally before its time but stunning and awe inspiring . Well worth the admission. We were lucky with queues as we went at 18 30 on a damp Sunday evening and the wait was only about 15 minutes. Audio tour very useful and essential to appreciate the place.

amazing place. Took your breath away, to think a family lived there,Well worth a visit Don't forget to visit the roof with the many very colourfull status and ornaments, you also get a good view across the roof tops of adjacent buildings,

Don't miss this place. In many ways It's even more interesting than Casa Battlo. Early Gaudi. Less fanciful and more remarkable archtectural features. Audio self-tour was helpful and free with the entrance ticket.

Even if you just walk around it. We didn't want to spend the money to go inside, but we were impressed and enjoyed the views from outside. We'd heard that it wasn't that exciting inside. The exterior is simply amazing. This is a MUST see.

Gaudi's magic. Guell Palace is another of Gaudi's magic at work. Because the place is built as a residence for the Guell family, it was interesting to see how Gaudi fashioned the various rooms giving much thought to details that were way ahead of his time. Truly magic. Make sure you get the audio guide to understand and truly appreciate these details. Enjoyed it thoroughly.

Artwork You Can Walk Through. Visiting Guell Palace ("Palau Guell") is a must for anyone visiting Barcelona. Antoni Gaudi was such a fascinating and ecentric architect, Palau Guell is a great opportunity to see his work up close. The walking tour is semi self-guided (you are given a hand-held device that narrates specifics of the house) but you can walk at your own pace. The best part of the house? The rooftop: an uneven, colorful display of trencadís (mosaic of pieces of ceramic). If you don't look up, the house sits almost unassuming on a side street and because we went during the "off season", we actually passed the house once before we realized where it was. We were able to buy tickets immediately, but I've heard that during busier times, there can be a line. Overall, a very interesting attraction unique to Barcelona that is highly recommended.

More like a very rich man's house. As much as the name implies, this place isn't a palace in the traditional sense. First of all, the person who stayed in it was not royalty and secondly, the 'palace' is attached on both sides to other buildings making it more like an apartment building. Nevertheless, this is another brilliant piece of work by Gaudi.
