Worth seeing - designed by Guadi. This was designed by Guadi in his early years and gives a good perspective of how he started. Even if it wasn't Guadi, the place is worth seeing just to see how the wealthy lived at that time. It wasn't cheap - 12 euros.

More than you expect from the outside.. Best audio guide ever, extremely well laid out. Very good thinking, providing a free secure locker room so that you don't have to cart around your belongings. Great architecture if rather scant in furnishing in some of the rooms. Thoroughly enjoyable, many good photo opportunities for the imaginative photographer. Give your trip down Las Rambla a purpose and visit this Gothic palace . Guell's wife didn't like it and maybe you can see why, almost expected to see Count Dracula appear in the main stairway.I'll post some pictures later to give you an idea what to expext

A must.... Less known than Casa Mila, casa Battlo and many others, we found this little pearl by accident, but this first work of Gaudi (ordered by his maecenas Guell) is a beauty....Hidden in a side street of the Ramblas, nearly no visitors (so, no long queues, not many people in the building), it gives you an idea of the budding genius Gaudi was already in his younger years; he has perfected this ideas in this later work but I found the examples about lighting, music, "secret" windows, ..... amazing. A must for Gaudi fanatics....

Famous Rooftop Work. Another beautiful Gaudi building. Be sure to make it all the way up to the rooftop. Only downside, there was a very long line around the corner where you had to wait in the sun, no shade.
Photo Op. If you are visiting Barcelona - You simply have to see this to believe it. Photos of the outside are a must and you can do people watching at the same time.

off the beaten path. This is just off Ramblas, and easy to miss, but you will be very sorry if you miss on of Gaudi's most impressive buildings. From the open foyer to the spectacular roof, the talent of its designer amazes. I thought I'd be in and out in 20 minutes, but ended up wandering for over 90 minutes.

I wish I bough a flat when the building was built. Forget a moment that it is a master piece forget it is Guell palace. Just imagine this building has just been built and the flats are on sale what would have been my reaction at that time was it crazy? Today which estate developer would be crazy enough or smart enough to put a project in hands of a truly genius or the most relevant question are there still people capable and talented to create something similar?

Awesome palace is a must see!. This reminded me of the mediaeval idea of a palace - a rich man's home in the centre of the city - not in some distant country park. So everyone could see Guell's wealth and taste, even if they never saw the interior. And for those who did, what a treat for the eyes. And now everyone can enjoy it for a modest fee - a towering achievement to bring this place back to life and open it to the public. Truly civilised.

Gaudi was given a free hand. The vulgarity of wealth. If you are anywhere related to architecture and interior design you will love this place. From the basement, the details, the metalwork, the dining room, the toilets, the terrace all enchanting and amazing... The guell family obviously had money, obviously this was their main residence and obviously they gave a free hand to gaudi, and why not? We get to see this marvel.

Excellent palace, must see. This place was shut for restoration when we first went to Barcelona but we were so glad to find it open this time.It isn't a big building but the whole building is open to the public so you can spend a long time wander round seeing its treasures. It is stuffed with interesting and amazing architectural features.Arrive early to avoid the queues and get the most from your visit.

A nice surprise outside the city. I was surprised at how large this area was once we went through the impressive entrance with its Gaudi mosaic stairway and 'gingerbread cottages' at the gates. You could spend a lot more time in this beatiful park that we had allocated.

A must see in the morning. There's no entrance fee for Guell Palace and therefore it gets really busy from about midday. Make sure you get there first thing in the morning.A truly magical place. I wish they charge entrance fee though or at least ban the people selling tourist souvenirs.

Guell Palace, another Gaudi masterpiece of design. If you like architecture and interior design, you will enjoy the tour of Guell Palace. Every floor of this Palace is amazing, from the stables on the ground floor all the way to the rooftop chimneys. The detail of the woodwork and ironwork is stunning. You realize again the genius of Gaudi. the audio guide was very good, also included interesting details about the family. We felt it was well worth the 12€ admission. There is a student rate and also free for EU pensioners. We arrived about 2pm on Thursday and had no queue and not crowded inside.

Gaudi house. There are two Gaudi houses that must be seen in Barcelona, La Pedrera and Guell palace,great views and fascinating architecture. we spent a long time walking around the building admiring his work - it is truly beautiful.It is opened from 10am to 9pm every day and it is recommended to visit it later in the day to avoid long queues. Admission is €12 including the audio guide.

Palau Guell. We visited at lunch time and founfd this to be quiet inside. We booked tickets earlier in the day when there were no queues and were given allocated time slots. The audio guides are included and are very comprehensive, there was a childrens audio guide that our 8 year old said was interesting. The building is sparcely furnished but a great example of early Gaudi

Roof is the only place worth visiting!. The interiors are average (but I don't like palaces inside in all) and very dark. About 7 floors. But the roof is fantastic! The light in the toilet goes off in 2 minutes for economy. Simply find the switcher on the touch and switch it on again.
Amazing place. This is an absolute must in Barcelona ... just an amazing place and with fantastic view from the roof.

Incredible. During the visit, the audio-guide is really helpful to understand ths story of this urban palace. You actuallty feel like if a member of the Guell family could sneak up behind you. There are incredible arquitectural details that will blow you away. Definetly worth a visit!

A Gaudí masterpiece. Though this doesn't have the fame of the other Gaudí buildings in Barcelona it is a real gem and a "must-see" for any tourist to this city. The renovation was completed in 2011 and so the rooms are in prisitne condition: very beautiful as well as being very original. The number of visitors is strictly limited allowing only about 20 inside every quarter of an hour. It makes sense to buy a ticket for a booked time convenient for you.

Accessible and friendly. We asked at the shop if we could get a wheelchair route guide and were told no access?? thankfully i had spoken to other wheelchair users and knew it was so we ignored the daft lady and found our own way round and it was well worth it the views and sculptures are immense and i cannot wait to go back.

Nice but..... We stood in the queue on Saturday which was quite long. We then noticed a sign saying entrance free on first Sunday of every month so we returned the next day and saved ourselves ?24. We arrived at 11 got our tickets and were told to come back at 3. House is lovely and rooftop v unusual. However there is no furniture in the house which I found to be disappointing. I wouldnt have been happy if I had paid ?12 and queued for hours

See what the early Gaudi was up to, pre-Casa Batllo. We ended up waiting till the very last tour of the day, at 6:45, and strolled over to the nearby Placa Reial for an aperatif to wait for our admission. Much better than standing in a long line earlier in the day. (downside is that the rooftop is most spectacular in late afternoon sun). An architectural treasure. Lots and lots of stairs, but they will allow the disabled and aged to use the little original lift.

Overrated a bit. The place is not too big. You can finish seeing it in an hour. But if you want to take pictures, you can spend half a day there. The admission is pretty high. Perhaps it is worth to spend it on food instead.

Worth a visit on a wet day. Not as good as Casa Battlo but enjoyable. Not a good idea if you can't climb stairs. Discount for over 65s. There are 2 queues - one for tickets and one for entrance. The queues start even before it opens.

This park is beautifull. A rare and beautiful park.
Has a gorgeous fountain!
A free place to rest. And it's not far from the chocolate museum and the arc du triumph
Highly recommended.

Nice, instersting Palace. It might not be as interesting as Casa Batllo, but Palat Guell is still a nice building. It's the first house designed by Gaudi and you can see how he evolved slowly.
TIP: on the first Sunday of each Monday it's free - we've been in there on 5th of May and we can confirm.

An amazing architectural monument!. We spent about 2 plus hours touring this house , and it was well worth it. It absolutely exceeded my expectations, in terms of architectural innovation and uniqueness. It definited encouraged me to learn more about Gaudi and his era!

Awesome place!. This place is unlike anything I've ever seen before and well worth a visit. The outside of the building is quite deceptive and doesn't give a clue as to what gems you'll find inside. The rooftop alone makes the visit worthwhile. If you plan to visit other Gaudi sites in Barcelona, would suggest you start with this one since it was one of his earlier works.
Unique architecture. Unique building.I didn't go inside because of the huge queue and I am not sure if it would be worth going inside.

A must see. This is an amazing beautiful place that is to be admired by everyone not only architect fansTicket pric includes audio guideThe beauty of the house is indescribable as it looks as if designed in the 2000s rather than 1882!Tip: The que was an hour long for the tickets on 11am but was really empty around 2:30 pm when I got out so plan your time ahead as there's no online reservation - you could book ahead of the visit day too

Loved it - take your time, don't rush - enjoy!. A gem behind a dour façade. An enjoyable walkie-talkie tour which you can take at your own pace (so you can let the annoying people overtake you and rush ahead). Stunning architecture and décor in a relatively small space culminating in marvellous Gaudi chimney pots on the roof.
Impressive. Amazing place. Visited with friends from the USA and would recommend to all. Great views and fascinating architecture. If in Barcelona, this should be seen.

Amazing introduction to the work of Gaudi. What a brilliant introduction to Gaudi. The building was amazing. we spent a long time walking around the building admiring his work - it is truly beautiful. The chimney's are magical.No charge for pensioners and we were given a specific time to do the tour. Audio guide and book were included.This is a must and if you don't know about Gaudi it will seriously stimulate your interest.
excellent. get there early! opens at 10 but queues start before. well worth the admission (€12 currently including audio guide)

Interesting. I think we paid 12 or 13€ to get in. It was intersting but i was a little bored after a while, we actually got 10% off from where we bought the hop on hop off bus tour, you get given a little booklet with lots of discount vouchers in etc.
Needs a Good Bath. The place is shabby and dirty. A good bath and some discipline in the area would make this a great attraction. Chaos abounds.

A hidden gem!. We had not planned to visit this house, we had already visited Casa Batlo and Casa Mila as they came highly reccomended, however we found this palace to be the most enjoyable and beautiful of the three. A great building to get an insight into Gaudi's architecture. The audio guide is great and comes in many languages. The Palace is open to 9pm so leave it till later to visit and the queues will have died down a bit. we only waited 10 minutes having arrived at 16:30.

Weird but wonderfull. Perfect photo opertunity for architecture buffs,very busy, we didn't go in but I think you can,it's on the side of a extremely busy street so you do have to jostle for a space to get your photo well worth it.
Gaudi building. One of the Gaudi buildings in Barcelona, it's not as spectacularly mad as some of the others, being an early example, but still worth a tour inside.

Nice gaff. Yet another example of the genius of Gaudi. Exquisite design and craftsmanship in a family home. Darkly sensuous and rooftop views over the city including iconic comic chimney exhuberances.

Must see Gaudi house. There are two Gaudi houses that must be seen in Barcelona, La Pedrera and this one. Both the exterior, including the roof with its fantastic chimneys, and the interior are works of great imagination and refinement. This is early Gaudi, when he was still greatly influenced by Moorish architecture and decor, and contrasts well with his later work which is more free and fantastical.

My favourite Gaudi building. We almost didn't visit this one but arrived as it opened to find a very short queue and were so pleased we did. An amazing building which has been painstakingly restored and the audio tour gives you a great guide to the building and the family. It's just off the Ramblas so easy to reach. Easily my favourite of all we saw (closely behind is Casa Mila, Pedrera). Our 11 year old loved it and listened to the whole tour.

amazing house. It was the first Gaudi bilding we entered to. It was amazing.
Audio guide is recommended
In the middle of the day, the line to the ticket office was very short

brilliant insight into the work of Gaudi. good value for money and very interesting audio tour included in entrance fee. Not as busy as other Gaudi 'attractions' so felt more relaxed and there was space to stand back and really look at the architecture.

Best Gaudi. We saw this house first and it is well worth visiting. It doesn't seem to as widely advertised as some of his other work, it is really central, just off the Rambla. Lovely, stunning rooms and not nearly as busy as his other works.

Great house. This was one of my favorite attractions in Barcelona, and between the Gaudi designed houses I liked this one better than the Casa Batllo. The central room with the chapel in it was just beautiful, as was the rest of the house. You could tell that every single detail was thought out, so the entire house was like a piece of artwork. Even the chimneys on the roof were really neat. The audio tour was informative and interesting, and I would definitely recommend it.I think the Palau Guell is a definite must-see in Barcelona.

unique architecture. very nice documentary on gaudi, audio sets are very helpful,unique architectural design both catalonial and arabian mixed architectural design. I loved the grand arabian walls and royal arabic designs. Also the cones on the roof and a lizard on one cone was very unique.
How the other 1% live. Seeing this building at night is a must do, it's even more beautiful as night falls and it's lit up. Another majestic gaudi masterpiece which had to be seen to be believed.

Fantastic Intro to Gaudi. Guell Palace was my Introduction to Gaudi. I am now hooked and can not wait to see the rest of his work. This is an amazing building that demonstrates the magic that results when every detail receives meticulous consideration. We initially decided to visit because we were passing by and there was no line! April is a perfect time to visit Barcelona if you don't mind a little rain.
Fantastic views of Barcelona. Another awesome place to visit. Great architecture and fantastic views of Barcelona - well worth the trip

Gem in the city. This was a very interesting museum especially if you are interested in architecture and/or Gaudi. It allows you to see more of Gaudi's work besides the Sagrada Familia. Definitely recommend this place as a stop in your Barcelona travels.

Early Gaudi, but just as crazy.. Stunning construction and decoration. Although he built this as a family home for the Guells, it is reported that they did not enjoy living in it (neither would I!). Magnificent and fairly traditional craftsmanship in every room/stairway/ceiling/wall and a few of Gaudi's later trademarks, such as the parabolic arches and the mad chimneys finished in trencadis (broken tiles). Worth a visit on any level, whether a Gaudi fanatic or a casual holidaymaker.

Fantastic Building, Great History... Tour is So-So. While I'm giving this 3 stars, I still think it's one of those "must do/see" places in Barcelona. Not too many negatives to speak of, but they're pervasive and affected my overall impression of the tour. Here are my negatives: its a long, boring tour with spotty electronic devices. You're given an electronic device with the audio portion of the tour pre-loaded. You select the audio track number that corresponds with the room you're in or the item you're looking at and hit play. You walk around the palace and continue to go through those motions. There is a LOT of history that they pack into the audio, and for me, it became dry and repetitive. Also, my audio device seemed faulty (my fault for not getting a new one). I couldn't skip tracks. If I tried to go forward, it only repeated the track I just listened to. Halfway through, I essentially abandoned the audio guide. Eh.That being said, the palace is absolutely stunning, showing the intricacies and versatility of Gaudi's architectural style. He built the palace in his usual-unusual manner and also crafted functional furniture into the palace's walls, railings, etc. It really is a sight to behold. The view on the roof is gorgeous, and I feel a trip to Barcelona for the first time would be incomplete without a trip to the roof of the Guell Palace. As you can tell, I have mixed feelings about the tour, but I still do feel this is a "must see".
the whole place is amazing. all i can say is wow. loved it. hundreds of people around but still incredible. if you love colour and originality this is the place to go

Very enjoyable visit. This was a great place to start a "Gaudi tour" of Barcelona because there is a very good movie that is shown in one of the rooms that gives you a lot of background on Gaudi and his relationship with Guell. Each room was unique: from the stables, to the central hall, to the roof top. Certainly worth a visit.

Nice presentation. The most amazing part of this place is the type of presentation of the palace.Every body has a walk i-taki device free of charge and even for children which their tickets are free.The palace itself is not so big but the type of architecture by Gaudi is interesting specially for university students. Also the refurbishment of this monument is interesting and the palace itself is very nice.

Amazing. Everything about this place is well thought out. From the purchasing of tickets that was quick and easy to the entrance time we were given to the audio guide it was all perfect. Think it cost 12 euros each, we were told to come back in half an hour as they only let a few through at once so it's not overcrowded and you can see properly. It's a Gaudi masterpiece so expect brilliance as you won't be disappointed. The complexity and quality of the build is simply awesome and they let you take photos everywhere. Only v v slight disappointment is generally a lack of furniture but the place is fantastic and didn't find the gift shop expensive either.

Interesting, but not a must. It's an interesting site, but as an architect may say: it's a manifest home. It's the house where Gaudí lived and where he had his study.You will find interesting pieces that Gaudí developed before creating the structure of La Sagrada Familia and some of the towers of Parc Guell. The place still is laid out as it used to be: you can see the original furniture, the toilettery, all Gaudí's desings...A nice place, but it depends on how fanatic of Gaudís work and architecture you are.
Intro to Gaudi. Enjoyed this visit. Good audio guide. Cool roof. We loved exploring Gaudi's buildings and this one did not disappoint.
Excellent audio guide. The Palau Guell is very impressive, with a free and very informative audio guide. If you like architecture, I should recommend the Palau Guell.

Very enjoyable. We enjoyed our visit to Guell Palace. We went at 10:20 in the morning, queued for a short time to buy tickets and the waited approx 10mins to enter the building, so we were in by 10:40. The cost at €12 each was reasonable, and included an audio guide - eight different languages available. The audio guide was a bit lengthy in places - I think it's designed to last approx 40 mins - but was interesting. The building itself is very impressive and you get some nice views from the roof terrace. Well worth a visit.

Stunning find. We wandered in on a Saturday afternoon. We were surprised to find no lines. We were even more surprised to find the wonders inside the Palau. It is an amazing architectural achievement. Every room seems to have something that captures your imagination. We were lucky enough to hear the organ play while we were there. Crystal clear acoustics throughout the whole house. The rooftop is wonderful and whimsical. Our tween girls thought it was spellbinding. There is a very informative but dry audio guide. It is almost too much. We stopped listening about half way through. Casa Mila and Casa Batllo get all the press, but this is a worthy stop if your like Gaudi, architecture or just appreciate beautiful design.

Wonderful grand town house. Not quite the wavy lines and irregular spaces of later Gaudi designs, but this is a stunning place and our second-most favorite Gaudi attraction in Barcelona. We liked it better than Casa Mila. Beautifully restored. Excellent audio guide.
An architectural gem. This house sums up Gaudis talent as an architect in every way. Gaudi was as much an architect of function as flair. Take the time to look at the brilliant detail throughout

After the Sagrada Church This is Number 2. Ok really this was one of the things I wish people would spend their time on. It is closed on Mondays and it a bit off the main road but for the love walk 5 mins off the main road and stop in and see this stunning beauty. Some of the best use of space I have ever seen and the quality of the work is amazing. Well worth two hours of your time to see this work of art!

A Must See. My husband is an architect and I an interior designer and we both love Gaudi's work, but we hesitated before buying tickets thinking it might not be worth the money. We decided to take the chance and were not disappointed. The audio tour is well orchestrated, descriptive and educational without being boring. The house itself has been perfectly restored to its original grandeur with exquisite attention to detail. From the amazing brick vaulted underground stables to the rooftop terrace surrounded by Gaudi's whimsical trees the house is a delight to the senses. And, since it's a little off the beaten track, there are not long waits or crushing crowds to contend with.Definitely worth seeing!

Another Gaudi's masterpiece. If you do not feel to be fed up with Gaudi here is the next one to be admired :) Palau is in the very centre of the city, just a few steps from Rambla, definitely worth seeing however, other Gaudi's constructions alike, expensive. And a long queues.

Fantastic structure. The day I went there happened to be the free day of a week, I was allotted to half and hour later than the time a got my free ticket. A bit funny. I had to walk around to wait for the allotted time. The inside was amazing, Gaudi's design concept throughout and exceptional balcony where you see the fruitful structure and overview the city. Well worth the time!

Very interesting artwork throughout & well worth a visit.. Chimneys well worth a visit. The detail in the walls, corners and flooring is beautiful. Also, not the expensive to get in so well worth a visit.
Great place to visit. Great house designed by Gaudi. But do not come back without going to the rooftop of the palace. Unbelievable chimney covers. I have never seen such a thing.

Incredible.... Wonderful building...All details are incredible... I am really impressed. We hesitated for visiting since the entrance fee is high. After seeing the details inside, we were captivated. Everybody must see inside of Guell Palace.

Really fascinating for those who like history. A short distance off Las Ramblas, you find the Gaudi designed Guell Palace where the family lived for some time. It's beautiful and VERY different from what you'll see in other "palaces". For history or art buffs, it's a can't miss. Do a little research first so that you can really understand it's significance. The audio guides that are available are good, not fantastic. If you want to really relate to the family life there, do research first.
The roof is the best part. I only give this 4 because Casa Batllo is marginally better. Again, the free audioguide is very helpful as you walk around this amazing building. 10/10.

Interesting "home". Gaudi made this house for a friend and sponsor Guell and it was home (housewife was not there telling what she thought about living-room three floors high and an organ on top of all). Plenty of stairs and fine details everywhere, so you need at least hour and half to have a good picture of this home.

Free on first sunday of the month- be there early. Having not been able to go into casa batillo or casa milar ( the hefty 20 euro per person admission price for two of us was pretty out of budget..) I realised this place is free on first sunday of the month- that you god!! Luckily our hotel was 5 mins away so we got there for opening time to see there were already queues to get free tickets!! argh! but we got free tickets for 10.30 viewing with free audio guides!!! The audio guide is very helpful and it is amazing to see on of gaudi's first works- lovely house, the roof with the decorated chimneys are very good. The gift shop has cool gaudi related stuff- some of the stuff were cheaper than other shops. But definitely go as it is cheaper than other places and I am glad I got in for free!!!

Amazing place. Really special place in the heart of the city but yet goes unnoticed down a side street off La Ramblas! The architecture inside is breathtaking how I would love to go back in time and live there! Well worth a visit.

Really interesting building and audio guide was good and included in the price. Credit cards accepted and a reduction for those over 65. The ticket office is down the road and has no protection against the rain! Staff helpful and advised that due to rain we could not go on the terraces before we paid. Audio guide included in the price and interesting. Lots of stairs but if you have a disability staff will take you in the lift. The history of the owner, his family, the architect and their relationship was well explained. No furnishings but good explanations and some photos of how it was furnished and lived in. Shop seemed very pricy to us 78 Euros for a scarf. Good exhibition in the attic / staff quarters explaining the 21 year renovations. An unusual building, very pleased that we went well worth a visit for adults.

Gaudi excellence.. How can one man do so much? I can understand why the mistress of the house didn't like it much as indicated, it does not conform to what I would think of as a home. But the mastery of the wood, marble and stone is to be admired for it's thought in use. Oh to have seen it so long ago. The audio guide comes with the price of admission and is very good. Do stop and give it a look. There is an elevator but does not access all floors. There are many stairs, be ready for it.

If you like Gaudi you will like it. Really good audio guide. Unfortunately when we were there some areas were closed off because it had been raining. However, we were told about this before we bought the tickets which was good.

So gothic! . Another one of his fantastic buildings, which i liked as much as the others and being 10 euros each rather than 20 it is a bargain! Wasnt let down by this place at all best to go first thing in the morning or late at night for the place to yourselfs...

Resurrected wonder. This palace has been under restoration for more than 20 years, but the result is fabulous. The interior shows the creativity of Gaudi maybe even more than the fanciful chimneys. In particular the central hall is a marvel.
Off the Ramblas. Worth a visit as it is off Las Ramblas and again outside quite remarkable - Gald I did not have to pay for it to be built

Lovely Gaudi Palace close to Rambla. Maybe not as famous as the other Gaudi buildings – but definitely worth a visit – It’s a beautiful place with lots of details in every room – the central hall and the roof top is amazing. In general the Gaudi attractions are bit over priced – this one is only 10 €.Not as famous

Worth the visit for the view from the roof alone. There are so many reviews for this attraction so I'll keep it short. If you like Gaudi architecture then this is a must. The inside is amazing and there is so much attention to detail. This is right off the Ramblas and we litterally ran into it by mistake one night. It is right across the street from the Hotel Gaudi, whose sign you can see from the Ramblas. If you are walking south down the Ramblas towards the Columbus statue / oceanfront, it is on your right, then less than a block down that street. The view from the roof is incredible and the chimneys are so unique. Find a time when it isn't crowded and you'll have more time to enjoy. The ticket booth is a few doors down from the actual building, but there are signs pointing you in the right direction.

Another showcase of Gaudi architecture. Again, Gaudi demonstrated his genius architecture design and thinking. This palace has several amazing features (noticeably the organ and the service alter). The roof is similar to the other Gaudi building but less grand. The palace itself is quite grand.

Marvelous site with a dark atmosphere. This is a palace located near the ramblas (not the park). It has a different style then casa battlo and casa mila. It's focused internally, with smaller windows, dark woodwork, floors, ceilings and marmer. It is masterpiece on it's own build around a splendid open space with an organ, chapel and stage for indoor performances.The audiotour is boring most of the times if you know about Gaudi.
A must. 12 euros, audioguide included. superb Gaudi house. from horse cellar to the roof terrace. audioguide story very interesting. 45 minutes pure pleasure, close to La Rambla.
Amazin. Not what u think from the outside , so weird and wonderful once you step inside , some say a bit expensive but we thought it to be quite reasonable

A good value attraction in the heart of the city.. This palace is bizarrely located in the middle of the street in a less salubrious area of town. It is stunning to look at from the outside and is massive on the inside. The tickets cost just €12 each. This includes an audio guide which explains each room as you walk round the house. If you were to listen attentively to this and take lots of pictures etc then I would allow at least 2 hours in the house. My partner and I, although impressed by the palace were not over keen to listen to the whole audio guide and rushed through some sections. Consequently it took us about an hour to look around. Overall we feel that compared to other attractions in barcelona this was good value, we've dropped it a star as it was not entirely our cup of tea and we thought it would have been interesting if they'd furnished it as it once was.

In Town Palace. The Palau Guell was the in town palace for a wealthy industrialist with 10 children who allowed a young, innovative architect, Antoni Gaudi, to create a home that could house his large family, but also serve as a place to entertain business and social guests. The innovative engineering, multi-story layout and use of a wide range of expensive materials - brick, stone, marble, wrought-iron, stained glass, mosaics, etc. is truly amazing.

Sombre but illuminating!. This looked like a medieval building and it was certainly very somber and stiff but then suddenly there were blocks of colour and more attention to detail as you travelled through this early work of Gaudi. The real stunner is the rooftop and the fabulous chimneys.

Trippy. Gaudi's work is absolutely amazing. When you visit the Palace you actually get an idea of the wavelength that he was on when he dreamt this up. It is an amazing display of architecture in the most surreal form. I recommend anything Gaudi to be seen!
Definitely worth a look. While this is a more contemporary work by Gaudi, his exceptional craftsmanship and thought are evident in everything. The ceilings and fixtures are amazing.

Gaudi at his Best. Hearing that this Guell "palace" was now open to the public after extensive renovation, we opted to visit. Marvellous!! Although it is not exactly "homey", or pretty, every aspect screams quality. It certainly shows the genius and originality of Gaudi's style as well as his sourcing of Catalan craftsmen and materials in order to showcase the expertise of the area of Spain he loved so much. The audio guide included in the entrance price was most informative, especially for us foreign visitors who might not have known that much about Gaudi.

Blink and you'll miss it.... Just off the main Rambla, this building is pretty unassuming mid terrace on a narrow street from the outside, but a complete marvel inside! They have an express audioguide for children and the audioguide is included in the entrance price.

It's alright. I was kind of disappointed by the experience especially after seeing Guadi's Casa Batllo. The design is very dark and lifeless. An insane amount of detail went into the wood work and reconstruction but you can tell from the corresponding exhibit that it's not genuine. I think it would be better if the rooms hadn't been modified so much and there was more furniture to give a sense life in the palace. Guadi's designs are amazing but need context. The audio guides are helpful but slow and hard to follow.
Outstanding Gaudi experience!. A must to visit, but not before seeing La Segrada Familia and Casa Batlo! Also good value, including the comprehensive audio guide.

Awesome. Amazing and really good value compared to La Pedera, The free audio guide was interesting and you could take your time wandering around the rooms soaking up all the incredible features, you end up on the roof with the chimneys, you have to see it to believe it , superb

Palau Guell by Antoni Gaudi - must see. I was impressed by Palau Guell. it's really beautiful place where you can see Gaudi's artistry. Walking is very interesting because the ticket includes the audio guide (languages​​: Catalan, Spanish, English, French, German, Italian, Japanese and Portuguese). "During the visit, we can discover the renewed concept of space and the manipulation of light, as well as the orginality and wealth of the constructive and ornamental solutions, the product of both the creative genius of Gaudi as well as the craftsmanship and skill of his collaborators (artists, industrialists, craftspeople) in the use of wrought iron, ceramics, glass, stone and wood that set this unique work apart. " - it's all true :) Enjoy!Prices: general 10 euro, reduced 8 euroOpen: Tuesday to Sunday (October-March: from 10 am to 5.30 pm, fimal admission time: 4.30 pm; April-September: from 10 am to 8 pm, final admission time: 7 pm)

A must-visit. Excellent experience, a real palace and Gaudi to his best!! This place is a real diamond. We spent almost 1hour and with the ticket you get an audio guide (available to multiple languages) for free. Also the gift shop has very good prices and good quality comparing to the shops outside. A must visit in Barcelona.

Wow - what a place!. Recently renovated to a very high standard, and they are very careful not to let too many people in at once. Free on Sundays, but the queues are very long, and they will give you an allocated time which could be 2 hours away.

Pretty rooftop. Personally, I think this was my least favorite Gaudí building of the four I visited but it's definitely worth a visit to see the beautiful rooftop. I was just disappointed with the dark interiors after having seen Casa Milà and Casa Batlló earlier in the day.Also, I noticed afterwards that I was charged €12/adult instead of the €10/adult I saw listed on the website. I thought maybe tax was included but when I checked my other receipts, I noticed I wasn't charged anything on top of the listed entrance fees for La Sagrada Familia, Casa Mila or Casa Batlló. I'm sure (or at least I hope) it was an honest mistake but I'd advise you to double check the total before paying. I was pretty good at checking when it came to restaurants but it slipped my mind to double check when it came to the sites.
real fairy tale castle. A little gloomy but like a fairy tale place. Such a wonderous imagination, every detail is different and amazing

Love it here. Palau Guell is a peaceful sanctuary off Las Ramblas where you can step back in time and see how the Guell family lived. I've been here several times over the years and will return in the future.

Tiles, tiles and more beautiful tiles!. Unfortunately the Palace was being renovated during our visit so the exterior was partially covered by scaffolding and plastic. Despite this we were still able to appreciated the design and vivid colours that feature on this attraction.
Richness Of Details!. Wow, what an interesting tour. A must stop is on top of the roof! The kids really liked the the mushroom tops! LOL

early Gaudi: you may be a little disappointed. Don't get me wrong, this is a World `Heritage site but if you come expecting a Gaudi spectacular like La Pedrera or the Sagrada Familia, you won't get that. Yes, the Palau, built for the tycoon, Eusebi Guell, shows many touches of the master. However, the interior is mainly darker woods (take a few flash photos and you will see how beautiful that actually are), which creates a slightly gloomy effect in places. I am sure he built what his client asked for. But as I said, there are touches of the master that you may miss: the decorations outside the front door, leaf-like structures, and a beautiful living room window. It's worth looking closely and listening to the excellent audio guide. Very impressive and beautifully restored. But just one more thing: Gaudi loved chimneys. When I stepped out to see these, I actually laughed out aloud: I could hear him saying, "well, I'm sure they will never come up here, so now I can do what I like!" . Wonderfully decorated chimneys, spectacular 'trencadis' (broken tile) patterns, the lizard sitting motionless (for a very long time !!) on one chimney, and , last but not least, the glorious weather vane in the form of a bat. It might not be top of the list but the Palau Guell is certainly worth a visit if you have the time to see all the works of Gaudi in Barcelona.

Early Gaudi. This is another do not miss Gaudi experience. This is an excellent example of some of his early work. Because of extensive renovation, which was very well done, this museum was only open after 2011. From the stables in the basement to the roof every aspect was amazing. The centerpiece of the house was the organ installed in the central room/atrium. Unfortunately the original organ was deteriorated beyond repair and a new one was installed during the renovation. While I was visiting the organ began playing and the music filled the house. They have several times during the day when the organ plays. Try to schedule your visit around these times. The audio guide is included in the admission price. Equal in awe power to Casa Batilla and la Pedrara.
Across the street from our hotel.. Palua Guell was one of Gaudi's benefactors. The palace is more of a museum than a home and fascinating to walk through.
Amazing detail. He thought about everything in the design from the below ground stables to the chimney tops. The audio guide is great interesting yet detailed.
Gaudi at his best!. This is a unique house, particularly the roof top was amazing!Many interesting antiques and furniture on display throughout the house.

Very Interesting. I visited this house museum and went realy to avoid crowds. This house is not overwhelmed with tourists in the way Casa Mila is and Guell Palace has much more interesting interiors. What I did was go first to the main floor instead of the basement and this put me at least 10 minutes ahead of the other tourists and so I essentially had the house to myself and could take photographs without interruption. There are some very unusual and beautiful rooms especially the main hall and dining room and the roof has some very interesting Gaudi pinnicales in a range of colourful tiles. This museum more than any other I visited gives a full look at Gaudi's domestic architectural style. It has a nice gift shop. Highly recommended.

Better value than the other Gaudi houses. For 10 euros including the audio guide this is a more realistic price than Casa Batllo or La Pedrera. It also has it's own charm although I prefer the other two. It has some amazing features inside and it all comes down to personal taste - the roof chimneys and staircases are fab.
Guell. Gaudi at his best, nice place to pick up souvenirs at an affordable price. This is a must see. Kids lived it to explore.

Magic. We loved this place, wandering around imagining what it would be like to live here. And the best spot is up on the roof amongst Gaudii's whacky mosaic chimney pots. The shorter audio guide was ample information for us, and they provided a kids version as well.You will most likely have to queue for tickets and then should be aware that you may not get immediate entry but be given an entry time for some time later in the day. Once inside you will be grateful that control entry numbers so tightly.
Good introduction to Gaudi.. Stop in while you are walking the Ramblas. Very informativeself tour, on tape, available in many languages.
Gaudian. Like pretty much everything else Gaudì did, is amazing. You should take your time to relax from the busy Barcelona, and walk around in the Palau, then go and visit the park. Worth it.

Fantastic Palace. Another one of Gaudi's classic buildings. Allow two hours for this visit and be prepared to ascend and descend to the roof level in this five story building without an elevator. The basement is also cool to see (where there used to be a stable area for horses and a ramp down from the street level). The roof level is a must see and has a great view of the city.

If you see "Designed by Gaudi", buy a ticket. If you are in Barcelona and you care at all about architecture, get to know Gaudi. There is a commonality to all his structures (you rarely see a straight line anywhere), but then again, they are all unique. Taking a tour is a must.

Glad I visited it. To get a good impression of the work of Gaudi, you should definitely visit the Palau Gaudi. At the start of the tour your receive headphones, and you can take the tour at your own pace. My daughter 10 enjoyed it a lot just like me. Very much worth the admission fee.

Palau Güell. Newly opened to the public. Gaudi's first private commission for his patron, the industrialist Güell. Excellent audio guide and limited numbers to enter on the hourly visits. A must see for Gaudi fans.

It's All About the Details. The first Sunday of the month is free, however you'll need to stop by the ticket kiosk to get a 'ticket' because the visits are timed. This being said, even if you have to pay the ticket price on other days, it'll be well worth it.I went from cellar to roof and didn't run out of things to look at and marvel at. I have often said that Spain is a place where I have more pictures of walls, floors, window and door frames and ceilings. The Palau Guëll is no exception. Every surface seems to have some decoration and some use--including a foldaway chapel and closets for the owners to hear mass without having to go downstairs. I especially liked the window treatment at the back of the palace and the chimneys. The chimneys are not to be missed--and how often do you hear _that_? I do have to say that I kind of half-wished that the furnishings had been left because I'd be curious to see how one would furnish the place. But only half-wish, because otherwise you wouldn't get as clear a view of the bones of the place.

Beautiful in the details. I liked it. It's a beautiful house with fantastic details. Loved the roof with all those beautiful chimneys. The price is good and include the audioguide.
Photos are allowed without flash and tripod.

Gaudis first palace. To get to the palace get off at Liceu (Line 3 green line). Signs are very clear to the palace which is off on a side street. Quite hard to take a picture of the chimmneys from the outside, as the street is very narrow. If you go on the first Sunday of the month you can gain free entrance, however beware queues can be quite long. Otherwise the entrance fee is just over 10 euros (includes audio guide). Once inside the palace its stunning and clearly shows how Gaudi makes full use of outside lighting. The roof is absoltuely stunning. The whole tour will take around 2 hours.
Gaudí's first palace. Especially the roof is spectacular. At €10 still not cheap, but a whole lot cheaper than La Pedrera (€16 without reduction) or Casa Batlo (€20)

Not to be missed!. We came across the Palace purely by chance as it was hardly mentioned our guide book. It was quite early so there were no queues and we thought we'd 'give it a go'.The 10 Euro per adult price of admission includes an audio guide with a choice of short or detailed tour. We chose the detailed tour which took an hour and was crammed full of information and anecdotes about the building and the main players. A young Gaudi was commissioned to build a palace for his rich patron Guell and his family, including 10 children. From the subterranean stables to the outlandish chimneys every inch of the building is amazing. An incredible mix of rustic materials and opulent designs, this palace was only recently reopened to the public after extensive and sympathetic restoration.

A masterpiece by Gaudi. I really had à great time visiting thé Guell Palace. The audio-guide is for free and provides valuable info about the Palau, the owner and the man behind the masterpiece. A must visit while ni Barcelona.

The best of Gaudi. If you are going to see one Gaudi creation this should be it. At 10 euros and right in the heart of the city it is the place to see. every turn, every step is a masterpiece. the roof is as beautiful as any of the other buildings. We paid to go into all of Gaudi's buildings and this was our favorite.

Rich, lavish, opulent. This is what you can do when money doesn't matter. Here you see splendid woodwork, opulent rooms, crazy rooftop. The house was made to impress. The spaces for the carriages, horses, staff, are well thought and efficient, functional. The rooms for guests and tennants are richly decorated with the best materials money could get at that time. I loved the yellow gutter with gargoyles at the back terrace. Remark also the three steps at the left intrance so you could easily mount a horse or get into your carriage.
Very Interesting House. Worth a visit. Get in line early if you want to visit on a free Sunday. Audioguides, included int he price, were very informative.

Cheap and Better than other Gaudi Places. Recommended by our guide Barcelona Running Tours and turned out be great. Cheaper than other Gaudi houses and you can visit it from cellars to right up the roof.
Very cool!. We stopped here as part of the Hop on, Hop off bus ride. Very cool place. Loved the architecture and atmosphere.

Nice, darker side to Guadi. Entrance fee of 10 Euros includes the very useful handheld audioguide. If you're in the Ramblas area, then worth a visit if you have the time and enjoy Gaudi's work. Lots of interesting details abound, lovely use of various materials, you can really imagine what this palace was like for the Guell family back in the time.

Great architecture. Great architecture nice intro to Gaudi's work and close to La Ramblas, open from 10am and includes an informative guide. Get knowing of Gaudi here you'll hear all about him throughout your stay in Barcelona!
great at early mornings. it is great to visit just shortly after opening, while it will be empty and you can enjoy it on your own + with audio guide
good value. very interesting quirky building typical Gaudi was good having your own handset to wander at your own pace.good value at 10 euros each.

WOW!!!. What can you say that isn't already said, think it was 15 euro each for entry which initially seemed a bit steep but as soon as we walked in the price was forgotten, beautifully architectured and displayed
Sparse. Its an interesting building but with little furniture from the period - I found it mildly interesting and a bit overpriced.

A One Family Home by Gaudi. This is the house Gaudi built for his patron, Guell. We took a self-guided audio tour which takes you from the stables to the roof of this house. There were surprises around every corner in Gaudi's style! The stables are elegant and roomy, there is a chapel with a pipe organ with a gallery around the top of the room so people could hear without being seen, the rooms were different and innovative, and the windows on the back patio of outside of the house are decorated with beautifully carved ironwork. The tour tells stories about the family as well as Gaudi, and is very informative. I highly recommend that you tour this site to get a different aspect of Gaudi and his work.
nice. we liked Guell Palace. Barcelona is full of gaudi The place was full of people but it is well managed so no a lot of wait time for us

Interesting example of Gaudi's work, good audioguide. I thought that the different architectural styles used in the Guell Palace were interesting and although it is seemingly not as popular as Gaudi's other works, it is well worth a visit. The chimneys on the roof are particularly impressive. The audioguide is good as the descriptions for each room are kept fairly short so you don't lose interest (as opposed to the audioguide at Casa Battlo, which I gave up on halfway through). We didn't have to queue at all to get in and the entry price is quite reasonable (6 euros for students and 8 for regular entry if I remember correctly).

Neat but not the best of Gaudi. The Guell palace is an incredible place to visit, but compared to some of Guadi's other whimsical creations, this site is dull and dark in comparison. There are still plenty of artistic details to appreciate if you do visit and the mosaic smokestacks on the roof display the more colorful side of Gaudi.

Wealth of ideas. The townhouse designed by Gaudi for his patron Guell. The free audio guide was brilliant. You really need it to appreciate the detail and clever technical aspects of the designs. Loved this place. Amazing roof too, with spectacular Gaudi chimneys.

The dawn of Gaudi.... PALAU GUELL is a city palace built by Antoni Gaudi between 1886 and 1888 at the demand of industrial tycoon Eusebi Guell I Bacigalupi. The palace has been splendidly restored and can be visited with the help of an outstanding audioguide.We recommend making Palau Guell the first stop on your tour of Modernista buildings because it is an early project of Gaudi. Therefore it provides a good introduction to his work and it will allow you to appreciate how he gradually developed his own unique style.The façade of Palau Guell is a lot less extravagant than his later work, being dominated by straight lines and lacking colour. However the architect already uses parabolic arches and displays his love for wraught iron with two magnificent entrance gates.The back of the palace is dominated by an impressive bay-window with balcony and on the roof you will find the typical chimneys with ceramics decoration.A second reason to include Palau Guell in your agenda is the wealth of its interior. There is very little furniture on display but the decoration of walls and ceilings in the public rooms at first floor level is simply breathtaking and unseen in any other Modernista building we visited (apart from Palau de la Musica).Among the highlights feature the entrance hall, the piano room, the smoking room, the dining room, the waiting room for guests and the three storey central hall. We advise scheduling about three hours for an in depth visit.

Really unique experience. I didn't know much about this place before going in to it. It's probably not as famous as some of Gaudi's other buildings but it is very impressive! There are so many interesting aspects of the building, from the front gates, to the back of the house, to the roof. I would highly recommend going here. The audio guide is definitely worth it. It is right off La Rambla ( you can't miss the signs). Also, it is free the first Sunday of the month but make sure to get there early to order your free tickets.

First Gaudi stop, but make sure it's a nice day!. This was our first Gaudi stop and was a great experience of his early work. €10 includes an audio self-guided tour, but make sure it's not a rainy day because they'll close off the roof where the best part is. We went anyways since the weather was not great the whole time we were there. The entrance is small and can be missed. Just head to the right after the ticket booth to one of the partitioned lines.

palau guell. Located a short walk off La Rambas , this Gaudi designed house was very interesting. It is different from other Gaudi works. The audio tour was very well done. The view from the roof was fantastic. It was recently reopened after refurbishing and is well worth visiting.

Early Gaudi. Reopened after an extensive restoration, the home of Gaudi's most important client, Eusebi Güell, is instructive in understanding the development of Gaudi's style. His use of wood and wrought iron in this home was a new discovery for me, and his use of the parabolic arches at the entrance to allow carriages to come and go without exposing their passengers to the weather is prescient. Gaudi designed this home to cater to the family's every convenience, allowing them to view what is happening in the public areas from floors away, saving them many steps. His fanciful chimneys are a delight and so colorful atop the home.

Great Early Gaudi!. The audioguide tour of this beautifully-restored private home took us from the basement stables to the very top with lots of information provided. Simply gorgeous and fascinating mix of Gothic and early Modernista. A new must-see for your Barcelona trip if you are a Gaudi fan as I am.
not to miss. If you have a 'must do' for a trip to Barcelona, this is it.10 euros per person and includes audio tour.
Gaudi gaudi gaudi. What an imagination! Our guide intimated that he was inspired by nature and with a little help from some mushrooms came up with his unique architectural concepts.

haunted palace. Cellar reveals the ingenious and inventive brickwork that is the frame of the building, the rooftop gives a view of the city, and a close meeting with Gaudi mosaic on the chimney/ventilators. The interior, very Art Nouveau, with hint of Dracula's castle.

Beauty in the details. Our guidebooks nearly led us astray by suggesting that this was skippable...that would have been a disaster! I fully loved this tour. It is so different from the other Gaudi houses and has so much design in the details of the building - like the drainage design in the basement, the angles of doorways, and the sight lines throughout the house. It's hard to imagine living here, but it's amazing to see the creativity and range of Gaudi through this building.

Extraordinary Gaudi. Just off the lower part of The Rambla, we almost walked by its simple street side elegance. From the elaborate wrought iron entrance gates, to the archectecturial brick work of the basement stable area, to the majestic entrance stairway, the spectacular upper rooms and their intricate wooden ceilings, the majestic center hall and organ, and the whimsical treatment of the chimneys on the roof, this is another Barcelona testament to the genius of Gaudi.

Beautifull restorated Gaudi Palace. This Gaudi palace is an absolute must see for everyone visiting Barcelona. You get access to all the rooms and a pleasant voice in the audioguide enlightens you about the most famous aspects of the building. Also, the explanations aren't to long, so visitors won't be bored with every little detail. The staff is perfectly multilingual en very friendly, and the entrance fee is rather inexpensive in comparison with other Gaudi buildings!

It's overwhelming!. So easy to get to from Las Ramblas. It's so interesting to see how Guadi used his ideas to create this "Town House" for Guell. Marvellous wrought iron work the style of which I've seen nowhere else. well worth the ticket price.

A great introduction to Gaudi. Really enjoyed seeing Guell Palace, one of Gaudi's first commissions as a young architect. Such innovative ideasand fascinating if a bit quirky. Just happened to get in on an organ recital while there---just lucky, I think, but perhaps it issomething they do every day.

Near the Boqueria. This house is really beautiful inside! The craftsmanship is exceptional and the fact that one can walk through the stables below the home and up on the rooftop to see the skyline is very cool. It is so fun to see the interiors of the modernista homes that were designed by Gaudi.

A good introduction to Gaudi. I think we were fortunate to go to Guell Palace before La Sagrada Familia. We didn't really know too much about Gaudi and the audioguide provided a good introduction to his work and signature styles (parabolic arches!). The building itself is very interesting with lots to look at and imagine but may be a bit underwhelming if seen after La Sagrada Familia. If you can get there in good weather then it's worth spending some time at the end enjoying the views and atmosphere from the roof at the end of the tour.

Beautiful Palace in a trashy neighbourhood. I love this little palace! It small but you can easily see how the family lived here. Not so crowded as all other attractions as most people done knwo about this one.

Stupendous. The inside really has the "wow" factor and the history of the Guell family and Antoni Gaudi is well explained in the audio guide. After the Sagrada Familia, this is a must-visit for admirers of Gaudi and anyone at all interested in architecture.Strange that the kitchen quarters were in the attic. In England, these were usually in the basement.

Interesting but smaller. One of the early works of Gaudi, overshadowed if you see Casa Batllo or Sagrad Famila.Line was not very long (weekday in November). Better to get audio tour, without it we missed many of the features.
Very impressive. You are given a recorded tour guide which really brings the whole experience to life. Very good indeed - and good value, too.

A must see while in Barcalona. We were staying at the end of the road where the Guell palace is and had walked past it many times before we realised what a gem we had on our door stap. You must go inside to witness just what a wonder this palace is. Make sure you have the head phone guide in order to fully appreciate this family home. Would personally hate to have lived here but still enjoyed it greatly.
Fantastic. This was amazing to see and the view from the palace was breath taking!!It was lots of fun to walk down and see the other bits of the park aswell

Beautiful Architecture. The Guell Palace is a must when in Barcelona for the simple reason that the architect of the building, Gaudi, is in the DNA of Barcelona. We went to the Guell Palace on the first Sunday of the month when the entrance is for free. The ticket system is quite clever, at different times during the day (check the website for the exact times) free tickets are distributed at the counter. Those tickets are for a specific time slot so most likely you'll have to come back at a certain time later that day. The biggest plus about this system is that since there are only a limited amount of tickets per time slot the palace is never extremely crowded which increases the joy of the visit. Try to be on time though, we arrived a tiny bit late and initially the guard at the door did not want to let us in. Luckily the staff of the palace is extremely friendly and the lady who had before given us the tickets at the counter recognized us and let us in. When you enter the palace you get an audio-guide for free which gives very extensive information on the whole palace and its numerous architectural treasures as well as the private lives of the Guell family. The whole tour takes about 90 minutes and leads you through every room of the palace (there is no furniture in the palace so it's all about the architecture and history). When we went the weather was not too good so the beautiful roof was closed for visit which was of course a shame but I can't blame the palace for that, safety first.In short, the palace is totally worth a visit and if I would have gone on a regular day I would have gladly paid the entrance fee.

Less visited, less expensive, and among the best of Gaudi. Palau Guell (Guell Palace) was among our favorite attractions during a recent visit to Barcelona.  We weren’t sure what to expect because the building doesn’t seem to get the same kind of mention as other Gaudi-designed sites.  Indeed, from the outside it didn’t look like much and the start of the self-guided tour in the lower level stables didn’t seem very promising (though Gaudi designed the area with thoughtful functionality and attention to detail).  By the first above-ground stop, however, I realized we were in for a treat!  The home’s many rooms show Gaudi’s brilliant style.  They do not have the same fanciful touches that we saw in Gaudi’s later work at La Pedrera and Casa Batllo, but the walls, ceilings, floor, lamps, windows, doors, and everything else are all beautiful with amazing workmanship.  I was so impressed!  The rooftop terrace has a wonderful assortment of Gaudi chimneys, and since Palau Guell was much less crowded than other places we visited, it was easy to photograph them all.An audioguide is included with admission, and we thought it was a very good one.  It offered lots of information about Gaudi and his architecture, as well as information about the Guell family, which helped us imagine how a family would live in these spectacular quarters (though they chose not to live there very long).  On one of the upper floors, there is also an excellent video presentation that synchronizes with the audioguide.  The restoration of Palau Guell was only completed in the past year or so, and consequently some online and print guidebooks have out-of-date information about visit logistics; check the website for current information.  The admission charge was considerably lower than that of many other Barcelona attractions and, in my opinion, represents a great value; we received a small discount with the coupon that came with our Ruta del Modernisme guidebook.  There is a lovely, small gift shop.I highly recommend a stop at Palau Guell for Gaudi enthusiasts!  And, those who are looking for a small taste of Gaudi’s architecture in a less expensive, less crowded venue won’t be disappointed with their visit either!

Step back into a more elegant time.. This mansion, designed early in Gaudi's career, is right off Las Ramblas, on a small lot. But much is packed into the small footprint. Gaudi hadn't found his whimsical flowing lines yet, but the fun, color, attention to detail and function are there, and the owner certainly gave him free reins with the check book. Apparently, concerts are still given in the main room, which comes complete with organ. If one had been available while we were there, we would have gone without doubt.

Pleasent Supprise, one of the best Museums of it's kind we have been in.. The audio boxes are really good and make the excursion through this fascinating architectural masterpiece a real delight. Built vertical on a small footprint, it takes a couple hours to go through.We stayed across the street in the Hotel Gaudi and noticed that the line to get in could get rather long since they limit the number in the house. We watched for no line times.
Gotta see it!. What a great site. The work of this place is like no other. And, the audio tour lets you pace yourself and see it all. Gaudi was a gift to the world -- magnificent!
Something differente. we spent about two hours at the Gull Palce and we received more than what we expected, i was something unique, something different

The cheaper of the Gaudi attractions. Think enterance was 10Euros including the headset tour. Nice to have a look around inside, I felt this one offered good value compaired to some of the other Gaudi attractions at 16-20 Euros.

Great experience. His was our first insight to Gaudi's. the audio tour guide is recommended. Whilst our teenage children were a little reluctant with our architectural trips. They certainly appreciated the educational experience. This was indeed a good call, and only 30minute wait mid afternoon.

Amazing. My husband and I were in Barcelona celebrating our silver wedding anniversary. I was the gaudi enthusiast and had wanted to see casa mila or casa batllo but they were so expensive so Palau guell was our last resort. It was amazing. So beautiful and intricate. Even my husband agreed. The staff member on the rooftop was very friendly and helpful taking a photo of my husband and me together and pointing out all the sights you can see from up there. I would definitely recommend seeing this above the other gaudi houses.

gorgeous. A place that deserves the title "palace#. Impressing - overwhelming -just wow.We have been there on late afternoon at 3:45 and got an entrance ticket for 4:30. In betweewn we had a drink at the "Ramblas".We entered the palace 10 min early, an audio-giude was included. Then we had an outstanding expierience of architecture.
It felt like be in a ginger bread house. wear comfortable shoes and take plenty of water it takes hours to climb to the top but its worth it the views are amazing

Another great Gaudi. An early work by Gaudi, not his best, but definitely worth visiting. The Guell Palace is remarkable because of its grandeur and many of the details that Gaudi would develop later are on view here.

An exceptional piece of architecture not to be missed in Barcelona. The Guell Palace is incredible floor by floor, so you have to walk everyone to see the rooms, stairs and the corridors! The figures, colors and environment is amaizing, so this is a place reallybto be included in everyone list. Price is really lower than expected or even other places, so do not miss it.

Very informative. It was great to see a house that had the littlest designs of him and was still brilliant. I don't mean that there were hardly any designs but the stuff you saw you could see being more adapted to simpler people. The house was also very grand showing Gaudi's work to be high status. Worth a visit if your a big fan of Gaudi
If you are interesting in Gaudi´s works.... Wow. If you visit hear, you can understand why Gaudi is really something. Shapes, lights, colours,... It takes about 1,5-2 hours to go around there.

Quite amazing. Really well set out with a good audio presentation. The history and actual presentation of each room was awe inspiring...the wood carvings are particularly impressive , but gave a very "heavy feel" to the whole house/palace and no doubt the reason Mrs Guell was not enamoured by it! Tip: Don't just join a queue to get in , the ticket office is before you get to the entrance.
FAB!!. Gaudi at his best. Amazing views, brilliant. Will go again. Well worth the money! Don't forget your camera!
Gaudi at his best. Not as colorful as Casa Batilo but dignified and beautiful in its details. Interesting to see both and compare,

Amazing place. Wonderful masterpiece ! I would have spent days there if I could.
It is very important to buy the audio-guide in order to understand better details of Gaudi's work.
I couldn't find tickets on internet but there was no line.

Beautifull for all. The great intention of Gaudi to enjoy the everybody with his works was a benefitt for all of us, unfortunately they are persons wich distroiied small pieces from walls , and to ripair the work of Gaudi is quite imposible. Very pity!

Cheap and entertaining. If I had to see one fine piece of Gaudis work other than the inevitable visit to the cathedral it would be to visit the Palau Guell. Very impressive building, well organised, not expensive. Pity about the surrounding slum..
Very cool. This is centrally located and easy to get to from La Rambla. Very cool place to visit. The architecture is amazing and the story of the Guells is intriguing.

European-Persian fine crafts palace of the 1800s. If ever there was a residence made to show the heights of of both European and Persian craftsmen's talent in Spain, this is it. The richness of craft of the sculptured woods, ebony inlays, flowered earthenware, delicate mosaics, made to measure furniture, and intricate and astute ventilation mechanisms, all contrive to arousing one's sense of the owner's strategically-intended display of power and culture upon his contemporaries and the imagination, inventiveness and resourcefulness of the architect creator of the Guell Palace, who became his friend. This is a true jewel of architecture and absolutely worth a visit. From the stables below street level to the roof, enjoy decorative and cultural refinement here at a level not often attained elsewhere. This mixture of both Persian and European architectural cultures certainly produced a luxury practical and pleasurable palace.

A land of fairy tales. After a long bus ride we finally arrived and it was worth it. There are several levels and routes surrounded by structures and walls that are beautiful. You can spend hours there and still not see everything.

Worth the cost; liked it better than Casa Batllo. After reading the reviews on tripadvisor, we took our time wandering through this palace. It is INSANE! It definitely made my wife join me in my love of Gaudi's work. At first we balked at the price, but based on reviews we decided to go in. I ended up listening to the entire audio-guide (which I never do), and had a great time wandering through this place. Of course it's personal preference, but my wife and I agreed that we liked this better than Casa Batllo. This is mostly because of the condition of this building. I think it's run by the government, so it's quite well done. The Casa Batllo is impressive in it's own right (especially the outside), but there are still tenants in the building and it's somewhat marred by the mundane exit signs and functional metal rails that I'm sure have been put in over time for practical use.

Amazing surprise and spectacular restoration!. You can see an early example of Gaudi and his principal sponsor, Señor Guell. But very "dark" by comparison to many other Gaudi homes. Literally. Lots of dark oak, limestone, shade, etc. A truly amazing restoration and affordable too. Worth a side trip off La Rambla, for sure.

Very nice. Though I prefer Casa Battlo, this is also very nice. It has a totally different feel to it, more down to earth if you like, until you reach the rooftop and see all the strange but beautiful chimneys. Worth a visit indeed.

What would it cost today. One of Gaudi's first commissions and you can see there was little constraint on money. The detail and materials used in all aspects on the contruction are so individually designed and themed. Good use of natural light and ventilation shows off the building to the full. Even using wooden cobbles internally so that the horses hooves didn't make a noise.

Domestic Gaudi. An amazing art-nouveau apartment. So many details that Gaudi designed into the house, from the amazing asymmetric doors to the fact that there are no right-angles in any room. It is just such a different way to design a house. Very interesting.
Unusually Awesome!. Loved the Gaudi architechtural designed stuctures that blend in to nature and make it practical and useful and gorgeous all at the same time.

Imaginative and powerful. This house is amazing, from the underground stables for the horses to the intricate work on the ceilings, walls, windows and floors. Made of stone, glass and wood, it just showcases the talent and imagination of Gaudi.
Magical. A unique building just off Las Ramblas, recently renovated. It seems tame compared to Casa Battlo but I prefer it to La Pedrera.
Interesting. Liked the personal headphones as it allowed us to proceed at our own pace. Wished the rooms were furnished.

A Striking Space. I enjoyed our tour of this less-frequented Gaudi gem very much. I didn't see Pedrera or Casa Batllo because we ran out of time, but this admission fee was the most reasonable of those (only 10 euro) and included an audio tour. As my husband and I were going through, the only Gaudi "staple" I couldn't find was the tile work. But sure enough, when we went up to the roof, we found it. Worth a visit!

Very simply, the tour of a home.. Unlike the other reviewers, I did not enjoy Guell Palace as much as the other museums and sights that line the streets of Barcelona. This is the house of Gaudi, and as you would imagine, it is empty rooms, hallways, etc. where he and his family lived--nothing too out-of-the-ordinary. Simply put, you are given an audio guide and as you walk through the house, you key in the numbers that you see as you walk around the room and you can hear about the history and design of the house. I did however like the roof of the house because it felt very Gaudi-inspired where many of the other rooms felt/looked like, well, just rooms. If you are a huge Gaudi fan, a visit to this house would be interesting, but for those guests who are not really into Gaudi, I would choose a different way to spend your time and money.

Tour through the mind of a genius (with the audio guide).. Before I start, I highly recommend you bring a set of earphones with you before you depart for your vacation. It's not that the audio guide set is filthy or anything (I'm sure the staff sanitize it regularly), it's just that it can get quite tiring holding the device up next to your ears throughout your visit. So just plug in your earphones (standard 3.5mm audio jack) and just hang the audio guide set around your neck while you tour this mesmerizing place.Just let your imagination take over and simply think Guell Palace is a small compartment of Gaudi's brain which magically became this building. You will realize much of the inspiration for Gaudi's design has been drawn from the shapes and patterns of nature and from the way I see it, it serves as a vindication to mass production. It makes me wonder when did I lose touch and all sensitivity to nature and my surrounding.Anyway, this is one of the attractions which you should go early and go light.

Great way to introduce Gaudi to teenagers. For picky teens who typically glaze over at the thought of a museum, this was a fun, informative and appealing way for our entire family to learn about Gaudi's art form. They could practically imagine what the home for the Guell family would have been like to live in. Rooftop was the highlight with its colorful chimneys. Right off La Rambla, good value and no line to get in at 11am on Saturday.

Don't bypass this on your Gaudi tour. It may not have the blaze of colour and fantasy that Casa Batllo, Park Guell or the Sagrada Familia has but it's just as amazing. It blows you away with its ingenuity, design, attention to detail and oppulence. Its been undergoing renovation for a number of years and it's great to be able to revisit again now and see it in its full glory

Fascinating, as with most of Gaudi's influence. I like the ambiance surrounding the par, especially the crowds from all over the world.If you are a female, I advice you NOT use the bathroom, go before you get there, or hold it.
Very interesting. Really enjoyed the Guell Palace is an amazing building and is so well explained with the audioguide.
Stunning. Quite exceptional restoration of this amazing place. free audio tour included in price of entrance. Unique architecture and truly bizarre chimney posts on the roof terrace!

Great option to meet Gaudi. The house was just renovated,great displays,very interesting and informative audio guide!The entrance fee is only 10€!The travel books do not highlight the house as much as they should,in our opinion it is a must see sight in Barcelona!!!

Unmissable. I had been to La Pedrera and to Casa Batllo so my plans were to skip the Guell Palace. I walked by and since there were no queues and the ticket was rather cheap (comparably) I decided to enter. I'm glad I did it. The Guell Palace is incredible and mesmerizing. I liked it more than La Pedrera. Audioguide is included in the ticket price. Do not miss it!
excellent carefull for weather. it's beautiful and really worth seeing. Important is to know that the terrace is closed when raining and the last entry is 7 pm.

Nice and "cheap". The palace outside is not inviting as mush as Casa Battlò, but it is worth a visit as it costs the half of the price of Casa Battlò: 10€ instead of 20€(!!!!).The price includes and audioguide that makes the visit interesting. Inside is very nice, but the best part is the terrace.
Gaudi. The most impressive Gaudi of them all! Amazing design from the stables in the basement to the roof top chimneys!
Another Gaudi work. and really luxurious private mansion he built for the Guells. The roof was closed due to rain but everything else was so beautiful

Fantastic house. The best Gaudi tour. The Rooftop with it's chimneys is the most famous aspect of this house but there is so much more to it than just that and is well worth a visit. At €10 this is excellent value and includes an audio guide. The house is no longer furnished and is displayed on its own merits as a piece of architecture.

Try it. We stood outside wondering whether to fork out 10 euros to go in and are so glad we did. What an amazing place, and designed so originally by so young a man! Entry is controlled so it's not overcrowded, you can take your time with the audio-guide, climbing all the way up. Allow more than one hour.

Gothic and haunting. always queues outside. Another fabulous example of Gaudi's architecture - perhaps not everyone's taste. If you've been to Sagrada Familia and maybe one of his other houses - this isnt essential. But, we are aficionados - so this was a must. We spent a good 90 minutes inside. As usual entry prices are steep in our opinion 10 EURO a head - but similar to other places in Barcelona.....dont miss the beautiful roof!

Ironwork Exraordinary. This Gaudi "Palace" is a grander building than the Casa Batilo, the one element that really stands out is the ironwork - the craftsmanship is quite exceptional, a revelation.
