The rooms and working arrangements of the building show Gaudi as an accomplished engineer as well as a considerable artist.

It's All Open Now. The restoration process was completed in 2011 and the palace is simply wonderful. Your admission price includes a self-guiding audio device so you can wander at your own leisure and have each room and section explained to you.

Genius. It is fascinating to see how Gaudi considered everything in his design, not just form, but function. How to keep the house cool, privacy, etc. Amazing to be so engaged walking around an empty building. Lovely.

Part madhouse, part heaven. There isn't an inch of surface in this building that isn't covered with texture. Some of it is just Gaudi itching to add decoration, and other parts are a testament to his architectural skill. Don't miss the world's maddest chimney pots. It's a small town house for such a rich owner, but there is a huge amount to see; and the audio guide is excellent. The local council have done a great job in restoring the house and opening it to the public.

Impressive.... Absolutely worths a visit! Maybe not so famous and not so typical for Gaudí from the first view, but absolutely gorgeous! In contrast to Pedrera or Casa Battlo it´s not so crowded so you´ re able to enjoy all aspect and all details of this fantastic building. Fabulous staircase, ceilings inlaid with expensive woods and magical ballroom...well, it´s not so bad to be immensely rich as Eusebi Guell was :-D

Amazing masterpiece in the city. I suspect the previous reviews may have got this mixed up with Gaudi's other creations, the Park Guell, Casa Battlo and Casa Mila. This is a house off La Rambla and is mostly indoors with a rear terrace and rooftop which you did not have to spend much time on if you did not want to.Visited this on a Sunday afternoon following a lazy lunch at Plaza which is just across the street. We had only read a short excerpt in our travel guide book so was not sure what to expect. Tickets cost €10 pp and comes with an audio guide which was very informative. The house is an impressive structure built over 6 floors measuring at just 500sqm. The attention to detail and the intricate carvings that was designed by Gaudi is simply mind blowing. The different ceilings and the dome in the house is something to behold. Definitely worth a visit.

at least, we saw it!!. This palace has been closed for years but finally we saw it!!It is another Gaudi's "jewel" togheter with Casa Battllo, la Pedrera and, for us,the best of all:the Sagrada Familia...There is no queue because many tourists prefer to visit other sites in Barcelona but they don't imagine what they loose ....Here you can see a house made for MrGuell and his family, with garage and stable and a chapel hidden by a door...all is perfec!! you can also hear the organ playing!!The ticket costs 10 euros...

Another Gaudi wonder. Gaudi is simply amazing. This palace is inspired by nature and is just so full of fun! You do have to pay an admission to get in though. However, the other house across is free and sells souvenirs and you can get a great view going up the tower.

Amazing Gaudi. Guell Palace visit offered more than expected. In the price of 10 euros you receive the audio-guide which coordinates you nicely through the house with lots of stories about Guell Family and the architecture/design of the Palace (cellar where the horses stayed, the entrance, music hall, the bedrooms). The roof terrace is very nice and offers a nice view over the city. In my opinion a visit to Guell Palace is a must in your Gaudi itinerary!
Gaudi & city views. Beautiful but full of tourists (just like me). May be better to go out of season if lots of people aren't your thing. Fantastic views of the city.

great look into gaudy genius and life in the 19th century. we found the visit to the palace ,a great experience to learn about gaudy work and the guell family.the palace is very impressive by it self .and the audio guide brings back to life the sounds from the past.a shade light on the brilliance if gaudy as architect.it was a great hour brake from the la ramblas hustle.we very much recommend this tour
Gaudi's subdivision. Just another of some absolutely incredible and mind boggling architecture, a must visit or you've missed out!

the gaudi experiance. ..our first time away without the children and what a way to celebrate my wifes birthday than with a trip to experiance the city of Barcelona. the strange art and archetecture makes for some spectacular viewing

Gaudi's work leaves you speechless. Even today we are amazed by Gaudi's concepts and work. Guell Palace is a masterpiece of design and urban planning. A lot of walking up and down, but plenty of places to rest and enjoy the view. Don't miss the open market and ceiling mosaics.

Amazing Architecture. I really enjoyed this tour. I wanted to go on the tour to learn about Gaudi's architecture, but for some reason the tour focuses too much on the Guell family. They incorporated several of the Guell daughters musical compositions into the tour for some reason and also talked a lot about the Guell families rich history. I would recommend Casa Batlló over this tour.
Another Gaudi wonder. Feel like i was at willy wonka's or the place has a disney flair to it. Again you will marvel at the genius that is Gaudi

Dark and Gothic. just off the Ramblas this is so easy to visit. Dark features, really characterful, another aspect to Gaudi. Great evidence of the construction, the brickwork in the basement is lovely. Don't miss it

Fab roof, very ostentatious. Although very dramatic and ostentatious, this building was not what I had expected to see from a piece of Gaudi's work. However, once we got to the rooftop I absolutely loved it - the chimneys are amazing and the views are fabulous. The visit itself includes a free audioguide and we followed this around. I found the bedroom areas quite boring as we were shown many rooms that were identical in decoration (and empty) and told about them. The organ music was fabulous though. If, like me, you're more into Gaudi's more modernistic work then I suggest Casa Batllo.I am a student and was able to get student discount even though I wasn't a student in Spain!

early design of Gaudi. the building was very different from the Casa Batlio. The shapes are traditional, iron, curves, red bricks, except the roof tops.The attics has a show and display of many workers involved in preserving this place as original as possible.The organ music seems to be played automatically which was very nicefree audio guide.

the middle ages. Clearly a house from Gaudi's early days. You can see the first steps towards the Batllo and Pedrera, but it looks far more medieval.Painstakingly restored with all the details that are so typically Gaudi. In this house you can clearly see in what direction he will move.
Gaudi architecture applied over a bigger space. It was very hot the day we went and quite crowded, but Gaudi's amazing architecture was in full view. Beautiful!

Must see!. I was a little hesitant to go in as the line was out the door and around the block and the admission price was more than I felt comfortable paying but.... I'm so glad I went! A highlight of the trip! It was a work of art. The inside was beautifully made and you can easily spend the whole entire day just walking around and around and taking everything in.

Great place !!. If you're a studier of Gaudi"s work, this "Palacio Guell" is a must see... Gaudi was commissioned to design and build this house and as all his work it is very interesting to say the least. A lot of mosaic work...and a great place to "people watch" !

A great attraction with lots of see and hear about. It cost us 10 euros each for entry and guided tour of Guell Palace. Compared to other attractions, this is good value for money. There's quite a lot to see here, and you are giving a hand held electronic guide in your language to tell you more about what you're looking at. The guide shows you the cellar where the horses stayed, the entrance, the very interesting music hall, the bedrooms, and best of all- the roof terrace- another classic Gaudi sight. Well worth a visit if you're in the area.

Expensive For What You Get. I kind of regret going to see Guell palace, it's a fine example of Gaudi's early workmanship but the only real points of interest was the outside gate and it's use of privacy (you can see out, but you can't see in), the main hall and the rooftop and it's chimneys.
Audio Tour Included. The audio tour is included - we went on the free day of the month. Takes 1-1.5 hours to complete. Really enjoyable and get up and personal with one of Gaudi's first works.

Anything Guadi is special. What Guadi has done across Barcelona is just special in every way, and I would say everything he has done is worth a visit. The only downside is it would be nice to actually look around the entire building and it just sectioned areas of it. From the outside it is just very different to everything and anything I have ever seen, similar inside, amazes one on how that man did what he did. Can be busy, like all of his attractions, so get down on opening or later afternoon. Well worth the visit for all, families, couples....

Beautiful and unique mansion, thorough tour. I really did not know what to expect from this attraction, a Gaudi-designed private mansion. But it's absolutely fantastic, with a great audio guide. Visitors are allowed to tour virtually the entire Palace (only a few rooms are off-limits). The guide was excellent - even my teenaged nephew was engrossed. There are wonderful descriptions of family life, and music of the period. It is interesting to see how an uberwealthy family lived at the time. Also, I have to say that the ticket-takers and docents were among the nicest we have encountered in Spain. Whoever is running this venue is doing a great job.

The most interesting thing I did in Barcelona!. I visited this building, almost by chance (I was looking for an internet cafe on the same street), with my mother. We took the 1hour audio guide tour, and it was absolutely worth it. This house is all about details, everywhere you turn it has been thought out. Definitely worth visiting.
Amazing chimneys. Well worth a visit if you're into architectureChimneys were amazing and the architecture inside the palace was really unusual gave my son some ideas for future projects

Gaudi's first work and worth a visit. Slightly difficult to spot but actually only a few meters off the Rambas so make the effort. Might even be owrth seeing this Gaudi work fist as you will then spot the differences with his later works.Good Audio tour which helps you understand what the thinking was for some of the areas, Stables, roof, some magnificent iron work, central rooms and living quaters.Worth the time which should be 1-2 hoursenjoy
Outstanding. First of all the visit to this Gaudi building only costs 10 euro compared to 16 or 20 euros for the others. I personally thought it was an amazing building.

Detail personified. do you ever see a house with this amount of detail? This man was wealthy...... he was regarded as the 20th wealthiest person in the world in the 1920, his wealth was 70 billion euros! tghe hosue is amazing, the detail is quite unbelievable! You must see this to understand what using an Architect is all about!
Great views but very busy. It has stunning views of the city. The architecture is simply gravity defying. Its very overun with tourists so dont expect to have the place to yourself.

Beautiful House. We weren't expecting much from this place, but it really surprised us, it ended up being our favourite attractions out of all the places we visited. Its a really lovely house which has been beautifully restored. The roof terrace is amazing. I would highly recommend visiting this place.
Interesting tour. There is a lot to see. Your tour is aided by a very helpful audio tour. Great views from the top of the building.
A must. Just rennovarted , really impressive Gaudi building. take your time to visit all floors and take the audi guide. Do not miis this Gaudi gem.

Art Nouveau Galore. Extremely interesting structure, clearly demonstrating that Gaudi was thinking out of the box. Reminds one of the play mansions of the high society in Newport, RI, USA, but those were built 30 years later and have none of the originality and elegance of Chez Guell.

WOW!. It's impossible to capture the experience of such a place in mere words alone. One has to visit to believe such structures! True to Guadi, all of his work references nature and is hard to tear away from. Loved this place!
great to see. Great to see,go in the morning to avoid the heat. advised get the tour in advance from internet to avoid not being able to enter or paying in Euro.

Interesting tour, crowded. A very interesting architectural tour of one of Gaudi's commissioned works. Gets a bit crowded at times and on very hot days can be very stifling inside the building. Great views from the rooftop. Go early in the morning or late in the afternoon to avoid the crush of tourists.
Amazing Gaudi. Another interesting architectural twist. Worth seeing. Very crowded which is distracting. In addition, ver hot in August.

If you don't want to line up to see Gaudi's work.... This palace is worth a check.
Like I wrote on the title, if you don't want to line up to see Gaudi's work because you're just passing through Barcelona or any other reason, then it's a nice place to drop by.

A Gaudi Masterpiece. Located just off the Ramblas this is an incredible building. The blending of styles is incredible. The visit was made all the more fantastic with the organ, autoplaying every half hour in the central hall.
Gaudi. this is close to Ramblas and if you love Gaudi's work you have to visit this palace. it cost 10 euro and you need 30-45 minutes to see it.
Gaudi's Guell Palace. Designed originally as a special housing development, only 3 lots were sold so it became a wonderful park instead. Lovely views, more amazing work by Gaudi.

Must. Finally opened after 20 years of restoration, ticket about Eur. 12,00. The building architecture is not as visionary as the one in Casa Battlò, but you can't help saying at the end of the tour that you would like to live in a house like this! Attention to any little detail reveals Gaudi as the best civil architect ever!

Incredible; Recommend to all.. Highly recommend all visiting Barcelona to visit the Guell Palace. The architecture is breathtaking. It is easy to find just off La Ramblas. Did not have to wait long in line. The audioguide was fantastic and very informative.

Fascinating house. We enjoyed our visit to Palau Guell. The tickets with timed entrance prevented waiting in line. The audiotour was very informative. The twenty year renovation of this house was amazing. It's early Gaudí but there's amazing craftsmanship and decoration of the place. Recommended.
Early Gaudi. Hard to imagine actually living in this building, but it has all the elements that Gaudi continued to develop and use. Great fun.

A great introduction to Gaudi. Chimneys are amazing. Audioguide included in admission.. We loved this palace. It was a great introduction to Gaudi and a great view of how the wealthy lived at the time. The three main highlights were the iron work, the chapel and the roof. The design of the chapel to make it look like there were stars on the ceiling was fascinating. The chimneys and the undulating roof was very interesting.We were travelling with our three small children and we were pleasantly surprised to find that the audioguide was included with the admission ... even for the kids. AND, they have a kids version of the audioguide with shorter explanations and theres a puzzle they can solve using the touchscreen on the audioguide. The older kids listened to the whole thing, while the younger enjoyed talking on their "cellphone".
Cool to see. This is cool to see, but take your picture and move on because the area around it is more encapsulating than the building itself

Well worth a visit.. Palau Guell was built for a very wealthy industrialist and was one of Gaudi's early commissions. No expense was spared in its construction so it truly reflects Gaudi's vision with curved lines, innovative use of materials, and a fantastic rooftop. Every visitor to Barcelona should visit at least one Gaudi house, and Palau Guell is very conveniently located to La Rambla and the Barri Gotic. Some writers have commented negatively on the cost, but these houses are expensive to restore and maintain, and tourists should bear their share of the cost. It is definitely worth going inside as you cannot appreciate Gaudi's genius just from the facade.

a MUST-SEE in Barcelona. If you go to Barcerlona and have more than one day to visit the city, you should definitively take some time to visit this wonderful building. Gaudi was genius that always invented new ways to marvel the observers of his art. The building has recently restored and now it shows all its beauty and charm.

Our favourite. We nearly missed this because it was not included in the tour guide we bought. Just off La Rambla, this had to be one of our favourite visits during our stay in Barcelona. The attention to detail that Gaudi took in designing every aspect of the house is amazing.

Without crowds, 5 stars. Likes:- creative architecture- Seeing the nature theme throughout the palace- His "home" and the behind-the-scenes work Gaudi did on Sagrada FamiliaDislikes:- Crowds- Heat- CrowdsOh --- and the long arduous walk to the top!!

An absolute gem. This palace was designed by Gaudí for Eugeni Güell, at the time one of the richest men in Europe. It's an amazing building, full of Modernista (Catalan Art Nouveau) details- and even a huge organ which is played regularly. It's dark and mysterious in parts, with typical Gaudí touches of curves and arches, gold leaf, dark stone, stained glass (I must say, I can understand that his wife didn't actually like living in it!). The view from the rooftop is splendid.Perhaps my only reservation is that it's not furnished and feels a bit "unloved". A good feature is that the audioguides are included in the 10 euro entrance fee, as well as an informative little booklet. Well worth a detour!

Well worth a visit. Guell Palace is just of the busy Las Ramblas, it is a haven of tranquility away from the hustle and bustle.
Another Gaudi masterpiece
Crowded but worth it. We went and it was amazingly crowded, but worth it anyways. It is beautiful and there is a great view of the city from the top.
Well worth a visit. Well worth the ten euros, was there for 2 hours, items in the shop were the cheapest out of all the Gaudi venues. No queue at 15.oo.
Something to Behold. The architecture was something to see. Gaudi's design and use of nature were terrific. Make sure you bring your camera.
too crowded in July. The Gaudi house was very interesting. Have a look if you can get a combined entrance ticket with other Gaudi experiences.

Visit it !. I only saw the Palace from outside and I couldnt visit because it is closed on Mondays.
But it is very impressive from the outside and I regret that I havent had the chance to see the Palace inside.

An incredible trip back in time. The architecture is stunning. The opulence is as well. I usually don't do the audio guide at museums, but I'd highly recommend it here as the information about Palace history is quite interesting.

Wit till you get inside. From outside this bulding looks quite austere and you may wondre of worth paying to go inside. Don't be fooled the inside is incredible, spread over 5 floors and once you get to the roof terrace and see the incredible chimneys you will be glad you made the effort

Gaudy, but not too "gaudy". Gaudy's first designed house. Guell spent lots of $ on the house. It's called a palace, but really a mansion where folks actually lived. Really neat tech and design from Guell's time. Amazing wood work too.
Definitely a must see!. It was mid-day when we went so it was hot. I would recommend you do it early in the day. Great views of the city and should not be missed.

Amazing Gaudi palace and great value. This was the first Gaudi building I visited in Barcelona and it was one of the best. Despite the outside being very dull, if you pay the very reasonable (compared to other Gaudi sites) entrance fee then you are greeted by a lovely house. Most of the house is open and there is a very good audio-guide to help you understand Gaudi's original architecture. The best parts are by a long way the light well and the roof which has the most amazing chimneys, most of which can't be seen from the street. Overall this was an excellent house that is really worth visiting.
Worth seeing. Fantastic house, really good audio guide, one of the highlights of our trip.

Amazing!. We went round this Palace (House) and the brilliance of the architect is just breathtaking. You will be amazed at all the different things which the architect thought of and designed. The commentary goes on a bit, but it is well worth the entrance fee. Tip, there are toilets.

Interesting and educational. Tickets can be bought at a kiosk further up the street (there is s bank in-between the kiosk and the museum). The audio guides are excellent and they have a super version for children which keeps them occupied while at the museum.

Interesting early work by Gaudi. This is not as much fun as some of Gaudi's later works, (except the roof), so if going with the family be aware that it is much more like a small modernist stately home. However it is interesting and beautiful and worth a visit.

A Bizarre but Wonderful Mix of Gothic and Art Nouveau. This is one of the earliest major buildings by Gaudi. Taken with visits to La Pedrera and Casa Battlo, you can see his development as an architect of unique if bizarre talent. Much of it is darkly Gothic (think Manchester Town Hall on a small scale) but some is exciting Art Nouveau, particularly the roof.

Stunning!. Somthing you can see easily in a morning as you stroll down Las Ramblas. Recently refurbished this is well worth a small diversion. A family home (well it was!), with its own private golden chapel - religious opulence at its worst and best. You also get to hear the organ playing music composed by original members of the family Guell.
Chimneys and Wrought Iron marvels. I love Gaudi, if he were alive now, I'd have to commision him for my house. Worth a look, just for the chimmneys and the Ironwork. So much detail, everywhere.....

Well worth seeing. If you are inspired by Gaudi and his work this is certainly worth a visit. It gets rather crowded in the high season so probably better visited in spring or autumn when you can take more time to browse.
early Gaudi masterpiece. an early example of Gaudi's work, just off La Rambla, well worth a visit, the underground stables with circular ramp, and the gilded chapel are amazing!
Great Example of Gaudi Architecture. Surprisingly short line to get in. Excellent audio guide. Wonderful Gaudi architecture. Great views from the rooftop.

Don't visit on a hot day!. Arrive early, try to avoid the inevitable crowds. It's a beautiful place to visit, no matter how many times you may have seen it. Children will get a kick out of it, a surprising change from churches and museums.
Worth a visit. We did the audio tour and from start to finish it was great. It got better and better finishing finally on the roof with the chimneys.

Intricate woodwork, and grandeur.. This was our first stop to Gaudi's creation. The neighborhood itself has many places to see. I recommend listening to the audio guide to appreciate fully this building. The friendship between the owner Guell and builder Gaudi is very heartwarming, and the woodwork is nothing we have seen before. Although a bit too grand and stuffy for my taste, the craftsmanship is impeccable, and the creativity behind every detail was inspirational. If you appreciate arts and craft, or simply loves a good story of friendship between two men, this is a great place to be.
You need to visit. Unik buildings and architecture.Great view of the city.
Great Experience. Audio guide was excellent and locations for each clip were well displayed. Guide was informative but not overwhelming, and worth the price

Do not miss it!!!!. We caught an excellent guided English tour , and were able to visit this Music Hall at a leisurely pace. The details inside this masterpiece are out of this world. My 7 & 10 year kids were able to walk away with a wealth of information on famous Spanish architects of that time, that contributed towards creating Palau Guell.
Amazing. Amazing, you will take wonderful photos there , go up and see a beautiful view

Breathtaking.. First time to Barcelona as a student and it is definitely pricey to go into any of the main Gaudi attraction. The Palau Guell is near the La Rumbla and it was totally worth my 8 Euro student fee. The free audio tour was fantastic and the Palace has been beautifully restored. Don't miss this!

A bit of Gaudi-ness. What an amazing palace!!! The tour has a audio guide in several languages, that will guide you through this most innovative property. Gaudi was very much ahead of his time. Well worth your time and money.
Art nouveau comes to life. It surpassed my expectations. Gaudi thought of everything in designing this building. Highly recommended

Another brilliant Gaudi building!. A Unesco World Heritage site. Designed and built with money as no object for Guell, the main patron of Gaudi. The ceiling in the Great Parlor and the basement where the stables and grooms' quarters are just amazing. The tour of the building ended on the roof top with a wonderful sight of colourful ceramic chimneys. Great view from there.
Worth Your While. Simply beautiful. Don't miss this gem. Early Gaudi at its finest, and newly restored to really make it sing.

Another Gaudi masterpiece.. We enjoyed our visit, unfortunately were unable to go on the roof due to heavy rain. Despite it's size the Palau Guell is very impressive and a very personal home . Not a show piece. Our visit was free, as the last Sunday of the month several sites are free.

Recommended by Barca people themselves. Only the basement and ground floor are open to visitors.
It's a palacial home designed and built primarily by Gaudi with all the brilliance you might expect.

One of Gaudi's first buildings. It is very easy to walk past this building tucked away on Nou de Ramblas and it always appears to be shut. That's because there are guided tours only. from the outside it looks dark and a bit forboding, but is full of surprises inside

This palace is well worth a look!. This palace is renowned for its spectacular chimneys done in different coloured mosaics. They have restored all the levels beautifully and given it is less known than some of teh other Gaudi buildings it wasnt so crowded.

Another Gaudi gem!. The Guell Palace is a luxurious and opulent mansion designed with the creative vision from Gaudi. Guell is a rich tycoon who commissioned a number of Gaudi's works and is partly responsible for spreading Gaudi's influence. You'll get a feel for the lifestyle of rich people back in the industrial age.Definitely worth the tour! The highlights for me were the sky ceiling and the colorful structures on the roof. This was one of Gaudi's earlier works so you'll be able to compare this with his other works and see how he progressed as an architect/artist.

Astonishing palace. Another Gaudi treasure! Unassuming palace from the exterior located off La Rambla, the amazing chimneys which can be seen from outside are probably the least exciting part of the builidng. Every room completely different from the last and the next one - each one with the 'wow' factor! Beautiful!

Don't Miss This. All the previous reviewers got it right: this is an exceptional jewel from top to bottom. It's a palace inside though you might not know it from the exterior, which is how it was designed. If possible, see Palau Guell before visiting Sagrada Familia and see how the stupendously wealthy lived in the 19th century. For architectural fans and history buffs, you will feel like a child in a candy store. It is two or three blocks away from Le Meridien Hotel, on a side street straight down La Rambla. If you're over 65 years, request the seniors rate. This applies to all attractions and museums.

A Palatial Mansion. This place is just amazing and has many many things to see. It is hardly at a distance of 50-70 feet from the La Ramblas street. To start with there is a Horse stable in the basement, then there is a wonderful staircase, rooms with many things to see, ceilings, fine artwork everywhere, glass, wood, stairs, furniture, etc.. This building even has a chapel in it. This place is just amazing. Tour ends on the roof which has Gaudi's Iconic chimneys. Audio guide is highly recommended. It takes around 45 mins to 1 hr to visit this place. There are lockers available. There is store on the ground floor inside the building where you can buy many things especially the Gaudi's chimney shaped key chains which you perhaps do not get elsewhere.

Palau Guell is a jewelbox. The Palau Guell is a jewelbox and to quote my husband, "You have no idea from the outside how insane it is on the inside." I would add insanely beautiful. Otherworldly. No one transforms and layers materials like Gaudi. It's also a little over the top. And if you like architecture history, this project sets the stage for all his other commissions to come, including the Sagrada Familia. You get to see everything from the vaulted stables to the undulating rooftop. It's a block off the Rambla on Carrer Nou, and well worth the ten euro price of admission (audio tour is included).

Beautiful. In the middle of nowhere such a majestic home! You can feel the love that Gaudi poured his work! The detail and only the best in materials! The audio headsets literally made the Palau come alive! Right in Las Ramblas where as far as we are concerned is SAFE! Enjoy and take in all of Barcelona!

Quirky palace in the city. This is one of the least visited Gaudi buildings so it doesn't have the long lines the others have. As a result you get in and out fairly quickly without being crowded or rushed. Enjoyed seeing the inner designs and the art moderne style.
Gaudi!. After several Barcelona trips finally made it here ( long queues on previous visits put us off!!) Worth every minute and one of the few audiotour guides I have had that were useful!
It's Amazing. Cheaper and more beatiful than the batlÃ² house!! The visit of palau guell is amazing and the audio guide is very well done!
Don't miss going to the roof!. A very interesting building to view. I could have stayed on the roof all day!

Architectural Wonder. I've viisted Barcelona 6 times and am a lover of all things Gaudi. I was excited to learn that Palau Guell was open this year after 22 years of renovation. It's a stunning palace and, as an organist, I was thrilled to see and hear a beautiful organ that was built for the space. I would recommend Palau Guell to any lover of beauty.

Amazing. We had low expectations of the Palau as the exterior looked less impressive than other Gaudi buildings and the entry fee was lower than others. We were very pleasantly surprised at the beauty and creativity and richness of the interior. We found it the most interesting, impressive and harmonious of all the residential buildings. Perhaps because it was designed for one familiy, rather than as a block of apartments. You are able to explore a large proportion of the building, over many floors, including a great roof terrace. The audiguide was particularly good and engaging. This was a real highlight of Barcelona for us.
Loved it. If you go take your time, some things I can,t imagine at the time this was built. Amazing. it was not gaudy until you get to the roofAntonio Gaudi was well

Gaudi Right Off the Ramblas. This first home that Gaudi's constructed was closed during our last trip and I'm so glad we had the opportunity to see it. What a visionary! It's a long trek to the top but make sure you make it to the roof. Gaudi has special touches throughout but the rood is a real treat.
Great Gaudi design.. Lots of unusual features in this home. Make sure and get audioguide to understand all the details and history of what you are seeing.
What a house!. Fantastic architecture, fantastic audio guide, fantastic detail inside and out.

Amazing Visiting. the ticket office close 1 hour before the Palau Guell(it closes at8:oopm), I went there around 6:45pm, there were only a few visitors. Recommend to visit it after 6pm if you wish to visit this place in nice and quiet time.
very nice. strong architec concept of Gaudi. Just go and enjoy. Book online!
Spectacular!. Wish I could live there! Gaudi thought of everything; spacious and luxurious. Even the chimneys are unique.

What a treat. Having only ever seen the outside of Gaudi houses we made the most of the free entry 1st sunday of the month to visit this 1 located just off las Ramblas nr Placa Reail.
Must see the roof top!
Absolutely amazing. The architecture is astonishing. Shapes, colors and ergonomics all blended. Lots of people and in the summer, very hot.

Incredible place, just, too many toursits. Incredible place, just, too many tourists. Were hot, but nice, and this is just amazing how one person could create new style, something different and so simple

Amazing Architecture. A visit to Palau Guell is a must in Barcelona. This building is a Gaudi masterpiece, and the tour with headphones enables one to understand the significance of what you are seeing. Don't miss it!
Expensive but worth every cent!. If you are interested in Gaudi's work - this is a must see! This place is just off the Rambla so it's on your way.
Loved it.. A little expensive to get in but a beautiful palau.

Favorite of the Gaudi Sights. Loved this Gaudi designed home. Right in the center of Barcelona, it is fascinating to imagine that a family actually lived here. So many unique design elements that it really shows the breadth of Gaudi's genius

outstanding building. Just off Ramblas only 20 meters to the right towards el RAVAL on new CARRER RAMBLA.,You can continue on this street till Rambla de Raval and turn up towards the stalls selling different cultural articles . A nice place to rest near the giant sculpture of a BLACK CAT.
Newly opened star attraction. Gorgeous detail, beautiful curves. Amazing form following function. A Gaudi must see.
Loved this palace!. It's worth getting there early to get in line for when they open. You will marvel at the decor and find it very fun experience.
another nice building to see. good to see, but two and half hours in quewe. Expansive tickets. I thik that the spanish are sorting recession this way- from tourists pockets.

Your eyes will not believe it. Wonderful experience. We were initially put off by the high entrance price, but it is worth every penny. Get there early before all the parties descend. You can either pay in cash or by card. Shop very interesting but oh those prices!

A interesting and inspirational place to visit. Brilliant insight into the work of Antoni Gaudi and the lifestyle of the family who lived here. Interesting place to visit - very well-restored, with an interesting exhibition on how this was done in the roof.
Stunning!. A great place to see the wonderful works of Gaudi. The headsets really make it
Amazing inside. Didn't have a chance to see Gaudi's other houses, but went inside this one. For about ten euros, you get an audio guide as well. Spectacular view from roof top.

Gaudi architecture. Reopened earlier last year following restoration work, Count Guell's small palace just of Las Ramblas is beautiful. You pay 10 euros for a ticket and the audio tour guide in English starts from the stables in the bottom of the palace & goes to the wonderful Gaudi rooftop.Fascinating building giving an insight into life at the time. You can take photographs but can't use a flash.Well worth a visit - you won't be disappointed

Take the time to inspect the designs of Gaudi at Palau Guell. My wife and I walked by the Palau Guell late one afternoon on our trip to Barcelona. Unfortunalely, we didn't have time to go inside, but the visitor photos make this site a place well worth seeing. Gaudi was a genius with his inspired designs.
Another lovely building. Another building we didnt go inside (bring plenty of money if you want to do it all) the LP guide said this was free unfortunately that is out of date and it is not.
Breathtaking. To think that Gaudi was commissioned to build this house when he was fresh out of school!! Take the audio guide, and take the time to look at the details.
Great building. Wonderful example of Gaudi and different from the apartment building elsewhere in the city - check when you are going we got in free when we when we went there!

A good introduction to Antonio Gaudi!. The entry ticket is only 10 Euros Vs. 15+ for the some of the other Gaudi buildings. It comes with an audio tour. You may want to fast forward through it after 5-6 stops (out of a total of 20+). The message is simple: Gaudi is a creative genius. Please assess it on your own. I did not get a very homey feeling from that house. But do NOT miss the roof top. With its great views and very, very creative chimneys.

Quirky place. Great place to spend a couple of hours. Stunning architecture and ideas. Far too many people in the entrance levels (lots of student parties) but once we got to the second level it evened out.

Interesting. This is unmistakably Gaudi, but not so bright and colourful as some of his other work. There is a lot of interesting architectural detail, but very less in the way of furniture and household items than his other houses. Because this is not such a popular attraction, it does not seem to get so crowded, so you have time and space to admire this lovely house. The free audio guide was useful.

Okay.. We didn't go inside the Palau, as the line was too long (we came here at about noon), and we also considered the fee to be quite high - 10€.But from the outside, the building is quite nice. At least the lower part is. It has a wonderful gateway, and some nice ornaments, worth seeing.It's just a minute of La Rambla, so you can pop by while strolling on La Rambla.

Amazing. Another building showcasing the imaginative mind of Gaudi. Amazing talent. Try to arrive when the building opens. We were distracted by the coin, stamp, and knickknack sale in Placa Rieal that happens every Sunday morning, and didn't arrive until 10:30, there was a 15 min wait to get in. The roof and the bedrooms were our favorite places.
Avoid the crowds. The thick crowd spoiled it for us. Best to go real early, if only for a good shot of the staircase. Otherwise, it's a tourist trap!

Fascinating home, well preserved, Gaudi was a genius. We spent more than 2 hours today touring this home, the palatial city mansion of the Guell family. The design by Gaudi is wonderful; be sure not to miss the roof! The tour is informative with the tour-in-an-audio-box, but just seeing the creative application of Gaudi's vision made for a very worthwhile tour. Of course La Sagrada Familia is a masterpiece; this is a more consumable version of the same creative mind and well worth touring.
Must see it to believe it!!. The incredible workmanship thruout this site is fabulous. Either Gaudi was a genius or he was a madman. Either case, most enjoyable & a once in a lifetime experience.
Silent but worth it. Just set off the ramblas you will have to queue up for your ticket.Inside the silence and the masterpieces will make you travel through time.

Esoteric and interesting but I wouldn't want to live here!. A lot of people here made the tour a little agonizing. I gave up on the audio tour after making it halfway through. For me it was mostly about the architecture and design, and trying to capture some nice photos of it all. But with so many people it is not easy to snap good pics, you'd have to spend all day here to do that. But we did spend about 1.5 hours and in the end the crowd and repetition was wearing on me. I only give it 3 stars because while I enjoyed the architectural merits of the place, I didn't appreciate how someone could live in such a place. I prefer form and function like a Howard Roark, rather than a gaudy Gaudi!
Fascinating. One masterpiece of Gaudí... The details of the construction of this palace can only be appreciated with our eyes. There's no cameras that can make a proper description.

Very impressive. This was the first time we had seen this magnificent mansion. It is quite different (more sombre and dark) to the other Gaudi houses we have seen, but it has the same attention to detail and quality, and the same wonderland of a roof terrace.

Build it, Antoni! Money's no object!. That must surely be what Eusebi Guell gave Antoni Gaudi as his working guidelines when he set him to work building this opulent piece of residential overkill. This exercise in spend, spend, spend was Gaudi's first major work....and turned out to be what became Gaudi's standard, over-the-top, signature style.Must be seen to be believed. I didn't see the stats on how many craftsmen actually toiled over the details in this magnificent tribute to the skilled use of chisels and saws, but Norm Abram must have been dumbfounded and awestruck when HE first saw it!For sure, put it in your top 10 to-do list when in Barcelona.
Impressive construction. Was very much interested in visiting it and the work of Gaudi really impressed us a lot. Spent more than two hours inside and took lots of pictures

Interesting building, beautiful roof. The building was interesting, and, once again, I loved Gaudi's roof with the wonderful chimneys! They are amazing and worth the visit. The terrace at the top is beautiful as are the views.

The early beginning's of Gaudi. Of all of Gaudi's works I had a chance to visit, Palau Guell was the most informative and well maintained construction. Recently reopened after a lengthy renovation, the Palau shows a different side to Gaudi's work as interesting as his most famous works. A super informative audio guide is included in the entrance fee and I didn't face any lines as this isn't one of his most famous works.
Stupendous. Now that it has been repaired it is even better than years ago. Be sure you go to the roof. Last time I was in Barcelona it was closed for the repairs. It was worth the wait.
Best Guadi building to visit!. Beautifully restored and not overcrowded as you go around. Our true FAVOURITE barcelona experience. We learnt so much and loved it.

Pricey but nice roof!!. Recent renovation work means the entrance fee is now of gargantuan proportion, and whilst I'm not entirely sure the interior was enough to make it worth it, I did love the rooftop area. Although even that was spoiled a bit by being a few feet away from a rundown hotel whose manky laundry room now features in my photographs! I know that a lot of Gaudi's architecture being in such built up areas means (very) close proximity to ordinary buildings, and that ina way adds to the appeal, but I do think that the area around this 'mansion' should be kept in better condition.

Extraordinary Creation. The Palau Guell is early Gaudi and a great place to start your exploration of his works as if you visit his buildings in chronological order you can see how his style develops and evolves. I had visited once before when the restoration was in progress and at that time could only see the cellar and roof top, to see the rest of the house and the incredible detail of the work involved was fabulous. Entrance fee including audio guide was about 10 euros.

best way to learn about Gaudi's life and work. With so many attractions to see in Barcelona, initially we just wanted to make some picture outside Palau Guell. The point is that you can't do relevant pictures because the building ios on a relatively narrow street. So, after peaking on the main entrance and discovering that the cue was not long we decided to buy tickets and visit the Palau. It was worth every penny of the EUR 10 price for adults (kids visit for free). You get to know about gaudi's life and friendship with his main sponsor Guell while exploring a representative masterpiece of his creation. It's a luxury residence actually inhabited by a (rich) family so you get to see how Gaudi thought of making their living pleasant and functional.The roof is even more spectacular with interesting slopes and splendid tilled chimneys which are a trademark of Gaudi.Go there, it will be a well invested one hour of your trip to Barcelona.
Wonderful renovation. After many years of renovation is now open and well worth a visit, wheelchair friendly except roof with chimneys, allow at least 1-2 hours

Great Gaudi experience, worthy alternative to other Gaudi sights. Although this sight is off the Rambla, it's far less visited than other, more famous Gaudi sights (Casa Battlo,Sagrada Familia,Parc Guell, and La Pedrera) making it easier to appreciate the sight as it was intended to be experienced by its creator. Note that if it's raining, you won't get roof access.

worth a visit. We all enjoyed this special building. Audio tour is included in the price and really enjoyable. Sadly on our visit we could not get onto the roof to see the chimneys up close. Still well worth including in your trip.

looking from outside is better. Outside is better than the inside. If you enter to all of Gaudi's works and pay the entrance fees, it will cost you a fortune. So you can skip this one if you are on a budget. It is nice for people like me who has seen others (this one was closed for a long time for restoration) but not for a new visitor/backpacker.

fascinating. Gaudi was a genius. My favorite part of the building was the sculptural looking chimneys - some decorated in mosaic tiles and each one different. It was difficult to find the steps leading to the roof but worth the climb.

Wow!. We have visited Barcelona before and dont know how we missed this hidden gem! We just happened to look up and saw the infamous work of Gaudi in the chimney pots but the inside of what must be the smallest palace in terms of square footage was a real find!
Must See. Put this on your short list for Barcelona. Absolutely stunning. The audio guide is a must. This was about my favorite site in the city.

Amazing...don't miss!. This is right off La Ramblas...follow the big flag-like signs. We didn't know what to expect, and we were blown away by this house. This is much darker than Casa Batllo, but it's a must see. Gaudi was a genius. Since this house recently reopened after many years of renovation, not so many people were visiting. The rooftops are amazing on his houses. Be sure to listen to the guided tour to appreciate what you are seeing. It's nice that they have lockers in all the houses, as well.
early gaudi. i used the audio guide which gave a really interesting insight to the building, rooftop again! absolute highlight, beautifully being restored.
Not just another Gaudi. This is the best Gaudi example of all. Better value than some of the others and well worth the visit. Centrally located and beautifully restored. Thoroughly recommend.

Another interesting work by Gaudi. If you like architecture, then this is a quick and easy visit. It's an easy walk from Catalunya station, 15 minutes and directly off Las Ramblas.Buy the ticket in the office next to the bank a few steps before the Palau, and go in.

Less crowded than other ‘Gaudis’. Highly recommended and worth seeing. It is not as often visited as other Gaudi’s jewels as it is a bit different in style (Gaudi was just ‘warming up’ while working on this project), but surely should not be missed. It gives a great insight into a mind of the genius. It is less crowded and not as pricy as other Gaudi’s buildings. The audio guide gives a lot of details and the tour of the building with the audio guide it is a must.

If You Appreciate Beautiful Architecture, Visit Palau Guell. This beautiful former mansion located in the historic district of Barcelona brings you back in time. The audio guide is superb, even includes some music composed by one of the family member's. Well worth your one hour time spent.

Unique. One of Gaudi's first major commissions in Barcelona. A unique urban palace, with some very unique features.
Entry: 10 euros.
Time: About 45 minutes.

Don´t miss this!. Palau Güell is Gaudí´s first Modernista work, begun in 1886. It was very expensive to build as Güell required the best materials available, and the plans were changed many times.The palace was confiscated by the anarquists during the Civil War in the 1930s, and was used as barracks for soldiers (and the basement as a prison!).It was obviously very run down, and changes were made several times during the 20th century. In 1986 the palace was declared Human Heritage by UNESCO.It was been closed for several years for extensive restoration work at the beginning of this century, but after painstaking work it has now been restored closely to its original.There is a very good itinerary you can follow with the use of audio guides, from the basement whih housed the stables, to the roof with its 20 impressive chimneys surrounding the spire of a dome.There is also an exhibition of the restoration work in the attic (which used to be servant quarters, kitchen and laundry).I paid 8€ as over 65 and my younger wife 10€. Well worth the price. GO!

A great gem!. Our hotel (Hotel Gaudi) was located directed across from the Palau. The details that Gaudi incorporated into the design of the Palau are incredible and must be appreciated. The headset with detailed information is well worth it and much appreciation would be lost without. Thank you to Senor Guell for being a patron of Anton Gaudi and allowing us the privilege of seeing his great work!!

Stunning. The work undertaken by the Barcelona authorities to restore this important Palace really pays off. The information about eh restoration and the details of the collaboration between Guell and Gaudi and of the familiy of 10 children who lived there really brought the building to life

Don't miss it. If you like to know how people lived in the past, if you're a fan of interiors and architecture, don't miss it! And do take the audioguide, it is perfect and it is included in the ticket.

Awesome. This is one of Gaudi's early houses, but it is spectacular. It is artistic and functional at the same time. The price of admission is also better than others of his design so this should be high on your list.

Wonderful. Visited with my mother and we were astounded by the house and the exquisite decor, and the audio guides were really good too which i normally wouldnt bother with!Only downside is amount of school tours as the children were very keen to get past us on very narrow steps and being very pushy!

The Palau is not to miss!. It never stops surprising me how Gaudi could be so broad-minded, imaginative and creative to picture and to build all-in-one buildings or rather homes! This Palau is an excellent example of how Gaudi incorporated space, natural light and air with architecture, structures and use of different materials (wood, glass, iron etc)! And it's amazing how the design doesn't confront with the functionality of the home! From the practical basement through the charming living rooms to the ornamental and functional roof-top - the building is just a gem! Audiotour is very helpful, informative and interesting. The Palau is just off La Rambla.
A must see if you love Gaudi's work. Palau Guell was Gaudi's first major work and it's amazing, the detail level the richness takes about an hour to look at the house, but it is really worth it!
More Gaudi. Terrace was closed as it was raining. Otherwise it was great. Audioguide very efficient I thought. Mr Guell was a very rich fellow!! All that gold leaf!!

A gem open again!. Wonderful masterpiece of Gaudi' at 50 mt from las Ramblas.
Every room is a discovery!
Worth a trip to Barcelona!
imaginative. fascinating gaudi palace- a must see. Make sure you have alook at the roof and chimnies
Wierd!!. Mind boggling place - every where you went in this extraordinary building we were confronted by another piece of Modernista jaw dropping room interior
Cumbrian Couples. Fine visit, make sure you get to hear the organ and visit the roof.

Amazing Gaudi designed building. I actually thought the tour of this building was more interesting than the more famous Casa Mila and Casa Batilo. Like most Gaudi buildings, words cannot do a good job of describing them. Do miss this building!
Gray. It is a surprise. Situated very close to La Rambla it is worst to visit. Take audio guide , it will help a lot to understand what you see
WOW you have to see this. This is somewhere we will go back to again and again, Gaudi was a genius and this is a mark of his talent. The drunken temple is amazing. Just go

Early signs of genius. The Palau is an early Gaudi project and his choice of materials and design concepts are harbingers of things to come in his career. The tour is well organized with audio guides with well spoken and well written commentary. Definitely worth a visit for Gaudi enthusiasts.

The least inspiring of the Gaudi Buildings. On a recent trip to Barcelona I was so fascinated by the Gaudi’s buildings, I made sure I visited as many as possible. This one however was a little disappointing. If it had been the first one I had visited I may not have been so keen to visit the others. The house is very dark and has a slightly claustrophobic feel even though it is a very large house. It does not have the inspiring feel of the other houses, its more conservative and in some ways a little ordinary. The chimneys on the roof have the characteristic crazy shapes and mosaic glass tiles of the other houses, but they don’t have the same magic. I would only recommend visiting the Palau Guell if you want to understand how Gaudi developed his style, as this is not an example of his best work.

a Gaudí masterpiece; jewelbox craftsmanship on mansion scale; a must-see sight. Palau Güell (Güell Palace) is a must-see sight of Barcelona. It is also a must-see for anyone seeking insights into the life and work of architect Antoni Gaudí i Cornet (1852-1926), and his patron, the industrialist and polymath, Eusebi Güell i Bacigalupi (1846-1918). It is one of the great monuments of "catalanismo", the insistence-on-being-different cultural pride movement of the Cataluña region.We have never seen anything else like this house, anywhere in the world. The nearest comparison in fantasy domestic architecture is the Moller House in Shanghai. Imagine an ornate carved jewellery box constructed of exotic dark hardwoods and elaborately inlaid with ivory, greenstone, marble, agate, and other polished precious materials, with panels of gold, bronze and mica. Extend this image to the scale of a five-storey mansion, give it a protective outer shell of stone embellished with wrought iron, mosaic tile, and frosted and stained glass, and you have something like the extraordinary work of imagination and craftsmanship in Palau Güell.The house was one of the first big commissions Gaudí received from Güell at the beginning of their long association over a span of about 40 years. Like much Catalan modernist architecture, it evokes ambiguity: it is jawdroppingly beautiful, but wildly impractical and challenging to a sense of what most people can live with every day. Its polished gilded gloominess would make an exquisite film set for a Harry Potter movie or a remake of the Addams Family. It is difficult to imagine living in its gloom as a family home, with young children, as evidently Güell did until 1910 he moved out to a new house in what is now Parc Güell on the heights above Barcelona. It remained a Güell family residence until 1945, when it was sold to the Diputació Barcelona (Barcelona Provincial Council) for use as a museum.The mansion has been meticulously restored in several major projects, and is still maintained and operated by the Diputació Barcelona. When we visited in February 2012, every one of its five floors above ground, and the cellars, attic and roof with its Gaudí-typical tiled chimney pots and vents, were open to visitors, and were in prime condition. There was a fascinating exhibition explaining restoration work. Self-guided audio tour units were available. Adult entry per person when we visited was €8 per person. At the time of writing, the official website for Palau Güell http://www.palauguell.cat/ (in English, French, Spanish and Catalan) indicates the general public entry as €10, while the €8 tariff applies to students, over-65s, and groups.A pleasant and practical 4km "Gaudí walk" route is from La Sagrada Familia via Carrer de Provença to the Pedrera, then southeast down stylish, boutique-filled Passeig de Gràcia past Casa Batlló, through Plaza Cataluña and La Rambla, to Palau Güell in the side-street Carrer Nou de la Rambla. This makes a great leisurely day walk, with a break for lunch in one of the many restaurants or bars in the lower end of Passeig de Gràcia or Plaza Cataluña. Be vigilant against pickpockets and bag snatchers operating in the busier areas.

Another stunning Gaudi designed building. This building has been lovingly restored to as new condition and it is spectacular. The sheer attention to detail and quality of the design and workmanship is breathtaking. Unsurprisingly, Ernesto Guell, who commissioned the building, was said to be worth $70Bn in today's money. Clearly cost was no obstacle in this project. Magnificent.
stunning. A study in opulence and granduer, a must see. Gaudi's imagination and attention to detail is amazing.

Don't miss this!. The audiotour is very helpful. This home is fascinating in its history, the history of the Guell family / Gaudi connection, and in its features and contents. The organ plays for about 5 minutes every half-hour...an added treat. The roof is the most whimsical of Gaudi's roofs.
Just a sandland. It is big and full of people. But once you know the idea of Gaudi design from Sagrada Familia, it just another copy of it, nothing special.

Well worth searching this out.. This amazing palace shows another side of Gaudi' vision, and it is definitely worth seeing. The self-guided audio tour was very well done, but the palace is the star. Don't skip it!

A Gaudi masterpiece. Aftr a couple of years of restoration - well worth a visit - and as a timed entrance the numbers are not ovewhelming. Lots of beautiful features and worth the view from the roof overlooking the chimney pots

Another amazing Gaudi House. We visited the Palau Guell just off the Rambla and it was another example of the growth of Gaudis architectural style.
Well worth using the audio guide to enhance your experience, and the roof top was lovely, along with the amazing internal layout.

One of Gaudí's best works. This little-known early work of Gaudí's is off the beaten track, and is well worth the visit. Not the same as Gaudí's other works, so don't go if you just want to see another Casa Mila or Park Güell, but through this building you really get a sense of the simple architectural genius of Gaudí.

Another great Gaudi house. At 10 euros, this is much cheaper than the other Gaudi attractions but you are still provided with a detailed tour complete with a free audio guide. This house is very nice and a fantastic job has been done with the restoration.  I didn't find this building as unique and crazy as Casa Mila and Casa Batllo, perhaps as it is one of Gaudi's earlier works, but its still worth a look and great value. I especially liked the chimneys on the rooftops, and the details in the iron work.

Very good audio tour. I enjoyed the audio tour of this house very much. Again lots of interesting details and historical information about what was what and how it had been used, or what the purpose of the design had been. There were a lot fewer people visiting this one compared to other Gaudi works, too, which was a nice break from the crowds.

Beautiful but sombre. Yes, I know this is one of Gaudi's masterpieces but it left me strangely unmoved. I found the place very cold and gloomy and not at all the sort of place I'd expect to live comfortably in. Nevertheless it is a fascinating building.....almost Tolkeinesque in many respects.
Spent hours there!. Beautiful, amazing views, Gaudi's house in the compound...incredible place!
BETTER THAN IT MIGHT LOOK. An insight into Gaudi`s work. If you really cannot cope with heights you will miss the amazing roof.
Lovely building and good concert venue. Nice guitar concert in a splendid environment. A very enjoyable night. Recommended

If you visit one Gaudi building, make it this one!. Traipsing around historical houses is not normally our cup of tea, but we loved this tour. Gaudi's first major project in Barcelona for the rich industrialist Guell to have a his beautiful city house just off Les Ramblas (his wife hated it apparently, mine didn't!) You get an amazing tour using audio phones which told you not only about the house and Guadis architecture but also the unique relationship between Gaudi's and his chief sponsor Guell but he was also his best friend!The house has been restored by Barcelona local authorities and in my opinion they have done an amazing job. Probably more incredible for a council run business like this was the very friendly and helpful service from all the guides when inside. Thank you.Once you have been here you will understand most of the basics about Gaudi and can probably skip quite a few other Gaudi tours. It was certainly enough for us and when we visited Guell Park, Sagria Familia etc we just walked around and admired his work understanding how he had done it. Only cost 10 Euro to get in and there was a 2 Euro concession for OAPs and students. Great value.
very cool!. Another awesome Gaudi attraction that is free on the first Sunday of every month. It includes the audio guide which is very informational. Huge house with so many intricate facets.

Reopened - refreshed and stunning. After an extensive restoration this masterpiece of an upper-class private residence glows. Just off the Ramblas, we scheduled for a 90 minute visit and after an engrossing 3 hours still felt like we rushed through the last few exhibits. Sets of china were fired then broken just to make the mosaics for the chimneys!!

Another amazing monument to Gaudi's genius. Don't miss the Palau Guell just off La Rambla. They only allow a certain number of visitors at a time into this old mansion of a wealthy Barcelona family. This means you are not crowded out as you crane your neck to see the unique decoration. Get the audio guide so you understand what you are seeing.
A place to visit. Very pretty palace, with audio guide full of interesting details. Shame there is no furniture left.
Great Views. Gaudi Again!! He left his imprint here on the heights to seal his love of Barcelona. Loved his house. The furniture exhibit was inspirational.
Stunning. Amazing example of Gaudi's work just off the Ramblas and the whole building is oprn to the public. Free audio guide and entry within 15 mins of buying tickets. Highly recommended.
A masterpiece of colours. Another wonderful work by Gaudi, you have to see it to believe it. One of the best assets of Barcelona and a MUST when visiting the city. Loved it!!!

Mansion in Barcelona. It is a mansion in Barcelona, designed by Antoni Gaudí for the Catalan industrial tycoon Eusebi Güell. The home is centered on a main room for entertaining high society guests. The main party room has a high ceiling with small holes near the top where lanterns were hung at night from the outside to give the appearance of a starlit sky. The palace was completely open with all restoration work in April 2011.
amazing building. loved the chimney pots, excellent audio guide included in price of 10 euros each

Good Gaudi Experience. My husband and I visited Barcelona on our honeymoon, one day we woke up a little late (darn those beach bars in Barceloneta....), and realized that we wouldn;t have time to hit all of the Gaudi sites we were planning and Mount Juic before everything closed. So, we made the treck down Las Ramblas and over to Palau Guell. It was very architechtually intriguing with extraordinary woodwork and patterns. We paid a couple of euros for teh English audio guide and it was well worth it. Unlike many of the other guides we used during our trip which could be a bit verbose.The best part of our visit was when the organs played, the sound reverbarted throughout the house and it was beautiful. If you are looking for a quick site to see, near Las Ramblas, I would defintely recommend.

Make Sure To Check Schedule. We've visited Palau Guell four times in the past. The first time it was totally closed and we viewed the exterior. The second time we could peek into the entrance atrium and got a tiny taste of the luxury and craftsmanship within. The third time we had a tour of the basement. This time we were really looking forward to seeing the whole building. Our guidebook told us it was open on Monday, but closed on Sunday. Unfortunately, it was just the opposite. We were very disappointed, since we'd visited the Sagrada Familia on Sunday and reserved Monday for Palau Guell. Hopefully we'll have another chance in the future to see the whole building.
Nothing special. The only pro is that it is close to Rambla but the road is stinky and full of drug-addicteds.
Great visit with audio tour. The audio tour device is well-design with lots of information and even music pieces. This is much less crowded than other Gaudi design and with a lot to see.

Loved it!. We went in December, so the tour guide said we had the explicit privilege to be able to see everything without a bunch of people wandering about. This happened in the Sagrada too. Wow. Just Wow... I can't believe Gaudi had such vision. I loved the Palau ... its worth it to get a tour guide because they give you insight on everything.

Facinating!. This is definitely worth the trouble of standing on line. We bought our tickets right outside the palace and waited in line for about 15 minutes. This was after we went to Boqueria Market, which was a few blocks away. Just walk down Las Ramblas and take a right a few blocks down. The Palace is a place designed by Gaudi for the Guell family. It truly is amazing to see how the very upper class lived around the turn of the century and to see how the young Guadi was testing some of his theories and techniques that would later be perfected in designs for subsequent buildings. My ten year old daughter very much enjoyed the children's audio tour, and we took the adult audio tour, which is free. The detail of the design and the thinking that went into it was unimaginable. The materials they used were dazzling. The main room of the house, used for concerts and religous services was incredibly moving, especially when the organ was playing. This is a worthwhile stop! It took us about 1 1/2 hours. Highly recommend it in combination with a walk down Las Ramblas!

It is newly opened and a must-see.. It is an amazing place that was just recently renovated and opened to the public. If you are going to la Boqueria, pass by it and buy tickets for a conveninet time. Enjoy the visit.

Check this out. Not only visually stunning but the architecture and engineering were truly ahead of it’s time.Why can’t we build houses like this anymore.Audio Guide is worthwhile and gives great insight into Gaudi and his works and you must see the multi coloured chimneys on the roof although it is a pretty uneven and disconcerting if you don’t like heights but worth doing.

My favourite Gaudi experience. Touring this building was my favourite Gaudi experience. The audioguide is included in the cost of admission and is indispensable for the tour. Plan to spend some time here, we thought we would stay for an hour but wandered for more like 2 or 3. The balcony is closed in inclement weather so try to go when it is nice, the chimneys on the rooftop are not to miss!

A very grand life.. Stepping back into history, and wishing it would all come back to life. My only wish for Palau Guell, would have been to see some of the rooms furnished with period furniture. What I found amazing about this place was, for the period it was build our did they manage to build something so large without 'modern' equipment, cranes and other things we now take for granted or can not do without, and what about OH&S. Well worth the visit.

Modernist splendour. I walked around with my mouth open with amazement at this quite unique building - and when the organ started up we all were transported! An excellent audio guide which truly illuminates this quite unique Gaudi masterpiece. Allow 2 hours to savour this building.
Worth visiting. Anyone who likes Gaudi will be interested to see this.

A must if you go to Barcelona. We had visited Palau Guell before the renovations and enjoyed it so through we would visit again when we were recently in Barcelona.The restorations were extensive and have totally changed and enhanced the Palau. Last time we visited we had a guide but personally I prefer the audio guides as you can walk around at the pace that you want to. There was an exhibition (temporary I think) of the renovation works which shows the massive effort that has recently been put in and is worth spending some time looking at. We were in the Palau for about an hour and half and all of us thought the 9 euro entrance fee was reasonable. For those with any mobility problems there are quite a few stairs to climb during the visit.

early Gaudi. Really interesting example of early Gaudi architecture. He built this palace for the industrialist Joseph Guell an dhis family and although more traditionally gothic than his later architecture it is still well worth a visit.
must see. must see by all who study arcitecture and by any one else the way that evry part feet in harmony to other thethinking of every detail in the building and the people who will live there

Beautiful Gaudi house. Designed by Gaudi for his friend Guell. Very different from Casa Battlo as it is dark and rich rather than light and airy. Fascinating stables under house and superb ironwork. Hidden in side road off La Ramblas..don't miss it.
panoramic view. many spots to view barcelona in a panoramic view. beautiful works of Gaudi
Worth seeing. There were performers doing acrobatics and dance moves while I walked through; pretty fun to see.
Too crowded. As far as possible, avoid peak hours and bank holidays... it is simply too crowded and yu would not enjoy it to the fullest
Excellent example of Gaudi's work. Very interesting woodwork, mosaics, decor, windows. Admission includes tape recorder which describes all the rooms.

A fantastic place. Well literally stumbled across this place early one morning and popped in for a tour. The audio guide was informative and added real value. The architecture was very impressive, but the roof terrace is the main attraction for me; so quirky and impressive. A good place to visit.
Great!. Wonderful place and great for kids. Would recommend.
great views of the city. great views and sights, however lots of steps and slopes so couldn't see as much as we would have liked

Another Gaudi Treasure. Do not miss visiting Palau Guell which is situated just off of Las Ramblas. It is another stunning example of Gaudi's work which has been lovingly restored, and the restriction of the number of visitors allowed in at one time makes it more enjoyable. The audio guide allows you to tour at your own leisure and gives not only commentary but musical passages if you wish to select them. At 10 Euros entrance fee it's well worth a visit.

Palau Guell Is a Gaudi Masterpiece. The Palau Guell is located at Nou de la Rambla, 3-5. Eusebi Guell was a rich businessman who became the patron of Antoni Gaudi. Gaudi designed for him his home, the Palau Guell. In this house, Gaudi designed everything, including the stained glass, the furniture, the lighting, the wrought iron decoration, the fireplaces,and the twenty chimneys on the roof designed using trencadis (mosaic of broken tile shards). The building was constructed between 1885 and 1889. Guell wanted to use this house for artistic discussions and acts that he could enjoy with his friends, who were the cream of Catalan society at that time. The grand salon had an organ for musical recitals. From the higher floors, the Guells could observe visitors in the parlor without being seen themselves. The wrought iron bars in the front of the building also allowed one to see the street from inside the house, but not the contrary. The inside of the palace was influenced by Mudejar art. The Unesco designated the building as a World Heritage site in 1984 and the building has recently been restored.

Colorful and Unique. I didn't stand in line and pay the fee to go inside but the outside is impressive enough to go there. It is one of Gaudi's mot magnificent creations. The fee is too high but you can see the outside without paying it.
gaudi at his best. a must place to visit, roam at your own pace using the audio guides. roof top chimney's are amazing.

If you only go inside one Gaudi building, make it this one!. This building is amazing. The audioguide is complete with photos, music composed by the family's personal organist and children, some of the furniture is still in place and the wall photos make this visit complete so you can truly feel how extravegent the building was.I also paid to go inside Casa Batlo and I have to say this was less "commercial", more off the beaten path. But if you have the chance to go in other buildings, you can really see the progression of his career since this is one of his first buildings.So happy I fit this into my visit. And it's only 10 Euros compared to 18 Euros at the other buildings.

Gaudi's first steps. I'd disagree with previous reviewer - I've been both to Palau Guell and Casa Battlo as well, and I'd choose the latter at any given time. To be honest, the only reason we went to Palau Guell is because we had the 'first Sunday of the month Free' opportunity, only paid 1 EUR for a locker, audioguide was free as well. The visit was a great introduction to Gaudi's further works, but it does not replace them.

If you only go inside one Gaudi building, make it this one!. This building is amazing. The audioguide is complete with photos, music composed by the family's personal organist and children, some of the furniture is still in place and the wall photos make this visit complete so you can truly feel how extravegent the building was. I also paid to go inside Casa Batlo and I have to say this was less "commercial", more off the beaten path. But if you have the chance to go in other buildings, you can really see the progression of his career since this is one of his first buildings. So happy I fit this into my visit. And it's only 10 Euros compared to 18 Euros at the other buildings.

Not to be missed for Gaudi fans!. Now fully open and operational, this was a great sight. It was one of Gaudi’s early architectural works, so if you’re going to see his other homes and the cathedral (Sagrada Familia), I’d recommend seeing this one first to appreciate how his style progressed. The price of admission included an audio tour, and it was really great to see inside the home of a very wealthy old family.

Under appreciated Gaudi buidling well worth a visit. This palace was Gaudi's first big commission for his life long patron Sr. Guell. In it you can find the seeds of all the glory to come. Get the audiotour, well worth the time spent.

I dont understand why it is only attraction no. 19. If you're in Barcelona, this is one attraction you must include in your itinerary because personally we found this attraction the best! It is just so majestic and will take your breath away. I dont understand why it is only attraction no. 19 though, it should be at least the top 10. Since we went on a Sunday, it was free so we had to queue for about 30mins because only a limited number of people could go in at one time. But worth the wait. Do get the audioguide as well. You will not be disappointed! Now let the pictures do the talking !

A Fantastic Piece of Architecture by Gaudi. Not to be missed!!!!!!. This amazing home commissioned by the Guell family has been meticulously restored by the City of Barcelona. Opened to the public in mid-2011, this is one of the most beautiful and amazing works by Gaudi after La Sagrada Familia. My husband and I visited it in August 2011 and for the very fair entrance fee of 10 Euros (8 for seniors). It is incredible. If you only have time for only two of Gaudi's works, Palau Guell and La Sagrada Familia are the ones to see. Luckily I took plenty of pictures because I don't have the words to describe this beautiful building.

Beautiful early Gaudi. Beautiful early Gaudi palatial home newly renovated and reopened spring 2011. Worht seeing for the ironwork alone but there is much more. Just off the Ramblas near the Barri Gottic and Bocqueria Market.
Not to be missed!. Absolutely stunning Gaudi house. Full of interest and beauty. Ticket price included an audio tour so is good value for money.

Barcelona Shines Through with Palau Guell. We spent two days experiencing all things Gaudi, and every time we saw how expensive the ticket prices were...STICKER SHOCK! But at the end of each tour, we agreed that the visit was more than worth the expense. So imagine our dismay when we learned that the Palau Guell was no longer FREE! Yep, now it costs ten Euros to visit Gaudi's first commission located just steps off La Rambla near the Liceu Metro stop.But be prepared for the best investment of ten Euros you'll ever make. The new renovation of Palau Guell is a labor of love and craftsmanship rarely experienced in a restored historic residence anywhere in the world. The self-guided audio tour is included with a comprehensive souvenir guide book in your home language. Admission is staged by appointment to regulated the flow of visitors. Music and video are included in the audio tour as well as the translated soundtrack to an excellent short film...'very high tech. The tour is comprehensive, providing access to nearly every space or a window view into restricted areas. Listen as the house organ (a new installation to complement the original instrument) plays tunes written by the music teachers of the Guell household. Walk the wooden cobblestones faux-finished to appear to be stone, but used by Gaudi to muffle horses' hooves in the interior carriageway. Climb the carpeted stairways from floor to floor and discover over-the-top rooms and original Gaudi-designed furnishings. Marvel at the meticulously restored coffered ceilings and millwork and Gaudi's innoventions. Scale the rooftop and get face-to-face with Gaudi's famous Modernisme chimney stacks. We even lingered in the obligatory gift shop offering tasteful site-specific replicas and appropriate educational souvenirs. This is a great addition to an already world class offering of Gaudi's work in Barcelona. Don't miss this one!

Coming Soon!. We went to the Palau Guell in mid March 2010 and it is still not complete. The art work on the outside of the building is totally wild. It is free to get in but we had to wait in line about 15 min before we were allowed to go into the basement, which is the only part that is open. There are several columns down there made out of brick which are cool but if you miss this attraction it wont be a big loss.
Still unfinished!. We walked by this historic building to see how it was progressing. Still not open, but we were able to take some pictures.
Closed for restorations.. You can’t see the exterior or anything. Seems to have been closed for the past 4 years and they don’t see it opening at least until spring I was told.

My Highlight of Barcelona. Count Guell's small palace just of Las Ramblas. You get a ticket and come back 10 minutes before the tour starts where you pay and wait for the guide. The guide gave a guided tour in english starting from the stables in the bottom of the palace to the wonderful Gaudi rooftop.The building is beautiful and fascinating giving an insight into life at the time. You can take photographs but can't use a flash.Well worth a visit - you won't be disappointed.
